INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
Indonesia Gets $1 Billion Without Rights Conditions
The United States gave Indonesia $1 billion in loan guarantees, free of any conditions concerning human rights abuses surrounding the protests against President Suharto's rule. Almost simultaneously, the Pentagon, citing the unrest, canceled a joint training exercise with the Indonesian military. A1 

About 200 students marched peacefully around the campus of the University of North Sumatra, demanding political reform. Earlier in the week, protests spilled into the streets and turned violent. A5
 
South Africa Rejects Amnesties
A South African court struck down the blanket amnesties granted to top officials of President Nelson Mandela's ruling party by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is investigating abuses committed in the apartheid era. The ruling raises the possibility that the officials will have to testify about incidents involving bombs and torture. A1
 
Rugby Practices Under Fire
South Africa's sports-governing body revived an effective anti-apartheid tactic and asked the world to boycott South African rugby. The National Sports Council had demanded that rugby's league president resign, apologize to President Mandela for humiliating him and cooperate with a Government investigation of accusations that league practices were corrupt and racist. A4
 
Netanyahu Rejects Deadline
A spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said there was "no way" that Mr. Netanyahu could meet Washington's deadline of Monday for deciding on withdrawing from 13.1 percent of the West Bank. A5
 
Iraq and Russia at Impasse
A travel ban imposed by the United Nations on Iraqi officials ended and the United States and Russia were still at impasse over how to respond to a report that in effect declared Iraq free of nuclear weapons. A5
 
Warning to the Serbs
The Clinton Administration has dispatched Richard Holbrooke, the architect of the Bosnian peace agreement, to warn President Slobodan Milosevic of the consequences of the recent violence along Yugoslavia's southern border. A3
 
G.O.P. Assails Clinton on China
The Republican leadership in Congress complained to President Clinton that the Administration had thrown a "veil of secrecy" in front of Congressional efforts to look into the case of space expertise provided to China in 1996. A5
 
Attack Spurs Protests in Spain
More than a thousand people marched in Vitoria, Spain, to protest the second attack blamed on the Basque separatist group ETA in two days, a shooting that critically wounded a retired Civil Guard officer. No group took responsibility for the attack, but the Government, opposition parties and the news media blamed ETA. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A6-9
 
Minnesota's Tobacco Suit Is Settled for $6.5 Billion
Minnesota, the first state to take its lawsuit against tobacco companies to trial, and its co-plaintiffs accepted a $6.5 billion settlement as jurors were hearing closing arguments. A1
 
President Clinton, Senator John McCain and others in Congress who favor broad anti-smoking legislation said the settlement improved the prospects for such a bill. A7
 
New Standards for 'Organic'
The Government announced that it would not allow food to be labeled "organic" if it was genetically engineered, irradiated or grown in soil fertilized with sewage sludge. The action came in response to comments from tens of thousands of consumers concerned about the purity of their food and the integrity of the organic label. A1
 
G.O.P. Strategy Session
House Republican leaders met with an array of Christian and other social-issue conservatives to discuss concerns that the Republicans could lose control of the House in November unless they energized their conservative base. A1
 
Effort to Reduce Class Size
President Clinton proposed and sent to Congress a $20.8 billion, 10-year program to hire 100,000 new teachers to reduce class sizes in the early primary grades. A8
 
Hubbells Plead Not Guilty
Webster L. Hubbell, President Clinton's close friend and former Justice Department appointee, entered a plea of not guilty to tax-evasion charges brought by the Whitewater independent counsel. Mr. Hubbell's wife, Suzanna, their accountant, Michael Schaufele, and their lawyer, Charles C. Owen, were also arraigned in Federal District Court and pleaded not guilty. A8
 
No Decision on Herman
Attorney General Janet Reno and her senior aides could not reach agreement on whether she should seek an independent prosecutor to investigate accusations that Labor Secretary Alexis Herman, above, accepted illegal payments while she was an official at the White House, law-enforcement officials. A8
 
Representative Alleges Bias
Representative Cynthia McKinney, a Democrat from Georgia, complained to President Clinton that she was treated rudely at a White House event because she is black. A8
 
Richardson May Switch Posts
President Clinton will probably nominate Bill Richardson, the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, for energy secretary, Administration officials said. A9
 
Italy Has Tape From Marine Jet
Italian officials have a videotape taken from the cockpit of a Marine jet that brought down an Alpine cable car, killing 20 people, prosecutors said on the final day of a hearing on whether to court-martial the jet's back-seat crew. Italian prosecutors said there was nothing on it. A7

Stocks and Sports Fuel A Hudson River Rivalry
New York and New Jersey sniped at each other over New Jersey's invitation to the New York Stock Exchange to relocate there. Mayor Giuliani said that if New Jersey got "too interested in our businesses, we could become very interested in their sports teams." B1
 
Restoring Battery Park
Mayor Giuliani is to announce a private initiative today to restore the Battery Park as a monument to its place in New York City history and to improve it as a public space. B3
 
Victim Is Diplomat's Daughter
A young woman found shot to death in Cunningham Park in Queens on Thursday was identified as the 19-year-old daughter of the second-ranking diplomat in Yemen's Mission to the United Nations, officials said. B3
 
A Killing in Greenwich Village
A Greenwich Village woman who had weathered a series of hostile encounters with her ex-boyfriend during the last six months was killed late Thursday, when the man approached her on a street corner, began arguing and shot her in the head, the police said. B3
 
NBC Apologizes for 'Seinfeld'
NBC apologized for an episode of "Seinfeld" broadcast Thursday night that contained scenes that prominent Puerto Ricans said were offensive. B3

HEADLINE: Democratic Candidates for Governor Struggle to Stir Interest

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Peter F. Vallone rounded up a battery of police union leaders on the steps of City Hall the other morning to endorse his campaign for governor. When the speeches ended, Mr. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, invited questions about his candidacy. He was met with silence. "Unrelated question?" a radio reporter finally asked, as Mr. Vallone grimaced.
At a Democratic club on the Upper West Side a few days earlier, Betsy McCaughey Ross was discussing her campaign with leaders when the moderator of the evening abruptly cut her off, announcing that another gubernatorial candidate was waiting to speak. As a puzzled-looking Ms. McCaughey Ross, the Lieutenant Governor, gathered her belongings, the moderator beckoned an unfamiliar figure to the front of the room. After a moment's confusion, it turned out that "our next candidate for governor" was a reporter there to hear the speeches. 
 This is shaping up to be one of the most compelling political seasons in New York in years. But for now, at least, that does not seem to include the gubernatorial candidates, who are struggling to rally interest from the public, contributors, the press and even, as Ms. McCaughey Ross discovered, supposedly informed Democratic leaders.
Not surprisingly, the Democrats seeking to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki are encountering many of the same problems that Democrats faced against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1997. They are challenging a popular, politically skillful and financially strong incumbent running for re-election during the kind of good times that normally work against challengers.
But candidates for governor are encountering an unexpected obstacle this time around: the race for United States Senate. The contest to unseat Alfonse M. D'Amato, which has drawn Geraldine A. Ferraro out of political retirement, is drawing interest, money and even potential campaign issues away from the gubernatorial race, leaving it an impoverished stepchild struggling for attention.
Democratic leaders these days are far more likely to perk up at the mention of Mr. D'Amato's name than they are at Mr. Pataki's.
"It's got the potential to be a very interesting race," David Eichenbaum, Ms. Ferraro's campaign manager, said of the race to challenge Mr. Pataki. But, he added with a note of sympathy for his compatriots running gubernatorial campaigns, "the challenge is how to make it one."
In addition to Mr. Vallone and Ms. McCaughey Ross, the other Democratic candidates for governor are Richard A. Kahan, a developer and the former chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation; James L. Larocca, the former State Transportation Commissioner, and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney.
To be sure, the candidates and their aides said, it is still relatively early in the race. Ms. McCaughey Ross, speaking to the single reporter who showed up to watch her serve as principal for the day on the Upper East Side last week, brushed aside any concern about the state of the race. "I'm sure that most voters aren't really paying attention yet," she said.
And several Democrats said they found it difficult to believe that New Yorkers do not have the appetite for two major contested races at the same time, even in these times of diminished interest in politics. "This is not a competition between races -- it's a competition between candidates," said Kevin R. McCabe, Mr. Vallone's campaign manager. "The Senate race will be the Senate race. The gubernatorial race will actually be just as exciting by the time it's over."
But with the state Democratic convention just three weeks away, and with the Senate race already a regular feature in news coverage and television advertising, an increasing number of Democrats are becoming concerned that the patterns being set today are likely to prevail between now and Election Day. Indeed, it is a measure of the standing of the governor's race that Democrats tend to grow more animated talking about the race for attorney general, in which the incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, is seen as vulnerable.
That feeling that the gubernatorial race is a foregone conclusion might be underlined today if the Liberal Party, as is widely expected among Democratic leaders, announces that it will support Ms. McCaughey Ross in November. If that happens and if Ms. McCaughey Ross does not win the Democratic nomination, that would create a split in the anti-Pataki vote that would probably insure Mr. Pataki's re-election. Even if Ms. McCaughey Ross wins the Democratic primary, many party leaders see her as Mr. Pataki's weakest opponent because she served in his government before switching parties to run against him.
For all their obvious obscurity so far, the candidates have, to some extent, been active. Mr. Larocca, Mr. Hynes and Mr. Kahan, for example, have spent much of the last year traveling across the state, discussing in particular what they describe as the state's weak economic performance under Mr. Pataki. Mr. Larocca drew notice among Democratic leaders this week for his performance at a candidates forum in Rochester.
But Mr. Vallone, who by virtue of his campaign financing is seen as a leading candidate in the race, has chosen in recent weeks to pay more attention to his duties as Council Speaker than to the campaign. He skipped the Rochester debate, saying he had a prior commitment at a budget hearing in Queens.
And it has so far been Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, rather than the candidates, who have taken the lead in attacking $1.6 billion in vetoes that Mr. Pataki made in state spending -- a series of vetoes that Democratic leaders believe may provide candidates the opportunity they need to mount a strong campaign against him.
In the end, perhaps the best indication of the state of the governor's race comes from the actions of Mr. Pataki himself. Unlike Mr. D'Amato, who has packed his schedule with campaign-like appearances, Mr. Pataki has kept a markedly low profile, confining his activities to state government business and doing what he can to keep attention away from the race.
Mr. Pataki's political adviser, Zenia Mucha, said the lack of activity so far amounted to a public endorsement of the "Governor's policies of creating jobs, reducing crime and reforming welfare, which have made this state a better place." But a revealing moment later, the woman who is to help direct Mr. Pataki's re-election campaign was stumped when asked to assess the Democratic field facing her boss.
"What are there, five of them?" she asked. "Four of them?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Jobless Rate Falls Sharply, More Americans Find Work
The nation's unemployment rate declined in April to 4.3 percent, the lowest level in nearly three decades, and employers added more than a quarter million jobs. 
 Economists and investors nonetheless worried that the Labor Department data provided more justification for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, possibly at its May 19 policy making meeting, to thwart inflationary pressure building in the economy. Page A1.
 
Securities Firm Agrees to Pay Fine
Credit Suisse First Boston has agreed to pay $52.5 million to Orange County, becoming the first securities company to settle litigation stemming from the California county's 1994 bankruptcy. D3.
 
Landmark Tobacco Settlement
The State of Minnesota, a health insurance company and the nation's biggest cigarette makers agreed to settle a closely watched lawsuit just hours before it was to go to the jury. The settlement of the case in Minnesota, which will receive $6.1 billion from the cigarette companies over 25 years, is expected to have a significant impact on tobacco litigation brought by other states. A1.
 
GTE Sues to Stop Worldcom Merger
GTE, which lost a bidding war for MCI Communications, has filed a lawsuit to halt Worldcom's $37 billion takeover of the company. GTE contends that the combined telecommunications giant would threaten competition in long-distance phone markets and monopolize the Internet. D3.
 
Aid For Indonesia
The United States gave Indonesia $1 billion in loan guarantees and almost simultaneously, the Pentagon canceled a joint training exercise with the Indonesian military because of unrest there. A1.
 
BMW Capitulates in Rolls Battle
BMW said it would not top Volkswagen's $705 million offer for Rolls-Royce. The announcement means VW is all but certain to acquire the prestigious British auto maker from Vickers. D2.
 
Stocks Snap 3-Day Decline
Stocks ended a three day losing streak with shares of drug, computer system and health care companies fueling the rally, helped by a positive reaction to the Labor Department's employment report. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 78.47 points, to 9,055.15. Broader indexes rose sharply. D4.
 
Bonds remained relatively steady. The yield rose to 5.97 percent from 5.95 percent. A week ago, the yield was at 5.93 percent. D4.
 
Japanese Officials Split on Rates
A split among top Japanese Government officials on monetary policy became evident after the chief of the Economic Planning Agency, Koji Omi, said he favored higher interest rates. Japan's discount rate is at a historic low of five-tenths of a percent. B2.
 
Suit Against Liz Claiborne and Union
Mademoiselle Knitwear sued clothing manufacturer Liz Claiborne and Unite, the main garment industry union, contending they conducted a fraudulent scheme to move manufacturing abroad, harming American workers and businesses. D3.
 
Tyson Settles Pollution Suit
The Federal government settled a lawsuit with Tyson Foods that imposes a $4 million penalty and requires Tyson to reduce the runoff of waste from its plants in Maryland, Virginia, Delaware and Pennsylvania. The plants are operated by Hudson foods, which Tyson purchased last fall. A9.
 
Conde Nast Buying Wired
Conde Nast, the publisher of Vogue and Vanity Fair, is purchasing Wired magazine for an undisclosed sum, its first foray into the computer magazine market.

HEADLINE: U.N. Envoy Likely to Get Energy Post

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Bill Richardson, the United States representative to the United Nations, is likely to be chosen as President Clinton's next energy secretary, Clinton Administration officials said today.
While Mr. Richardson would be giving up one of the most high-profile jobs in American diplomacy -- a job that he seemed to relish, given the opportunity for diplomatic trouble-shooting -- the energy post could provide the former House member with a stronger platform to pursue higher political office. 
 Mr. Richardson is mentioned in political circles as a potential running mate if Vice President Al Gore wins the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.
Mr. Richardson would replace Federico F. Pena, one of President Clinton's longest-serving Cabinet officers, who announced last month that he would step down.
Mr. Richardson was elected to the House of Representatives in 1982 and was re-elected seven times.
There was rampant speculation within the State Department and at the United States Mission to the United Nations over who would succeed Mr. Richardson in New York. Most officials agreed that there were two obvious candidates: Richard Holbrooke, the former diplomat who brokered the 1995 Bosnian peace agreement, and George Mitchell, the former Senate majority leader who was the architect of last month's peace settlement in Northern Ireland.
Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, insisted that there was still no decision on whether to name Mr. Richardson to the energy post.
"There is no decision on the energy secretary," Mr. Toiv said. "He would be a very strong candidate given his experience as a Congressman from New Mexico, but he's doing a fantastic job at the U.N."
Mr. Richardson, who was in Washington today to make a speech, called reports that he was a candidate to become energy secretary "just press speculation on a premature report."
Asked if he ruled out taking the job, Mr. Richardson smiled and said, "We all serve at the pleasure of the President."
The only apparent stumbling block for Mr. Richardson in obtaining Senate confirmation to the energy post would be the job offer that he made last year to Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern who is alleged to have had a sexual relationship with President Clinton.
Mr. Richardson has said that he offered a position to Ms. Lewinsky only because she seemed well-suited to a job open at the United States Mission to the United Nations. Critics of the Clinton Administration have charged that the job offer was made at the request of the White House to get Ms. Lewinsky out of Washington.
Diplomats at the United Nations had some trouble today sorting out why Mr. Richardson, who is already a member of the Cabinet, would want to give up the excitement of international diplomacy for the nuts and bolts of energy policy.
But the energy job would provide Mr. Richardson with a platform on an important domestic issue and could bring him more attention than his niche at the United Nations, especially with such a visible Secretary of State as Madeleine K. Albright garnering most of the headlines.
Mr. Richardson, who is Mexican-American, is expected to be an appealing running mate to any Presidential candidate eager to capture the Hispanic vote in the big border states. He speaks Spanish fluently and was reared in Mexico City.
In his home state of New Mexico, he is frequently mentioned as a potential candidate for governor or for the Senate. The state's economy is hugely dependent on the Energy Department's national laboratories and on its nuclear weapons testing program.
F. Chris Garcia, a professor of political science at the University of New Mexico, said: "The energy position is so important, particularly to New Mexico, that if he's looking to run in a statewide race, this would certainly help him in a very tangible way. The United Nations position is more symbolic."
Mr. Garcia said that the energy post would also give Mr. Richardson a chance to prove his administrative skills in heading a large department. But whether Mr. Richardson goes to energy or stays at the U.N., Mr. Garcia said, "It's difficult for him to do the wrong thing."
While still in the House, Mr. Richardson served as a roving diplomatic trouble-shooter for the Clinton Administration, traveling to parts of the world where most Americans fear to tread: North Korea, Cuba, Iraq, Serbia, Nigeria and Myanmar.
The trips were often remarkably fruitful, with Mr. Richardson winning the release of several hostages held by governments or rebel leaders unfriendly to the United States. Last month, Mr. Richardson became the first American Cabinet member to visit Afghanistan in more than two decades and obtain agreements from the warring factions there to begin peace talks.

HEADLINE: Border War As a Ploy: Companies Seldom Lose

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Close the borders.
Wall Street is defecting to Jersey City. The Yankees are abandoning the Bronx for the New Jersey Meadowlands. The New Jersey Nets are vaulting over Manhattan to get to a new home at the Nassau Coliseum. 
 Officials on both sides of the Hudson River are loading their muskets with steely pronouncements and alluring tax breaks as the economic border battles threaten to break into a full-scale war.
Well, probably not.
In keeping with a longstanding tradition, corporations and sports teams today routinely play on the insecurities of public officials who fret over losing a business to the other side. H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, chalks it up to pure posturing by the corporations in an attempt to scare public officials into granting tax breaks, land and cash.
"The border wars are really a milking of the public sector, rather than a determining factor in where a company wants to go," said Mr. Shostal, a former real estate executive who once lured companies to New Jersey but now opposes the practice. "The region doesn't benefit from all this shuffling around."
In the latest skirmish, the New York Stock Exchange announced this week that it had received an offer by New Jersey to build a $1 billion trading floor with a glittering array of tax breaks. (Of course, that offer came after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would try to grab up New Jersey's sports teams -- which came after New Jersey officials said they would welcome the Yankees.)
On Tuesday, New Jersey officials presented Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the exchange, with a menu of tax rebates, grants and loans that would be available to the exchange if it moved to Jersey City or elsewhere in the state.
On Thursday, Mr. Grasso called the deal rewarding. But not before saying that he would rather stay in New York, where he favored building a new home at Battery Park City.
It was all in the time-honored fashion of Prudential Securities, Bear Stearns and Standard & Poor's: pitting one state against another in a game of corporate poker that usually results in a multimillion-dollar tax break to stay in Manhattan.
In fact, despite New Jersey's fervor and enticements, three developers there who are most likely to build a headquarters for the exchange expressed doubts yesterday that the stock exchange would ever abandon lower Manhattan.
"We have spoken to the state, but we have not been approached by the exchange," said Leonard Stern, chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries, whose company is building a new office building at the Colgate center in Jersey City. "If they want to come to brush their teeth at Colgate, we're a player. But I think the stock exchange certainly wants to stay in New York."
But that did not stop the political back and forth across the Hudson, which was traded as fervently as a hot new stock.
"The fact that a body as auspicious and august as the New York Stock Exchange is even talking about New Jersey as a potential home shows what a good place it is to do business," Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. "Whether it comes to fruition or not, I have no way of knowing."
Not to be outdone, Mayor Giuliani fired back, accusing the stock exchange of "pitting New Jersey against New York to get a better deal" and warning his neighbor that if it got "too interested in our businesses, we could become very interested in their sports teams and I think it would work, because some of them are very unhappy in New Jersey."
Mr. Giuliani's apparent preoccupation with sports teams may actually be the snag that has slowed down the talks between the city and the stock exchange.
Some executives at the stock exchange, who have been scouring lower Manhattan for two years for expansion space or a new headquarters, say city officials seem to be spending an inordinate amount of time on stadiums for baseball teams, rather than on a business that pours hundreds of millions of dollars into the state and city coffers.
They say the exchange is in desperate need of new quarters: the number of companies listed on the exchange has jumped by 550 since 1996, and the average daily trading volume has grown by 50 percent.
"We would like to finalize a deal," said Robert Zito, senior vice president of the New York Stock Exchange. "Whatever the reasons for the delay, you'll have to check with the city."
Mr. Zito also said that New Jersey was now an option, one "that we hadn't even thought of two weeks ago."
Of course, the exchange is looking for the sweetest deal it can get -- one that probably lies in New York. Officials say they want the same deal given the Mercantile Exchange, the commodity market that recently completed a new headquarters at Battery Park City with the help of a $183.9 million incentive package from the city. The deal with the Mercantile Exchange came after it had engaged in its own decadelong corporate poker game.
Colleen Roche, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, said that City Hall had not ignored the New York Stock Exchange.
"The Mayor and Governor have spent more time with Dick Grasso than anyone in New Jersey has," Ms. Roche said. "This is merely a negotiating strategy and an attempt to drive up the price."
Most often, corporations say that such deals with tax breaks are a key consideration in whether to relocate a business. But at this point, the deals have become so routine that it has become hard for city or state officials to say no.
In a moment of candor, Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of CBS, explained why his company had received a $49.5 million benefit package in 1992. "We never threatened to leave the city," he said at the time. "I just wanted to be treated like everyone else."
Yesterday, the Mayor said he doubted that there was even a lucrative offer from New Jersey, recalling that Mr. Grasso had promised him that the exchange would remain in New York.
Mr. Giuliani said he would prefer that the exchange try to expand on Broad Street, although he would consider other options, including a vacant lot at Battery Park City.
But Gualberto Medina, New Jersey's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, said he believed that his state was in serious contention for the exchange.
"We are convinced that we are not just a stalking horse here," Mr. Medina said.
In keeping with the state of relations on both sides of the Hudson, Mr. Medina held out hope for a reconciliation. "We hope to invite the Mayor to the groundbreaking for the stock exchange in New Jersey," Mr. Medina said. "He is our friend, and we invite our friends to important events."

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE PLUNGES TO 4.3%, LOWEST SINCE 1970

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate tumbled in April to 4.3 percent, the lowest level in nearly three decades, and employers added more than a quarter-million jobs to payrolls, the Labor Department said yesterday.
The steep drop in unemployment, from 4.7 percent in March, is superb news for most Americans whose pay is now rising faster than the cost of living and who are employed in greater numbers -- 64.2 percent of the population -- than ever. 
 "It's a great number," said Arthur J. Rolnick, senior vice president of research at the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis. "This is exactly what we have been shooting for for almost 20 years: strong growth and low inflation."
But signs that the labor market is getting tighter are also flashing yellow lights for forecasters and investors. They worry that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is now a step closer to raising interest rates at the central bank's next monetary policy meeting, on May 19. Other things equal, higher rates tend to slow the economy and thwart inflationary pressure by reining in purchases of interest-sensitive items like houses, cars and, especially, stocks.
Investors, on the lookout for hints of inflation or clues to the Federal Reserve's next move, reacted relatively calmly. Prices in the bond market eased slightly but there was no selloff. And the stock market rose, snapping a three-day decline, as the strength in the job market was seen as a sign that consumers would keep spending and corporate earnings might hold up better than expected.
The size of the decline in joblessness may have been exaggerated by an unexpected drop in the number of workers who said they were working or looking for work -- a figure that zigs and zags from month to month. But strong growth in employment, including self-employment, accounted for more than half of the April decline that took the jobless rate to its lowest level since February 1970.
The trend was widespread, affecting every major demographic group. For Hispanic workers, the April unemployment rate of 6.5 percent was the lowest since data were first collected separately in 1973; the rate for blacks, 8.9 percent, was the lowest in all but one month since 1973.
"You always have to be cautious with one month's data," said Tom Nardone, chief of labor force statistics at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the jobs report. "But it does look as if unemployment has ratcheted down again."
The report underscored the very strong start to the second quarter. The momentum in the job market is such that most economists, inside the Fed and out, expect the unemployment rate to edge down even further.
"There's still room to move down," said Alan Krueger, an economist at Princeton University, "because of the pool of the people who are available to work, especially high school dropouts and workers who have only high school degrees."
That does not mean that unemployment can fall forever, of course. Few economists believe that unemployment can stay at, say, 4 percent for a long period of time without causing inflation to speed up.
Job growth, which had stalled in March because of unusually cold weather, was back to the fast pace of most of the last year. Jobs in construction, restaurants and retail stores rebounded. Payrolls of local governments swelled sharply. Companies in the services sector did a lot of hiring, adding 139,000 jobs. Most of the jobs were in finance, insurance, real estate and computer services, exactly those parts of the economy where demand has been booming.
The rapid pace of hiring is leading to shortages of certain kinds of workers. Thomas Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, who has visited 60 cities in the last seven months, said trucking companies, hotels, restaurants and hospitals were facing the most acute shortages of qualified help. High-technology concerns, from telephone companies to software developers, are having trouble filling vacancies as well. "There's been a major acceleration in retirements, and the hot economy is demanding more people than ever before," Mr. Donohue said. "It's going to get worse."
Manufacturing, buffeted by the economic crisis in Asia and a pileup in inventories at the end of last quarter, is virtually the only cool spot in an otherwise hot labor market. Some 10,000 factory jobs disappeared last month, mostly in export-sensitive industries like electronics and heavy machinery. But Mr. Nardone of the Bureau of Labor Statistics pointed out that the losses were small relative to the strong gain of 169,000 industrial jobs from September through January.
April was an opportune time to go job hunting. Nearly 700,000 unemployed workers found jobs. The number of jobless fell below six million and the number of people who had been out of work for 15 weeks or more shrank sharply.
Almost every major demographic group had an easier time finding work. For teen-agers, the jobless rate fell to 13.1 percent, and for high school dropouts, to 7 percent. Unemployment among workers with high school diplomas and those with some college, roughly 60 percent of the work force, fell the most. Their unemployment rates dropped to 3.9 percent and 2.7 percent, respectively.
Workers are taking home real pay gains as wages continue rising faster than inflation. Hourly earnings of production and nonsupervisory workers rose 4 cents, to $12.67, and are up 4.4 percent over April 1997; the Consumer Price Index rose just 1.5 percent in that period.
Wage inflation, while hardly alarming, is creeping up. Compared with the 4.4 percent increase of the last 12 months, wages grew just 3.7 percent and 3.1 percent in the two previous years. Not surprisingly, given the buoyant stock market, the biggest gains in pay are showing up in the services sector in general and financial services in particular. Pay in finance, insurance and real estate was up 7.3 percent from a year earlier, for example.
Despite the boom in construction, however, the pay increase for hard hats is less than 4 percent, while factory pay is just inching up, at less than a 3 percent annual rate.
For the last couple of years, solid growth in productivity has offset part of the rise in wages, and the strong dollar, lower oil prices and the shift to managed health care have helped suppress price pressures. For those in the central bank who believe that the labor market is not a good predictor of inflation, yesterday's report did nothing to raise alarms. But for those who believe the opposite, yesterday's report confirmed longstanding fears.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Labor Picture in April" shows employment and unemployment statistics for April. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)(pg. D3)

HEADLINE: Fretting Over Grip on House, G.O.P. Courts Conservatives

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
After months of confidence that the nation was heading into a serene, status-quo election, Republicans are suddenly worried that they could lose control of the House this November unless they energize their conservative base.
"There's a whole host of warning signs," said Ralph Reed, a Republican strategist and former executive director of the Christian Coalition. "My own view is that the Republican House majority is in jeopardy. I'm not predicting a Democratic pickup. I'm just saying it's in jeopardy." 
 This concern has been driving a variety of House actions lately and was much in evidence today as House Republican leaders huddled at the Library of Congress with a wide array of Christian and other social-issue conservatives.
After a contentious three-hour session, the senior Republicans vowed a new commitment to the agenda of the groups, which were a crucial element of the Republican Congressional victories in 1994 and 1996. Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, described the meeting as "a lot of good, solid, frank talk about our concerns, their concerns, listening to each other and carrying on a dialogue."
The meeting came at a pivotal political moment for the Republicans.
The chairman of the House Republicans' re-election committee, Representative John Linder of Georgia, still maintains publicly that House Republicans will pick up at least 10 to 15 seats. But Mr. Linder acknowledges, "We've got to energize the base. I also want very much to energize my colleagues who need an understanding it's a political year."
Republicans say Mr. Linder was far blunter in a closed-door meeting of the House Republican leadership just after the last Congressional recess in mid-April. He gave his fellow Republicans a strategy memorandum warning that they could endanger their majority status unless they started drawing sharp distinctions between themselves and the Democrats.
The sudden jitters among Republicans have several causes. For one thing, the Republicans have more districts to worry about than they had expected, defending 17 open seats as compared to 16 for the Democrats. And they have little room for error. The Republicans' 11-seat majority is the narrowest in the House in half a century.
The death of Representative Steven H. Schiff of New Mexico and the unexpected decision by Representative Wes W. Watkins of Oklahoma not to seek re-election have left the party with uphill fights. Mr. Watkins, for example, is a former Democrat and his district is known as Little Dixie because of its traditional Democratic allegiance. It was once held by Speaker Carl Albert.
In addition, voters for months now have consistently told pollsters they prefer a Democratic Congress over a Republican one or else they put the parties at a virtual tie. Such poll readings are considered a rough but useful indicator of the political terrain on which individual candidates must fight.
Democrats are also doing remarkably well financially. An analysis of reports to the Federal Election Commission shows that Democrats in the 33 open House seats are raising more money than the Republicans are. The typical Democratic candidate in an open seat has $112,415 cash on hand, compared with $77,688 for the typical Republican.
Perhaps most importantly, House Republicans have become concerned that social conservatives, who can help Republicans turn out their core supporters, are increasingly disaffected with a Congress that has not been able to deliver on their issues.
"It's very clear that the people who stand out in the rain for us have not been enamored with the past year," said Representative Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican who is one of the conservative members of the sophomore class.
Mr. Graham praised party leaders for reacting, saying, "What's stupid is to ignore the obvious."
These concerns, Republicans said, help explain why the leadership is scheduling an array of votes over the next several months on issues dear to conservatives, such as prayer in the schools, even though much of that legislation has no chance of passage.
It is also, Republicans said, one reason Speaker Newt Gingrich has returned to his old, more slashing style, accusing President Clinton recently of corruption, coverup and a dearth of moral authority.
Today, Mr. Gingrich, Mr. DeLay and Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, met with about 20 groups representing a conservative grass-roots base -- among them the Christian Coalition, the Family Research Council, the National Right to Life Committee, the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention and the Home School Legal Defense Association.
When it was over, Mr. Gingrich said that "on almost every major issue the people who are meeting represent the vast majority of Americans." He lashed out at the National Endowment for the Arts, saying "every time people see the latest example of pornography, the latest example of obscenity they say, 'Why are my tax dollars being wasted on that kind of activity?' "
Mr. Gingrich said House Republicans would dedicate themselves to phasing out from the tax code the so-called marriage penalty under which many couples pay more than they would if they were single taxpayers. He also pledged renewed drives to ban a particular form of late-term abortion, known by opponents as partial-birth abortion, and to eliminate funding for the National Endowment for the Arts.
The House leaders created a new House task force called the "Values Action Team," headed by Representative Joseph R. Pitts, a Pennsylvania Republican, to coordinate with the groups on an array of legislation.
Next week the House takes up legislation important to Christian conservatives that could impose economic sanctions on countries that persecute people for their religious beliefs. Coming this summer is a vote on a constitutional amendment to allow prayer in schools.
The groups said the session could be the beginning of a rapprochement, but that they were looking for action, not just promises.
James Dobson, whose "Focus on the Family" radio show draws 5 million listeners, said there was "good discussion," but added, "only time will tell. It's easy to talk about things. It is tougher to get action in Congress and certainly in the Senate."
The Democrats have welcomed the Republicans' latest tack to the right, saying it also serves to energize their own core voters.
"Newt is a great fund-raiser for the Republicans and should not be discounted in any way," said Representative Martin Frost, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Democrats' election committee. "But the more Newt goes on television, the more small donations we get from the mail. He's a fund-raiser for them and a fund-raiser for us. It's a very interesting situation."
At the spring meeting of the Democratic National Committee today, Roy Romer, the party's national chairman, said that Mr. Gingrich was following a "losing political strategy."
Democrats at the meeting said they had a chance to reverse the historical trend in which the party in the White House loses seats in Congress in a midterm election.
"I think there is a chance the Democrats will gain seats, which is unprecedented, and I think there is a possibility they will regain control of the House," said Mark Gersh, the chairman of the National Committee for an Effective Congress, which is a Democratic advocacy group.
Not every Republican is comfortable with the latest tack of the party. Recent efforts by the House Republicans to end affirmative action and to pass a constitutional amendment limiting tax increases have failed, with some moderate Republicans bolting from the party.
Representative John Kasich of Ohio is also having a hard time selling to his fellow Republicans a budget plan he drafted that would cut domestic spending by $154 billion -- including elimination of the Commerce and Energy Departments and the National Endowment of the Arts.
Mr. Kasich acknowledged this week that he was still scaling back his proposal. "I don't know where we're going to end up at the end of doing this," he said. "We are not interested in making the Federal Government bigger."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
A Call for Splitting Surplus

 WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- Mr. Gingrich says projected Federal budget surpluses now look so big that they should be split evenly between cutting taxes and shoring up Social Security.
In recent weeks, Mr. Gingrich had been saying the surplus should be used to reinforce Social Security by distributing it among Americans to establish "personal retirement accounts" that would supplement their retirement income.
President Clinton wants the surplus to strengthen Social Security and the House Budget Committee chairman, Mr. Kasich, had said tax cuts should be paid for by cutting spending.

HEADLINE: Lessons of Rome For Today's Politics

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Speaker Newt Gingrich invokes a powerful historical precedent in warning that 1990's America is confronted with many of the conditions that brought down the Roman Republic (news article, May 3). But the problems he cites -- a state "corrupted by foreign money, by personal ambition, by a politics so vicious" -- miss the causes of that disintegration. 
 The crisis sprang from growing social inequality and the unrestrained avarice of Rome's upper classes. After the assassination of the reformist Gracchus brothers, conservative senators blocked off avenues of peaceful political reform. Wealthy candidates lavished fortunes on campaigns that dealt less and less with real issues.
A frustrated populace began embracing conquering generals who confronted senate oligarchs with force, and a downward spiral began. Maybe the Speaker is on to something.
 
JEFFREY LAURENTI
Trenton, May 6, 1998

HEADLINE: The Georgia Republican Who Uses the I-Word

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Representative Bob Barr complained that he had a plane to catch, but the young female security guard at the airport metal detector cursed and instructed her colleague to take her time looking through his bag. When Mr. Barr angrily demanded her name, she stuck her ID in his face, and he slapped her arms down forcefully. She came charging back at him, and he yelled, "Nobody swears at me!" The guards who quickly surrounded them led her away, and he walked on.
A few seconds later, when he pulled out his ticket to check the gate, his hand was not trembling. Did the incident not bother him? "Not at all," he said. "The problem is they hire these people with no education or training." 
 Mr. Barr, a Republican of Georgia, is President Clinton's most energetic detractor in the House, where he is leading the drive for an impeachment inquiry, and he often has occasion to vent his anger these days.
As a frequent guest on the Washington talk shows, Mr. Barr, a former prosecutor, argues that the President has very likely broken a number of laws. On Capitol Hill, Mr. Barr's more unsettling shows of temper are well known among colleagues on both sides of the aisle, who whisper about the committee meetings where he had to be talked down and about aides who seemed to fear his tongue-lashings.
But if he is not Mr. Congeniality in the Class of '94, he is an important figure for members of his party's conservative base, who express disappointment that few Republicans on the Hill are as mad as they are about the Presidential scandals. A number of Congressional Republicans say they are glad Mr. Barr is on the case, acting out their common private resentment that the Democrat in the White House is probably getting away with something.
And though impeachment remains unlikely, the Republican leadership has moved somewhat closer to Mr. Barr's position. For the last two weeks, Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, has taken out after Mr. Clinton nearly every day. He also met privately in Georgia with Mr. Barr, who declined to talk about their discussion. But when Mr. Gingrich spoke of a cover-up and a "line in the sand" and said, "This is not about sex, this is about lawbreaking," he was echoing the language that Mr. Barr has been using for months.
Mr. Gingrich is still not even close to using the I-word, and many in Congress say he is considering appointing a special committee to handle any impeachment inquiry specifically to get around Mr. Barr and a couple of other firebrands on the Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Barr said he did not consider himself a particularly angry guy. Of his outbursts in committee, he said, "Sometimes what we have to deal with is just beyond the pale. It's hard to sit there with a nice smile on your face."
And of the airport incident with the security guard on April 25, Mr. Barr said he merely "moved her arms away. I think if anybody had a security guard who got in their face and swore at them, they would get angry or be intimidated."
These days, Mr. Barr often travels nationally to speak about impeachment -- as he did recently at the invitation of the John Birch Society, which paid for a trip to Los Angeles. And on the road, his fight is anything but lonely.
On a recent weekend, Mr. Barr began Saturday morning in his heavily conservative north Georgia district in the new Douglas County courthouse, at an event for high school students who want to attend one of the service academies. Mr. Barr's father was a West Point man, and he is in his element. But he still does not smile much.
His wife, Jeri, who at the event wore red, white and blue and American flag earrings, heads a social service agency for homeless people in Cobb County, where the Barrs live. She says she often beeps her husband when he is on television: "Smile, honey," is the message.
At the next event, he joined a group of men in Confederate uniforms and women in hoop skirts, all suited up for a barbecue at Twelve Oaks on the edge of a parking lot.
"In Washington, particularly in the area of holding our leaders accountable, one of the great figures is Robert E. Lee," Mr. Barr said. "We try to keep in mind the standards of General Lee. There is more to our Southern heritage than whether the economy is running well."
Mr. Barr remarked how energizing these trips home were after the week in Washington, where he slept on his office couch, E-mailing his staff at all hours of the night.
After Mr. Barr rushed to the Atlanta airport, and had the run-in, his flight to Austin was delayed. While he waited, he voiced small and large resentments, about airline service, high prices and the I.R.S. Passing a cigar store reminded him that the Government "is trying to go after" cigars now: "Of course. People like it, so let's regulate it."
Mrs. Barr said the incident with the security guard reminded her of the time she was delayed by security people at Washington Dulles. "They were all from other countries, and they were talking about me in their language, and I couldn't even tell what they were saying," she said. "I thought, 'Hey, this is my country. This is my home airport.' "
There was one bit of good news. Glancing at a newspaper, Mr. Barr said, "Hey! They canceled 'Ellen.' " Mrs. Barr said: "It wasn't as funny after she made her announcement."
When Mr. Barr seemed buoyed by the sight of an airport Starbucks, she exposed him as a fan of the store's espresso shots. Her husband chuckled in guilty pleasure and said his staff did not really approve of him patronizing such a liberal company.
When the Barrs stopped for lunch at an airport TGI Friday's, he talked about his many problems with Mr. Clinton. It quickly became obvious that his objections were more legal than moral. He talked about the Constitution rather than the Bible. He seemed obsessed not by sex but by possible breaches in national security. And when he mentioned Monica Lewinsky, it was only to call her a bit player in the current spectacle.
"There's something very wrong with what this President is doing, and if we don't do something, I worry about the future of our country," he said.
At 49, Mr. Barr is only a year younger than Mr. Clinton but seems of another place and time. While Mr. Clinton grew up in the small-town South, apparently bonding for life with every member of his kindergarten class, Mr. Barr spent a rootless childhood in Iran, Malaysia, Pakistan and Panama, where his father took engineering jobs. The years abroad made him more patriotic, he says. He became a Southerner by choice, settling in Georgia as an adult.
In a telephone interview, his mother, Beatrice Barr of Manassas, Va., said her boy was "a usual, obnoxious" kid. "There were six kids and I can say that about every one of them."
While Mr. Clinton was protesting the Vietnam War and smoking dope, Mr. Barr "found other outlets for youth," he said, and cited the Young Trojan Republican Club at the University of Southern California. His mother said that as a freshman he considered joining a group of Democrats -- but came around when she threatened to cut him off. Mr. Barr said his mother, who turned him on to Ayn Rand, still considered him a "flaming liberal" and called regularly to blast his galling moderation.
Mr. Barr became active in a fraternity for young men who hoped to join the foreign service. He married before college graduation, and later went to work for the C.I.A. while studying law at Georgetown University. When he links Mr. Clinton to "the 60's counterculture," it is with considerable venom.
He first became interested in running for office, he said, when Richard Nixon disappointed him by tarnishing the reputation of the C.I.A.
And despite his antipathy for this President, Mr. Barr said that he would never call him names. "When I was young I was teased very maliciously at some times and I'm sensitive to that," he said. "I was short. I have scars on the side of my head from an operation I had after I was born." He recalled being chosen last for sports teams, and said he had never really been much for socializing and had made no close friends on the Hill.
In fact Mr. Barr is as hard on himself as on any of his political foes and often repeats that he does not consider himself very smart. But he is sensitive to the criticism he has taken in recent years, especially in sponsoring the Defense of Marriage Act. Critics said that as a twice-divorced man, he had no business moralizing about same-sex unions.
Mr. Barr seems to avoid attacking Mr. Clinton for his personal life. When asked to describe his primary emotion when he sees the President, he said, "amazement," and sighed. "Here is this man, there's serious evidence he's abused his power, and yet his wife sticks by him, every one of his colleagues in the House stick by him and a large number of the American people."
He seems to feel that he himself would not be so fortunate, though he has survived a few mini-scandals of his own, including minor campaign finance problems.
When he arrived in Texas just before dusk at a country club with a dazzling view of the hills outside Austin, Mr. Barr found himself surrounded by the like-minded members of the Texas Review of Law and Politics, which published his article on impeachment and named it "article of the year." They give him a standing ovation.
But he seems more comfortable battling an absent adversary than taking compliments. When one man told him how brave he was to go on programs like "Crossfire," he squirmed a little. And when another called him "a spokesperson for the truth," he changed the subject.

NEWMAN, LENORE

 BODY:
NEWMAN-Lenore. Died quietly at home on May 6 in her apartment in New York City. Family and friends join together in sorrow at the departure of this caring, loving person who carried her professional social work training as a way of life. She retired from Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital as supervising medical social worker. Lenore was proud of her volunteer work at the United Nations where after her retirement she dedicated increasing time as a representative of Economists Allied for Arms Reduction. Her surviving family include her nieces Sharon and Marla, her nephew Bernarr, her grandnephews Frank and Jeremy, & her sister-in-law Janis Newman. The service will be at noon on Monday, May 11, at the Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City, and the family will be receiving there on Sunday 6-8 P.M., and at the residence of L. Levi, 91 Central Park West (69th Street), Monday 6-8 P.M., and Tuesday 4-8 P.M. Interment will be at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

LENGTH: 2656 words

HEADLINE: Literary Pilgrimages;
William Faulkner

BYLINE: By Beverly Lowry; Beverly Lowry is the author of "Crossed Over: A Murder, a Memoir" (Knopf).

 BODY:
This is not a dream. It's real. For lunch, one warm perfect day in Oxford, Miss., I had a grilled portobello mushroom and Italian ham sandwich. The mushroom had been quickly flamed so that it was nicely browned along the edges, but as juicy in the middle as rare beef. When I dipped a chunk of it into the olive oil in a shallow bowl beside my plate, I was careful to scoop up some of the freshly ground pepper at the bottom.
Later on, cruising the downtown courthouse square, I ran into a friend who asked me what I'd had for lunch. When I told her, she rolled her eyes. "When you can get a portobello sandwich in Oxford, you know we've gone too far," she said. 
 I knew what she meant. I grew up in Mississippi and went to college in Oxford, at the University of Mississippi -- Ole Miss. Back then, a noon meal in any small town in Mississippi meant either a blue-plate special, a burger or barbecue. These days in Oxford, the Bottletree Bakery makes excellent baguettes, croissants and brioche, Don Pancho's spoons up Caribbean fare, and the Henry Cafe serves strictly vegetarian fare on Fiestaware, in a minimalist setting. You can still get excellent barbecue and blue plates -- including huge breakfasts of ham steaks, grits and biscuits at Smitty's -- and good fried chicken breast on a stick at the Chevron station, but jazzier options are available, as well.
Leaving the square, I drove down South Lamar. The elegant, mostly antebellum houses lining that street are immaculately kept, and have a delicate, spindly look, like lace dresses preserved in a glass case. Azaleas, dogwood and wisteria ride the hilly yards in careful drifts. At the corner of South Lamar and Old Taylor Road, there is a small sign saying "Rowan Oak." Turn right, drive a couple blocks, park under some trees, and you've arrived at Oxford's main tourist attraction, the home of William Faulkner.
Oxford's no ordinary Southern town. Its population is only about 20,000, half of whom are students at the university. But Rowan Oak -- which Faulkner bought in 1930 and lived in with his wife, Estelle, and his daughter, Jill, until 1960 when he went off to Charlottesville, Va., to teach and ride horses -- draws upward of 12,000 visitors a year. People come from all over the world to trace the events in his books -- "The Sound and the Fury," "Absalom, Absalom!" and "Light in August" among them -- and attach them to the real places of his actual life, and to see where it was he lived and slept and ate. They like to ride around Oxford, the seat of Lafayette County, and reminisce about the fictional counterparts Faulkner created -- the town of Jefferson, the county of Yoknapatawpha -- and the characters he dreamed up and placed there, the Compsons and McCaslins, Sartorises and Snopeses.
"People like to think he planted his behind in that chair and never moved," says the novelist Cynthia Shearer, who has been curator of Rowan Oak for five years. She's referring to the completely ordinary ladderback chair, set at an angle in front of Faulkner's well-photographed and battered portable Underwood, facing a window overlooking his famous stables and horse barn. "We have pictures of him and his typewriter all over the house. Outside, in the library ... Anyway this room was a porch until 1950."
On the walls behind the writer's desk, the day-by-day outline of "A Fable" is famously hand-lettered by Faulkner on the wall. And, Cynthia Shearer points out, there's a potentially significant can of shellac on a bookshelf beside his office chair. After her husband had finished writing "A Fable," Estelle Faulkner, according to legend, rashly ordered the wall repainted, over the outline. Using photographs as a guide, the outraged writer redid it and afterward, shellacked the wall, for the sake of permanence and posterity. (Interestingly enough, the topmost lines of lettering are located about six feet from the floor. Faulkner was about five-two.)
When Faulkner died in 1962, his widow leased Rowan Oak to the University of Mississippi. At that time, only two downstairs rooms were open to public viewing -- his library and office. In 1973, after Estelle Faulkner's death, Jill Faulkner sold the house and 28.5 acres of its surrounding countryside, mostly woods -- known as Bailey's Woods -- to the university.
Set off from the street by a protective shell of swingy cedars and stolid oaks, the house itself, it must be said, is not a thing of beauty. It has columns, meant to lend it an air of grandeur, but really it's just a big old white house. The setting, however, is splendid -- green and whispery, lush with wisteria and roses in the spring. The yard is not fenced off or protected from local foot traffic. There is no entrance fee.
Inside the house, the same sense of stillness pervades. There is nothing for sale. A bowl on a table by the front door usually contains a couple of donated dollars. Guides are prepared to answer questions but if you don't want to ask any and don't feel like listening to stories, you get to do that.
The deed to Rowan Oak states that the house be shown as a memorial to the writer -- not a furniture show. In the beginning, nobody thought any of this out. Curators opened the doors and people came. Somewhere along the way, somebody scissored Faulkner's signature out of every Dickens novel in his collection ... presumably to sell. There is no way of knowing who did that. To this day, khaki pants, tux shirts and many pairs of shoes belonging to Faulkner are shut up in a chifforobe in his bedroom -- some of the shoes still caked with the red mud of northern Mississippi. In one of the curatorial offices, there are boxes of as yet uncatalogued items, including paper shirt collars and a vial of painkillers prescribed in Sweden to ease the writer's back pain so that he could make his 1949 Nobel Prize acceptance speech.
In 1979-80, the house was closed for renovations, including the painting of rooms and structural repair. In 1992, after an extensive fund-raising campaign, the university did major work on the exterior buildings, replacing rotten timbers, rebuilding the barn. But there is as yet no climate control mechanism in the house. In winter, it's heated by radiators. Room air-conditioners have been installed to offset the stifling summer heat. But time, dampness and light have done their work. Soon, Faulkner's books will be transported out of the house for their own protection, replaced with copies, or dummies.
"There are two schools of thought among museum people," Cynthia Shearer explains, as we stand in the formal parlor looking down at a seriously ugly and worn mouse-gray rug. One is to re-create the reality of Faulkner's time. The other is "to keep the original and worship it like the Shroud of Turin." Museum purists wish the university would move the furniture out and exhibit it somewhere where it can be properly preserved, say a real museum, where it would be put behind glass, beyond the reach of mildew and sunlight. Presumably, signs would be put up, saying "Faulkner's Writing Desk," "Faulkner's Hairbrush" and so on.
I spent a long time in Faulkner's bedroom, leaning across the Plexiglas barrier to study the books on the shelf beside his bed. They turned out to be mostly mysteries, as well as some fiction of the times ("Elmer Gantry," "Pal Joey"), a big book called "The Negro in the History of Methodism," which looked unread, and a tome called "The Judgment of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg." An entry number from a horse show is propped on the mantle above a fireplace containing a gas space heater. Faulkner, it is said, was a terrible rider, but loved the pomp and -- especially -- the outfits. There is a painting of him in the parlor in full pink-jacketed hunting gear, looking grimly proud of himself and a bit ridiculous in the top hat. In the library, on another mouse-gray rug, is the wooden shell of a phonograph that serves as an end table. William Faulkner would allow neither a radio nor music to be played in his home. When his wife and daughter bought a record player anyway, he ripped out the mechanisms, and there it sits. If he didn't directly write about his troubled life or his equally troubled marriage, it's not hard to get a strong impression of them, looking at his furniture and things.
Local people get a little weary of the Faulkner myth-making, but they don't minimize its importance. In the past 133 years, the South has had to reinvent itself many times over, and only the towns that have remained open to new ideas have found ways to thrive. Oxford is one of the few Southern towns I know of with a viable downtown. To acknowledge the contribution of the Faulkner industry to Oxford's economy, the mayor and board of aldermen asked William N. Beckwith to design a statue of the writer, to be situated in front of the City Hall. It was installed in September 1997, on the occasion of his 100th birthday. He's seated, with his pipe, looking quizzically away from the other town statue, of a Confederate soldier. Nobody pays much attention to that statue. But it's there.
Oxford was not a literary town in Faulkner's time, but it is now. Barry Hannah lives there, also Larry Brown, Cynthia Shearer and -- some of the time -- John Grisham. A big Conference for the Book takes place in the spring, and the Faulkner conference in August draws scholars from more countries than he probably knew existed. One of the best bookstores in the country, Square Books, stands on what is possibly the best corner on the square, downtown. You can sit in Square Books, drink cappuccino, read books and visit with friends pretty much all afternoon long.
Down the street from Square Books, there's a clever shop called Mississippi Madness, which sells all manner of foods, cookware and Mississippi-made ceramics. A sign of the times: many of the packaged foods are speciality dishes cooked by women who live in dying towns in the state -- caramel icing from Boyle, salad dressing from Yazoo City, black-eyed pea caviar from Clarksdale. At Material Culture, a virtual emporium of "all things Southern and good," I resisted buying a mostly ice-blue painting called "Mississippi the Magnolia State" by the folk artist Sam McMillan in favor of some less pricey purchases at other stores -- a new cassette tape for the drive home, a huge iced cinnamon roll from the Bottletree.
I ended my day in the cemetery, in the north of town. The stately stone marking Faulkner's grave doesn't offer much in the way of messages from the beyond -- only "Beloved Go With God." Like the furniture at Rowan Oak, it looks pretty much store-bought and without mystery.
I had a final dinner with friends at the Yocona River Inn, a small and very pretty converted catfish joint on a country road southeast of town. The restaurant doesn't have a liquor license and so we had to bring our own wine. But the rack of lamb and grilled fresh tuna were nicely cooked, and so was the creme brulee. Unquestionably these are the trendiest kind of dishes, light years from the greens and ham hocks of former days, but I didn't mind. Too much nostalgia can make you stupid, not to mention fat. On the other hand, for old and new times' sake, I've decided to buy that "Mississippi the Magnolia State" painting.
 
Yoknapatawpha County Seat
Oxford has a number of chain motels, among them the Comfort Inn (601-234-6000), Downtown Inn (601-234-3031) and Ramada Inn (601-234-7013), where double rooms cost about $65 to $70 a night (higher on football weekends).
There are also three bed-and-breakfasts within walking distance of Courthouse Square:
Barksdale-Isom House, 1003 Jefferson Avenue (601-236-5600), has six rooms, all with private bath, for $120 or $150, including a full breakfast of, perhaps, peppered ham, green onion cheese grits and homemade buttermilk biscuits with an assortment of homemade jams. The house, which was built in 1835, has its original floorboards, and is furnished with early 19th-century French antiques.
Oliver-Britt House, 512 Van Buren Avenue (601-234-8043), is a 1905 Greek Revival house with five individually decorated rooms, all with private bath, that are $45 and $55 Sunday through Thursday, and $55 and $65 on weekends, when a substantial breakfast of cheese grits, eggs, ham, bacon and sausage is served.
Puddin' Place, 1008 University Avenue (601-234-1250), is an 1892 house, with many original details, furnished with antiques. There are two suites, one with one bedroom and one with two, each with a private sitting room and bath. Each bedroom and sitting room has a wood-burning fireplace; the two-room suite has a fireplace in the bathroom. Rates are $90 (with an additional charge of $10 for a third person in the room), including a full breakfast, typically juice, fruit, a version of eggs Benedict and homemade apple muffins.
Old Venice Pizza Company, 1112 Van Buren Avenue (601-236-6872), is open for lunch and dinner from Monday through Saturday. The menu changes seasonally; a portobello mushroom sandwich is $5.95. Other specialties are lasagne ($7.95) and a variety of pizzas, including the John Wayne, with barbecued chicken and cheddar cheese ($6.95). There are a number of domestic and imported beers and a wine list (average bottle, $15 to $20).
Bottletree Bakery, 923 Van Buren Avenue (601-236-5000), offers croissants, brioche filled with jam or fresh fruit and cinnamon rolls for $1.50 each. Coffee, soft drinks and sandwiches are also available; the most popular is the Van Buren, smoked turkey with Oregon raspberry mustard, provolone, lettuce, tomato and red onion on rosemary-garlic sourdough bread ($6.25). Open 7 to 4, Tuesday through Friday, 9 to 4 Saturday, 9 to 2 Sunday.
Don Pancho's, 512 Jackson Avenue East (601-238-2736), serves Caribbean and Spanish specialties including shredded beef ($8.95, with rice, beans and salad) and catfish in garlic sauce ($12.95, with rice, beans and salad); desserts include homemade flan and homemade rice pudding ($2.75 each). Open Monday through Saturday for lunch and dinner.
Henry Cafe, 1002-1006 Jackson Avenue East (601-236-3757), recently under new ownership, now serves a lunchtime pork loin sandwich ($5.95) as well as a vegetarian plate lunch ($4.95); dinner choices include chilis rellenos wih Spanish rice and roasted corn salsa ($8.95) and glazed roasted duck with jalapeno mashed potatoes ($14.95). Desserts include chocolate mousse cake ($3.75) and tiramisu ($3.25). There is a full bar, with tapas, and a short list of wines priced at $18 to $35 a bottle. Open for lunch and dinner Monday through Saturday, Sunday for brunch.
Smitty's Restaurant, 208 South Lamar Boulevard (601-234-9111), serves breakfast all day; a plateful of country ham steak, grits and biscuits with red-eye gravy, is $7.95. Open daily from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.
Chevron Food Mart, 502 South Lamar Boulevard (601-234-0275), serves grits and biscuits (79 cents to $1.59) for breakfast and plate lunches (meat and two vegetables, $3.50). Fried chicken breast on a stick is $1.99. Open 24 hours a day, seven days a week.
Square Books Cafe, Courthouse Square (601-236-2262), serves espresso for $1.25, cappuccino for $1.75 and a selection of homemade cookies and biscotti (macaroons are 80 cents). Open from 9 to 9 Monday through Thursday, until 10 on Friday and Saturday, 10 to 6 on Sunday.
Yocona River Inn, Highway 334 to Yocona (601-234-2464), has a menu that changes weekly, but might include crayfish cakes with chipotle mayonnaise ($5.75) and a giant pork chop with cornbread stuffing and bourbon-pecan sauce ($14.95). For dessert, creme brulee ($4.75) and sour cream cheesecake ($3.75) are always available. Open for dinner, Wednesday through Sunday; bring your own liquor (mixers are $1.50) and wine.
Rowan Oak, Old Taylor Road (601-234-3284), is open, free, from 10 to noon and from 2 to 4, Tuesday through Saturday, and from 2 to 4 on Sunday.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Safer Riding For Children

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
HERE are some cautionary statistics to consider: Traffic injuries are the leading cause of death among children in the United States, killing 2,122 children 15 years of age or younger in 1996 and injuring 330,000, according to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration figures. And last summer, the Travel Industry Association of America says, 43 percent of adults who traveled took children with them, most of them in the family car.
And in the most recent figures, 40 percent of injuries to passengers under 14 occurred during only one-third of the year -- from May to August -- said Richard A. Schieber, who is in charge of efforts by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to reduce child injuries and deaths. 
 So safety is the first watchword for travel with children, both in and out of the car. Here is a quick review of ways to protect children, plus information on a couple of new products.
Air bags have received a lot of attention, out of proportion to the overall statistics. The latest cars and most sport utility vehicles have air bags in front of both front seats. Since air bags appeared widely on the 1990 models, they have killed 55 children by force of inflation, all but 13 of them improperly buckled in or unrestrained. But air bags have saved 3,000 lives over all in the last decade, Federal regulators estimate.
Air bags pose no danger to children in the back seat. And that is where children of all ages should be riding, the National Transportation Safety Board said last year. So far only one state -- Rhode Island -- has a law requiring children to sit in back. A vote in the North Carolina Senate may come this week.
 
A Shift to Seat Belts
But safety advocates have shifted their focus from the back seat to seat belts. The Air Bag Safety and Seat Belt Campaign says that 6 out of 10 children who die in crashes are unbelted. The group, financed by automobile and air-bag makers and insurance companies, has figures showing that the child does as the driver does. In Colorado, it was found, if the drivers were buckled up, 72 percent of the passengers ages 4 through 15 were, too; if the drivers were not, the child figure dropped to 11 percent.
This group is therefore lobbying legislatures in states that have no adult seat-belt laws or laws that are not "primary," meaning they do not permit a traffic officer to pull over a driver simply for not wearing a seat belt. The group is also pressing for stricter enforcement in the localities with primary laws: 14 states and the District of Columbia.
Side air bags, to supplement the now mandatory front air bags, are on the way. Avis and Hertz say that they will appear in some 1999 models.
Dr. Schieber said the Centers for Disease Control had looked at tapes of children in their seat belts showing that within minutes of being buckled in, they were squirming or partly out of the belts. "A belt protects only when the passenger is sitting squarely in it," he said. The solution? Be sure that children sit straight and stay buckled, and build in time for stops where they can run around or otherwise work off the squirms.
Children in car seats also deserve frequent breaks on a long trip. Some car seats can be used to a later age, and it is worthwhile to keep a child in the safety seat or to use a booster seat, if adult chest straps chafe the neck.
Dr. Schieber also saw opportunities for safety training while on vacation. He started with an obvious one that might be missed. "Crossing an unfamiliar street is a teachable moment," he said. "Be sure the child looks left and right and tell him or her: 'Be sure you see the driver and the driver sees you before you cross.' "
Three of my grandchildren, who just made their first weeklong car trip, into Canada, were thrilled with room service and hotel pools. The first taste they share with Eloise; the other they share with most American children. Dr. Schieber considers the pool the main hazard for children at a hotel, because it is unsupervised and may not have a shallow end. Parents should keep children who are good swimmers in sight, he said, the others within reach. A child, even a good swimmer, should not be in the pool alone; a buddy system is needed. Most motel pools no longer have diving boards. If children dive from the edge, parents should test the depth of the water first and be in the water at the time.
 
What Hotels Are Doing
Going beyond the regular hotel "summer programs" for children, Novotel New York, at 52d Street and Broadway, began to think about keeping small children safe in a room devised for adults. Although the program is narrow -- at this Novotel only -- and its "safety pack" expensive at $35, it provides good alerts to parents with toddlers.
The hotel provides a list of safety tips devised by a company called Child Proofers. The tips -- keeping the toilet lid down, for example -- are mostly familiar to parents, but one is unusual: putting a towel over the top of the bathroom door to keep a child from getting locked in. The kit contains a bath thermometer (a wrist or elbow would do), an inflatable cover for a tub spigot, a night light, plastic covers for electric outlets and tape to secure electric cords out of the way. Child Proofers will mail its free checklist to parents who send a self-addressed stamped business envelope to: Child Proofers, 540 West Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, N.Y. 10543.
A new item worth tossing into the luggage to supplement the first-aid kit is a six-by-five-inch plastic envelope offered by Johnson & Johnson called First Aid to Go. Intended for treatment of scrapes, it contains two antiseptic wipes, antibiotic ointment, four Band-Aid bandages and two Tylenol caplets. It sells for $1.79 a pack in pharmacies.
 
Tricks for Trips
Keeping the stress level down in the car eases the work of the driver and any navigator. On their road trip, the grandchildren field-tested a new card game: "Are We There Yet?", consisting of 430 cards challenging children to spot certain things on the road: "A driver with one hand on the wheel," for example, or "A sign with an X in it." These children, age 6 to 11, got five cards each and took a new card each time a challenge was met. The game costs $14.95 and is available at nondiscount toy stores, including F.A.O. Schwarz, and by mail order from L. L. Bean, (800) 809-7057; item QR 27323; $15. Information about other outlets: (800) 892-9012.
When the game got too exciting, the parents turned on the book tapes they had checked out of the library. Age has not dimmed the appeal of "Pippi Longstocking," I was told.
I have heard of parents who rely on the calming effect of a videotape playing in the back seat. At Soundcity on 45th Street in New York, Joe Kaufman, a salesman, said that the model most often bought for this purpose is the Philips Magnavox CCX 092, with a nine-inch screen and an attachment that plugs into the lighter outlet. It costs $399. For some sort of ultimate, it has a plug to accommodate the camcorder, so the family can review its day's activities.
