Cooperstown Without a Car
Q. I will be visiting New York City and would like to take a side trip to Cooperstown, N.Y., to visit the Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. Can I get there by public transit? -- Bill Van Deelen, Fresno, Calif.
A. Without a car, you may find it nearly as difficult to get to the Hall of Fame as Phil Rizzuto did. But the Scooter made it, and you can, too. 
 For now, Adirondack Trailways runs buses to Cooperstown from New York City only once a day Friday and Sunday. A 7 A.M. departure from the midtown Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and 42d Street, arrives in Cooperstown at 12:30; the return leaves Cooperstown at 4:30 P.M., reaching New York at 10 P.M. Summertime service, June 24 to Sept. 8, has three trips daily from New York and two from Cooperstown. The round-trip fare is $76.70.
Another option is to travel to Utica on Amtrak, which makes at least two stops a day there from New York ($108 peak round trip), and take the daily Trailways bus to Cooperstown. For Adirondacks Trailways information, call (800) 225-6815; for Amtrak, (800) 872-7245.
But a much simpler -- and economical -- plan would be to reserve a place on the Catskill shuttle, a 14-passenger van run by Lans Transportation Service, (800) 607-2753. From May 15, Lans runs at least one shuttle a day except Tuesday and Saturday from New York to Cooperstown, leaving between 10 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. Bill Lounsbery, the owner, said you would have to stay overnight, though, because the return is early in the morning. The round-trip fare is $65.
The Hall of Fame is open daily 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. through September, then till at least 5 P.M. the rest of the year. Admission is $9.50; $8 for ages 65 and up, and $4 ages 7 to 12. Information: (888) 425-5633 or on the Web, www.baseballhalloffame.org.
 
Concorde Global Tours
Q. Are around-the-world trips on the Concorde still available? If so, how demanding is it for someone who uses a wheelchair? -- Annette Horstman, Freehold, N.J.
A. Both British Airways and Air France Concordes are chartered for around-the-world tours a couple of times a year, generally. This year, though, only Air France Concordes are making such trips. British Airways spokesmen said they knew only of a January 1999 around-the-world golf trip out of Hamburg.
But Intrav, a St. Louis company, is organizing two around-the-world excursions on Air France Concordes this fall, and plans three more next year. The ones this year are sold out, said Richard Hefler, senior vice president of Intrav, but there are waiting lists.
The itinerary for this year's excursions -- leaving Sept. 15 and Oct. 8 from New York, Dallas-Fort Worth or Las Vegas -- takes travelers to eight countries in 24 days. After two days in Hawaii, the tour makes three-day stops in Queenstown, New Zealand; Sydney, Australia; Beijing; Hong Kong; New Delhi (and the Taj Mahal); Nairobi, Kenya (and a game preserve), and Paris. The cost: $55,800 a person, double occupancy. Air travel will be in daylight hours. All meals are included, as are special parties, all sightseeing and gratuities.
Two of the Concorde global tours leave on the same dates in 1999: Sept. 15 and Oct. 8. The Sept. 15 itinerary is identical to this year's, but the Oct. 8 trip will have a few different stops, heading first to South America, then across the Pacific.
Intrav's third 1999 global charter is an 18-day trip leaving Dec. 24 -- to Hawaii (for Christmas), Australia, Hong Kong (for New Year's Eve), India, Kenya and Egypt. The cost: $75,000, double occupancy.
Asked about the rigorousness of such a trip, Lohn Lampl, a spokesman for British Airways, likened it to a cruise. Dennis Overman, vice president and general manager of Intrav, has led several of these trips and said that people confined to a wheelchair might find their enjoyment of some sights minimized. He said that there might be special arrangements needed for someone who is confined to a wheelchair, and that Intrav would make those arrangements.
Keep in mind that the Concorde is fairly narrow, and that Intrav has another global tour by air: 24 days starting in Indianapolis or Las Vegas on a refitted L-1011 wide-body jet. This trip makes many of the same stops as this year's Concorde trip, but with no more than 88 people on a plane designed for up to 362 seats, and which has been refitted with two lounges. So this plane may be more comfortable. This trip costs $37,800, double occupancy; an optional golf package is an additional $2,000.
For information on either trip, call Intrav at (800) 825-2900.
 
Finding Polish Roots
Q. I am traveling to Warsaw and Lodz to investigate my family history. I need a guide who speaks Polish, and perhaps knows some Hebrew. Do you have any information on finding one? -- Sophie Zimmerman, Great Neck, N.Y.
 A. The Polish National Tourist Office, at 275 Madison Avenue, New York 10016, can provide a list of Polish-tour operators and the general services they offer. Call (212) 338-9412; Web: www.polandtour.org.
At Air Tours Poland in New York, one of the companies listed, Beata Zieja, the sales manager, said her agency can arrange custom excursions with a driver who speaks English. The company's Warsaw office deals often with travelers from Israel, she added. She can be reached at (800) 223-0593, extension 243.
At another New York agency, Orbis Polish Tours, Richard Cichocki, the manager, said his company also can help you find a guide and plan excursions. Call (800) 867-7247 and ask for the FIT department.
Orbis also works with a genealogist, Miriam Weiner, whose company, Routes to Roots, specializes in genealogical research and travel in Poland, Ukraine, Moldova and Belarus. Based at 136 Sandpiper Key, Secaucus, N.J. 07094, she can be reached at (201) 866-4075 and has a Web site, www.routestoroots.com.
Miss Weiner also recently published "Jewish Roots in Poland," a guide to sites and archives. It includes descriptions of cities and towns (including several pages on Lodz, an industrial center once known as "the Polish Manchester"), chapters on genealogical research, and archives in Poland. On page 123, it lists The Jewish Information and Tourist Bureau (Our Roots), "a travel agency specializing in Jewish sites"; call or fax (48-22) 620-0556.
The book costs $50, plus $8 shipping (and $3 tax in New Jersey), and can be ordered from (800) 742-5403. RAY CORMIER

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Gay Cruises Draw Hostility in the Caribbean

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
AFTER hundreds of demonstrators heckled some 800 lesbian passengers who arrived in Nassau, the Bahamas, last month aboard Premier Cruises's Seabreeze, a headline in Cruise Week, a trade publication, asked, "Homophobic Protests on Rise in Ports?"
Two previous antigay incidents occurred in the Caribbean this year. In January, the Cayman Islands denied boarding rights at Grand Cayman to the Norwegian Cruise Line's Leeward, which was carrying some 900 gay passengers on a charter. And in March, religious groups in Nassau protested the scheduled arrival of Holland America's Veendam -- chartered by gay passengers, according to the protesters -- at Half Moon Cay, Holland America's nearby private island. Stipulating that it does not check on passengers' sexual orientation, Lawrence A. Dessler, a Holland America spokesman, said the ship was not chartered to a predominantly gay group, or any group; the situation was defused when rough weather eventually prevented the landing. 
 Even as the Veendam was heading for the Bahamas, Hubert Ingraham, prime minister of the Bahamas, denounced the antigay rhetoric in a televised news conference. After reminding his country of the large economic impact of the 1.7 million cruise visitors last year, and another 1.6 million stopover visitors (i.e., those spending a night on an island), he restated the islands' policy of nondiscrimination. "The future of the Bahamas is not threatened by foreign persons of homosexual orientation," he said. "Homosexuality is not a contagious disease, and it is not a crime in the Bahamas."
After the speech, some Bahamian religious leaders called for the prime minister's resignation. And when the Seabreeze subsequently arrived in Nassau, demonstrators, organized by a religious group called Save the Bahamas, were on hand to greet passengers with protests, heckling and signs saying, "No gay ships."
After the Cayman Islands incident, Billy Kolber-Stuart, the editor of Out & About, a travel newsletter for gay men and lesbians, wrote, "Few destinations in the Caribbean are truly gay friendly." Much of the Caribbean, he added, is out of touch with the realities of modern gay travel. The newsletter has called for a boycott until the Cayman Islands publicly assures gay travelers that they are welcome.
The 1,350-member International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association, hoping to arrange a meeting with Thomas C. Jefferson, minister of tourism for the Cayman Islands, has not yet taken a formal position on boycotting the Caymans. But it has suggested that individual members, including 900 travel agents who cater almost exclusively to gay travelers, conduct their own boycotts.
The growing importance of gay travel can be gauged in part by the growth of the international association, which had only five airline members five years ago and has 50 today, including most major airlines. It has also added about 400 members -- including travel agencies, hotels, airlines and cruise lines -- since last May.
"I personally believe these are just the expressions of a very few religious people," Richard E. Thompson, the executive director of the association, said of the Bahamas' protests. "I see it as just pockets of individual objections, not as a trend."
But a month before the Leeward set sail from Miami on its seven-day cruise, Mr. Jefferson wrote to Norwegian Cruise Line saying: "Careful research and prior experience has led us to conclude that we cannot count on this group to uphold the standards of appropriate behavior expected of our visitors. So we regrettably cannot offer our hospitality."
In a recent telephone interview about that "prior experience," Mr. Jefferson said that a ship chartered by gay tourists came to the Cayman Islands in 1987, and that the visitors' public displays of affection in George Town, the capital, offended many residents. "We are deeply religious and culturally conservative, and it is not in our nature to show public affection," Mr. Jefferson said. "So it is disturbing to see others do it."
After that 1987 incident, Mr. Jefferson said, "the Government made a decision to deny landing rights to chartered ships that we perceive to be party boats with single people. We did not and do not intend to criticize the life style of any individual aboard those ships, but we continue to consider it our right and responsibility to insure culturally compatible conduct on this island." While the Cayman Islands will continue to review each charter request, he said, it welcomes every individual, regardless of race or sexual orientation.
Derek Bergl, owner of Pied Piper Travel, a New York travel agency, has two gay groups booked on cruises scheduled for Bermuda this year -- about 30 people on the Norwegian Crown's weeklong cruise departing New York on May 23, and about 60 on the Queen Elizabeth 2 departing New York Sept. 4. Though not in the Caribbean, Bermuda is usually lumped with it in cruise itineraries and industry statistics, and, like the Caymans, it is a British dependency. But its attitude toward gay tourists appears to be markedly different. "We've been doing groups to Bermuda for about eight years, and we haven't had any problems," Mr. Bergl said. "The Bermudian Government is gay friendly."
As for other Caribbean nations, "We haven't taken an official position," said Michael Youngman, executive director of the Caribbean Tourism Organization, to which 33 governments belong. However, he added, there will be an attempt to formulate one during the meeting of ministers of tourism on May 27 in New York.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC;
Markevitch as Composer: An Icarus Who Flew Too High?

BYLINE: By RICHARD TARUSKIN; Richard Taruskin's latest book is "Defining Russia Musically."

 BODY:
TALL, gauntly handsome, icily cultivated, the subject of many reverential memoirs and just as many backbiting or salacious rumors, Igor Markevitch was for more than five decades a spook of the first magnitude in the musical life of Europe and some of its North American artistic colonies like Cuba and French Canada. In the United States, however, he has been relatively little known, or known only as a conductor, a situation that may begin to change when the American Symphony Orchestra, directed by Leon Botstein, performs "Icare," Markevitch's reputed masterpiece, on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.
Like Prokofiev's "Prodigal Son," a farewell offering to Serge Diaghilev and the Ballets Russes before the composer's return to the U.S.S.R., Markevitch's Icarus ballet has been all too easily interpreted as a metaphor for its composer's fate. Intended as a memorial to Diaghilev, in 1932, it tells of the arrogant high-flying youth of Greek mythology who fell to earth and perished in consequence of his hubris. Along with Erich Wolfgang Korngold one of the 20th century's most amazing composer prodigies, Markevitch burned himself out creatively by the age of 30. For most of the next 40 years, although he maintained an active career as a conductor, he never performed his own music, which mainly languished unpublished, and neither did anybody else. 
 Although his former pupils, many of whom have far outstripped him in fame and fortune, still swear by him as one of the great conductors of the century, Markevitch never held a major post. The best-known orchestra he ever directed was that of the Concerts Lamoureux in Paris, with which he made recordings in the late 50's that are highly prized by collectors. For the rest, he worked in Stockholm, Montreal, Havana, Madrid and Monte Carlo, appeared frequently in England (where he made more legendary records) and held court for many summers at the Salzburg Mozarteum.
A curmudgeonly stickler for textual fidelity, Markevitch retreated in his late years into the realm of maverick scholarship, leading to a vast study of Beethoven's symphonies published in German in 1983, shortly before his death, at 71. His tell-all (but in fact, withhold-most) autobiography had come out in French a few years before. An earlier memoir about his wartime experiences in the Italian underground was written in English. This was a man of parts, a man of legend.
But behind the legend of the phantom conductor-ascetic lay the bigger legend of the wild Wunderkind composer. Now that story can at last be told with musical illustrations, thanks to the yeoman work of the English conductor Christopher Lyndon-Gee, who has recorded Markevitch's complete orchestral music -- eight works in all, dating from 1929 to 1937 -- with the Arnhem Philharmonic Orchestra, a Dutch ensemble, on three Marco Polo CD's (8.223653, 8.223666, 8.223724). On a companion disk (Largo LC 8943), Mr. Lyndon-Gee and other excellent musicians perform four chamber works, including a version of the Icarus ballet for a Bartokian ensemble of pianists and percussionists.
So, how high did Markevitch fly?
Born in Kiev in 1912 but raised abroad from his second year, he composed his first published piece, a stylish little suite for piano called "Noces" ("Wedding") at 13. (It's on the Largo disk.) On the strength of it, he became a protege of Alfred Cortot, who taught him piano and farmed him out to Nadia Boulanger for training in harmony and counterpoint. He quickly progressed to free composition, since (as Boulanger liked to say) he was born knowing all the rules.
In 1928, he played part of a Stravinsky-saturated Sinfonietta for Diaghilev, who fell hard for him and immediately began touting the young man as his latest great discovery. In this case, Diaghilev's passion was requited only artistically. As with his other young men -- Vaslav Nijinsky, whom he presented to Paris at 19, or Boris Kochno, who wrote the libretto for Stravinsky's "Mavra" at 17 -- the great impresario took over the young Markevitch's life. He "unveiled" the lad in a concert hurriedly held at Covent Garden in 1929, 12 days before Markevitch's birthday, so he could still be presented as a 16-year-old in a hastily composed Piano Concerto Diaghilev had commissioned from him. (It is the one piece that the publisher Boosey & Hawkes, when it belatedly signed Markevitch on as a composer in 1978, could not get him to reissue.)
A couple of days earlier, Diaghilev had published an open letter in The Times of London proclaiming that his "young countryman" would finally put an end to the gaudy "Paris orgies" of the last two decades: artistic orgies that Diaghilev himself, of course, had perpetrated, but of which he now blaringly repented. It could even be said (and was said) that the great man laid down his life for his last boy toy. Against his doctor's orders, Diaghilev romanced Markevitch with a whirlwind tour of Germany, where they met with Hindemith, heard Mozart (under Richard Strauss) and Wagner ("Tristan und Isolde"), and went to all the museums. Diaghilev returned to Venice exhausted, and died 12 days later.
He left Markevitch a marked man, at 17 already a figure of jealous controversy. The protagonists of the "Paris orgies," Stravinsky and Prokofiev, not pleased with what they had been reading, snubbed him.
Stravinsky settled scores with the young Markevitch, as he did with so many others, in his books of "Conversations" with Robert Craft. He tried (unsuccessfully) to prevent his own German publisher, Schott, from taking an interest in Markevitch's work, writing that the boy was not so much Wunderkind as "altklug," a precocious flash-in-the-pan. He even sent his son Soulima, also a pianist and composer, to insult Markevitch at the premiere of a choral cantata in 1930. "It must be awful being another Igor," Soulima taunted. "It must be worse to be another Stravinsky," little Igor shot back.
THE anecdote comes courtesy of Prokofiev, who included it in a letter home along with uncomplimentary remarks of his own. But Prokofiev's put-down, however ill-meant, gives insight into why Markevitch's composerly career ultimately fizzled. "He has definite abilities," Prokofiev allowed, "but the good moments drown in waves of Beckmesserisms."
The reference to Wagner's inept mastersinger, whose name is synonymous with clumsy pedantry, was Prokofiev's catty way of signaling that Markevitch suffered from German influences, mainly Hindemith's. Probably few listeners today would agree, even though one of the pieces now recorded, the Concerto Grosso of 1930, took Hindemith's Concerto for Orchestra as a model.
The composer whose music Markevitch's most resembles is Arthur Honegger: not the Honegger of Les Six (though there's an echo of those composers in Markevitch's "Galop," which would make ideal theme music for "The Simpsons") but the biblical Honegger of "King David" and "Judith" and the muscular "polytonal" Honegger of the early symphonic poems ("Chant de Joie," "Rugby," "Pacific 231").
Even without benefit of Hindemith, though, Beckmesserisms there certainly were. Markevitch's great flair was for colorful orchestral textures, often polyrhythmic. In works like "Icare" and "Rebus" (his other ballet), and in two monumental suites -- "Hymnes" (1933) and "Le Nouvel Age" ("The New Age," 1937) -- he often builds up magnificent sonic montages combining concurrent ostinatos with two, three, four, six and nine beats to the bar. But then, usually, his imagination stalls, and he just sits on them, or alternates a couple or three, for pages at a time. Not only that, but the units so tiresomely reiterated are almost invariably a dull two or four bars in length.
Foursquareness also pervades the harmonic rhythm, the rate at which chords change. The "Cantique d'Amour," of 1936, a lush jungle growth of virtually themeless orchestral tissue, is an obvious homage to the Scriabin of the "Poem of Ecstasy," and also, perhaps, to the Brasilianas of Villa-Lobos, then a frequent presence in Paris concert programs. Its sensuality quickly palls, however, as polyharmony succeeds hyperharmony (as Rimsky-Korsakov would have said) with clockwork predictability at every bar line. Call it the march of ecstasy or the poem of accuracy: either way, the effect is nugatory.
The deadness of his "larger rhythm" despite all the inventive tinycraft is Markevitch's most obvious liability today. When his work was new, there were esthetic handicaps as well. The music is resolutely modernistic yet old-fashioned at the same time, because what it tended to flaunt was yesterday's modernism, or even the day before's. This was something about which Diaghilev cautioned Markevitch at their first meeting. Suspecting that his young idol was worshiping the thoroughly outmoded Ravel, Diaghilev upbraided him. "Why get so excited about yesterday?" he asked. The 16-year-old drew himself up as best he could and retorted, "I'm not interested in yesterday or today but in what is forever." From that moment, Diaghilev was smitten.
But he was right. Markevitch remained always about a decade behind the avant-garde, and in avant-garde circles a decade or two is maximum lag. Stravinsky sensed Markevitch's fixation on his own "Rite of Spring" (of which the later Markevitch became an intrepid exponent on the podium) and chided him mercilessly in a letter of 1934 about his devotion to a work "from whose esthetic tendencies I have been moving further and further away in what I have been doing for more than 15 years."
Stravinsky may have had in mind "Hymnes," a set of four noisy paeans to contemporary life that kept alive (or on artificial life-support) the neo-primitivist esthetic of "The Rite" long into the age of Neo-Classicism. They also reverberated with the "Symphony of Machines" rhetoric of the Italian futurists, already stale in George Antheil's "Ballet Mecanique," by then a decade old.
The second movement, the "Hymne au Travail" ("Hymn to Work"), even smacks of Alexander Mosolov's dowdy old "Iron Foundry," the emblematic "constructivist" opus of the Soviet 20's, and it is no surprise to learn from the CD booklet that Sergei Eisenstein, the great director, tried to entice Markevitch to return to Soviet Russia at the height of Stalinism to collaborate on films. (Only his mother's objections -- her "irrational fear" of Soviet Communism, as the booklet puts it with remarkable obtuseness -- prevented Markevitch's acceptance.)
But even Stravinsky was impressed with the Icarus ballet, the one piece that deserved a future. (Markevitch gave symbolic assent to this judgment in 1943, when he revised and simpflied the ballet, originally titled "L'Envol d'Icare," or "The Flight of Icarus," as the symphonic poem "Icare," the version Mr. Botstein will conduct. It was his last creative act; only arrangements -- Bach, Mussorgsky and Johann Strauss, of all unlikely trios -- lay ahead.) The ballet was planned in collaboration with the dancer and choreographer Serge Lifar, the other significant young man of Diaghilev's last years.
LIFAR, who in his autobiography claimed credit for the idea and for commissioning the ballet as a memorial to Diaghilev, pulled out, calling Markevitch's music "anti-danceable." (Since he also said that of Stravinsky's music, the remark only shows why as a choreographer Lifar was only Lifar.) Nevertheless, its rhythmic momentum is irresistibly corporeal; for once the ostinatos and the polyrhythms conspire to produce exaltation and, yes, "elevation."
Ultramodernistic touches abound: quarter-tone harmonies (removed in the revision, after they had caused the BBC to reject Markevitch's own early recording as unsuitable for broadcast due to poor intonation); toneless blowing into the brass instruments when the slain Icarus's wings are discovered, a marvelous symbol of deflation and mute grief; measured accelerandos and ritardandos, anticipating Elliott Carter by 15 years, in the section where the singing birds (anticipating Messaien) teach little Icarus to fly. But they are un-self-consciously evocative, never mere stylistic effrontery.
Finally, there is the strangely moving ritual dance, set to imitation gamelan music, to mourn the hero's death. This score has magic. The poetic justice of its influence on Stravinsky's "Orpheus" (1948) is satisfying.
Unfortunately, like the rest of the orchestral music recorded by Marco Polo, it receives a somewhat shaky, tentatively paced and haphazardly balanced performance from Mr. Lyndon-Gee and his orchestra. It is possible that one reason I have been left relatively unimpressed by Markevitch's polyrhythms is that I have not heard them performed with the requisite independence of parts. Big triplets, in particular, are reduced to rhumba rhythms in a manner that anyone who has rehearsed such a passage will instantly recognize. It's a hard task for any orchestra and for the conductor who has to teach the players how to "group" and "subdivide" their count against the general beat. I wish Mr. Botstein luck.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Riverhead Considers 2 Offers on 2,900-Acre Site

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: CALVERTON

 BODY:
JUST over two years ago Northrop Grumman closed its operations at the 2,900-acre Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant here, laying off or transferring the last of 3,000 workers and leaving behind 1.1 million square feet of industrial and office space and two runways.
Grumman and its successor, Northrop Grumman, , had been leasing the property from the Navy and assembling and testing military aircraft in this rural corner of the Town of Riverhead for 42 years. 
 In 1994, Congress authorized the Navy to turn the property over to Riverhead's Community Development Agency at no cost after the military contractor's departure.
A 3,000-acre buffer zone, also owned by the Navy, will be turned over the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.
Now that the transfer to the town appears imminent -- town officials estimate it could take place in as little as 60 days -- Riverhead has two bidders vying for the property.
One is First Industrial Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago, which offered $17 million for the 550 acres containing the industrial and office buildings, a 10,000-foot-long runway and development potential for buildings with an additional 2 million square feet of space.
In a letter of intent signed March 17, the town agreed to temporarily withdraw the 550 acres from the market, and First Industrial was given 120 days to evaluate and assess the land and buildings. A $500,000 earnest money deposit would be payable upon the signing of a contract, with the balance of the $17 million due at closing.
The second suitor is Mentmore Development, of San Francisco, a subsidiary of the privately held Mentmore Holdings Corporation of New York City. Mentmore's offer, presented to the town on March 20, is to purchase the entire 2,900 acres for $35 million in cash, with the town receiving a 25 percent share of future profits. William D. Talmage a local real estate consultant, is a partner with Mentmore in the offer.
Mentmore has offered to pay $20 million at closing, with the $15 million balance to be paid out as the various components of its $1.1-billion proposed project are developed. The construction schedule would be by mutual agreement. The town as a limited partner could receive, under Mentmore's estimates, more than $375 million in additional revenue over 20 years.
Many other candidates have expressed interest in leasing or buying the property, said Andrea H. Lohneiss, the director of Riverhead's Community Development Agency. Several prior offers have been rejected, she said. The town's goal, Ms. Lohneiss said, has been "from day one the creation of quality jobs and a tax base to support this community."
"Also," she said, "this has never been perceived to be a Town of Riverhead project, but a regional project with regional impact and benefits. In our evaluation of all proposals, those factors are paramount."
Jack O'Connor, the president of Grubb & Ellis/Island Realty of Melville, the brokerage handling the marketing of the site for the town, said he favored the First Industrial offer because "if you parcel out the properties you maximize the dollars."
He noted that the town could realize $55 million to $70 million if it sold parcels individually. And because the economy is so strong, he said, "we have the confidence that we can move two-thirds to three-quarters of the property in a year's time."
Rents for the available buildings have been set at $4.50 annually per square foot for industrial space, and $11 per square foot for office space, with tenants paying for their own electricity in both cases. Vacant land is for sale for $20,000 to $35,000 an acre depending on the amount of acreage purchased, the zoning and the location.
A portion of the property has been proposed for inclusion in New York State's Economic Development Zone program under which businesses that make physical improvements and/or create jobs receive state tax credits and other benefits. A maximum of 1,280 acres could be set aside for the zone under state legislation.
T HE Calverton property is so unusual that real estate experts say any appraisal of value is difficult.
Northrop Grumman left the buildings in pristine condition. One is the 300,000-square-foot Building 6-01, formerly the main operations building. It now houses the remains of TWA Flight 800, the airliner that exploded over the Atlantic off Long Island in July 1996, with no survivors.
The structure has been leased by the National Transportation Safety Board on a year-to-year lease with options to extend the lease for 51 years or until its investigations are completed. The lease would be transferred to the new owner.
The other main structures include a two-story, 73,400-square-foot office building; the 191,000-square-foot former final assembly building, known as Building 7, which houses four hangars, the airport control tower and about 35,000 square feet of office space and a 110,000-square-foot building with 33,000 square feet of offices and two hangars.
In addition to the 10,000-foot runway on the property First Industrial is bidding for there is one measuring 7,000 feet and a railroad spur. The balance of the property is woods and flat open area.
Except for a manned guardhouse at the entrance, the site is eerily empty, although it looks as if it could jump back to life any moment. With people gone, herds of deer graze placidly next to the buildings, and Canada geese roost next to the roadways. But the runways are well-maintained. In the control tower, phones and monitors are at the ready.
A re-use strategy prepared for the town two years ago by Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler of Manhattan, a real estate and economic development consulting firm, suggested turning the existing buildings into an industrial park and keeping at least the larger of the runways in operation for the industrial tenants.
For the remaining 2,350 vacant acres the report suggested a hotel-conference center, a golf course, a sports complex, a theme park and other tourist attractions. The plan projected 2,200 new jobs within five years and 6,400 jobs within 20 years.
First Industrial would not comment on its proposed plans, saying only through Steve Solomon, a public relations spokesman, that "we are still a long way off from consummating a deal." The company, formed in 1994, owns almost 57 million square feet of industrial space in 24 major markets around the country.
Mentmore Holdings Corporation owns steel, life insurance, plastics, entertainment and aerospace companies among others. It also is a major developer, having built more than 20 million square feet valued at $3 billion in various projects around the country, several of them under the public-private partnership arrangement it is proposing to enter into in Riverhead.
Its projects, which usually combine office, retail, residential and occasionally hotel development under one roof, include the 1.2 million-square-foot Market Square at Pennsylvania Avenue and Seventh Street in Washington, D.C. The company also has another project there, the 3 million-square-foot The Portals, under construction at the 14th Street Bridge across the Potomac River.
In Riverhead, its proposed project would create 10,500 jobs, said Robert H. Mendelsohn, the chief executive of Mentmore Development.
The components would include the re-use of the existing buildings and new construction for an industrial park designed to attract high-technology tenants offering the high-paying jobs lost when Northrop Grumman left, he said. The park would include a job-training center. Another element would be a showcase for new technology that would combine the entertainment of a traditional theme park with technology exhibits and demonstrations.
In addition, a resort hotel and conference center would include golf, horseback riding and skeet shooting among its recreational facilities. And a family-oriented hotel featuring an indoor swimming complex among other climate-controlled recreational activities would offer year-round moderately priced short-term stays.
There would also be a retail and entertainment center with shops, restaurants and a 16- to 20-screen movie theater. And Mentmore is also proposing to build a retirement community with on-site health services and recreational facilities.
"We have proposed a master development program with a master developer, where the various elements are integrated and each one is interdependent with another," Mr. Mendelsohn said. "We think it would be a tragic, missed opportunity for the town to allow the Grumman site to be developed in a piecemeal way."
Ms. Lohneiss, the Community Development Agency director, said that the town would prefer "not to be in a partnership situation under which we would have to audit the books over a long period of time." And Mentmore is free to make an offer on the acreage First Industrial doesn't want, if that deal goes through, she said.
And should that happen, would Mentmore be interested in the balance of the site? "No comment," Mr. Mendelsohn said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
As Office Squeeze Tightens, Builders Grab Trowels

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE signs are clear -- dirt being moved here, steel going up there -- that after two good years of job growth, declining vacancy rates and rising rents, 1998 is shaping up to be a year of development and redevelopment in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market.
"The market is getting down to a very, very short supply of space," said Donald P. Eisen, executive managing director of the New York area for Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage. So landlords are seeing "now as their turn, and are building," he added. 
 In a market where real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, seem to have an insatiable appetite to buy properties to continue their growth "national and local developers are also looking to create product to sell to them," added Robert J. Rudin, executive director of the Saddle Brook office of the Insignia/ESG brokerage.
He also said that as REIT's continue to compete for a thinning supply of properties "the prices some are paying are approaching, and in some cases exceeding, the $150 to $180 a square foot cost of building a new building."
But buy they did. The amount of properties investors purchased in 1997, some of which closed in the first quarter of this year, reached $2.1 billion, up from $934 million in 1996, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Leading the way was Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, of Cranford, among the nation's largest REIT's, which purchased 1.3 million square feet of office space this year. Its purchases included the Prudential Business campus straddling Parsippany and Hanover, which has five existing buildings with a total of 860,000 square feet of office space and space for an additional 1.3 million more square feet.
With most of the major properties spoken for, some REIT's may also enter the development arena this year, brokers and analysts said. All told, there are more than 4.5 million square feet of office space currently under construction in the 11-county northern and central sections of the state, according to the West Orange office of Grubb & Ellis, another national brokerage.
In areas where the space squeeze is the tightest some builders have taken or will soon take the plunge into developing space on speculation -- without a signed lease from a single tenant in hand.
Among the largest such projects are a 350,000-square-foot two-building complex now under development in Parsippany by SJP Properties, a local development company, and the 285,000-square-foot structure being built along Interstate 78 in Berkeley Heights by Connell Realty & Development Company of Westfield. And Gale & Wentworth of Florham Park is developing the last of four buildings in its Park Avenue at Morris County complex in Florham Park. It will have 175,000 square feet.
Existing buildings are being or will be reshaped on speculation into modern offices. They include a 180,000-square-foot former silver plating plant in Clifton that is being converted by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville L.I, another REIT. Reckson is also planning to renovate a 128,000-square-foot building two miles away in Nutley. And Wellsford Property Trust of Chatham is renovating and expanding the old Estee candy warehouse in Parsippany into a 250,000-square-foot office structure.
The Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City may get two new buildings this year -- the first in nearly a decade. There, the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, is putting up its own money for a 561,000-square-foot building scheduled for a groundbreaking on Thursday in its 600-acre Newport mixed-used complex. In addition, Samuel LeFrak, the company chairman, said there were plans for a second office building, of 450,000 square feet.And in June Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus will start driving piles for a 419,000-square-foot riverfront tower about a mile south on part of the 20-acre Colgate Palmolive Center site in Jersey City, once occupied by a toothpaste factory.
Other builders have development sites ready to go and will build to a specific tenant's need. One case in point is the Rockefeller Group, which is constructing a 175,000-square-foot building for AT&T in Florham Park. Still others will build only after a tenant signs on for a sizable amount of space, which is needed to obtain construction financing from lenders. For unlike the halcyon days of the 80's, lenders "are still lukewarm when it comes to speculative development" and therefore require an equity cushion from developers, said Douglas H. Haynes, president of Alexander Summer, a real estate concern based in Paramus. As a result, there "will not be a whole crop of new buildings," he said.
AND that, in a way, reflects the two sides of the 1998 office market in which caution and optimism seem to be running on parallel courses. "The market is good and there is confidence, but we don't have the unbridled optimism of the 80's," said Mr. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield, "and that will mitigate against excess building."
Other factors will also help keep the lid on new construction. In the first quarter of this year the state gained 20,000 new jobs, indicating that it will match the same level of growth achieved in 1997 when 87,000 new jobs were added, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. He added that 1997 had been the best year since 1984, when 150,000 new jobs were created.
While this growth pattern will continue to yield the lowest unemployment rates of the 90's, Dr. Hughes said it also "presents a potential speed bump in the highway of the future -- the lack of available labor." It is an issue that has come to the forefront in the last six months, he added, noting that "it becomes a natural inhibitor" to overbuilding. Dr. Hughes stopped short of talking about a recession in a state that is entering its 72d month of recovery. "It is an amazing economic run we are going through," he said, "and while there is always the possibility of some economic shock, the downside potential is not likely for '98."
Most industry executives added that while demand may level off from its feverish pitch the market will stay on a relatively even course through this year. But some are not so sure about what will happen in 1999 and beyond if more developers -- REIT's as well as pension funds -- jump on the building bandwagon.
"Everything comes in waves and my concern is that the market not get carried away with its success," said Andrew J. Merin, executive director of the financial services group at Cushman & Wakefield. "Those with buildings in the ground this year have a good shot, but it takes 18 to 24 months to finish an office building and one has to figure that at some point from now until the year 2001 there will be a downturn in the economy." While Wall Street "can turn on a dime, our business can't," he added.
In the short term, however, the state's job growth has translated into a need for space in a market where steady leasing has chipped away at much of the excess inventory left over from the recession. "Tenants looking for 100,000 square feet of prime space have only 10 alternatives and there are serious negotiations on half of them," said David Simson, senior vice president at the Teaneck office of CB Commercial.
The lack of premium space led to increased demand for secondary properties, which accounted for 56 percent of the overall leasing activity in the first quarter of this year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. In turn, the first-quarter vacancy rate for the overall market dropped three percentage points from the same time last year to 12.4 percent, the lowest level since the brokerage began keeping records in the 1970's.
The rate for Class A space fell to 7.2 percent from 10 percent during that same period. At the same time, average asking rents rose to $20.19 from $19.66 for all space and to $25.35 from $23.79 for prime space.
Most of the demand came from expanding companies, not new arrivals, and big deals were missing, reflecting the dwindling supply of large blocks of space in all categories. Among the space takers was the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which leased all 164,000 square feet at 2 Montgomery Street in Jersey City, a building undergoing a complete renovation to modern office space. Additionally, Philips Consumer Communications, a new entity that is a joint venture of Philips Electronics and Lucent Technologies, leased 73,000 square feet at the former K-LineShipping headquarters off I-78 in Murray Hill.
Mr. Rudin of Insignia/ESG said that there would be a temporary oversupply of space in the first half of the year. But then the "market will catch its breath before it moves forward and sort itself out in the second half," he said.

HEADLINE: Q&A: William Flynn;
Guiding the Knights of Malta in Charity

BYLINE: By LINDA TAGLIAFERRO 

 BODY:
THE Sovereign Military Order of the Knights of Malta traces its origins to the time of the Crusades. This Roman Catholic charitable organization is currently dedicated to the relief of poverty and sickness around the world.
William Flynn of Garden City has been the president of the American association of the order for two years. He is the former chief executive officer and present chairman of the board for the Mutual of America Insurance Company in Manhattan. 
In the past, he has served as chairman for the Advisory Committee to the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, the Ireland Chamber of Commerce and the New York Foundling Hospital, among others. He is a member of the board of the Elie Wiesel Foundation for Humanity and the Ireland-America Economic Advisory Board and many other organizations.
He also played a part in the recent peace talks in Northern Ireland. The chairman of the National Committee on Foreign Policy, Mr. Flynn was instrumental in bringing the Sinn Fein leader Jerry Adams to the United States.
The son of Irish immigrants, Mr. Flynn was born in Manhattan. He is the father of four children and e has lived in Garden City for more than 25 years with his wife, Peg.
Q. How did you become involved with the Knights of Malta?
A. I was involved in various and sundry organizations such as the New York Foundling Hospital and others. About 30 years ago, someone suggested I apply for membership in the Knights. You've got to have the approval of your bishop when you apply, and I passed the tests.
At the time, the organization was under the leadership of Peter Grace. He was the first to open the organization to women. A lot of good was being done at the time, but few people knew about it. There were no newsletters sent out and the members weren't called to be part of these projects. Perhaps it took too much initiative on the part of the members to become involved in these.
Q. How does the American branch of the order fit into the international organization?
A. I'm the president of the American Association of the Sovereign Military Order of the Knights of Malta. With 1,800 members, we're the largest group within the Order of Malta in the world. There are two other orders in the United States. The Federal operates out of Washington and the Western is based in San Francisco. They're smaller, but they're very effective.
I think there is a feeling that the American association hasn't realized its full potential. There's much more that can be done, and we're striving to perfect our ability to be more effective in taking on our mission, which is to help the sick and the poor and to defend the faith.
Q. When you say that part of the Knights' mission is "to defend the faith," what do you mean?
A. I'll give you an example. There are many organizations in the country that are fighting the battle against abortion. Partial birth abortion is one extreme version of this. There are government people who have been unable to do away with this, and that has distressed us. It distresses me.
So the Knights have helped in that fight. We call that a defense of faith because we believe that partial birth abortion is infanticide. Since we believe that, we have to put our energies where our thinking is.
We raised a quarter of a million dollars to help the bishops fight that battle, but there are some members who think that we shouldn't be in that battle. There are those who say that the money would be better spent helping the sick and the poor, so there's a theoretical battle between these two missions.
The great truth is, that no matter what our activities, very few people are aware of what the organization is doing.
Q. Why isn't the organization more well known?
A. It's the best kept secret because part of the philosophy of many people is the idea that what is done should be done privately and quietly. Unfortunately, in today's world, if that's how you operate, the perception is that you're doing nothing.
There are those who think that we shouldn't be communicating what we're doing because it's gauche. I believe quite the contrary, that we have to publicize what we're doing. How else can we get the public and our membership to support what we stand for?
If even some of our members don't know what we stand for, then we haven't got a prayer of effectively accomplishing our mission. I look at that as my charge, and there are those who feel quite strongly that this is an error and that I'm leading them in the wrong direction as a result.
Q. What are some of the establishments that have been founded by the Knights in the United States?
A. In Haiti, which is probably one of the poorest countries in the world, there's a Malta installation that was started by people in St. Louis. They have a very strong contingent of Malta, very small in number, but very effective, who felt that they had an obligation to help, so they started a small hospital out there.
It's only 30 beds, but there is nothing else there, and it takes care of an incredibly large number of people. There are volunteer doctors like Dr. Carlos Reese and others. They do surgical procedures and deliver babies. Without them there would be no help for the people there.
In the Dominican Republic, there's a clinic where we work together with the Dominican Association of Malta. There's also a clinic in Honduras that was started by a couple in New Jersey, which has a very effective chapter.
Within the United States, in various areas, work has been done. In St. Louis, there's a facility that looks after recovering drug addicts.
I feel we're not doing enough because we have a very limited budget. It's been a tradition that we don't go out raising funds, so we operate off our dues. We have to challenge that tradition. Why shouldn't we raise funds? Our budget is less than $2 million a year.
Q. Are there any Malta facilities on Long Island?
A. We have an area chairman in Long Island who is just getting under way. His name is Carl Schwartz. He's a man of great initiative and great strength. He's put together a facility for pregnant women who want to keep their children but don't have husbands or anywhere else to turn. It's called Malta House and it's in Brentwood. It's another well-kept secret.
Q. On the international level, do the Knights have more financial resources available and a chance to be more widespread?
A. Yes. Internationally, the Order of Malta accounts for over 200 hospitals around the world. In Ireland, for example, they run an ambulance service.
I feel that with our 1,800 members here, if we can be better organized, we're capable of doing much more here than what we have done in the past.
Q. You said that you are trying to be more inclusive of ethnic groups. Can you explain?
A. This was an order that originally was restricted throughout most of its history and in Europe is still restricted to the nobility. In America, they ran into a problem. There may be noble people, but there is no such thing as nobility here.
So now, our preference is for people who have contributed to education or religion or the world of science. That's the American nobility, really.
In the next century, half of us are going to be of Hispanic backgrounds. We should have more members of that background to reflect this. I would also like to see members of black and Asian origins. We have to promote the idea of including these people.
The Knights of Malta will profit, just as America has profited, from diversity. That makes for great strength, and unless we do that, we'll become a feeble, old organization.
Q. Some members of the Knights have asked you to resign, but you have the backing of Cardinal O'Connor. Can you explain?
A. There are some members who feel differently about the direction in which I'm taking the organization. I stand for change. There are those who stand for the status quo or who stand for change, but in a different direction, and that's perfectly legitimate. But some opponents feel very strongly about it and feel that the only way they can accomplish what they believe is the right course is for the entire board to resign and for me to resign.
Cardinal O'Connor is a member of the board, and the board supports me. The Cardinal does not care to be partisan, and he has offered to be a bridge for those who feel strongly one way. I'm quite certain that he will succeed and that we will succeed.
Q. What would you like to see happen with the organization in the future?
A. I want to see us be much more effective in helping the sick and the poor across the country. Remember, we can only do so much, so what is being done successfully in one place such as in New Jersey or here in Long Island, we must do right across the country. We must marshal our members to get up and become a part of getting the mission accomplished.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Flynn of the Knights of Malta in his Manhattan office. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Main Street, The Movers Behind A New Look

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
EAST HARTFORD, tucked away across the Connecticut River from its parent city and namesake, has always had something of an identity problem.
From its days as a farming community and river town to its more recent role as a highway nexus and home to aircraft-engine manufacturer Pratt & Whitney, the city was never much of a stopping point for people who didn't live there. 
 "The way I put it was, I wanted East Hartford to be a place to go to rather than a place to go through," said Bob DeCrescenzo, the city's mayor from 1993 to 1997.
The problem, as Mr. DeCrescenzo and others readily admit, was that East Hartford wasn't even much of a place to go through.
Pratt & Whitney was diminishing its presence drastically and the city faced double-digit unemployment. The storefronts along Main Street were dingy and often vacant, and crime was becoming an overriding concern.
"We were dying," said Raymond E. Tubbs, an art dealer and 28-year East Hartford resident.
Skip forward a few years to the present: The storefronts are being spiffed up and their interiors refurbished, unemployment is down to under 6 percent, and community spirit is high. The four-and-a-half-acre parcel on Main Street that for years was an abandoned supermarket site has been transformed into a town green that is host to annual music festivals as well as young mothers who take their toddlers to the playground there.
The improved state economy is one reason for the turnaround, as are efforts by business and civic organizations.
But one other factor is also cited by residents: East Hartford's membership in the Connecticut Main Street Program, a downtown renovation project sponsored by Connecticut Light and Power.
Lisa Bumbera, an employee of the utility company who coordinates the Main Street program in the state, describes it as tough love. Rather than sending grant money to participating municipalities, the Connecticut Main Street Program forces them to organize and figure out the financing of their projects.
"It's not a grant program," she said. "It's roll up your sleeves. You're going to do the work. We'll provide access to consultants, technical assistance, provide knowledge from other parts of the country on what's worked elsewhere."
Forty-three states have Main Street programs, but Ms. Bumbera said Connecticut is the only one where the program is entirely supported by a private business. The Main Street approach encourages communities to develop their own businesses, foster cooperation between local groups and preserve older buildings that give each downtown a particular character.
The Connecticut Main Street program began in 1995 with four communities, including East Hartford. Two years later three more municipalities joined in. They range from commerce centers to bedroom communities.
All have one thing in common: a desire to revitalize their downtowns.
"Main Street is a process," said Jerry Lintner, director of the Simsbury Main Street Partnership Inc. "There is a pattern that works."
Simsbury, like East Hartford, enrolled in the program in 1995; the two have been Connecticut Main Street's biggest successes. It's hard to imagine two more different communities: East Hartford, proudly blue-collar; Simsbury, affluent and suburban. Yet both saw hard times in the early 1990's.
"We had an eroding middle class," Mr. Lintner said. "Simsbury was very affected by unemployment. The answer for a lot of people was to relocate. It became too expensive to live here."
Reinvigorating a downtown area more than a square mile in size was seen as the answer a year before Simsbury joined Connecticut Main Street. Once joined up, the town was provided with structure and advice.
Another of the original four, New London, is the most likely participant in a downtown renewal project, as it is the business center of southeastern Connecticut. Its Main Street program, though, is a step behind East Hartford and Simsbury; it is still trying to organize itself and find an executive director.
James Mallove, chairman of a steering committee for the New London program, said Main Street in the past "was never able to involve the community."
"Part of the problem was there wasn't as much cooperation between city groups like the City Center Tax District, the neighborhood alliance, and church organizations," Mr. Mallove said. "New London has always been a kind of fractionalized city."
Creating cooperation is a major part of Main Street programming, its administrators say. Committees are formed to court opinion from landlords, tenants, home owners and others while adding muscle to common goals.
Not every town that has joined Main Street has been successful: Torrington, also one of the first four, pulled out after failing to find a director.
"A program manager is like the conductor," Ms. Bumbera said. "They're going to keep the various committees of Main Street going, hopefully in the same direction in conjunction with the board. Unless they have that cooperation, it's not going to work."
Even today, in better times, no one would ever confuse East Hartford with Litchfield County. Yet its Main Street has a certain undeniable visual quality, much of it in the form of a streetscape that looks plucked right out of the past.
In 1817, James Monroe reportedly called East Hartford the most beautiful Main Street in America. Back then, it was a fairly sleepy, pastoral town, its Main Street lined with Colonial-era mansions and shady trees.
The road grew busier with the passage of time, and the construction of highways like Interstate 91 and Interstate 84 sliced huge portions out of the city's flat landscape. With the emergence of the military industry during and after World War II, multifamily housing and postwar prosperity arrived. Its residents tended to be working-class immigrants trying to make a new life for themselves and their families.
"East Hartford is a big-shouldered city," said Main Street coordinator Tana Meier Parseliti. "People here are plain-spoken about things."
Then came the 1980's, and with them the beginning of the end for Connecticut's prosperous military industry. Pratt & Whitney's East Hartford work force was gradually winnowed from a high of 20,000 in the late 70's to 7,500 last year. Other businesses, particularly stores, fled.
Main Street was left with some attractive but quiet buildings, like Governor's Corners, built a century ago in Spanish Colonial Revival style. There was the Sage-Allen Building, a block-wide Art Deco edifice from the 1930's vacated by its original chain-store tenant after 50 years and left empty.
Then there was the Comstock Building, a one-time theater built in 1899 and a source of special pride to residents even as parts of it moldered quietly away.
"Every town in Connecticut had a building like this at one time, but very few are still standing," Mr. Tubbs said of the Comstock Building. "It has a Main Street look, a strong architectural presence."
After taking office, Mayor DeCrescenzo had the city buy the Comstock Building, renovate its exterior and light it up at night, a move described as symbolic of his commitment to a better future by pointing to the city's rich past. Now the building is being privately developed.
How much of this is due to Connecticut Main Street is an open question. Mary Beth Reid, executive director of the East Hartford Chamber of Commerce, noted that things like the Comstock rehabilitation and the creation of the town park were "not really connected" to the city's Main Street Plus campaign.
But Mr. DeCrescenzo called the Main Street program "a natural fit."
"Connecticut Main Street should be funded and run by the state government," he said. "Thank goodness C.L.&P. is willing to do it. They audit us and help us move forward. You can't let inertia set in. You've got to keep current, and have a sense of urgency."
Ms. Bumbera said East Hartford has seen the most success of any community taking part in Main Street, with $2.5 million in new investment and 50 new jobs. Those might not seem large numbers, but "We have to take baby steps before we can walk and run," she said. "For every new business that moves in, eyes are watching and people are looking. Investment shows confidence."
For East Hartford natives, the visible changes are small but profound. Three major development projects are being reviewed or supported by Main Street Plus, including one to renovate the Old Town Hall.
A new restaurant has just opened a block away from the downtown headquarters of Main Street Plus, which means you don't have to take a prospective business tenant to Hartford for a nice meal.
Mike Cardello grew up in East Hartford before moving out to make a living on the West Coast. Now he is back working on the interior of the city's first coffee bar and intends to stay awhile. "I see a big turnaround for the good," he said, "I think the visual change here is quite impressive."
One major problem still dogs the city. Main Street is an emergency alternative to Interstate 91 and a major traffic corridor between highways. Despite such volume, retail businesses don't thrive along a downtown where shoppers must cross the street with caution.
Bob Fortier, a town council representative and building supervisor, said he sees an average of 20 U-turns every morning and 30 every afternoon.
"Traffic is a major problem, and the speed of it," Mrs. Reid said. "You look at the big traffic count as a retail person, and you think you'd move there. But the traffic moves so fast it's dangerous."
Main Street Plus leaders say they are working to help devise a solution to this problem. In the meantime, three new municipalities have joined the state program in the past year: Middletown, Windsor and Coventry.
Coventry represents a new sort of challenge for Main Street. It regards itself not as a city or town but as a village. Its downtown is dominated by a lake and mills that date to the Industrial Revolution. The Coventry Main Street manager, Mary Lou Sullivan, says the village doesn't want new retail business so much as it wants innovative uses for the mills and a lower tax burden on residents.
"We could use a hardware store, a delicatessen, another restaurant," she said. "But most people want Coventry to stay rural."
If Main Street is about anything, Ms. Bumbera said, it is about making communities understand just how large a role they can play in their own development.
"People aren't aware of the leverage they can have, and developers take advantage of that," she said. "We need things like malls. But we need to understand why a downtown is important.
"We already have a core here. Rather than enlarge the infrastructure, which costs money to the towns and the utilities, let's build on what we have."

HEADLINE: Providing Trained Liaisons in Health Care

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
"WE HAVE all had personal experiences with doctors, hospitals, clinics and the like, and as more and more of us find ourselves in managed-care plans, it has become increasingly difficult to navigate the health care delivery minefield," said Joan Marks, director and founder of a graduate program in health advocacy at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. "We all could use a friend at court."
The program, the only one of its kind in the country, was founded in 1980 by Ms. Marks, a psychiatric social worker. 
 "I realized the need for trained health advocates back in 1969 when I was working as a geriatric counselor," Ms. Marks said. "Patients needed someone to act as a liaison between them and health care providers. In one scenario, 51 different specialists saw the same patient and neither she nor her family spoke English. Clearly, there were difficulties. What they needed was an ombudsman, but when our program began, the term 'health advocate' was barely understood."
Sarah Lawrence College, a small private institution with a focus on the humanities, provided the broad educational base needed for the expanding roles of the health advocate, Ms. Marks said. "The college recognized the growing need for professionals to represent the consumer in health care issues," she said. "And today, consumers need professionals more than ever to help them get through the health care maze that changes in managed health care have brought about. Consumers are beginning to have serious questions about the intentions and integrity of everyone involved in health care."
The Health Advocacy Program, she said, offers an unusual approach to the study of health care. "Unlike other advanced-degree programs, the focus is on health care from the perspective of the patient-consumer," Ms. Marks said. "Graduates of the program work in diverse positions such as patient representatives and administrators, on ethics committees and medical policy boards at hospitals and health agencies. Health advocacy draws on concepts from medicine, law, economics, social work and health care administration."
At a recent open house, potential students from a variety of backgrounds were represented. What they had in common, Ms. Marks said, was a desire to enter a profession "where they could make a difference."
She added: "The first health advocates were nurses and social workers because they knew the system. But now students come from many occupations across the board in such fields as economics, law or photography. "
The need for professional advocates is being fueled by national and state debates over managed care and consumer rights. In New York, a bill calling for a state ombudsman program, which would include a network of community-based agencies to provide direct help to all health care consumers, is under consideration.
"The opportunities for careers in health advocacy are growing accordingly," Ms. Marks said.
"Our graduates can expect to find a wide variety of jobs. Some will become patient representatives, hospital administrators, health educators and consultants to community groups. Others will staff health agencies, serve on ethics committees and medical policy boards, while others may find work sorting out inequities in the insurance industry."
Salaries range from $45,000 to $100,000 for someone heading a department dealing with major moral and physical issues, Ms. Marks said.
"The bottom line is that advocates play a vital role in health care today," she said. "They give objective advice from the smallest question posed by patients to the largest. They are in contact with the family. They can be found at a patient's bedside explaining a medical procedure or before a senator's desk, discussing legislation. And they have the ability to interact with doctors, administrators and community agencies alike."
As students they are exemplary, said Dr. Marsha Hurst, who teaches two of the program's courses. "They are mature, highly motivated adults who have made an unusual choice to go into the field of health care advocacy in its early stages," she said. "And many have made sacrifices in order to be in the program. This is a professional discipline that attracts people who are not only smart and looking for new career opportunities but also those who are interested in helping others and making a difference. They are wonderful to teach."
The importance of a master's degree as a health advocate, Dr. Hurst said, is demonstrated by the success of the program's graduates. There are patient representatives' programs at major teaching hospitals, including the Hospital for Special Surgery, Mount Sinai Medical Center, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Westchester Medical Center. The programs have employed Sarah Lawrence graduates, who also serve in advocacy roles in groups like the San Francisco Health Plan and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
"From the very beginning, when consumerism was just beginning to be an issue, major hospitals were impressed with the advocacy concept," Ms. Marks said. "A compelling reason is economic. Having an impartial patient advocate on the staff enables a hospital to operate more effectively, which translates into cost saving."
Citing one hospital, Ms. Marks said: "They were experiencing an inordinate number of complaints about their pediatric department. The advocate went into the pediatric clinic to see what was going on and to try to solve the problem. What was discovered was that the clinic scheduling was unacceptable to parents. They were complaining because they were not permitted to stay overnight with their very ill children. When the advocate brought the problem to the attention of the hospital administrators, the scheduling was changed, and complaints dropped off."
In another, more harrowing incident, Ms. Marks said: "This hospital was responsible for the death of an infant. The ombudsman suggested that the hospital tell the parents the truth and admit the blame. Because the hospital treated them honestly, the parents never filed a malpractice suit against the hospital."
Ombudsmen perform such an important job in hospitals that 3,000 annual requests for their help from the medical staff -- as was the case tracked by one metropolitan hospital -- is not considered unusual, Ms. Marks said. "They are skilled listeners, communicators who are objective, empathetic and smart," she said. "And most important of all, they are trained for the job, with the best will in the world. Do-gooders who mean well can do more damage than good."
Representative Sue W. Kelly, Republican of Katonah, is a graduate of the program. So is Janice Levy, now patient representative director, department associate hospital administrator at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. "In the health advocacy program, the advocacy role is defined and developed in a way that enables graduates to work creatively and effectively in a multitude of settings," Ms. Levy said.
Hope Ryan, who worked as a photo editor at Gannett Newspapers in White Plains for 18 years, is now health information specialist at the March of Dimes national headquarters in White Plains.
"This is a second career for me," Ms. Ryan said. "I was always interested in health care, and when a friend told me about the program, I checked it out. I have always wanted a job in which I could really help people and now, as an advocate for the children and parents across the nation, involved with more than 5,000 birth defects and genetic diseases, I provide information and referrals to the proper source in the country where they can get help. I love my job. At the end of the day I feel I've really done something and made a difference in people's lives."

HEADLINE: The Task Of Filling School Jobs

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
WHILE school enrollment soars -- leading to more advertisements for teachers -- vacancies are also appearing at administrative levels. Searches for high school principals are under way in Ardsley, Chappaqua and Pelham, and superintendents are needed in Irvington, Hendrik Hudson, Scarsdale, Mount Vernon, Tuckahoe and Yonkers.
Dudley Hare Jr.'s recent announcement that he would resign as Superintendent of the Yorktown-based Putnam-Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services as of Oct. 15 underscores only the latest vacancy in what many educators see as a growing leadership crisis. 
 "There's no question that for administrative positions it's becoming more difficult to find people," said Dr. Donald R. Kusel, Superintendent of the Tarrytowns public schools. "Aside from the dollars and cents, there's huge stress and huge pressures for anyone in a public position today. A lot of people argue about how the standards are being raised. The superintendent becomes the focal point for things that don't go well in the schools."
Having so many openings in the county has become a matter of concern. As the future of education gains attention on the national and state agendas, fewer people seem willing to assume leadership roles. Some attribute the shortage of candidates to the narrow salary gap between experienced teachers and beginning administrators, while others believe the pressure put on superintendents and principals, especially in high school, is the major deterrent.
"It's a problem," said Dr. Charles T. Wilson, Superintendent of the Pelham school district. "The pay differential with respect to the top paid teachers in comparison with principals has caused a lot of people to think twice. The workload and pressures for principals are so intense. There are higher expectations from parents and students, along with the push for higher standards, the state report cards and new assessments. And the general public is far more vocal and assertive. No wonder that would-be principals see themselves in the crossfire."
As a result, Dr. Wilson, whose district is looking at finalists for high school principal, said "we're finding that the scope and range of choice is narrower than we'd like to have it."
"We're not seeing the same volume of applicants," she said. "We're seeing good people, but we had to be very aggressive in soliciting people."
For Jackie Roy, president of J. A. Roy & Associates in Cambridge, Mass., which is conducting the search for an Irvington superintendent, the situation in the county mirrors national trends.
"A lot of people prefer staying in the assistant superintendent role as the superintendent's job has changed and become a political lightning rod," Ms. Roy said. "We have to do a lot of active, vigorous recruiting to reach out to people and really persuade them that it's a wonderful opportunity. We still get high-quality candidates for high-quality districts, but we are getting fewer candidates. It's down by half from 10 or 12 years ago, when we might see 85 to 100 candidates. Now it's 35 to 50 candidates."
Some people seem to feel that finding good leaders requires a shift to a more corporate outlook, especially regarding compensation.
"This is now a very accountable business, with the public demanding that districts run cost effectively," Dr. Wilson said. "The salaries and compensation package have to reflect that economic reality check. The reality is that you're losing people. Historically, people who became district superintendents were those who wanted regional responsibility, and often there was considerably more compensation. Now to do all those things, regional leaders will have to take pay cuts in some cases."
At issue in the resignation at the Board of Cooperative Educational Services is a combination of economic pressure and other factors. As Superintendent, Dr. Hare is paid $128,625, the limit imposed by the State Legislature in 1993 after a Suffolk County superintendent retired with a compensation package of nearly $1 million. Under a 1997 law, Dr. Hare's compensation would actually decrease by about $7,000 when his contract came up for renewal in the fall.
"This impacts the rate for a pension basis," said Dr. Hare, who has been on the job since 1995. "I took the job with an awareness and acceptance of the cap placed on the Boces' superintendent's salary. But as I approach my retirement years, the compensation decrease makes the decision to stay here difficult. The other part of it is that the Commissioner of Education has an aggressive reform agenda that I agree with and support. Within the strategy of a reform agenda, the Boces district superintendent has to implement it. The state role has significantly increased, and it's more difficult to be a hands-on superintendent."
