HEADLINE: Women at Helm Set A Course To the Top

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
ONE built an empire from her kitchen table, another turned her back on a Fortune 500 employer and struck out on her own and the third was determined to fly solo even though she was married to the boss. These three entrepreneurs from Westchester are on Working Woman magazine's first list of the largest 500 female-owned businesses in the United States, published in the May issue.
Although each of the three pursues a separate dream, they share much in common -- in particular their penchant for taking risks, a tenaciousness when it comes to fulfilling goals and an ability to spin ideas into gold. And as concerns owned by women, their companies represent the fastest growing segment of the American economy. 
 A few of the entrepreneurs on the magazine's list -- which encompasses almost every business endeavor from manufacturing and construction to publishing and entertainment -- are household names like Martha Stewart and Oprah Winfrey, but most are less well known. Prominent or not, the women own businesses that showed annual earnings ranging from $13.2 million to $5.4 billion last year.
In Westchester, the top female-owned businesses are Lillian Vernon, the New Rochelle catalogue business, which was the idea of a young housewife in the early 1950's and showed $258 million in revenue last year; the Wen Technology Group in Yonkers, which was started by an International Business Machines early retiree seven years ago and reported $84.7 million in revenue last year, and Robison Oil, an Elmsford-based heating oil and home-improvement company, which resulted when a determined boss's wife struck out on her own two decades ago and last year reported $53 million in revenue.
The three -- Lillian Vernon, chairwoman of the board and chief executive officer of the catalogue business; Dr. Sheree Wen, president and chief executive officer of the Wen Technology Group, and Fran Singer, president of Robison Oil -- are among the nearly 8 million female business owners in the United States employing more than 18.5 million people and generating close to $2.3 trillion in sales in 1996, according to the National Foundation for Women Business Owners, a research organization in Washington.
Between 1987 and 1996, the number of female-owned companies increased by 78 percent nationwide, outpacing overall business growth nearly 2 to 1 and accounting for 36 percent of all companies in the United States, the foundation said.
In recent interviews, the three Westchester businesswomen, like their counterparts across the United States, described themselves as hard driving and demanding. And each said she was committed to a goal that she expected her employees to share. None said the course that she had chosen was easy, but neither did any of them say she would choose differently if she had the option to do so.
"My husband said: 'You don't have to do this. Why don't you just stay at home and live a quiet life?' " recalled Dr. Wen, president of Wen Technology Corporation in Yonkers and inventor of low-emission computer monitors, voice activated notebook computers and touch-screen tele-video conferencing systems, among other things.
"But I believe we each do what we have to do in life to fulfill our mission," said Dr. Wen, 47, of Briarcliff, a former I.B.M. vice president who started her own company and now has 12 patents under her name. She holds a doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley in materials engineering, solid state physics and statistics. The Government and the United States Army are her largest clients, buying among other things the low-emission Wen monitors, which are designed to thwart the theft of high-security information from a computer's memory.
For the 70-year-old Ms. Vernon, who emigrated from Leipzig, Germany, with her family in the early years of Nazi rule, it was the concept of monogramming belts and handbags and turning $500 spent for an advertisement in Seventeen magazine into a $32,000 profit. "There were naysayers along the way," she said recently, "but I was never defeated, even though I cried a lot in the early days."
Ms. Vernon wished she had done some things differently, like putting up her feet occasionally at the end of the day instead of taking work home. But she said she would not choose -- not in the 1950's or today -- to stay at home and leave the bread winning to a husband. Still hard driving and now a frequent visitor to the White House, she raised two sons along the way to success, left two husbands and grew a business that is publicly owned. As a septuagenarian, she is planning to marry for the third time -- this time, though, promising herself to set limits to her six-day work week.
She was born Lillian Menasche and took the name Lillian Vernon, for Mount Vernon where her original warehouse was. She now lives in Greenwich and Manhattan.
For Mrs. Singer, 58, of Dobbs Ferry, the first step was becoming the partner of her husband, Saul, in an oil supply company in the Bronx, and the next was taking off on her own to start a Westchester-based concern. She still bristles when businessmen call her "hon" or "sweetie" -- "I tell them I prefer Fran, thank you" -- but she knows that the long days and stretches without a break have paid off in respect from most people she meets, even if some still derogate her and other successful women.
Robison Oil is currently expanding to include home-improvement services as well as oil deliveries, and two of her three grown sons have become vice presidents in the business. Notwithstanding the grueling schedule of running one's own company over the years, she said she never served a TV dinner to her children or her husband (they have been married for 38 years). As for juggling a growing business, a busy household and the Singer family's philanthropic efforts in Israel, she said that like other business owners, "I thrive on stress."
Studies of the traits of successful female entrepreneurs show that they have "unbelievable perseverance and are disciplined to stick with a task," said Edie Fraser, president of the Business Women's Network, a Washington-based organization with 10 million members.
Female entrepreneurs differ from their counterparts who work for Fortune 500 companies in that successful corporate managers are politically savvy and tend to work comfortably within the framework of a group. By contrast, entrepreneurs tend to ignore the rules, strike out on their own and flourish when taking risks, Ms. Fraser said.
"A lot of it is street smarts, common-sense intelligence," said Ms. Vernon, who graduated from high school but did not go to college. "It's wisdom, not a degree, that gets you ahead in business, even though at first I thought I was just getting lucky."
Lillian Vernon, which ranked 53d on Working Woman's list, employs 1,350 workers year round and more than 4,500 near the Christmas shopping season. The company, which markets gift items and household, gardening and children's products, will relocate its headquarters to Rye this summer. It also has a distribution center in Virginia Beach, Va., and a buying and quality control office in Florence, Italy.
Wen Technology Corporation manufactures its products in Yonkers and sells them through distributors, government agencies and chain stores. The company introduced its first voice-recognition notebook at a consumer electronics conference in 1995. Two years ago, it introduced a 29-inch, high-definition television with Super VGA computer monitor capabilities. And last year, it announced two new products -- an extra-thin liquid crystal display monitor with a wide viewing angle and a portable wireless security monitor with a 4-inch screen, which can be carried anywhere within a 150-foot radius.
Dr. Wen has invented all the products that her company manufactures. She most recently invented and patented an electronic cleaning processor, which can destroy bacteria, viruses, microbes and pesticides on food.
A self-described risk taker, she said, "You have to be brave enough to take risks and shrewd enough to avoid those that are too big." She called her managerial style with her 40 employees "quite demanding," but said that was necessary in a small and growing company like hers, which ranked 127th on Working Woman's list of 500.
And while she often begins her workday before 8 A.M. and does not end it until midnight, Dr. Wen leaves her weekends free for her 9-year-old daughter, Aileen McGroddy, and her husband, James C. McGroddy, a former director of research at I.B.M. and now a Government consultant for security matters.
Robison Oil, which Mrs. Singer bought from Mobil Oil in 1978, serves 25,000 homeowners in Westchester and Putnam Counties and was 178th on the list of 500 female-owned companies, with 120 employees. In addition to selling fuel oil, the company markets electricity, furnaces, humidifiers, air-conditioning equipment, awnings, storm windows and other home-improvement items.
Mrs. Singer said a critical thrust of her business is letting customers know that there "really is a Fran Singer" behind the company name and that she will "answer each and every call and letter she receives." The personal touch -- one could call it the woman's touch, she said -- is one of the keys to her success.
Although one could argue that women demonstrate the same characteristics of success that men do, studies have shown that their styles are different.
"When a man says, 'I'll think about it,' he means no and he is probably giving you the brushoff," said Sharon G. Hadary, executive director of the National Foundation for Women Business Owners in Washington, offering an example. "But when a woman says the same thing, she really means that she will think about it. Any salesman who assumes that a female C.E.O. means what her male counterpart means and fails to check back is mistaken and probably out of a sale."
Or as Dr. Wen explained it: "If I'm not interested, I'll simply say, 'I'm not interested.' Perhaps women are just more straightforward than men."

HEADLINE: The Fresh Air Fund;
Family Welcomes Girl's Return

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
MICHELLE RIVERA hadbeen to Yankee Stadium before but never in $20 seats right behind home plate. That is where Michelle sat when she went to a ball game last summer with Gary and Kristin Friedman and their children, Sarah, 9, and Matthew, 6.
"It was excellent," Michelle, a fifth grader, said. "The best. Terrific. I had been to Yankee Stadium before but never so close to the players." 
 Michelle, 11, of the Bronx was visiting the Friedmans, who live here, for two weeks, thanks to the Fresh Air Fund. The fund, a 120-year-old noprofit agency, provides free summer vacations for disadvantaged New York City children. This year, 7,000 children will visit volunteer host families in suburban and rural areas in 13 states and Canada; 3,000 children will also attend Fresh Air camps in Fishkill, N.Y., and 1,000 youngsters will take part in year-round Fresh Air camping programs.
The Friedmans decided to open their home to a Fresh Air visitor after reading about and contributing to the fund for several years. They would have been hosts sooner, Mrs. Friedman said, but they were initially reluctant to sign up "because we thought a suburban house might not be the proper venue -- we were afraid that we didn't have enough countrified things to offer."
Her misgivings turned out to be completely unfounded: not only did both visitor and hosts have a great time but Michelle is also returning this summer.
Their activities will probably be almost identical to those of last summer: swimming in the Olympic-size Scarsdale municipal pool, going to a Yankees game and a Broadway show (last year it was "Beauty and the Beast"), watching Fourth of July fireworks ("I think each fireworks display is a little miracle," Mrs. Friedman said) and relaxing on the front porch of the family's 94-year-old, Tudor-style house.
Michelle said she enjoyed swimming in the Scarsdale pool and added that she "can't wait to go back" to visit the Friedmans this summer.
Mrs. Friedman, who is a landscape designer, will also show Michelle, the many plants and flowers that grow in the garden and inside the house, and Michelle will most likely make a few contributions of her own.
"Last year she showed us Rollerblading," Sarah said. "She's really good."
The Friedmans' background led them naturally to reach out to others. Mr. Friedman, a 45-year-old lawyer, grew up in Merrick on Long Island. Although he had a comfortable upbringing, his grandparents were Jewish immigrants who came to America with very little money. His father eventually became a labor arbitrator, but as a young man he had to find work through the Works Progress Administration. His mother dropped out of high school to go to work; it wasn't until later in life that she became an economist.
In the 1930's, Mr. Friedman said, both of his parents "were part of a group of young Jewish intellectual socialists."
Although they did not explicitly tell young Gary to look out for those less fortunate than he was, the message was certainly implied.
Mrs. Friedman, 39, grew up in TriBeCa "before it was chic." Her mother, a sculptor, and her father, an art dealer, divorced when she was a child. Some summers she spent visiting her father and his new wife in Italy, but mostly Kristin went camping across the country with her mother to visit grandparents in Dallas.
"We camped because we had to -- we couldn't afford motels," she recalled. Asked if her mother ever directly told her about children who had less than they did, Mrs. Friedman laughed and said, "I don't think she ever would have said, 'There are kids who are not well off,' because we ourselves were not."
As for Michelle and other Fresh Air children, they come from low-income families and are chosen on the basis of need.
First-time visitors are 6 to 12 and their stay is two weeks long. Those invited back to the same family may continue until they are 18 and may stay longer.
There are no financial requirements for being a host family, nor is there financial reimbursement. As Fresh Air Fund literature says, "Most hosts simply want to share their homes with inner city youngsters."
Volunteer hosts are always needed. The number to call to volunteer is (800) 367-0003. Tax-deductible contributions may be sent to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10018.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania County Resumes Commercial Growth

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: EXTON, Pa.

 BODY:
WITH the recession of the early 90's ended, Chester County is once again the fastest-growing county in eastern Pennsylvania, with plans for five million square feet of new commercial space set in motion last year alone.
The 756-square-mile county is a 45-minute drive from both Philadelphia and Harrisburg, the state capital. Its growth is the result of move-outs by companies that had been operating in the more fully developed nearby Montgomery and Delaware Counties in Pennsylvania, and New Castle County in Delaware, as well as growth by companies already based in Chester County. 
 The main corporate centers are in West Chester, Devon, Exton, Downingtown and Coatesville, although the best-known sites are in Brandywine Valley, a tourism center in the southern part of the county.
The total office and warehouse-distribution space in the county is only about 25 million square feet. But with sites in the more developed counties at a premium, the key to commercial growth has been lower costs and the regional road system. The Pennsylvania Turnpike crosses the county in the north, and Route 30, linking Philadelphia with Lancaster, runs roughly parallel to it farther south.
The Exton-Downington ramp off the turnpike, Exit 23, was a magnet for corporate growth in new parks in the 80's. Now construction at these parks has resumed, in part because of the completion a 5.5-mile four-lane bypass that diverts around the center of Exton. Opened in late 1995, the bypass is considered the key that unlocked the area's commercial potential.
The county's two largest employers, The Vanguard Group, one of the nation's largest mutual-fund companies, and QVC Network, the shop-at-home cable television retailer, have both added new buildings in the last year. And smaller companies are moving into the county from nearby centers in Montgomery County, where King of Prussia, 20 miles northeast of Exton, is a principal corporate center and a retail hub as well.
Among the beneficiaries of the new growth has been the Oaklands Corporate Center, a 305-acre office park in Exton that had 1.16 million square feet of occupied space in 26 buildings at the end of 1995.
Within the last year, said James J. Gorman, a partner in the ownership, six new companies have moved in, taking 145,000 square feet of space. One company, Omegaflex, an existing tenant that makes corrugated steel pipe, doubled the size of its building to 60,000 square feet.
It was King of Prussia's growth that led to a demand for warehouse and distribution space in Chester County, Mr. Gorman said, with companies forced out by rising demand for space from retail and office tenants who pay higher rents. Rents have risen in Exton, too, he said, but office tenants still pay under $20 a square foot a year, compared with roughly $25 to $30 a square foot closer to King of Prussia.
"It's like a game of checkers," said JoAnn West, a director in commercial brokerage in Cushman & Wakefield's suburban leasing office. She has watched companies move progressively farther west along turnpike exits in Fort Washington and King of Prussia, both in Montgomery County, and now to Exton.
THE projects now facing the approval process would add 20 percent to the total inventory of office, warehouse and distribution space, said Gary Smith, executive director of the Chester County Development Council. Last year nearly 500,000 square feet of new or renovated office space was added to the county's inventory, which totals about 11.6 million square feet, according to figures compiled by Smith Mack & Company, a regional real estate management company.
Much of this growth had been forecast for towns like Exton and Downingtown because of their proximity to Exit 23, Mr. Smith said, but there has also been growth to the north in Lionville and in Malvern south of Route 30. Expansions by existing tenants include a new 265,000-square-foot building for Shared Medical Systems Inc., which makes computers for the health-care industry, and a 300,000-square-foot campus for CFM Technologies, which makes electronics cleansing equipment for semiconductor manufacturers.
The Vanguard Group opened a 150,000-square-foot data center last year in Devon, not far from its corporate headquarters in Malvern.
And QVC Network unveiled its $20 million studio and office facility in a 585,000-square-foot building in West Chester. The studio adds 1,000 jobs to QVC's local workforce of 2,000 people.
Most of the area's corporate parks are owned by local developers, but the market has drawn the attention of real estate investment trusts, said Peter O. Schultz, regional director of First Industrial Realty Corporation.
The Chicago-based REIT made its first Philadelphia-area purchase in the Exton area, buying 16 buildings with 535,000 square feet built years ago by a local developer, Raymond Carr. "The Exton office market is relatively small but there's strong growth, particularly for technology and pharmaceutical companies," Mr. Schultz said.
Chester County is the only suburban county in southeastern Pennsylvania that shares no border with Philadelphia. More than 60 percent of its residents work within the county or in other suburbs, said William H. Fulton, executive director of the Chester County Planning Commission.
WE have people who travel to work by commuter train in the south end of our county," Mr. Fulton said. "And people who travel by horse-drawn carriage in the north as you enter Amish communities." Agriculture remains the county's top industry, anchored by mushroom growers clustered around Kennett Square, near the Delaware border.
Population forecasts estimate 500,000 residents by the year 2020, up from 420,000 today. Many of the transplanted employers are high-tech companies that include light manufacturing, research or subassembly operations along with their headquarters offices. Adopting a policy favoring "prudent development" years ago, county officials put in place a land-use plan allocating open space and office usage throughout the town's 73 municipalities, which has served as a guide to new growth.
Some employers are relocating to escape a road construction program in King of Prussia that will surely delay commuters near the Pennsylvania Turnpike's interchange with Route 202 and Interstate 76. An estimated 85,000 cars each day clog a four-lane, seven-mile-long section of highway between Exton and King of Prussia at rush hour, according to a local planning agency.
The newer corporate parks in Exton, Malvern and West Chester, the county seat, offer day-care and fitness centers, and stores and restaurants are usually closer by than they were in older parks. And Eagleview, a 700-acre planned community, will include not only offices but also a town center and at least one hotel, said Jack Purcell, marketing director for its builder, The Hankin Group.
Anthony J. Izzi, president of GEI Mateer Burt, which manufactures equipment for food and pharmaceutical companies, said he had surveyed his employees and found many already live in Chester County. After considering several sites, the company chose a new building in the Eagleview complex, about a 20-minute drive from its current headquarters in Devon, Pa. Last month, his company moved into 80,000 square feet of space.
"I wanted to go west because the pricing was lower and the next five years in this area will be a mess because of the Route 202 construction," he said. "We intend to have 4,000 square feet of lab space for the pharmaceutical industry where they can run clinical trials on our equipment."

HEADLINE: New York Area Retirees Get More Housing Choices

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AT 73, John Curran has made a decision about where he wants to live next. He will be moving when he turns 75 from his one-bedroom co-op on East 76th Street to a new retirement community in New Jersey called Seabrook Village, in the Monmouth County town of Tinton Falls.
"My health is good," Mr. Curran said, "but I'm getting leery of living by myself. When I move I want to forget my worries about taking care of myself. It will be up to them to take care of me to the day I die." 
 Seabrook Village, which went into construction only this year, is a formidable symbol of the growth in the forms of housing available for older people in the metropolitan area, especially those in their 70's and 80's. It is a continuing-care retirement community, with independent living, assisted living and nursing care available for life. The entry fees for the independent-living apartments vary, but most are under $200,000, with monthly service charges averaging $1,500. Buyers will have the option of moving on later to assisted-living or nursing care, at additional costs, in facilities that are to go into construction late next year.
There are few such communities in the Northeast -- most are in Pennsylvania and Maryland -- and even fewer that have been built by a for-profit developer. Because of its scale, Seabrook Village is a departure among all of them in the New York metropolitan area. It will have 1,650 apartments for independent living, plus 192 assisted-living apartments and 160 private rooms for nursing-home patients. About 2,500 people will eventually live there, most of them in their 70's.
Seabrook Village will not be a traditional "life-care" community, however, because residents do not contract for life upon entry for possible future nursing care or other supportive services. Instead, they pay for these if and when they are needed. Also, they or their estate get a 100 percent refund of their entry fee upon move-out or death, once the apartment is reoccupied.
Seabrook Village serves to drive home the point that middle-income people of retirement age are getting a wider choice in independent-living accommodations. This is especially so for those who have long lived in a house that has appreciated in value. It can be sold, and the profits plowed into retirement housing, making many of the newer choices affordable. An expansion is also under way in pure assisted-living developments, in which residents usually get all their meals served plus help in the tasks of daily life.
The main choice for healthy, vigorous retirees has historically been what are now called active-adult leisure communities -- age-restricted communities of houses or condominiums where at least one member of the household is 55 or older. Most of them in the metropolitan area are in New Jersey beyond typical commuting distance to New York City, in Ocean, Middlesex or Monmouth Counties. Some have golf courses, but all have at least a clubhouse. They take years to complete and some are still expanding even as new ones continue to open. And recently new retirement communities have opened closer to the population centers of northern New Jersey.
One of the new ones, Brookfield, will ultimately have 300 single-family homes and 185 apartments on 115 acres in White Township adjoining the town of Belvedere, the county seat of Warren County, two miles from the Delaware River. Land clearance got started this year and the first homes are to be ready for occupancy in December.
With a sales campaign due to start next month, early shoppers have been quoted prices from the $120,000's to the $150,000's for single-family detached houses. Belvedere Development Company, whose principal is Kenneth G. McDermott, is the builder.
Another new community is Fox Hills, 30 miles to the east of Brookfield in Rockaway Township in Morris County. Fox Hills will have 600 apartments in three-story steel-and-concrete buildings plus a 23,250-square-foot clubhouse in a gated community near Interstate 80. Sales on the first phase of Fox Hills, with 84 units, began just last month, and 56 buyers have already signed up, said Morton Salkind, the developer.
"This area could take 10 more communities like ours," said Mr. Salkind. Most buyers live within a radius of 30 miles, embracing Morris, western Essex and southwestern Bergen Counties, where the population is more than one million, he said. The price range is $130,000 to $219,000.
In New York City, Brookdale Living Communities, based in Chicago, is moving forward with plans for a $45 million development for retirees in in Battery Park City, a pure-rental project on which marketing may begin as early as this summer for occupancy in about two years. Rents for a one-bedroom are expected to be at least $4,500 a month. It will have 216 apartments, including a small assisted-living component.
AS these and other projects indicate, the character of housing designed for retired people is diverse. The market includes younger, robust people, often couples in their 60's ready to sell their homes after retirement and start out on some of the most pleasurable years of their lives. But it is not necessarily easy for them to adjust to the idea of moving at all.
"I had to convince my husband to move to an adult community," said Deanna Zacune, 60, who succeeded. She and her husband, Harmon, 63, a dentist who taught dental-hygiene students after he sold his practice, both retired this year. They sold their condominium in Edison, N.J., and bought an 1,800-square-foot three-bedroom detached house with a two-car garage at K. Hovnanian & Company's Four Seasons at Lakewood community off Route 70 in Ocean County.
"We're now 40 minutes farther from our son, but I thought it would be nice to be in something new, with other adults all over 55 or 60 so we can grow old together, rather than be dependent on our children to watch out for us," said Mrs. Zacune, a former state employee. "This place helps keep you younger. There are so many places to go. There's something to do here every day if you want to do it."
The Lakewood community, with a nine-hole golf course, is Hovnanian's largest adult community in New Jersey. It opened in 1995, and so far 850 houses have been sold and occupied. When construction is completed, there will be 1,300 detached and attached homes on the 407 acres of land. Houses are currently selling from $141,000 to $192,000. The most popular model -- a two-bedroom with 1,860 square feet of space and a two-car garage -- has a base price of $189,000.
Farther north, in Monmouth County, homes are more expensive. At the new Four Seasons community in Wall Township, off Route 34, detached two-bedroom houses with two-car garages, for example, sell for $228,000 to $240,000.
Eventually, some of the residents at active-leisure communities move out, perhaps to assisted-living developments, where meals and personal care are offered. At the Shady Oaks retirement community in Lincroft, N.J., in Monmouth County, which has attached homes and multifamily two-story buildings built in the mid-80's by Hovnanian, about 70 apartments a year turn over because of vacancies or death, said Bernice Jachter, a real estate broker who lives there. Prices range from $90,000 to $190,000.
The appreciation in value has been greater in downstairs units than upstairs units, Ms. Jachter said. "People are looking for one-level living -- with no steps," she said.
People in their 70's and 80's are often looking for long-term care as well as a secure environment and social activity among other adults of their age. The assumption that there is a broad middle-income market for this type of housing in the region will be tested by the ambitious Seabrook Village project.
The developer is Senior Campus Living of Baltimore, the developer-operator of the large-scale communities of Charlestown, outside Baltimore in Catonsville, Md., and the newer Oak Crest Village in Parkville, Md. Seabrook Village has bused more than 500 prospective buyers to Oak Crest Village for a daylong inspection, an experience that has been a prelude to a purchase by some of them. The company is also developing Henry Ford Village, with the Ford Motor Company, in Dearborn, Mich.
Seeking a large-scale New Jersey site five years ago, Senior Campus Living was rebuffed by local opposition first by Franklin Lakes, in Bergen County, and then by Wayne, in Passaic County. But Tinton Falls was welcoming. After final site acquisition last fall, the developer is in construction on the first of three large "neighborhoods," each of which is to have 550 apartments for independent living. The entrance is on Essex Road off Asbury Avenue near the Garden State Parkway.
The apartments at Seabrook Village will be in interconnected buildings of four to seven stories, linked to a central 70,000-square-foot three-level community building with a main dining room capable of serving 275 people at a time, various special purpose rooms and a 4,800-square-foot medical center with staff physicians. Residents reach the community building from the residential wings through glass-enclosed walkways. There are also landscaped outdoor courtyards, and about a third of the site is to be kept in a natural state. The land planner is Schoor DePalma of Freehold, N.J., and the architect is The Hillier Group, of Princeton.
According to Gary T. Engelstad, the director of sales, there have been 200 reservations for the 253 apartments that are so far on the market, with first occupancy planned for November. The entrance fees range from $111,000 to $340,000. An 850-square-foot one-bedroom, with a fully equipped kitchen, has an entry fee of $148,000; for a typical two-bedroom, with 1,100 square feet, the fee is $197,000. Entry fees are used principally to pay down mortgage debt and thereby reduce monthly service charges.
The monthly charges, ranging from $1,100 to $1,700, cover operating costs and include one meal a day, all utilities except phone service and apartment upkeep, plus the on-site and off-site activities and transportation services offered in adult communities generally. For additional charges residents can also get reserved parking, housekeeping services or home health care.
If a resident moves into the assisted-living section, the charge rises. It is currently projected at $2,500 a month. The projected cost of care in the nursing-home unit is $176 a day.
The fee-for-services system at Seabrook Village shows how developers have modified the original approach in continuing care, which was to guarantee care for life without any rise in monthly costs. Buyers who moved out would get no refund, nor would their estates get a refund if they died while living independently.
Some of these life-care developments went into bankruptcy in the 60's when they promised more medical benefits than they could deliver. In New York State the bankruptcies led to new regulations that made development conditions so restrictive that for-profit development has virtually ceased. The state has also been conservative about adding new nursing home beds unless a local need can be demonstrated.
Nowadays even nonprofit continuing-care developments rarely guarantee future assisted-living or nursing care at no increase in cost. And they, too, refund most of the entrance fee when the resident dies or moves out. Usually fees are 90 percent refundable, although at Seabrook Village refunds 100 percent. And some projects are designed as pure rentals.
OUR goal is to get to the large population centers with middle-income retirees," said John C. Erickson, chairman of Senior Campus Living. "You can have one every 30 miles." The company is currently developing a community for 3,000 residents called Riderwood Village in Silver Spring, Md., 30 miles south of the 2,000-resident Charlestown community, which itself is only 20 miles southwest of Oak Crest Village.
But the company cannot build in New York State, Mr. Erickson said, because the state requires that revenues are set high enough to cover the future cost of extended care, including a certain amount of nursing care. Only one in 14 residents of Senior Campus Living's projects turn out to need extended care, he said. Requiring charges to independent-living residents to cover it would mean that monthly carrying costs would have to be twice as high -- about $2,000 a month instead of $1,000, he said.
"New York State says charge $2,000 a month and make no distinction on whether the services are needed or not," Mr. Erickson said. "Middle America won't do that." To prevent overconstruction of nursing-home beds, the state also puts a limit of 90 on the number allowed in a continuing-care project, a figure too low for developments the size of those that Senior Campus Living builds, Mr. Erickson said.
In Connecticut, another private owner-operator, David Reis, the principal in Senior Care Development in North Branford, Conn., is developing a major continuing-care community in Fairfield County. The 136-acre site is on a hilltop off Route 107 in the Town of Redding, with panoramic views of the countryside. Mr. Reis bought the land last year from the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, a maker of scientific instruments based in Wilton, Conn., which had planned to build a new corporate headquarters.
Mr. Reis said he would break ground in June for Meadow Ridge. It will have 380 units for independent living plus assisted-living and nursing-care rooms. Its typical two-bedroom apartments will have 1,350 square feet, and its three-story community building will have a 10,000-square-foot atrium and an Olympic-size pool. The buildings will be reached from a winding road rising nearly a mile through woodlands from a manned gatehouse on Route 107.
With entry fees starting at $360,000, Meadow Ridge will be a high-end community, a reflection of the higher-income characteristics of the area in which it is built. "We'll be attracting a lot of wealthy couples," said Mr. Reis, who also developed Evergreen Woods, a continuing-care development with 247 apartments for independent living in North Branford, Conn., near New Haven.
Meadow Ridge will be a true life-care community, with assisted living or nursing care provided with minimal additional charges. Its nursing-home component will take private-pay patients from the start, and the revenue generated will be used in part to meet the expense of providing nursing care for those Meadow Ridge residents who eventually need it. About 20 percent of the monthly fee of those in independent living -- where charges are expected to average $2,000 -- will also be set aside for this purpose, Mr. Reis said.
New York State, for its part, defines a continuing-care community as one that accepts prepayment for possible future health services, and it must be licensed by the Department of Health. An interagency Continuing Care Retirement Community Council within the state's Department of Health is in place to help move applications through the five agencies that must approve any project (after a feasibility study, an actuarial study, a demand study and a market analysis).
According to Nicholas J. Mongiardo, a principal in the White Plains health-care consulting firm of Cicero Shapiro Velazquez & Cicero, at least four major projects are in the process of seeking regulatory approval. They would provide more than 1,000 independent-living units in the greater metropolitan area. And in the 90's, two projects have been completed -- Kendal at Ithaca, in Tompkins County, and Glen Arden in Goshen, in Orange County. Two others are in construction -- the Jewish Home, in Rochester, and Canterbury Woods, in Amherst in Erie County. All four are nonprofit development projects.
"My feeling is that the for-profits have been busy marketing in other states around New York, but they also know that eventually they'll have to come to New York because there's such a big market here," said Mr. Mongiardo, a former deputy director in the Department of Health and the former chairman of the interdepartmental Lifecare Community Council, as it was then known.
The "fee for service" approach used in other states has also begun to show up recently in New York State. Developers are building independent-living units without Department of Health licenses, while contracting with licensed health-care providers to offer services to residents on a fee basis. The developments are usually rentals.
MR. REIS, the Connecticut developer, doubts this, however. The reserve requirements that developers in New York are required by the Department of Insurance to keep are too high to allow projects to pay down development debt from entrance-fee revenue, he said, a practice that allows projects to run economically.
Also, Mr. Reis said that a requirement that the insurance department reserves the right to pass upon future increases in monthly rates, which he said are pass-throughs of rising operating costs, is unacceptable to him. "We could not take the risk of being denied an increase in charges needed for operating," he said.
Whatever the new developments are that are built for retirees and older people generally, many of them will find other options -- if they can bring themselves to move at all.
Dr. Morton Salkind, an 86-year-old retired dentist in Nyack, N.Y., said he resisted moving out of the house he had lived in for 40 years even though he had been living in it alone since the death of his wife, Helen, six years ago. He finally sold the house and moved last August into a rental building called West Shore apartments on the Hudson River in Nyack.
"I was living alone but I couldn't make up my mind to move," Dr. Salkind said. "I kept putting it off and putting it off. Last year I decided it was time."

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Solutions to Traffic Problems

 BODY:
The number of cars in the state keep increasing, but there is no room for new roads. How should the state handle its traffic problems?
 
Gas Is Too Cheap 
 Until a gallon of gas exceeds a gallon of milk in price, nothing will change. The general population will believe (based on advertising) that today's cars are more efficient and less polluting, and thus feel free to drive more often. Public transportation is still geared for getting people to Newark, New York City, and Philadelphia in the morning and getting them home at night, with limited service everywhere else. If officials really want people out of cars, public transportation needs to provide more service to more locations.
 
K. C. JACKSON
Teaneck
 
Keep Right
One quick, no-cost way to greatly increase the capacity on present high-speed roads is to cut down the radar traps and have the troopers moving and enforcing the "keep right except to pass" law. The speed limit will soon be at 65 and since most traffic on I-295 in south Jersey has always moved only slightly only above that (at 72) there is less need for radar traps. If all kept to the right except when passing there would be three lanes continuously moving with no slowing as each lane would find a comfortable steady speed and there would be no bunching up.
 
SHELDON CHIBNIK
Cherry Hill
 
And Stay Out
 Make all New Jersey roads one-way -- due north.
 
ANNETTE KRUGER
West Orange
 
Move Truck Traffic
One of the most obvious problems is the mix of auto and heavy trucking traffic during the rush hours. Trucking during rush hour impedes the flow of traffic, increases pollution and increases the economic and social costs to all of us. A simple solution would be to restructure our shipping and distribution system to exclude heavy truck traffic during the rush hours. A more radical and controversial approach would be to have our distribution system operate between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M.
 
FRANK J. MALKIEWICZ
Edison
 
Increase Tunnel Tolls
 From where I sit, in a bus seat high above the passenger vehicles approaching the Lincoln Tunnel, I would say that most cars have but a single occupant, their driver. I propose changing the toll structure as follows: cars with only their driver must pay $100 to drive through the tunnel; two occupants, $50; three occupants, $4 (the current toll), and four or more go free. For most of these motorists there are alternative ways to get into Manhattan. Let's force these inefficient users of our resources to seriously ponder their extravagance.
 
CHARLES A. RUBIN
Westfield

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
First-Quarter Housing Sales Top '97 Quarter by 23%

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
WITH almost a quarter more homes sold in the first three months of this year than in the same period last year, Westchester County continues to benefit from the Wall Street boom and the fallout from New York City's surging real estate market.
The total number of residential sales in Westchester rose 23 percent in the first quarter, compared to the same period last year. That total, which includes single-family homes, cooperatives, condominiums and two- to five-family houses, represented 1,778 closings in the first quarter, against 1,448 for the same period last year. 
 "It's really a continuation of the level of sales we've been seeing for several years now," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "It's reflective of the strong local economy and, of course, low mortgage rates."
In the period from October 1997 to January 1998 when most contracts were signed that resulted in first quarter closings, the average interest rate on a 30-year conventional mortgage dropped from about 7.5 percent to 7 percent.
Another factor contributing to the sales increase was the resurgent residential market in New York City, which enabled people to sell their co-ops and move to the suburbs, Mr. Mercurio said. "Also renters are now making the decision to buy due to improved job security," he added.
The total dollar volume for first-quarter sales was $560 million, up from $434 million in the first three months of 1997. All housing categories experienced double-digit increases in numbers of sales from the year-earlier quarter, with condominiums rising 19 percent and co-ops 41 percent.
"The market's been so good, everybody is gasping for air," said Merritt Mitchell, president of Merritt Associates, a brokerage with offices in Scarsdale, Rye and Larchmont. "We're tied to the fortunes of the stock market. As long as that keeps gaining, we'll be in good shape."
The one downside to the good times, according to brokers, is lack of sales inventory. "Across the board, it's light," Mr. Mitchell said. The inventory of detached homes declined 24 percent to 3,945 units, from 5,171 units the same time last year. Condominiums are down 35 percent, to 685 units from 978 in 1997. And co-ops declined 21 percent to 1,422 units from 1,790.
Even with such robust sales activity, prices across the board are relatively flat. The first quarter median sales price for a detached home was $290,000, up just 3 percent from the prior year; the average price was $403,020, a 7 percent increase from a year earlier.
"The mean price shows there wasn't much shift in the relative proportion of inexpensive to higher-end sales," Mr. Mercurio explained. "While the average price indicates there were some price increases at the higher end."
Mr. Mitchell confirmed this, saying that in his markets "our brokers are amazed at the prices some houses are getting." But, he added, "the buyers don't seem to wince." There's also been a noticeable increase in the number of multiple bids, he said.
"It's something I don't like to see, frankly," Mr. Mitchell said. "Some brokers unfortunately encourage it. And the sale comes down to a bidding war. We also saw it in the 80's."
In a recent sale, Mr. Mitchell said, there were 11 bids on a three-bedroom colonial, which was in foreclosure. "The house was in disrepair," Mr. Mitchell said. "The bids started at $160,000 and went to $205,000. The house eventually sold at close to its $236,250 asking price."
Mr. Mitchell said he had seen instances where a house sold for $50,000 above its asking price. "In one particular case, a house hit the market on a good weekend," he said, "and everyone went after it."
Nevertheless, in most areas, pricing still matters. "Realistic pricing by sellers is still imperative in order to make a timely sale," said Ebie Wood, a regional manager for Houlihan/Lawrence. "If a home is priced competitively, it flies out the door. But if it's above the market, it will languish. Our buyers are extremely savvy."
In general, houses are taking less time to sell, according to Ms. Wood. In the year ended April 1, for example, there were 201 transactions in Bedford. The average time on market was 175 days. A year earlier there were 195 sales and average time on market was 226 days.
Edmond and Mary O'Reilly didn't want to wait until the spring market to buy their new home. "We wanted to get this house off the market," Mr. O'Reilly said. "We wanted to close before the spring rush."
The couple paid $395,000 for a five-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath Tudor in the Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon. They closed on March 17 and moved in on April 18. "We had set our limit at $400,000", Mr. O'Reilly said.
WE did get a lot of calls on that house," said Liz Lindsey, of Lindsey Real Estate, which handled the sale. "If the O'Reillys hadn't already been under contract, there probably would have been multiple offers. Luckily for them, they moved with dispatch."
The couple had been living in a two-bedroom co-op in Yonkers. But with three children and another due in August "it was definitely time to move," Mr. O'Reilly said. They were able to sublet their apartment, which was a critical factor. "With co-op prices what they are now," Mr. O'Reilly said, "we couldn't have afforded to sell it at this time and take the loss."
The O'Reilly's bought their apartment at the height of the co-op market in 1987. And while co-op sales posted the biggest increase in the first quarter, prices continued to drop. In the first quarter 260 co-ops were sold, compared with 185 in the same period last year. But the median sales price fell to $63,000 from $64,000 last year, a 2 percent decline.
Mr. Mercurio explained that just 20 percent of co-ops in the county sell for over $100,000, so the presence or absence of just a few sales in the higher price ranges noticeably affects the countywide averages.
In some markets, co-op prices have fared a little better. In the Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon, where there is an abundance of co-ops, there were 21 sales in the first quarter, compared with 19 in 1997, which represents a 9.5 percent increase, according to Liz Lindsey.
More significantly, prices during that same period were up 6.9 percent. "We're a real co-op area," Ms. Lindsey said. "People come here because we're right by the train station with access to Manhattan. The broker who handles co-ops in our office now has 11 under contract."
A total of 231 condominiums were sold in the first quarter, compared with 194 last year. The median sale price increased to $157,000, from $153,000 last year, a 3 percent change.
"Condominiums tend to track the progress of single-family homes more than co-ops," Mr. Mercurio said. "There's still a big inventory in co-ops. I don't expect prices to climb until the inventory is substantially reduced."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
The Hill Gets Steeper For State's Land-Use Plan

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When Governor Whitman vowed earlier this year to use the state development plan to help slow down suburban sprawl, she was applauded by the lobbying group that represents local officials.
The New Jersey State League of Municipalities has been a longtime supporter of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which was created six years ago to help cities and towns avoid haphazard development. 
 But now the League of Municipalities has joined forces with the New Jersey Builders Association to oppose what Whitman administration officials view as a routine housekeeping matter intended to help municipalities manage growth.
The administration is proposing to consolidate state government's planning and land-use functions within one state agency by moving the Office of State Planning from the Treasury Department to the Department of Community Affairs.
"Our core mission is community development and planning," said Jane Kenny, Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs. "And the state plan is the blueprint for community planning."
So why has this proposal caused such a ruckus and created an unusual alliance between the New Jersey Builders Association and the League of Municipalities?
In the past, the builders association and the League of Municipalities have taken opposing sides in the debate over the state's efforts to guide planning and development.
The new alliance troubles those who view the plan as the state's best hope to manage growth and prevent acres and acres of open space from being gobbled up by new construction. Environmentalists and other proponents of the plan fear that local officials, represented by the League of Municipalities, could derail the administration's attempts to move forward.
"We must take steps now to scale back overdevelopment to some sane level, or in the near future the New Jersey we know will disappear beneath bulldozers," said Bill Neil, assistant director for conservation for the New Jersey Audubon Society. "The lobbyists for local municipalities should be part of that effort, rather than providing political cover for the special interests who are sitting in the driver's seat of the bulldozers."
William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the League of Municipalities, said that there was no grand conspiracy between his group and the builder's association to block implementation of the state development plan or Governor Whitman's vision to manage growth.
"We just happen to agree that the Office of State Planning should remain in the Treasury Department," said Mr. Dressel, in an appearance before the Assembly's Local Government and Housing Committee last week.
Mr. Dressel says his biggest concern is that the Department of Community Affairs is a regulatory agency while the Treasury Department does not have any regulatory authority over land-use decisions. And he is concerned that land-use functions, within a state regulatory agency, could erode New Jersey's longstanding tradition of home rule, which allows cities and towns to determine their fates.
He asked the legislative committee to consider blocking the administration from making the move without legislative approval.
Patrick O'Keefe, the executive vice president of the Builder's Association, echoed Mr. Dressel's concerns. He also criticized the Whitman administration for not consulting his organization and other groups before proposing the move.
"In the end, the lack of consultation regarding the transfer may be the single strongest argument against it," he said.
But Barbara Lawrence, head of New Jersey Future, a watchdog group created a decade ago to oversee the implementation of the state plan, said she is concerned that the League's opposition is sending a signal that the powerful lobbying group does not recognize that residents want their state and local officials to take a stronger stance against haphazard development.
"I think it means the league is out of step with the people of New Jersey," Ms. Lawrence said.
The proposal by the Whitman administration to consolidate state government's land-use planning functions demonstrates that the Governor is serious about using the state plan to guide development and growth in New Jersey.
Ms. Lawrence and other proponents of the plan wonder if that is what local officials fear.
New Jersey has already demonstrated its commitment to winning consensus from local communities for the plan. That is what makes New Jersey's state plan different from similar plans in other states.
In New Jersey, the state does not impose its own ideas about where development should or should not occur in each of the state's 566 municipalities. Those decisions are made with the consent of local officials through a lengthy process, involving a great deal of public discussion and debate.
The debate over this proposed transfer of the state planning office from one state agency to another shows that Governor Whitman is likely to face uphill battle over implementing her vision for managing development and growth in New Jersey. It was easier for local officials to say they agreed with the state plan when it seemed as if state government was ignoring it.

LENGTH: 444 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOHO/GREENWICH VILLAGE;
Non-Artists' Housing Seen as Blot on Local Canvas

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
Most of the housing in SoHo consists of lofts, where only city-authenticated "artists in residence" are supposed to live. But the city has approved a developer's plan to build more than 100 conventional apartments in the neighborhood, which has some local residents up in arms.
The Continuum Company is planning two buildings on parking lots on the south side of Houston Street, from Mercer Street to Wooster Street, in an area zoned for manufacturing. Until recently, variances allowing residential use of buildings in the neighborhood were granted only under state law and city zoning rules that allow artists -- certified as such by the city -- to inhabit large "joint living work quarters" in low-rise buildings, said Sean Sweeney, a member of the SoHo Alliance neighborhood group and the chairman of the landmarks committee of Community Board 2. 
 But the Continuum Company applied for variances to put up buildings that would be taller than the five- and six-story structures that predominate in the area, and to create smaller units, mostly studios and one-bedroom apartments. There was no mention of any artist requirement in its application.
Local groups opposed the project, citing concerns about increased congestion in an already crowded area and worries that SoHo's distinctive flavor would be eroded.
"We want to preserve the character of SoHo as a working artists' center," said Alan Gerson, who is the chairman of Community Board 2. "We're against any type of land use that doesn't bolster that." The community board has formally opposed the plan.
The SoHo Alliance faulted Continuum's calculation that large loftlike spaces would be uneconomical. "If they had only one or two apartments per floor, they would still make a lot of money," Craig Whitaker, an architect hired by the Alliance, said, citing recent sales in and around SoHo at prices exceeding $400 a square foot for lofts of 1,200 to 2,400 square feet.
But Continuum's lawyer, Bob Davis, said the company's economic data showed otherwise. He also said many non-artists are already living in SoHo. "The addition of the residents of these apartments is not going to change the character of the area," Mr. Davis said.
On April 21, the city's Board of Standards and Appeals approved the developer's plan, which calls for a building of nine stories with 60 apartments on one of the lots and another of eight stories with 43 apartments on the other. Members of the SoHo Alliance said they plan to sue the city in hopes of getting the decision overturned.
"We must win this," Mr. Sweeney said. "The future of SoHo as an artists' center depends on it." BERNARD STAMLER

GRAPHIC: Photo: Parking lots on the south side of Houston Street are in line to get eight- and nine-story apartment buildings, not restricted to artists. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST NEW YORK;
Weed-Choked Acres Bring Forth Frustration, Not Housing

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
"Future Site of Gateway Estates," reads a sign at the edge of a weed-encrusted plot of land in East New York. "A Planned Community of 3,000 Affordable Homes, Regional Shopping, Parks and Schools."
That community was to be Brooklyn's largest housing development in two decades. For more than five years, the Starrett Corporation, the builder of Starrett City, has been molding and remolding plans for the land, 227 acres of a former city dump in the Spring Creek area of East New York. Starrett had also agreed to let the Nehemiah Project, a nonprofit that builds subsidized housing for working families, to put up 500 homes on the land. 
 But the project has hit snag after snag, and its fate is increasingly uncertain. Today, the vacant land seems less a symbol of urban rebirth than of a bureaucratic and political morass. It also testifies to some potential complications in the public-private partnerships that the Giuliani administration favors as an answer to many of the city's woes.
In March, the administration withdrew $10 million that it had promised to build roads, sewers and the like at the site. City officials, particularly Richard T. Roberts, the Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, have said that the infrastructure money was withdrawn because the Starrett Corporation had been unable to buy a piece of land needed to build a shopping center that the city feels is crucial to the project.
As it turns out, that land, 10.55 acres, is owned by the state, which is negotiating with Starrett over the purchase price. "There is a dispute over the value" of the land, said a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation, Caroline A. Quarterero.
And now, the development's originator, the Starrett Corporation, is suddenly its wild card. In December, the company, which was publicly traded, was bought for $80 million by a group of private investors. Its new chief executive, Joel Simon, said that the Gateway project was being re-evaluated and that it was unlikely that the more than 2,000 housing units that were part of the original plan would be built. The shopping center is a better bet, he said, but not a sure one. "We are looking very earnestly to see whether we can proceed with the commercial part of the development," Mr. Simon said.
Michael Gecan, the regional supervisor for the Industrial Areas Foundation, which has worked with Nehemiah for 14 years, said even if the Gateway homes were not built, the Nehemiah homes would be. "We will build at Spring Creek," he said.
As to the infrastructure money, Mr. Roberts did not respond to a request for comment. Officials of East Brooklyn Congregations, the church consortium that runs Nehemiah, said administration officials have refused to meet with them. At a City Council hearing on Thursday, a deputy Housing Preservation commissioner, Hector Batista, said, "When this project is ready to go, we will re-evaluate."
The City Council has the power to restore the money without the Mayor's approval, and Mr. Gecan said that tomorrow, he and East Brooklyn Congregations officials will formally request that it do so.
And, at least one hurdle has been removed, if only temporarily. The New York City Audubon Society had sued the state over a building permit granted to the Starrett Corporation without a public hearing. On March 24, a State Supreme Court judge dismissed the lawsuit. The society, however, said it plans to appeal. AMY WALDMAN

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Creditors Lead Push To Curb Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WHAT was once a staple of the economic cycle -- recession driving more people into bankruptcy and then recovery thinning their ranks -- seems to have disappeared.
Last year, the number of Americans declaring themselves bankrupt jumped by nearly 20 percent, to 1.34 million, despite an economy that marked its sixth full year of uninterrupted expansion with the lowest jobless rate in a quarter-century. 
 Whatever the reason for this decoupling, the fact that one family in 75 winds up in such financial distress during boom times has fueled a long-simmering effort by banks, credit card companies and other lenders to persuade Congress to fix what they regard as overly permissive bankruptcy rules. The resulting clash with consumer groups has turned the bankruptcy issue into one of the most heavily lobbied in a Congress that is also weighing tobacco legislation and Social Security reform.
Bankruptcies are now more than six times as common as when the debtor-friendly Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 was passed. And too many people, the lenders and their political allies contend, are legally walking away from debt they could repay. As a result, the lenders say, costs they estimated at about $44 billion in 1997 -- or $400 for each American household -- are shifted onto more prudent consumers.
"The only reasonable explanation is that the stigma of bankruptcy is all but dead," argued Representative George W. Gekas, Republican of Pennsylvania, whose measure to limit filings is set to reach a sharply divided House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.
This view is hotly disputed, however, by the National Consumer Law Center, labor groups and others as unfairly burdensome to those who are struggling to pay their bills. In addition, they say, it constitutes an assault on the long-established principle that society needs a mechanism to give the hopelessly indebted a fresh start.
"The credit industry has launched a massive media and lobbying campaign to discredit the consumer bankruptcy system," said Gary Klein of the Law Center, which represents low-income people. The proposed legislation, he argued, would jeopardize spending by its clientele on "essential items like their homes, cars and utilities." Moreover, debtors would be "yoked to unmanageable credit card and medical debts by a taxpayer-funded Federal collections bureaucracy."
DESPITE a short election-year calendar, Congressional action has become likely. In the House, the main bill, sponsored by Mr. Gekas and James P. Moran, a Virginia Democrat, would introduce a means test to determine how much relief debtors needed and would require them to repay what they could.
Supporters say the bill's focus is on those who have come to regard bankruptcy as a financial planning device or a Government program for debt forgiveness rather than on those who are overwhelmed by, say, catastrophic medical bills.
Under the measure, those with incomes at least 75 percent of the national median for households of equivalent size and who have the ability to pay at least 20 percent of unsecured debt within five years would be forced to enter into a Chapter 13 repayment plan. Money spent on priority items like alimony and back taxes, though, would not count toward the 20 percent.
Applying this test, and using the 1996 household median income of $42,300, earnings of more than $31,725, adjusted for inflation, would touch off the plan.
Proponents figure this requirement would force some 15 percent, or 200,000, of the least-stressed bankruptcy filers to make some payment instead of seeking relief under Chapter 7. That section of the bankruptcy law, under which virtually all debts are erased without regard to financial situation, is used for 70 percent of all personal bankruptcies.
Debtors earning less than 75 percent of the national average would be unaffected and could continue to choose between Chapter 7 and Chapter 13, which requires the debtor to agree to at least partial repayment.
The Senate has scheduled a drafting session for Thursday on its version of the legislation, whose chief sponsors are Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, and Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois.
It seeks to curb abuse by allowing lenders, rather than a Government trustee, to argue in court that someone filing for bankruptcy can afford to pay. Banks and credit card issuers object strongly to a provision that would make them liable for at least $5,000 of a debtor's legal costs when the court rules against the lender.
IN arguing that the bankruptcy surge reflects undisciplined spending and an indulgent law, the credit card sponsors and their allies cite research showing that some 25 percent of those filing under Chapter 7 had their debts erased even though they could have repaid a "significant" proportion. Ten percent of those filing, they contend, could have repaid it all.
Consumer advocates counter that these industry-financed studies are irrelevant and misleading. Indeed, the advocates contend, lenders are promoting the studies with the same aggressiveness with which they marketed high-rate credit cards to marginally solvent consumers.
Opposition has also come from women's groups concerned that raising credit-card claims to a status equal to that now granted child support would make it harder for mothers to collect delinquent support. With more debtors forced to use Chapter 13, the mothers would have to wage continuing battles with powerful claimants like credit-card companies, the groups contend.
It is not yet clear how another issue will play out: a little-publicized move that would likely make it harder for businesses to get bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11.
"It really puts the screws to the small-business person," said Elizabeth Warren, a professor at Harvard Law School who opposes the bill.
But the National Federation of Independent Business still supports the legislation. "For every small business that's a debtor," said Nelson Litterst, senior manager for legislative affairs, "there's about five or six small businesses that are creditors."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Huddled Masses Of the Wealthy

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
THE fortunes being made in Silicon Valley draw much attention, but they are not enough to lift the average incomes in that high-technology center into the top tier of the nation's counties, new financial data show.
Five of the 10 counties with the highest average adjusted gross incomes reported on Federal tax returns are in the New York area. Only San Mateo County, at the northern edge of Silicon Valley, is in the top 1 percent of the 3,140 counties, according to figures for 1995, the most recent available. 
 The poorest counties are no longer concentrated in the South but rather in Nebraska, Texas, New Mexico and South Dakota.
A point-and-click map for Internal Revenue Service data on each state and county is at www.trac.syr.edu/ tracirs/, the Web site of Syracuse University's Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: Capitalism Victorious (Thanks, Everyone)

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
THE Daimler-Chrysler deal is the model for global capitalism, a marriage of champions of free enterprise whose success has been driven by their ability to deliver products that customers around the world want at prices they are willing to pay.
Well, not quite. 
 While no one disputes the technological or marketing savvy of these giant auto makers, their profitability, their staying power -- and, at times of crisis, their very survival -- have depended as much on cozy relations with the state.
"Both Daimler and Chrysler have been masters at getting what they need from government," said Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University.
Hitler, Eisenhower, Adenauer, Carter: all will figure in any honest history of the new DaimlerChrysler, alongside the founders and ahead of many of the chief executives as key characters in the stories of the predecessor companies. And that makes last week's stunning $39 billion deal, the biggest industrial merger ever, an intriguing study of just how "free" free markets really are.
Look back, first, at the early decades of Daimler-Benz. Almost everyone knows that Gottlieb Daimler and Karl Benz were among the very first to produce commercially feasible cars. What is less well remembered is how closely Daimler-Benz's early fortunes were tied to the German state.
In 1934, Hitler, a car enthusiast with a special affection for Mercedes, commissioned the deeply depressed company to build the world's best racing car. Daimler-Benz satisfied its patron, dominating Grand Prix racing through the late 1930's and literally showing the Nazi flag across Europe.
"The cars were painted with little swastikas," said Bob Casey, the curator for transportation at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich.
Daimler-Benz also built the 1,200-horsepower diesel engines that powered the Hindenburg and Graf Zeppelin dirigibles, yet another symbol of German technological superiority. And during World War II, the company manufactured 100,000 of its DB-601 aeronautical engines, the workhorse of the Luftwaffe, prized for both their reliability and their capacity to operate at high altitudes.
Not surprisingly, Daimler-Benz's factories -- the company also made diesel engines for tanks and military trucks -- were reduced to rubble by bombing raids in 1944. But even in defeat, the hand of government lifted the company up. The rapid reconstruction of Germany's flagship industrial corporations became an Allied priority after the fall of the Third Reich. With assured access to capital, Daimler-Benz was churning out trucks and buses in quantity by 1949. And with the mark deliberately undervalued by the postwar financial regime, the company's exports got a jump-start.
"To make the spectacular comeback, they had to have help from the state," said David Lewis, a historian at the University of Michigan's business school.
The fortunes of Chrysler have also turned on government patronage. As a leading armaments producer during World War II -- Chrysler built the Sherman M-4 tanks that went head-to-head with Daimler-powered Tigers -- the company amassed the capital to compete effectively against the far larger General Motors.
And what the hot war facilitated, the cold war sustained: Chrysler's armaments subsidiary, the prime contractor for the XM-1 tank, generated a recession-proof flow of income for a company that otherwise had few cushions against the ups and downs of the auto industry.
Indirect dependence on Washington, of course, segued to outright dependence in 1980, when Chrysler ran out of cash and required Federal credit guarantees to keep its production lines running.
AND while that "bailout" during the Carter Administration has been widely celebrated as a stroke of Government leadership that allowed Chrysler to pull itself up by its bootstraps, the company's continued success has been no less tied to the corridors of Washington power.
In the early 1980's, Lee A. Iacocca, then Chrysler's chief executive, led the political lobbying for barriers against Japanese vehicle imports. The "voluntary" restraints that were negotiated protected the Big Three's core market even as the domestic steel, electronics, machine tool and earth-moving-equipment industries were mercilessly battered by Japan's high-quality goods and the strong dollar.
American consumers, meanwhile, paid extra for the Japanese cars they so dearly wanted -- or could not get the models they wanted at all. (And Chrysler was selling rebadged Mitsubishis imported from Japan.)
"Nobody navigates the regulation maze better than Chrysler," said Lawrence White, an economist at the Stern School of Business of New York University.
CHRYSLER'S skill at playing the Washington game is even more apparent in its exploitation of the corporate fuel-economy standards.
On the one hand, the company successfully beat back efforts to relax the mileage standards for cars during the Bush Administration, when it had a competitive edge over Ford and G.M. in compact cars. On the other hand, as the maker of the Chrysler Town & Country, Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango, it has benefited even more than its competitors from the less demanding mileage standards applied to truck-like passenger vehicles.
Of course, it isn't just Chrysler and Daimler that are masters of the free enterprise system's dirty dance with the state. France is eager to overlook Iraq's interest in anthrax to sell oilfield equipment. Brazil and Israel sell everything from Uzis to howitzers to Central American generals in mirrored sunglasses. Washington does Boeing's bidding in China, while European governments, wrapped in national pride, provide billions in subsidies to Airbus Industrie, the Continent's principal aircraft maker.
Indeed, Airbus may figure in the Daimler-Chrysler merger. As a 38 percent shareholder in Airbus, Daimler has made no secret of its wish to privatize the consortium, whose other members are government-controlled French, British and Spanish companies.
But that probably will not happen unless Airbus can fend off future efforts by Boeing to contain the Europeans' penetration of the American market. An alliance with a giant American company that has more than 100,000 unionized employees cannot hurt the cause of Airbus in Washington.
None of this reflects badly on Daimler-Benz or Chrysler; to thrive, modern corporations must adapt to the environments in which they do business.
But it does offer another perspective when free markets get credit for triumphing over central planners, and when globe-spanning deals are heralded as victories for the world's shareholders over narrow national interests.
"Big business," Mr. White of New York University said simply, "has always been a creature of big government."
