HEADLINE: Capitol Becomes a House United

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 9

 BODY:
The legislative session here ended on Wednesday at midnight, and in this and other state capitals around the country, a strange thing has happened. While Republicans and Democrats in Washington continue to do battle, a spirit of bipartisan cooperation has dominated the politics of many state governments.
"A lovefest" is how State Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, the Democratic leader of the Senate, described this year's session here. 
 State Senator James T. Fleming, the second-ranking Republican, agreed. "No one who has been around this building in the past would believe that this is an election year," he said.
Lawmakers from around the country said the bipartisan peace was partly a reaction to the budgetary standoff in Washington three years ago and the public disgust over that bickering.
But legislators and others who follow state government also said that the strong economy and the accompanying budget surpluses have made it more difficult to find things to fight about. The debate has shifted from which programs to cut to which programs to finance and which taxes to cut.
"There is less wrangling and a greater level of comity and cooperation," said William T. Pound, executive director of the National Conference of State Legislatures. "It has not been a terribly contentious year."
The New York State Legislature passed a budget in April, the earliest it had done so since 1993, and neither party picked a fight until Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed more than 1,000 items. Republicans in Florida, who control the Legislature for the first time since the Reconstruction, talked about what a pleasure it was working with Gov. Lawton Chiles, a Democrat, after finishing the budget earlier than at any other time in recent history.
Even in California, where the Republican Governor, Pete Wilson, has clashed often with Democrats, who now control the Legislature, things have been surprisingly quiet. "This has been a tea party," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a professor at the Center for Politics and Economics at the Claremont Graduate School in Claremont, Calif., comparing it with other recent sessions. "There's even a modicum of decorum."
Of course, some legislatures continue to see deep partisan divisions. Republicans and Democrats in Indiana were unable to agree on how to spend their surplus, and in Pennsylvania, the Republican majority barely talks to the Democratic minority.
"I have to fight every day of the week to be recognized," said State Senator Robert J. Mellow, a Pennsylvania Democrat. He added, "There are no personal relationships -- these Republicans aren't the kind of people I would want to go out to dinner with."
Yet Mr. Pound of the National Conference of State Legislatures said that the bipartisan harmony in legislatures overshadowed the divisions, and among the places where peace prevailed, Connecticut was at the forefront.
Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, remarked on this political cooperation in the text of his address at the end of the session, writing, "At a time when our national politics has become a blood sport, the men and women of this General Assembly -- Republican and Democrat -- have set the standard for how our democracy is supposed to work."
The Legislature passed budget revisions in record time, approved a rebate that would send checks of as much as $150 each to thousands of taxpayers, raised the minimum wage and set aside $20 million to improve reading instruction for young children. It allotted hundreds of millions of dollars to economic development projects for the state's three largest cities, changed campaign finance laws, raised the speed limit and ended the monopolies enjoyed by the state's power companies.
The cooperation came from an unusual alignment of people, politics and money, but at the beginning of the session in February, few lawmakers predicted that this combination would yield such harmony.
It was, after all, an election year, with Governor Rowland seeking a second term. The most powerful Democrat in state government was Thomas D. Ritter, the retiring Speaker of the House and the campaign co-chairman for his party's likely challenger to Mr. Rowland. Add to this mix a State Senate in which the Democrats gained a one-vote majority in 1996 and that has been known for its partisan fights.
Mr. Rowland and Mr. Ritter had worked closely in the three previous years, though often with periods of tension. But there were no such periods this year, and State Senator William H. Nickerson, Republican of Greenwich, said the reason was simple: "the S-word, the surplus."
Like many other states, Connecticut is expected to end the fiscal year on June 30 with the largest surplus in its history, at least $460 million, in a budget of $10.5 billion. This abundance meant that the tough debates of recent years, mainly over what programs and services to cut, were easily resolved this year.
While some state governments, like those in Indiana and Massachusetts, have fought bitterly over how to spend their surpluses, that did not happen in Connecticut, and some credit Mr. Rowland's willingness to compromise. "He was skillful enough to know when he need bend, and when he need not," Mr. Nickerson said.
Democrats said the prospect of a tough gubernatorial challenge from United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly made Mr. Rowland move to the left.
Last year, Mr. Rowland proposed cuts in the education budget, while this year, he added money for schools and state colleges. In addition, he quickly yielded on his proposed cut in the income tax rate -- despite his 1994 campaign promise to eliminate it entirely -- agreeing instead to a property tax credit that Democrats had been seeking for years.
Still, Mr. Rowland walked away with a deal that will use surplus money to send rebate checks of as much as $150 to 1.2 million taxpayers in July. The compromise could help Democrats maintain their hold on the Legislature; it left no issue that Republicans could use to attack them. But the agreement was also borne from a sense that voters here were tired of the partisan politics associated with Washington.
"When the Federal Government shut down, people got angry, and the message reverberated to many of the state houses," said Roy Occhiogrosso, a spokesman for the Senate Democrats. He added that Connecticut politicians from both parties had learned from the efforts of third-party politicians: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s gubernatorial victory in 1990 and Ross Perot's Presidential campaign in 1992. Both men ran on the idea that partisan bickering was destroying government.
Lawmakers remarked that the desire for a civil, well-run legislature may have transcended politics. They said that in this Capitol, where lawmakers from both sides of the aisle gather at the end of the session for a midnight-to-dawn party with blaring rock-and-roll, personal relationships often supersede partisan politics.
Mr. Ritter, the only person to serve three terms as Speaker, made bipartisan chumminess the hallmark of his tenure, and it was apparent Wednesday as the session prepared to adjourn. Early in the afternoon, he received one of many standing ovations from both Republicans and Democrats in the House, and he could not get them to stop.
"I'm not going to cry until later, no matter how much you try," he said.
That night, State Representative Robert M. Ward, the Republican minority leader, spoke before the House and declared, "I will miss you, Mr. Speaker," adding that Mr. Ritter had treated him as a partner. Later he said that at national legislative conferences, some Republicans were shocked when he and Mr. Ritter would go out for a beer.
"We would be hard-pressed to find anything we didn't like in the session," Mr. Ward said.
Mr. Ritter agreed, saying, "If you'd asked what would have been a perfect session, this would be close to it."

LENGTH: 3597 words

HEADLINE: Dominicans Allow Drugs Easy Sailing

SERIES: LETHAL PARTNERS: First of two articles.

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
In the early 1990's, Colombia's drug barons were fed up and eager to rearrange their business. Impatient with the Mexican traffickers who were demanding half of every load delivered and distributed in the United States, they went looking for a country with weak law enforcement, proximity to the United States and established drug distribution networks.
It did not take long for them to find the Dominican Republic. By the spring of 1995, Colombian cartels were ensconced here and looking to expand their network, which is what led one boss to invite Hidalgo Elias Velez, the Colombian owner of a struggling tropical-woods business here, to a lavish party outside Bogota and recruit him as an agent. 
 The Dominican Republic was "excellent," Mr. Velez, now serving a prison term here, recalled being told by his Colombian host.
"You don't have any problems with your merchandise," the Colombian said. "Getting the money out is easy." Compared to their Mexican and Colombian counterparts, the Dominican authorities were so inexperienced, unprepared and ill equipped, "you don't even have to pay protection."
The Colombian drug cartel leaders also recognized, Mr. Velez said in an interview recently, that low-level Dominican drug dealers based in New York City were pushing their way up to the next echelon of the drug business, bidding for a bigger share of the wholesale distribution of cocaine and heroin in the New England and mid-Atlantic states.
Just a few years later, the alliance between Colombian cartels and their Dominican partners has changed the geography of the drug trade once again. For the first time since American authorities began trying to blockade South Florida in the early 1980's, a significant portion of the drugs sold and profits made in the Eastern United States is moving through the island countries of the Caribbean, with the Dominican Republic, a nation of eight million, serving as the main gateway.
With that flood of drug profits have come a wave of corruption and a growing threat to political stability throughout the region. The amount of money from the United States laundered through Dominican financial institutions has doubled over the last three years, according to United States Customs Service estimates, to more than $1 billion annually. Much of this is being invested in real estate, banks and businesses here.
At the same time, Dominican and Dominican-American drug traffickers are popping up in Puerto Rico, Haiti and the English-speaking Caribbean as the heads of smuggling operations. Since they are willing to work for commissions of only 25 percent, or sometimes even for cash rather than merchandise, they are increasingly favored by the Colombian cartels.
The Dominicans are supported by Colombian cartels determined not to repeat the error they made with Mexican rings, which are now gobbling up the Colombians' markets in the United States and even trying to encroach on operations in South America.
A University of Miami expert on international drug trafficking, Bruce Bagley, put it this way: "When the Colombians saw the Mexicans becoming greedier and even develop into rivals, they began to look to the Dominicans as more reliable partners."
The Colombians moved huge amounts of drugs through the Caribbean in the early 1980's, prompting the Reagan Administration to mount its major crackdown. That in turn spurred the Colombians to emphasize other routes, primarily through Mexico. The alliance that ensued has ravaged that country's already weak judicial system, corrupted high officials and shaken its growing partnership with the United States.
While the bulk of Colombian cocaine and heroin continues to move through Mexico, the Colombian traffickers have in the last few years come full circle, returning to the Caribbean as a base of operations.
A big obstacle remains in the way of this new breed of techno-savvy Dominican trafficker: Leonel Fernandez, the country's reformist President. Mr. Fernandez, 44, a lawyer, grew up in Manhattan, where in the 1960's he watched a drug culture emerging around him. It was then, friends say, that he developed an antipathy for narcotics and the corruption they engender.
But as President, Mr. Fernandez must combat a recalcitrant Government bureaucracy and a political opposition that controls the Congress and is becoming increasingly dependent on drug money, American and Dominican officials say.
Those drug profits are finding their way into the economy in this island nation. Office buildings, hotels and shopping centers are springing up in Santo Domingo, Santiago and San Francisco de Macoris -- often in a gaudy style that some describe as narco-deco. Dominican banks have opened branches as far away as Thailand, raising new fears about the growing economic influence of the traffickers.
"There is a process of Colombianization going on," Marino Vinicio Castillo, the outspoken law-and-order crusader whom Mr. Fernandez chose as the leader of his anti-drug program, warned in an interview here. "It is a very serious threat," he said, adding, "The Colombians may not have been able to detect it happening there, but here we can see the narcotics traffickers covertly infiltrating the banking system, political parties and the media."
 
The Safe Drug Channel
A Nation Ill-Equipped Against Traffickers
To hear Mr. Velez and American officials tell it, the Dominican Republic in the mid-1990's was a drug dealer's paradise. Less than 24 hours from Colombia by fast boat, and only 75 miles from Puerto Rico and American territory, this country was forced to rely on a weak, corrupt and ill-equipped military as its main line of defense.
Traffickers were aided, Mr. Velez said, by Colombian military officials, who were routinely selling the coordinates of the American and Dominican vessels on patrol in the Caribbean. With that information in hand, it became a simple matter to land drug cargos of a ton or more on isolated beaches here.
"You can get eight days of information for $5,000," said Mr. Velez, "and I know because I went to Cartagena and saw it happen with my own eyes." His job was to supervise the landings and deliver shipments to a warehouser known to him only as Robocop.
"Without that information, we wouldn't have been able to do what we did."
At that time, as during much of the last three decades, the Dominican Republic was ruled by Joaquin Balaguer. Now 91 and still politically active, Mr. Balaguer came to office after the American invasion of his country in 1965, and kept himself in power through a mixture of guile, rampant voter fraud and other forms of corruption.
But when the Colombians were moving in here, Washington's main policy focus was not on drugs. Instead the Clinton Administration was desperately seeking the Balaguer Government's cooperation with a United Nations economic embargo aimed at toppling the military dictatorship in Haiti, which shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic.
After a come-from-behind victory in a runoff vote, Mr. Fernandez succeeded Mr. Balaguer on Aug. 16, 1996, promising change and less corruption. American officials expressed pleasure, describing him as a Kennedyesque figure who knew the United States intimately and shared the view of trafficking as a menace to both countries.
Cables from the American Embassy in Santo Domingo in late 1996 drew a grim picture of the situation Mr. Fernandez had inherited. One described how corrupt personnel routinely incapacitated airport X-ray machines here to let drugs through. A second cable detailed corruption as "widespread among airport employees, the national police, military security and the army's J-2," the military intelligence division.
From the start, Mr. Fernandez was also hamstrung by his party's weakness in Congress, where it controlled less than a tenth of the seats. He has since faced an uphill fight to cleanse a corrupt bureaucracy, replace judges and prosecutors who delayed and undermined drug cases, and cajole banks to tighten rules aimed at thwarting money launderers.
"Fernandez can only go so far," said John F. Forbes, a senior United States Customs investigator who works on Dominican money-laundering cases. "The head of General Motors can fire people, but the President is stuck with the existing civil service and bureaucracy from 30 years of one-man rule."
The results so far, American and Dominican officials acknowledge, have been mixed.
On the positive side: Dominican drug suspects are for the first time being extradited to the United States; the tiny budgets allotted to anti-drug agencies have been increased; more than 50 properties linked to narcotics-related crimes were seized last year; wiretaps are more widely used to monitor trafficking groups, and a newly appointed high court has been given powers to remove corrupt, incompetent judges from lower courts.
In a report issued in March certifying that the Dominican Republic is cooperating fully with American anti-drug efforts, the State Department noted that under Mr. Fernandez's leadership, "promising reforms began in 1997."
But the department also noted that the Dominican Government "only achieved sporadic seizures" of cocaine and heroin last year, "as it has not adequately motivated its police and military forces to join in the struggle against the illicit drug trade."
Drug Enforcement Administration figures indicate that only 1.2 metric tons of cocaine were seized in the Dominican Republic in 1996, compared with 3.6 metric tons in 1995. Last year, the figure rose slightly, to 1.35 tons, but arrests for drug-related offenses declined, and the impatience of American officials has increased accordingly.
"The fact is that under President Fernandez, not a single drug-related case has been prosecuted," said a State Department official who deals with Dominican policy. And in a recent intelligence report, the Drug Enforcement Administration asserted that "Colombian and Dominican trafficking organizations continue to maximize well-established cocaine routes through the Dominican Republic" and that "heroin trafficking continues to be on the rise."
Meanwhile senior aides to Mr. Fernandez, under pressure from voters demanding that campaign promises to ease poverty and improve public services be fulfilled, are divided as to how much emphasis to put on cooperation with the United States to fight drug trafficking. Mr. Castillo, President Fernandez's drug czar, cited the flow of "narco-dollars" into local political campaigns. He expressed concern that cooperation might become more difficult after crucial elections scheduled for Saturday to choose the legislature that would have to approve any new anti-drug treaties or laws.
Dominican officials say they are doing the best they can with meager resources at their disposal, which are being drained by the need to patrol a long, porous border with Haiti. And they assert that even more drugs flow through the American commonwealth of Puerto Rico than their country.
The country's attorney general, Abel Rodriguez del Orbe, criticized the United States for a "lack of cooperation."
"If we had the proper equipment," he said, "planes with infrared lights, for example, we'd be finished with this plague in a year."
 
The Bend in the River
A Tough New Leader Allows Extradition
At the peak of their criminal careers, Maximo Reyes and Francisco Medina were among the most wanted men in New York City, accused of the contract killings of more than 30 people on behalf of Dominican trafficking groups. With the police closing in, they returned to the Dominican Republic, certain that they were finally beyond the reach of American authorities.
Last August, however, President Fernandez broke with decades of tradition and bypassed the Dominican Congress, signing an executive order that sent the two men back to New York City to face charges. That day, law enforcement authorities in New York City detected a dramatic increase in telephone conversations among Dominican traffickers alarmed that they would no longer enjoy impunity in their homeland.
In a larger sense the episode illustrated the strategy that the Fernandez administration, trying to turn a liability into a strength, has adopted. With limitations on equipment, personnel and spending that weaken its ability to interdict drugs, the Dominican Government has instead decided to use the instruments of law to attack traffickers and curb the enormous profits they make.
"The only thing the cartels fear is extradition," said Mr. Castillo, the country's anti-drug program director. "That is the most powerful tool in the hands of both Governments."
Heartened by Mr. Fernandez's cooperation, the Clinton Administration is now seeking the extradition of more than 30 other Dominicans wanted in the United States. But that process promises to be even more controversial and convoluted, with resistance rising in the Dominican Congress and media coverage against returning those on the list, including the two most prominent, Edmon Elias and Ricardo (Tito) Hernandez, both influential businessmen.
Mr. Elias's interests include casinos as well as hotels and other real estate investments; Mr. Hernandez is an owner of the popular Cibao Eagles baseball team. Both face charges in Miami concerning a Mexican-American named Luis Cano. They are accused of having helped him buy airplanes he reportedly used to smuggle 10 tons of cocaine into the United States.
Mr. Hernandez did not respond to calls requesting comment, but Mr. Elias, in an interview here, denied wrongdoing, calling himself "an enemy of drugs and a friend of the United States" and dismissing the charges as a "fantasy." He acknowledged that he had introduced Mr. Cano to leading Dominicans but said Mr. Cano had gained his confidence under false pretenses.
Still, Dominican law enforcement officials describe the country's casinos, Mr. Elias's among them, as a main mechanism by which drug profits are laundered here. They say that banks, boutiques, businesses, sports betting parlors -- almost all forms of private enterprise -- are being used to turn illicit cash into tangible, legitimate assets.
As a result, Dominican officials and business people say, more and more drug money is flowing in unimpeded. The problem is probably most acute, they maintain, in cities like Santiago and San Francisco de Macoris, in the northern Cibao Valley, birthplace of many of the most notorious Dominican traffickers based in the United States.
For instance Santiago, the country's second-largest city, has in the last two years gained many new businesses like as auto dealerships and hardware stores. That would not be suspicious in itself, since the Cibao Valley is enjoying a tobacco-led economic boom. But many of these new businesses are selling their products below cost.
As one Santiago businessman put it: "How can you buy steel rods or cement blocks in the capital, transport them up here and then sell them for less than you originally paid? There are suddenly a lot of people around who went to New York as nobodies a few years back and have come back with lots and lots of money whose origins no one seems able to explain."
Along the country's north coast, multimillion-dollar weekend homes are also going up. Nor is it unusual to come across expensively protected country mansions adorned with stained glass windows, mock Greco-Roman pillars and tile images of the Virgin of Altagracia, the country's patron saint.
"All this recycled money that can't be traced is creating a new culture," said a lawyer in San Francisco de Macoris. "You go into a restaurant, and there are all these guys wearing ostentatious rings and glittering medallions of the Virgin of Altagracia, flashing big wads of thousand-peso notes and boasting about their big cars outside. It's a new reality that is very disturbing to us and which no one seems able to control."

The Course Yet Uncharted
A Reformer's Future In the Voters' Hands
This week, voters here will go to the polls for elections that Dominican and American officials regard as crucial to the Fernandez Government's success during its two remaining years in office. At the moment, the President's party controls only one of 30 Senate seats and 10 of 120 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, meaning that no legislation can be passed without the backing of at least one of the two main opposition parties.
The Fernandez administration has expressed support for tougher money-laundering legislation and streamlined extradition procedures, which Congress would have to approve to go into effect. So it is obvious why the stakes in the vote are so high. Mr. Castillo, the Dominican anti-drug chief, said trafficking groups here and in New York and Colombia had responded by funneling money into the campaigns of candidates they believe will vote against the proposals.
"This is the greatest problem we face in these elections," he said. "Not only that, narcotics traffickers from New York are putting their own people, by which I mean their brothers and cousins, into the campaigns, and some of the candidates know that."
American officials have long harbored similar suspicions of the Dominican political process. During the 1996 presidential campaign here, in fact, the Drug Enforcement Administration, responding to a Central Intelligence Agency inquiry, took the highly unusual step of organizing a sting operation in the United States against Mr. Fernandez's chief opponent, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, in an effort to determine whether he and his party were involved in drug trafficking.
Mr. Pena Gomez was running well ahead of Mr. Fernandez in election polls when he took his campaign to New York City's large Dominican immigrant community early that year. At a rally at the Washington Heights headquarters of the Dominican Revolutionary Party, or P.R.D., members of his staff were approached by a couple who said they were representatives of a Colombian cocaine cartel but in reality were Drug Enforcement Administration agents working undercover.
The pair offered the Pena Gomez campaign an immediate $50,000 and said $250,000 more would be forthcoming each month if Mr. Pena Gomez, once elected, would agree to let five planeloads of drugs land unobstructed. Such an agreement was already in place with Dominican military and police authorities, they said, urging Mr. Pena Gomez and his aides to check the authenticity of their claim with the officials involved.
One of his New York representatives later met the drug agents at an office at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, but Mr. Pena Gomez eventually rejected the overture, and shortly afterward he sent a letter of protest to President Clinton. American suspicions were again aroused, however, when, just days after Mr. Pena Gomez won the first round of the election and declared himself "virtually president," several of his party members were detained and a shipment of 778 pounds of cocaine seized, according to Dominican officials.
In an interview here, Mr. Pena Gomez attributed the case, which those officials say is still pending, to a political vendetta against his party. "An accusation like this can destroy a person in this country," he said, "and that's what my enemies are trying to do to me. I was the victim of a campaign in which false denunciations were made to middle-level American officials in an effort to involve me in this."
Recent polls indicate Mr. Pena Gomez as favorite in the race next month for mayor of Santo Domingo, the second-most-important elected post in this country. But Mr. Pena Gomez is also suffering from an advanced case of pancreatic cancer. The struggle to succeed him as party leader is already under way, and American and Dominican law enforcement officials said there is ample evidence that some of the contenders are receiving support from drug traffickers.
"The narcotics traffickers don't like to have all their eggs in one basket," a senior Dominican Government official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "And so they donate to all the parties. But the biggest problem is in the P.R.D. We don't like to say that publicly, however, because then people think we are acting from political motives."
In the United States, Federal drug agents and local law enforcement officials have also been looking closely at the party's branches and leaders throughout the Northeastern United States. The drug enforcement agency's documents identify the party's New England headquarters in Worcester, Mass., as a major drug distribution center. They say that local party officials in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, some of whom have previous drug convictions, are also involved in such activities.
Even if the drug traffickers' candidates are defeated, the rings will offer no respite, warned Mr. Velez, the Colombian businessman who is in custody here. The Colombian cartels, having established an enormously lucrative foothold in the Dominican Republic, will stop at nothing to expand it, he said, even if that means "killing judges, lawyers, cops and reporters," as well as ordinary citizens who stand in their way.
"In whatever country they establish themselves," Mr. Velez said, "the cartels get involved in politics and the economy, buying up properties and infiltrating all aspects of public and private activity. That's what's coming here, and this country isn't prepared and doesn't know how to stand up to it. It's going to be a catastrophe."
NEXT: Repercussions in the United States.

HEADLINE: West Puts Pressure on Serbs With a Ban on Investment

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 9

 BODY:
The main Western industrial nations imposed an investment ban on Serbia today and froze its assets abroad as their concern grew about the violence in Kosovo, a southern Serbian province. They also froze the overseas assets of Yugoslavia, which is made up of Serbia and Montenegro.
Foreign and Finance Ministers of the Group of Eight countries, meeting here as part of the summit meeting in Birmingham next week, called for urgent discussions between Belgrade and the Albanian leadership in Kosovo, where Albanians make up 90 percent of the population. 
 Because Yugoslavia's leader, Slobodan Milosevic, has not met conditions set by the West to withdraw special police forces from Kosovo and begin negotiations, the sanctions were approved by all the countries meeting here today except Russia and Japan.
Russia, a traditional ally of Serbia, opposes the sanctions outright; Japan said it would study the measure. Britain, the United States, France, Italy, Germany, and Canada all supported the sanctions.
To help bring the message home to Mr. Milosevic, the Clinton Administration has sent Richard C. Holbrooke, a banker who helped negotiate the Dayton accords to end the war in Bosnia, and Robert S. Gelbard, the American special representative to the Balkans, to warn the Yugoslav President of the dangers of civil war breaking out in Kosovo and spreading.
In the past, Mr. Holbrooke has had mixed success in persuading Mr. Milosevic to bend to the will of the United States, which is seeking a form of enhanced political autonomy for Kosovo within Serbia.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sharply criticized Mr. Milosevic today for rejecting talks with the Albanians in Kosovo.
She expressed regret over Russia's opposition to the new sanctions, but said the measures would "significantly hamper Belgrade's ability to fund its repressive policies." Even Russia, she said, agreed that "the situation in Kosovo is unacceptable."
In their final communique, issued today, the Foreign Ministers made clear that they do not support independence for Kosovo.
Together with the Finance Ministers, they also spent much time on issues of nuclear safety; controlling the spread of dangerous materials, weapons and technology; developments in Iran, and regional investment, aid and debt-relief initiatives in Africa.
They also expressed the hope, Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain said, that Israel would agree to American proposals for a West Bank withdrawal and allow talks on a final settlement with the Palestinians to begin in Washington on Monday. Israelis should consider what might happen "if America and others are not encouraged to believe that efforts to assist in the progress will be rewarded with cooperation," Mr. Cook warned.
Ms. Albright said she remained hopeful that the Israeli Cabinet, which meets on Sunday, would make it possible for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, whom she again praised for his "constructive ideas," to go to Washington.
In their private discussions, the seven Finance Ministers (Russia does not take part) spent most of their time on the shaky prospects for Indonesia, and how best to present a united view to President Suharto for the need to continue economic and political reforms.
Officials said the ministers were troubled by political unrest in Indonesia and by how much Mr. Suharto is "internalizing" the need to continue on the path laid out by the International Monetary Fund and Western governments.
In a speech here today, the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said that "in Asia, we are beginning to see a return to financial stability in a number of the countries affected by the recent crisis." But he emphasized that Japan in particular must push for structural reform to boost its lagging economy.
In their final communique, the Foreign Ministers also welcomed "recent encouraging political developments in Iran," and urged the country "to build on this and play a more constructive role in world affairs."

HEADLINE: Workfare Lacks the Vision of Roosevelt's W.P.A.;
Remember Bread Lines?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Surely Mickey Kaus must be joking (Op-Ed, May 5). Franklin D. Roosevelt created the Works Progress Administration in the face of gross unemployment, not the "abuse" of a welfare system. 
 It was a major program of public works to create decent jobs for people whose only crime was that the Depression put them on bread lines.
Roosevelt did not conspire to undermine other workers.
There were literally no other workers.
 
LARRY SOLWAY
Toronto, May 5, 1998

HEADLINE: Warren Beatty Is Trying to Say Something

BYLINE: By Lynn Hirschberg; Lynn Hirschberg is a contributing writer to the magazine. She has written about Quentin Tarantino, Tom Ford and Jamie Tarses, among others.

 BODY:
There was no one moment when Warren Beatty decided not to run for President. In the late 60's and early 70's, he was greatly distracted and intrigued by Presidential politics, working on the short-lived campaign of Robert Kennedy in 1968 and then, in 1972, for George McGovern. "I enjoyed the tumult," he recalls. "Partly it was because it didn't have to do with the work that I did." But he was never really tempted to run himself, for President or anything else. "I've never seriously found it attractive," he says. "Everyone who has any involvement with politics thinks about what it would be like to be stuck with having to get elected."
Beatty long ago decided he wasn't going to get stuck doing anything. He is, and has long been, a movie star, and he has used the power of that office to insure he would never have to do anything less than what he wanted to do. He would produce and direct his own movies as well as star in them. He would make movies when he wanted to -- only seven in the last 20 years. And in an era that would see the political center move to the right, he would make movies rooted in the ideas of the cultural and political left: "Reds" (1981), a sweeping romance about John Reed and the American Communists caught up in the Russian Revolution, and now "Bulworth," a dark comedy about race and class in America, in which Beatty plays a corrupt Democratic Senator from California who, just days before an election, remakes himself as a rapping radical populist. 
 About all this -- his politics, and how they find their way into his movies -- he would rather not say too much. Attention of this sort makes him squirm, and like any good politician, he dodges inquiry. Beatty is much more comfortable asking questions than answering them. "Why do I feel like making movies instead of getting votes from people?" Beatty asked one afternoon late last month, just a couple of weeks before "Bulworth" had its opening in New York and Los Angeles. He is in an empty suite at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. He is wearing all black -- black T-shirt, black exercise pants, black sneakers -- and he is munching on a carrot stick from the room-service tray. "Well, the thought of having to buckle down and get things done in a political sense does not strike me as a thoroughly enjoyable endeavor. It's more fun to say what you think."
Much of what "Bulworth" says is what Beatty thinks. "Bulworth" says, among other things, that America is divided by class, that elected officials serve mostly the interests of the rich and that black America has been ravaged by the globalization of the economy. This is not what the majority of Americans think or what the Democratic Party, with which Beatty has a life-long involvement, thinks.
"I would never know if I'm going to have impact," he says, rolling up a slice of smoked turkey. "That's not my goal. It can't be. I think things and I'm lucky enough to be in a profession where I can express them."
But isn't the point to have an impact? Why do something political if the goal isn't to change things?
He answers, after a long pause, with a different question, his question. "The question is," he says, "When you have the freedom to make choices, what do you do? What are the choices that you make?"
Warren Beatty is seductive, and it's not just a sex thing. With Beatty -- and it is said that this is the key to Bill Clinton as well -- it's all about interest, his interest in you. He will ask about your mother, where you were born, your politics, your father's politics. And he will remember the answers, link them up, connect the dots.
I first spoke to Beatty last fall. "Good evening," he purred into the phone. It was late morning. His voice -- light, insinuating, sly but disarming -- is all midnight. Years ago, when he was in his 20's, he would begin calls with "What's new, pussycat?" and you can see how this would work. Initially, he wouldn't talk at all about "Bulworth" -- nor would he volunteer anything. "If you have something to hide," he told me once, "then hide it."
Occasionally, when pressed, he would confide some bit of nonconfidential information, like a change in the release date of the film. More typically, he would simply find a way -- a polite, nonconfrontational way -- of not answering a question. At one late-night meal at the Apple Pan, in West Los Angeles, Beatty sat at the counter and ate a hickory burger, fries and a tuna-fish sandwich (very deftly). I asked him if he'd ever slept with Brigitte Bardot. He stared, took a bite and never answered. "Is this off the record?" he finally asked.
Even when he is saying nothing, he is saying something. Beatty is a study in counterpoint. He's physically manic -- he jumps up, sits down, stretches his legs, drums the table, fidgets -- but he can lull you with his voice. A comb falls out of his pocket, but he's tousled and boyish and wears the same clothes for weeks. He bores in on a conversation but often seems to be answering a question that someone else asked a few days ago. What comes across most, perhaps, is that Beatty is one of the least angry people I have met. Working and socializing in Hollywood, a town full of feuds, he has nothing awful to say about anyone. He sees no point. Instead, he tries to understand. He asks. He asks.
All this questioning, while seductive, is a little unnerving. You begin to wonder, as people must about Clinton, how much of it is genuine interest and how much of it is reflexive charm. To charm is to be gracefully distant -- to remain in control. As Beatty studies the artifacts of my life as if they were long-lost Mayan ruins, his attentiveness seems genuine. But is it real? Or is this Beatty the politician, working hard to get my vote?
It's March 30, Warren Beatty's 61st birthday, and he's celebrating with a trip to the South Bronx with his wife, the actress Annette Bening, and some friends for a test screening of "Bulworth." Beatty has a lot invested in this project. He co-produced, co-wrote, directed and stars in the movie. He is test-screening it in the South Bronx because places like the South Bronx are what the movie is concerned with.
As Senator J. Billington Bulworth, Warren Beatty talks a lot about racial and class divisions. At the beginning of the film, the Senator is alone in his office on Capitol Hill, sunk in a deep depression watching his own TV ads, in which he asks for the votes of middle-class whites by preaching racial code: family values. Self-loathing and suicidal, Bulworth arranges to have himself assassinated while campaigning in Los Angeles on the weekend before election day.
The pending hit sets him free -- he drops his stump speech about the millennium, with its clear echoes of Clintonian bridge building, and starts preaching populism. At first his speeches are largely aimed at Washington and the electoral process -- the corrupting power of campaign contributions. But at a church stop in South-Central Los Angeles, Bulworth meets a beautiful young black woman, Nina (played by Halle Berry), and falls in love. Revitalized by this woman and his rediscovered political voice, Bulworth tries to call off the hit and begins talking more and more about racial injustice, first in fitful rhyme and then, soon enough, in pure inner-city rap.
"Rap music is the language of social protest," Beatty explains on the phone from the van as he heads to the South Bronx. "He who fails to listen, fails to hear at his own peril."
The message Bulworth raps is funny and outrageous. It is also unlike anything in America's discourse about race. It is certainly not about welfare reform or taking a hard look at affirmative action; but neither is it about the kind of identity politics you find on the cultural left. During one CNN-like appearance, Bulworth raps about how average white people really have more in common with black people than with rich whites. In one of the movie's most intimate scenes, the Senator and Nina stare into each other's eyes and discuss the lack of black leaders -- how when blue-collar jobs got exported to Korea and Thailand and so on, blacks lost not only employment but also their place in the political structure.
"The picture has. . .a message," says Beatty, still on the phone in the van. "My political conduct has changed. I now think as a person who deals in mass media. I don't think I'd be very effective in practical politics, the way I used to be with Bobby Kennedy or George McGovern. But you can say things in a movie. You can say black people are treated badly in the United States. It's an oversimplification but it needs to be said. You can say rich people control politics. It's an oversimplification but it needs to be said.
"I'm in the entertainment business," he goes on to say. "The message happens to be true, but any time you try to have a message in a movie, you sound like you're on C-Span. Listen, I have a lunatic in this movie who has a nervous breakdown, runs around in short pants, acts like an adolescent, talking in a voice that's not even his own. He oversimplifies the message pretty drastically, but he's funny. I tried to make it funny enough and move it quickly enough so they don't walk out."
As always, Beatty is canny. "Reds" may have been about radicals, but it was also a dramatic love story. "Shampoo" (1975) may have been about Nixon-era sexual and political deceit, but it was wildly entertaining. "Bulworth" may be brimming with indignation over racial strife and political compromise, but it is full of laughs. "It doesn't work unless they laugh," he says. "The intention is always to entertain."
Around 3 in the afternoon on a day in early April, two black female singers are rehearsing a gospel song in a recording studio on the 20th Century Fox lot in Los Angeles. This song will be added to "Bulworth," replacing some singing that Beatty isn't quite satisfied with, and these two women have the rather complicated task of matching their vocal intonations to those of the actresses singing in the film. The movie should have been finished by now, but it isn't. Beatty is off somewhere, talking on the phone.
"W. F. W.," jokes one of the sound editors. "Waiting for Warren. We do quite a lot of that." Moments later, Beatty bursts in, wearing the all-black outfit he'd wear most days I saw him this spring, and looking, as he often does, a mix of preoccupied, overwhelmed and excited. He hugs one of the female singers and inquires about the other's pregnancy. "Do you want to hear?" the first woman asks. Beatty raises an eyebrow -- with Beatty, a flirt is always possible -- and he coos, yes, let's hear.
Beatty stands while they sing, rocking back and forth, studying the film projected behind them. The scene they're synching takes place in a restrained all-white church, and the joke, like most of the humor in "Bulworth," is about racial contrast: these two black girls let loose with full-bodied gospel voices while the stuffy white congregation looks on in discomfort.
When Beatty set up the deal for "Bulworth" in 1992, he did not mention to Fox, the only studio he pitched, that the movie would be set in the rap world. He did not mention that he would play a politician or that there would be an interracial love story. He sold the idea on a simple, high-concept premise: a man pays someone to kill him, then falls in love and tries to call off the murder. "I thought it was a good idea," recalls Joe Roth, who, as chairman at 20th Century Fox, made the initial deal with Beatty for "Bulworth." (Roth is now chairman at Walt Disney Studios.) "And as long as he didn't exceed the budget, which was $32 million or $34 million, he could do what he wanted. Beatty has final cut."
Control was crucial to Beatty. "I wanted to have complete freedom to do what I wanted to do," Beatty recalls. "I always felt I would set it in this world, but I didn't want to be influenced by commercial considerations. I wanted to do a movie about contemporary politics because I felt I knew it better than other people in the movie business."
Beatty became fascinated with the world of rap music about 10 years ago. Through his friend Bobby Shriver, a producer and the nephew of Robert Kennedy, he met two of rap's leading black impresarios, Russell Simmons, who runs Def Jam Records, and later, Suge Knight, the controversial chief executive of Death Row Records, who is currently serving a nine-year prison term for violating his parole by beating up a man in a Las Vegas casino. Simmons recalls sending Beatty videotapes of "Def Comedy Jam," an HBO series. "He wanted to see everything," Simmons says. "He would watch them unedited. He wanted to know everything about the rap world -- he'd ask the same question three times sideways. He'd call me in the middle of the night to ask me who Cheryl Underwood is. She was a comedian on one of the 'Def Comedy' tapes and I didn't even know.
"Once, I went to his house with Bobby Shriver and a date," Simmons goes on to say, "and it was us and Annette and Warren and we had this long dinner and, finally, Annette went to sleep and my date was dozing off but we sat for hours and hours. He's such a charming person that you don't mind all the questions."
Knight, too, would travel up to Beatty's house in the hills above Los Angeles. Unlike Simmons, who was raised in Hollis, Queens, Knight was from Compton, the tough South-Central neighborhood where Beatty planned to set "Bulworth." Knight and his gangster-rap record label, Death Row, also had an outlaw reputation -- guns and drugs and pit bulls -- and he was impressed by Beatty, by the outlaw roles he'd played in "Bonnie and Clyde" (1967) and "Bugsy" (1991).
But it was mostly Beatty's reputation as a world-class romancer of women that gave him street credibility in the rap world. "Warren Beatty is a mack," Simmons explains. By "mack," he means a "mack daddy" -- a smooth, big-time lady's man. "He's been with a lot of women," Simmons says admiringly.
Beatty and Knight spent a lot of time together. "Suge, who is always at least four hours late, would show up on time for Beatty," recalls a former Death Row employee. "He was honored by the association." Beatty was intrigued by Knight's world and pumped him for information. By the time he began writing the script in 1996, Beatty was saturated in rap culture.
Simmons is not troubled by Beatty making a movie about black ghetto life. Blacks, he says, "don't care that he plays a rapper in this movie, but everybody likes everybody doing certain things. They would rather see him as Bugsy."
Probably the people at 20th Century Fox would share that sentiment. It will be interesting, to say the least, to see what Rupert Murdoch, the right-wing media baron who owns the studio, makes of "Bulworth" and its politics -- especially the Senator's raps about communications-industry monopolies. "Every time I see Rupert Murdoch," Beatty says, "he is extremely nice and says, 'When can I see your movie?' I look at my watch and say, 'What time would you like to see it?' "
Even as the movie was being screened two weeks before its May 8 opening in New York and Hollywood, Murdoch had not, to the best of Beatty's knowledge, gone to any screenings. Fox also seemed to be avoiding preparing a marketing plan for the movie. There were no television commercials on the air, no advance advertising.
"Bulworth," even with its relatively modest budget, is a commercial risk. "The audience is ghettoized," says a studio head who wishes to remain anonymous for fear of seeming to sound racist. "Blacks go to certain movies and whites go to others. How many white people saw 'The Players Club'?" (It was set in South-Central and directed by the rapper Ice Cube.) "How many black people went to see 'The English Patient'?"
But then, Beatty is Beatty -- a star, and also, as people in Hollywood will tell you, a very smart producer. And a perfectionist: in the recording studio, after the girls finish up their gospel number, Beatty asks the engineers if he can rerecord part of his dialogue, a rap that Bulworth delivers during an interview on national television. They say sure, and the image of Bulworth is projected on the screen. He is wearing cutoff sweat pants, a red T-shirt, a black stocking cap pulled low, narrow sunglasses and a three-day growth of beard; and he is rhyming: "That's the real obscenity/ black folks living every day/ Is tryin' to believe a expletive word/ Democrats and Republicans say."
Repeating the rap quietly to himself, Beatty is completely focused. He clears his throat and singsongs the rap in an angry, growly voice. He does it again. And again. Two days later, he will go back to his original take, but this afternoon he wants to get the message across exactly as he hears it in his head. "Was that loud enough?" Beatty asks. "I want it loud."
When Beatty likes someone, thinks they're smart, attractive, handsome, clever, perceptive, whatever, he will say they're funny. Funny. That's his all-purpose adjective. As in his thoughts on his ex-great love and still great friend Julie Christie: "She makes me laugh. She's funny." Or his opinion of Ronald Reagan: "A funny guy." Sometimes he will elaborate. "I showed 'Reds' to Reagan," Beatty recalls. "I always had a good time with Reagan. He was very funny about the movie. He's an actor, and he was very impressed that I had done all those jobs on the movie and still acted in it. He said he wished the movie had a happy ending." They discussed the marbling of meat and how, in "Reds," Beatty had botched a joke. "He was funny," Beatty says. "Reagan was funny."
He often says someone's funny, in lieu of saying anything else. An example: I say, "Oliver Stone wanted to cast you as Nixon." "Uh-huh," Beatty responds. He pauses, seems to remember an amusing moment he has no intention of sharing, then says, "Oliver is funny."
Beatty gravitates toward funny. He wrote a part for the actor Oliver Platt in "Bulworth" because "I thought he was funny." He entertained the notion of playing the pornographer Burt Reynolds eventually played in "Boogie Nights" because he found the director, Paul Thomas Anderson, "funny."
"Funny" can mean talented, it can mean gorgeous, it can mean anything. Only Beatty knows. The way he uses it, "funny" is an inexplicable compliment, but a compliment all the same. You never know what he really thinks; "funny" encompasses all.
Beatty and Bening and their three children live in a large white Spanish house in the hills above Beverly Hills. Beatty lived for years in a suite at the Beverly Wilshire hotel until after he made "Shampoo," when he built a white glass house with spectacular views on Mulholland Drive. The house collapsed in the 1992 earthquake. The new house, although beautiful, feels empty, temporary. There's very little furniture, and the children and Bening are away in New York. (She is filming a movie.) It's late, around 10 P.M., and Beatty, again in the all-black ensemble, is eating dinner.
The white dining-room table is covered with small, lighted candles and Beatty is tearing into his corn chowder, the first course of many, with his usual gusto. The phone rings every 10 or 15 minutes, and Randy Ledarman, his cook, has twice passed him a note with a name on it. "Does he need me?" Beatty says, pondering one such name. A pause. He abandons his soup and jumps up to return the call.
In the Beatty universe, it is now as it has been: they were always calling and he was always eating a four-course meal. He has been famous for so long, since his first movie, "Splendor in the Grass," in 1961, when he was 24, that he can't even remember a time when he wasn't known. "After that movie, I was like Leonardo DiCaprio is now," he says, having returned to the table and his soup. "Dustin always says to me, 'You've been famous longer than you've been a person.' I'm in there 10 years before Dustin or Jack or Redford or any of those guys."
In a way, he was famous even before he was known to the world. Growing up in Arlington, Va., Beatty was president of his class and a football star. "I was a center and a linebacker," Beatty recalls. "I learned more from football than anything else. I couldn't con anyone into anything. I was there with the tackle or the block or I wasn't. There was no choice. You just had to do it."
Beatty's father, Ira, was an educational psychologist and a public-school administrator, and his mother, Kathlyn, taught dramatics and directed plays put on by local amateur drama groups. His sister, the actress Shirley MacLaine, danced and performed as a child, but Beatty did not show any interest in the theater until he attended Northwestern University. He found he loved it. "I stopped playing football," he says now. "I was in the process of consigning myself to a more effete way of life."
He visited New York after his freshman year and never returned to college. "I was having such a good time," Beatty says. "I decided to study acting. I went to Stella Adler. And she liked me. A lot. She convinced me that I was a good actor."
To film a TV show, Beatty came to Los Angeles in 1958; he was impressed. "I liked L. A. from the get-go," he recalls, starting in on an artichoke. "I stayed a week, two weeks, something like that and, finally, I thought, All right, I'll make a movie deal. I went under contract to MGM. I was rolling in money. Four hundred dollars a week. I was not used to this kind of money. It coincided with a certain liberalization of my life style. I was having a very good time."
For a while, Beatty was content being a boy about town, but soon, he says, he came to a realization: "I wasn't doing anything that meant anything." A meeting at MCA, which was representing him, changed all that. William Inge, who would later write "Splendor in the Grass," was at that meeting. "They asked me why I was not doing a play," Beatty recalls. "I said, 'Because it's not fun, it's work doing a play.' And they said, 'Are you afraid of work?' By the end of the conversation, I realized I had to get out of California."
He borrowed $2,600 from MCA, bought his way out of his five-year MGM contract and returned to New York, where he did an Inge play called "A Loss of Roses." It was not a success, but the director Elia Kazan saw Beatty in the play and cast him in "Splendor in the Grass."
Randy appears with the main course of fish and pasta, and the conversation shifts. "From the beginning," Beatty says, "I definitely had some feeling that if I was to go out and just take the gigs and do the press and be in the public eye, I wouldn't live much of a life. I would live a pretend life of story after story on celluloid, and I didn't want to do that."
Beatty's fame allowed him access to many worlds and he was (and is) an avid collector of worlds. When he speaks about the last fashion show he attended, he was in the company of the legendary editor Diana Vreeland. (She was my buddy.") "Do you know Kissinger?" he'll ask, by way of introducing an anecdote about the former Secretary of State.
Beatty says that he does not simply seek out famous people but only those who interest him. "I'll give you an example," he says, twirling some pasta. At my first big Hollywood party, I looked across the room and saw Rita Hayworth. It was before 'Splendor in the Grass' and I. . .stared. She was dancing with a guy with floppy shoes. She got a little closer and she was looking at me and I'm looking at her and she's looking at me and, finally, I said, 'You're Rita Hayworth,' and she said, 'You're Warren Beatty.' I said, 'How did you know that?' And the guy with the floppy shoes said, 'I told her.' I said, 'Hello, I'm Warren Beatty,' and the man with the floppy shoes said, 'I'm Clifford Odets.' And at that point, you could have airbrushed Rita Hayworth out of the picture because he was Clifford Odets. I said, 'Can I talk to you?' Odets was my hero."
Through Odets, Beatty goes on to say, he met Jean Renoir, the great French director of "Grand Illusion" and "Rules of the Game." "I've always been a guy who stays up late," he says. "And I like to talk to people. I like talking as much as. . .many things." He laughs. "As an actor, I passed on a lot of good pictures. But if I'd done them, I couldn't have stayed out till 4 in the morning in different cities around the world."
Beatty revered Odets because he thought his plays were full of political insight. No matter that when Beatty met him he was living in Beverly Hills and rewriting Elvis Presley movies. Odets, to Beatty, was still an artist with a conscience. He would much rather stay up all night talking politics than romance a famed Hollywood star. (Or maybe he could do both, but that's a story he's not about to tell.)
Beatty's introduction to electoral politics was Bobby Kennedy's brief campaign in '68. "I felt that I was living in my time," he recalls. "I remember Cary Grant saying to me when I asked him why he didn't want to make one more movie, 'Why would I go and trip over a lot of cables?' He knew that how you appear to be in front of a camera is not who you are."
It was through his connections to people who had worked for Kennedy that Beatty became involved with the McGovern campaign. He traveled with McGovern, giving speeches on his behalf in small towns in New Hampshire and Florida. His biggest contribution to the campaign may have been the five fund-
raising concerts he organized. For the one held at Madison Square Garden, he convinced Simon and Garfunkel to reunite and perform. The concerts raised a million dollars -- in those days a staggering sum -- for the campaign.
Gary Hart was McGovern's campaign manager, and he and Beatty, who were born less than six months apart, formed a close bond. (Beatty also met Bill Clinton during the McGovern campaign.) When Hart sought the Democratic nomination in 1984, Beatty was one of his closest advisers. Many have said that Hart wanted to be Beatty -- that he envied and emulated Beatty, who was then single, and his movie-star life full of women, money and luxury. Beatty has repeatedly refuted this assessment, claiming it's much more complicated that that.
In any case, it was Beatty who persuaded Hart to reenter the race for the '88 Presidential nomination after the Donna Rice scandal drove him out in the spring of '87. Hart's bid failed, and some feel that his flameout spelled the end of Beatty's intense involvement in politics. "You could say," Beatty told the author Ronald Brownstein after Hart withdrew from the race, "that what a man has to do to obtain public office is to destroy himself."
One suspects that a good deal of what Beatty learned from Senator Hart was used to create the despondent Senator Bulworth. One suspects too that Hart's travails and burdens led Beatty to better appreciate the freedom of the movies. And yet, he is nervous about "Bulworth" finding its audience. The movie is scheduled to open wide, on 2,000 screens across the nation, later this month, opposite "Godzilla," the summer's monster, which will open on 6,000 screens. Beatty fears his smallish movie with a political message, unless properly marketed, will be crushed.
"The movie culture is totally dependent on TV advertising," he says. "That's the whole thing. And what that has done is decimate anything that is not already known." Beatty pauses. "You could say this is all very democratic. Or you could say that the public votes with their feet. But it doesn't have a lot to do with movies as a near art form. It causes everybody to trim their sails. And that's true in every other phase of life. It's true in politics. You can't succeed unless you're espousing things people already know."
So why try? "Did I tell you what John Huston said at that gin game with Willy Wyler and Sam Spiegel?" Beatty asks, providing, again, his own question to answer. "They were all in their 80's and someone said: 'We're really old. If there's one thing you could still have, what would it be?' They went around the table and Wyler and Spiegel said: 'Food! Women!' When they got to John Huston, he said, 'To be interested.' " Beatty pauses. "Now, I'm not near the age of John Huston, but at a certain point you realize you do what you're interested in. Interest is all that really matters."
"Do you know how Lenin met with people?" Beatty is saying. It's around 4 p.m. and he's in yet another empty suite at the Carlyle Hotel. He's still wearing the black, still eating carrots off a room-service tray. "This is how." He jumps up, pulling a straight-back chair opposite me. He sits down, so that our knees are touching, placing his hands flat on my legs. He holds the pose. "They say," Beatty says with a grin, "that his interviews were not long."
Beatty laughs and pulls his chair back. A few hours ago, Paula Jones's sexual-harassment case against President Clinton was thrown out, and this seems to have put Beatty in a good mood, although he will not admit that. Earlier, he was flipping around the TV, looking for some coverage of the event. The networks had gone back to their regular programming and all Beatty could find was a very pretty blond lawyer on ABC who seemed very earnest but not terribly well informed. Baffled yet intrigued, Beatty studied her presentation. Naturally, he would not say anything harsh, but he kept chuckling, as if to say, This is the movie, this is what I was getting at in "Bulworth."
When I ask him, flat-out, what's wrong with America, he answers: Those of us in politics, culture and business whose high standing empowers us to lead, are, in fact, led by public-opinion polling in order to maintain our standing. We follow rather than lead. So, our politics and culture don't develop. They stagnate. What doesn't stagnate is business. The profits go to the upper class, whose advertising money has itself formed public opinion. And the classes are pushed further and further apart." This is the essence of Beatty's new movie, his mission statement.

PUB-DATE: May 10, 1998,
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 14; Page 8; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL;
Circular Makes the Rounds and Residents Complain

BYLINE: By ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY 

 BODY:
Last month, Sandy Balboza set out to do some spring cleaning. She and a few neighbors got about 200 Boerum Hill residents to sign a petition calling on The Marketeer, a free weekly advertising circular, to cease its "indiscriminate littering of our neighborhood."
"I was annoyed a long time before that," said Ms. Balboza, who lives on Atlantic Avenue and is the president of the Atlantic Avenue Betterment Association. She said she had called The Marketeer's office several times to get delivery stopped and was unsuccessful. So she asked for help from Ralph Perfetto, the Democratic leader in the 52d Assembly District and an ombudsman in the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. 
 Mr. Perfetto got the drive moving. He drafted the petition and delivered it to the Sheepshead Bay office of The Marketeer on April 21. And given his ombudsman role, his involvement may raise the stakes of the controversy beyond Boerum Hill.
"We're using the Atlantic Avenue corridor as a pilot project," Mr. Perfetto said. "If we're successful here, than I'll start with other areas."
Mr. Perfetto said that his ombudsman office gets complaints from all over the city about circulars, menus and the like, as well as about the littering summonses that addressees sometimes get from the Sanitation Department. "The worst problem is calls from senior citizens with their little brooms in front of their homes," Mr. Perfetto said.
In the Boerum Hill controversy, which was reported late last month by The Park Slope Paper, the petitioners have put forth several ways The Marketeer can tighten up on distribution. "You must sign up to get it," is what Ms. Balboza prefers. Mr. Prefetto suggests that only as many circulars be delivered to a building as there are households inside, and that The Marketeer make sure people who don't want the publication don't get it.
Mr. Perfetto added: "I don't want to hurt the people making minimum wage who do the delivering, nor the store owners who advertise. But we want to stop the indiscriminate delivering."
Has the petition changed The Marketeer's policies? "No," said Jerry Mallach, the publisher, who said his company does maintain a do-not-distribute list. "We're not going to force-feed them," he said.
The Marketeer has been landing on Boerum Hill stoops only for six months, Mr. Mallach said. The paper is already distributed throughout Brooklyn and Staten Island.
Delivered in a clear plastic bag, the weekly has a circulation of 500,000. Its advertisers include small businesses and large chains like Caldor, Pathmark and Sears.
"We deliver a neat package," Mr. Mallach said. "And we keep the local economy strong. Where else can the pizza man with a shop on Third Avenue get 30,000 families to find out about his pizzas?" ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY

He is an ombudsman in the office of the city's Public Advocate, not the Department of Consumer Affairs.

HEADLINE: Adrift in the Global Economy

BYLINE: By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten, an Under Secretary of Commerce from 1993 to 1995, is dean of the Yale School of Management. He is the author of "The Big Ten: The Big Emerging Markets and How They Will Change Our Lives."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
When the heads of state of the top industrial nations hold their annual summit meeting this week in Birmingham, England, one of their most important tasks will be to figure out how to prevent another Asian-type crisis. Unfortunately, they cannot succeed.
This is not to say the leaders cannot shore up parts of the world economy. They can start designing what Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, call a "new architecture" for global finance -- including tighter regulation and more extensive disclosure of financial statistics in emerging markets. They can create the conditions for a more effective International Monetary Fund. They can even propose experimenting with controls on short-term investments that can destabilize developing nations by moving in and out of markets with startling speed. 
 But even if all these ideas are carried out, the problems threatening the global economy will not go away, because the international financial system has become crisis-prone over the last two decades. In the early 1980's, the Latin American debt bomb was detonated, and in 1987 stock markets crashed around the world. In the 1990's, Japan's bubble burst, the European monetary system nearly collapsed, and Mexico needed a bailout of unprecedented size. The East Asian meltdown is only the latest in a series of financial collapses.
Although no one can predict where the next crisis might come from or precisely when it will happen, there are at least four reasons to suspect trouble is on the way.
First, the combination of explosive growth in world trade, direct foreign investment and cross-border trading in stocks and bonds has created an ever tighter web of connections among countries, all of which are in very different stages of development. The network is highly vulnerable to its many weak links.
Start with Japan, the world's second largest economy. Its problems include $600 billion or more in bad debts, dragging down the banking system, as well as shrinking industrial production, sagging consumer confidence and a political system that is all but paralyzed. China, too, is potentially at risk. While Beijing has carried out many important reforms, it has yet to tackle a banking system that is as insolvent as Japan's, and it has yet to close down thousands of bloated state companies, a move that would result in the layoff of tens of millions of workers.
Then there is Brazil. Its economy, which constitutes 40 percent of South America's gross domestic product, has an overvalued currency and a large budget deficit, the kinds of imbalances that could cause foreign speculators to pull out. And the fate of the new European currency is creating nail-biting uncertainty in currency markets.
The global economy is vulnerable to wild market swings, too. In the last five years, the American balance-of-payments deficit has risen by more than 100 percent, while Europe's surplus has grown fivefold. In the last three years the American dollar has risen 60 percent against the yen. Meanwhile, the total amount of capital flowing to Southeast Asia dropped to $12 billion from $93 billion from 1996 to 1997. In an ever smaller international marketplace, these sharp course changes are akin to major storms in a big ocean, and emerging markets, being small boats, could be easily capsized.
A second reason for concern is that financial regulation lags well behind the phenomenal expansion in banking and in securities trading. More money is moving around the world than ever before, in more complicated ways and at ever faster rates. Take the $1.5 trillion in foreign exchange dealings that occur each day and the tenfold increase in private capital that has moved to emerging markets since 1989, not to mention the trillions of dollars of so-called derivatives, including options, futures and swaps.
If this were all that was happening, regulators in each nation would have a hard enough time. But the supervisory agencies face additional uncertainties. In the United States the rules separating banking, securities underwriting and insurance are being rewritten, while in Britain, regulatory agencies are being merged into one Securities and Investment Board, and in Japan there is extensive deregulation of financial services. In this unsettled environment, there are too many complicated moving parts, and no one is minding the entire global store.
A third cause for alarm is the so-called emerging economies. These nations have yet to meet the awesome challenge of building economic and social systems able to deal with global capitalism. Virtually all of them lack antitrust laws, bankruptcy courts, patent and copyright protection and a history of effective corporate governance. It will take at least a generation for these countries to develop a culture of objective credit assessment to replace the typical take-care-of-your-family-and-friends ethos. The most serious threats to financial stability occur when an economic and political system is in transition -- as is the condition today in Asia, Latin America and the former Communist countries. We can expect all manner of booms and busts in the emerging markets, with global fallout.
 Finally, while the financial playing field is supposedly more sophisticated now, investors and lenders are no smarter today than in the past. They take the same risks that traders always have, whether in the early 1700's, when European financial wizards went broke investing in the South Sea Company, a speculative real estate venture, in the prolonged spree of the 1920's that led to the crash, or in the current Asian debacle.
Similar features recur in all these crises. To begin with, there is good news, and confidence rises. Then more lenders and investors appear on the scene, attracted by the new opportunities.
Soon, optimism turns to euphoria, and new theories emerge to justify why this particular business cycle will not have a downswing or why these super-high valuations aren't really excessive. (Remember how in the 1970's lending to Latin America exploded on the theory that sovereign nations couldn't go broke? Or how just before the '87 crash, experts declared junk bonds and highly leveraged companies to be the wave of our financial future?) At last, a troublesome event -- a default, or a change in investor sentiment -- causes the bubble to burst, and everyone rushes for the exit. The pattern has hardly varied.
Today two new developments reinforce it further. Computers now insure that investors, traders and bankers have instant real-time information. As a result, hundreds of billions of dollars move by keystroke in response to a rumor, thereby worsening the damage caused by lemming-like financial behavior. Also, lenders have become emboldened to take ever greater risks with increasing sums of money because they believe -- with good reason -- that in a crisis Uncle Sam and the I.M.F. will bail them out to limit global fallout.
None of these factors should deter the leaders at this week's summit meeting from doing the best that can be done now. But down the road they'll have to do more, like stabilize exchange rates among major countries and establish real global financial regulation. For the time being our leaders resemble King Canute, who, in the old legend, tried vainly to hold back the tides. As things now stand, the global economy will not be submerged, but we're all going to get wet for a long time to come.
