HEADLINE: Filmmakers Optimistic On Summer

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, May 10

 BODY:
The summer movie season opened this weekend with a catastrophe that delighted Hollywood. "Deep Impact," the disaster film about a colossal comet the size of New York City hurtling to Earth, opened the season with an unexpectedly strong box office.
The film received mixed reviews, and the expected box-office take of more than $41 million was seen by executives and producers not only as a positive omen for the summer, when Hollywood releases more than 100 movies, but also as a powerful indication that moviegoers have been eagerly awaiting the season. Producers of the film also saw it as the beneficiary of some smart marketing. 
 "There's been a paucity of big pictures, and Paramount wisely put together a trailer for this film that showed with 'Titanic' -- and it played and played and played," said Richard D. Zanuck, who produced the film with David Brown.
Terry Press, the marketing chief of Dreamworks, which financed the $80 million film with Paramount, said: "The movie was intended to jump-start the summer season, and it has. It's been a long time since there's been a big movie. And I think people are captivated by the trailer and TV spot showing New York being decimated by a tidal wave. Let's face it, any time you wipe out New York or L.A., people love it."
Several executives said that the film had, essentially, two weeks to make the bulk of its money at the box office before the opening of "Godzilla," the most lavishly promoted film of the summer. The movie, about a prodigious lizard that stomps all over Manhattan (is New York a new whipping boy in Hollywood?) must match the $229 million box-office take of the "Jurassic Park" sequel, "The Lost World," or it will be viewed as something of a disappointment.
The other big film of the summer is expected to be "Armageddon," opening on July 1, with Bruce Willis leading a team of roughneck oil drillers who are launched into space to implant a nuclear bomb in an asteroid (this one is the size of Texas) hurtling not only toward New York but also the rest of the Earth, too. Whether "Deep Impact" hurts "Armageddon" is, of course, unclear.
"You're dealing with talented filmmakers here, and you have to be concerned," said Jerry Bruckheimer, producer of "Armageddon." "There's nothing we can do about it, except make as good a movie as possible."
What top studio executives are hoping for is a sleeper or two: a film that cost $30 million to $60 million, is relatively unknown at this point and then seizes the attention of moviegoers and unexpectedly grosses more than $100 million. There were three sleepers among last summer's big winners: "The Full Monty," the serious comedy about a group of unemployed British men who become unlikely strippers; "My Best Friend's Wedding," the Julia Roberts comedy, and "George of the Jungle," based on Jay Ward's late-1960's television cartoon.
Several studios are already predicting their sleeper hits. Robert Daly, co-chairman of Warner Brothers, predicted that a relatively modest film, "The Negotiator," directed by F. Gary Gray and opening on July 31, would emerge as a hit. "This is one that nobody has really talked about, but it's going to be a big surprise of the summer," Mr. Daly said. The film, which has tested very strongly, stars Samuel L. Jackson as a smart Chicago police negotiator who takes hostages after he is framed for murder, and Kevin Spacey as an equally smart negotiator who comes in to resolve the crisis.
At 20th Century Fox, William Mechanic, president of Fox Filmed Entertainment, said that a zany romantic comedy, "There's Something About Mary," directed by Peter Farrelly and Bobby Farrelly, would emerge as a surprise winner. The Farrelly brothers are known for their hilarious grossness: they made "Dumb and Dumber." In the new film, Ben Stiller plays a loser who hires a private eye (Matt Dillon) to find the prom date (Cameron Diaz) who jilted him years ago. Mr. Dillon falls for Ms. Diaz, and turmoil ensues.
At Disney, executives predicted that the sleeper hit would be "The Parent Trap," opening on July 29. The film, directed by Nancy Meyers and starring Dennis Quaid and Natasha Richardson, is an update of the 1961 Hayley Mills classic about twins (played by Lindsay Lohan in the new film) who meet for the first time and seek to reunite their divorced parents. The film has been hugely popular among young girls.
"It's tested terrifically," said Dick Cook, chairman of the Walt Disney Motion Picture Group. "It's as good as any live-action Disney movie we've ever had."
Another potential winner: Dreamworks and Universal's "Small Soldiers," opening on July 10 and directed by Joe Dante, about toy soldiers who unexpectedly spring to life and wage war against one another and their human owners. The film is seen as a young boys' movie.
Looking toward the summer, producers and studio executive see several trends: with the exception of Warner's "Lethal Weapon 4," which opens on July 10, there are far fewer sequels than in previous years. "Everyone started to realize that a certain amount of originality was required, and if you make a sequel it should be better than the last one," said Mark Gill, president of Miramax's Los Angeles office.
There are also seems to be, especially in the early part of the summer, an unexpectedly large number of pictures for grown-ups at a time when Hollywood usually unleashes escapist movies. The grown-up films include "The Horse Whisperer," Robert Redford's romantic drama, and "Bulworth," Warren Beatty's political fantasy (both opening on May 15); "The Truman Show," the Peter Weir drama starring Jim Carrey as a man who doesn't know that his life is actually a television show (June 5), and Steven Spielberg's World War II drama "Saving Private Ryan" (July 24).
Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group, said of the summer: "No one said let's do more adult films. It's a coincidence. But if I had to say anything about the summer, it's that it feels less popcorny than other summers."

HEADLINE: City of Angels Is the City of Death for Magazines

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
When Buzz magazine put out its first issue in 1990, seven other city magazines were trying to distill the essence of Los Angeles and find a loyal following. With its focus on hip clothing designers, personalities and inside-Hollywood tales, Buzz outlived nearly all its rivals. But even a booming California economy was not enough to insure that the monthly made money. Buzz filed for bankruptcy-law protection last month.
Its demise leaves the nation's second-largest city with a single city magazine, the money-losing Los Angeles, owned by the Walt Disney Company's Fairchild division. In a pre-bankruptcy deal that put its competition out of business, Disney agreed to pay what is considered the steep sum of $5.3 million for Buzz's subscription list and its trademarks. Just 10 percent of Buzz's 138,475 paid circulation came from newsstand sales; a third was mailed out of state, according to figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations. 
 "Buzz was worth more dead than alive," said Allan Mayer, Buzz's former editor, who co-founded the magazine with his New York publishing colleague, Eden Collinsworth, and Susan Gates, its former publisher.
Buzz often teetered near ruin. Twice it was revived with fresh capital from out-of-the-blue investors, who ultimately became impatient with the high cost of glamour publishing. Buzz executives have little hope for a third 11th-hour rescue. Even so, publishing executives say Buzz achieved some measure of success because the largest markets typically only support one glossy general-interest city publication.
The city of Angels is a notorious magazine graveyard, having buried California, Angeles, L.A. Style and Exposure among other defunct titles. The survivor, 36-year-old Los Angeles, has been unprofitable for three years and has a third of the circulation of New York, one of the nation's most successful city magazines.
There are various theories about why that is true.
While New York is one city with five boroughs, the Los Angeles region is one county and 88 cities. It is a checkerboard of political and cultural interests.
"It's a disparate sprawling city that feels more loyalty to individual cities than to a whole," said Michael J. Caruso, a Tina Brown protege and editor of Details, whose stint as editor in chief of Los Angeles magazine lasted little more than a year. "L.A. is a tough nut to crack."
Joie Davidow, founder of long-gone L.A. Style, blames transplanted East Coast editors. "They don't get the city. L.A. is so different from New York; it's amazing they speak the same language."
Another explanation comes from David Adler, a spokesman for Primedia Inc., publisher of Chicago and New York. "The common conception is that L.A. is not a reading market," he said, also suggesting that Hollywood Reporter and Daily Variety, serve, in effect, as city magazines.
"The economics of one-title companies don't work," he added, because independent magazines lack clout when bargaining for services.
Bruce A. Hoenig, vice president of print services for Western International Media, a media buyer in Los Angeles, disagreed. "You can succeed if you're focused," he said. "But it's very difficult to provide to all the constituencies."
For the last year, Buzz's majority owner, Sharon Chadha, had tried to make the magazine profitable. A technology investor, she got her entree into publishing from a neighborhood friendship with one of the magazine's editors. Now, she said she expected a 45 percent loss on her $4.5 million investment. "Buzz had been given many lives," she said.
While advertising revenue had grown 40 percent last year, Mrs. Chadha said, operating losses continued unabated. Buzz's ad pages rose 16 percent last year, to 642.5, according to the Media Industry Newsletter. But, she said, "We ran into our risk limit."

HEADLINE: American Publishers Add Readers in Booming Latin America

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RECIFE, Brazil, May 6

 BODY:
In this languid beachfront city, home to Latin America's oldest newspaper, newsstands are suddenly filling with glossy upstarts -- Selecoes, a new Brazilian edition of Reader's Digest, and newspaper supplements of Time and Fortune in Portuguese.
Hot on the heels of American cable television's invasion of Latin America, magazines and newspapers from the United States are stampeding south. In the last two years, magazine publishers started Spanish-language editions of Newsweek, Glamour, Discover, People, National Geographic and Rolling Stone. 
 In the newspaper field, 20 Latin American newspapers now publish Wall Street Journal Americas, a daily section of The Journal's business news translated into Spanish or, for Brazil, Portuguese. For tourists and business travelers, The Miami Herald has rapidly become Latin America's international English-language newspaper, establishing 10 satellite printing sites in two years, including Sao Paulo Brazil, last month.
"By the end of the decade, I see probably three more printing sites and total distribution going up to 35,000 to 40,000," said Jose C. Romano, The Herald's international manager. With these sales, Latin America could soon account for 10 percent of the Herald's daily circulation, currently 366,243.
Several publications have become jaw-dropping success stories in Latin America. Brazilian sales of Reader's Digest in Portuguese soared to 600,000 last month, from 35,000 two years ago. And six months after their debuts, National Geographic en Espanol is selling 290,000 copies a month, while Glamour en Espanol is selling 500,000 copies.
"Europe and Asia have traditionally been the largest revenue areas for Time Inc. International, but now we view Latin America as the place for explosive growth," said Hugh Wiley, president of Time Inc.'s Latin American division. "It is the only region in the world we can cover entirely in two languages."
At Reader's Digest, Christopher Willcox, the magazine's editor in chief, said: "After the war, we did most of our expansion in Europe. We now see Latin America and the Asia-Pacific region as our 21st century."
The explosion in American publishing is part of a wider surge in foreign investment into Latin America. Over the last five years, the annual flow of new foreign investment into Latin America quadrupled, hitting $50 billion in 1997. During the same period, the foreign investment flow to Brazil, the region's behemoth, increased fourteenfold, hitting $18 billion.
American publishers are discovering Latin America for the same factors that lure other investors: newly opened markets and newly tamed inflation rates.
"It's very difficult to sell subscriptions in a market where inflation is hyper," Mike Brennan, the Digest's vice president for developing markets, said, referring to the early 1990's, when Brazil's monthly inflation regularly hit four digits. This year, Brazil's inflation is expected to be 4 percent.
With a stable currency allowing long-term subscription sales, Reader's Digest has become Brazil's second-best-selling magazine, after Veja, a long-established newsweekly owned by Editora Abril S.A. For the Digest's Spanish edition, Selecciones, subscription sales have allowed the Digest to sell 150,000 copies in Chile and 250,000 copies in Argentina, becoming the best-selling magazine in those two countries. Last month, Selecciones started selling subscriptions in Peru and Colombia.
"If you look at Europe today, you see Latin America 10 years from now," Mr. Brennan predicted, noting that the Digest now sells 1.7 million copies a month in Latin America.
Digest sales, he said, often give a clearer picture of a country's middle class than official statistics, which miss unreported income. Though Government statistics show low levels of per-capita income, he predicted that the Digest could double its Brazilian sales in five years.
Indeed, the strength and huge size of the Brazilian economy have prompted American publishers to overcome ingrained biases in favor of Mexico and Spanish over Brazil and Portuguese. Two years ago, Brazil, for the first time in recent memory, surpassed Mexico as the region's largest recipient of foreign investment.
With a population of 172 million, Brazil has a domestic car market five times the size of Mexico's.
In "mature" newspaper markets like Europe and the United States, newspaper sales are largely stagnant. In contrast, with low inflation and growing literacy, Brazil's reading market is expanding. In the last five years, newspaper sales in Brazil have jumped 9.5 percent.
"Latin America is now the best market in the world for offset presses," said Rosental Calmon Alves, a Brazilian newspaper columnist who teaches journalism at the University of Texas in Austin. Over the last year, he noted, new daily newspapers have been started in Buenos Aires, Rio de Janeiro and Belo Horizonte, Brazil.
This August, Globo, Brazil's largest media company, plans to open a $120 million printing plant outside of Rio de Janeiro and to start Brazil's third major newsweekly, Epoca.
American investors are catching this wave.
Time and Fortune, both owned by Time Warner, and The Wall Street Journal, owned by Dow Jones & Company, have followed the path of selling translated material for local language supplements in Latin American newspapers.
Time, which started only in March, now appears in nine newspapers, with a total circulation of 900,000. Fortune appears every two weeks in 23 newspapers, with a total circulation of 1.4 million.
Some Latin American publishing groups have been wary of buying these inserts, suspecting that the Americans merely want to familiarize Latin readers with their titles, before selling the magazines separately. Mr. Alves said, "Once they become a known brand name in the market, they could say 'bye-bye' to the paper and launch their own product."
Mr. Wiley of Time replied: "We looked long and hard at paid circulation. But it is very difficult to develop paid circulation in Latin America."
The Wall Street Journal's supplement reaches 2.2 million readers through a network restricted largely to one newspaper per country. In Brazil, a nation of continental size, The Journal will limit itself to one newspaper per state, planning to add six newspapers in coming years.
"Of all the American ventures, Wall Street Journal Americas is by far the most successful," Laura Lopez, a former Time reporter in Latin America, said from Santiago, Chile, where she is a spokeswoman for a United Nations economic research agency. "It is read by everyone, quoted in every cocktail party, quoted by ministerial level people at conferences. People love it."
In a symbiotic relationship, The Journal's five-day-a-week supplements have proved to be so profitable since they started in 1994 that the newspaper has tripled the size of its news staff in Latin America to nine, and a bureau is opening in Sao Paulo this month.
"When reporters' material can be read by people they are covering, they get better access -- and better access begets better quality," Richard J. Tofel, a spokesman for Dow Jones, said of the Latin America articles that are printed in the mother newspaper as well. Wall Street Journal Americas proved so successful that The Journal has expanded from Spanish and Portuguese and produces supplements in Turkish, Polish, Korean, German, Chinese, Hebrew and Greek.
Another Dow Jones investment, a Spanish-language business magazine, America Economia, has proved so successful that it added a Portuguese edition in 1995. The magazine went from monthly to twice monthly publication in April. America Economia and its Miami-based rival, Latin Trade, have circulations of about 85,000 each. Latin Trade, an English-language monthly now owned by Freedom Communication Inc., added a Spanish edition last year.
The Miami Herald, which is owned by Knight Ridder, is aiming for the niche market of English-speaking visitors and residents in Latin America. Half a century ago, The Herald introduced an international edition, named The Clipper because it was carried south on Pan Am Clipper planes.
More recently, by printing locally via satellite, The Herald moved its deadlines ahead 12 hours, cut its newsstand prices in half, and guaranteed home delivery in key foreign markets by 8 A.M.
In two years, this two-section daily newspaper has tripled its circulation to about 20,000.
Competing for some of the same market, TimesFax, an eight-page daily summary of The New York Times, has moved from a regional base of selling to Caribbean hotels and cruise ships to selling to hotels and businesses in Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru.
The International Herald Tribune, which is owned by The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has virtually ceded Latin America to The Miami Herald. The paper, which prints at 15 sites around the world, stopped printing in Miami a few years ago and sells only 1,500 copies in South America.
"Latin America is not really where our growth goals are now," said David Auchincloss, the newspaper's vice president for the Americas.
Despite the success stories, some publishing executives experienced with Latin America's ups and downs foresee a shakeout in coming years.
"This is a part of the world that is volatile," said Richard Burns, president of Latin Finance, a 10-year-old investment monthly owned by Euromoney Publications P.L.C. "I do not assume that it will be blue skies forever. Latin Finance has been through good times and bad times, and realizes there are cycles."
But for others, weaned on Latin America's deep-rooted protectionism, the region's new publishing environment is stunning.
"I'm flabbergasted by the turn of events," said Gary Neeleman, who first worked as a reporter in Brazil in 1958. Now responsible for Fortune's distribution across Latin America, he said: "People in Ecuador want to read about Bill Gates. It's refreshing to me, this newfound zeal for the print media throughout Latin America -- and their willingness to try new things."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brian Nicholson, a British writer in Brazil, reads The Miami Herald, which has 10 printing sites in Latin America. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)(pg. D1); The English-language Miami Herald is a fixture at newsstands in Rio de Janeiro. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)(pg. D12)
 
Chart: "Extending Their Reach"
Major English-language publishers have been expanding into Latin America. And, while business publications were some of the first on the scene, the selection is now as diverse as a Spanish edition of Rolling Stone and Discover en Espanol.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
'I Don't Think It Works'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
With President Clinton going to China next month, attention is focusing again on the question of how the United States should try to improve the human rights situation there. I raised the question in an interview with the Dalai Lama, who for 40 years has been a pre-eminent symbol of resistance to oppression by the Chinese Communist Government.
"China should not be isolated," the Dalai Lama said. "It must be brought into the mainstream of international life. Now the next question: How?" 
 He laughed heartily at his own question. Then he continued, emphatically:
"Confrontation or condemnation: I don't think it works. The only practical way is to be a genuine friend. Within that framework, the American stand on issues like human rights, democracy, liberty and Tibet should be made very clear to them.
"So I feel the American Administration's current policy of engaging the Chinese and establishing friendly relations is right."
When President Clinton came to office in 1993, he first adopted a policy of pressure on the Chinese Government to end its violations of human rights. But then he decided that that approach was ineffective and changed it to a policy of "engagement." In recent months, Beijing has released and sent to the United States its two best-known political prisoners, Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan.
The Dalai Lama, who was here visiting Brandeis University, took a similar view of his own relations with Beijing. "At this moment," he said, "meaningful dialogue with the Chinese Government is crucial."
Attempts to open a dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Beijing were broken off in 1993. The Chinese Government has treated his current effort in that direction disdainfully, suggesting that his talk of autonomy rather than independence for Tibet is a sham. He said the United States, "knowing my view, can help dispel the suspicions of the Chinese."
"Inside Tibet things are really bad," he said. "There are human rights violations, damage to the environment, degeneration of spirituality. Talks with the Chinese Government are the real hope to solve these problems."
He said he was "very optimistic" about the trend of conditions in China. "It is comparatively more open," he said. "Now some critical articles about Government policy regarding Tibet are appearing. They may not be in big-circulation journals, but they are there. These are very, very positive factors."
The Dalai Lama made clear that his support of a friendly U.S. approach did not mean silence on human rights issues.
"If you are only concerned about the economic side," he said, "that would be a terrible mistake. President Clinton should not go there and just forget about the issues of human rights, freedom and Tibet."
A strikingly similar view was taken by Wang Dan, who spoke at Harvard University soon after his release from prison last month. He said he thought improved U.S.-Chinese relations "will help economic and political reform in China." But he added that the United States must keep emphasizing its "moral standards."
Wang Dan was a leader of the democracy movement crushed in Tiananmen Square in 1989. President Clinton has agreed, at the Chinese Government's request, to visit Tiananmen Square next month. That seems a craven concession, a violation of the principle that America should hold fast to its ideals.
But it is equally true, I think, that we should avoid gestures likely to do more harm than good. An example is the proposed Freedom From Religious Persecution Act, which the House takes up this week. Designed to please the Christian right, it would largely duplicate existing human rights laws, except for a shameful provision making it easier for those claiming religious persecution to win asylum in this country than for those tortured or threatened with death because they want political freedom.
I have always believed that Americans committed to human rights should follow the advice of the oppressed in any country, as in the Soviet Union and the old South Africa. In the past I favored sanctions on China. Now there are signs of change: much greater freedom of movement, local elections, some lawsuits against authority. I think we should follow the advice of Wang Dan and the Dalai Lama.

HEADLINE: Road to Riches Starts In the Golden Triangle

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: YANGON, Myanmar

 BODY:
Chauffeured about town in his gleaming white sedan, Lo Hsing-han befits his reputation as one of the most influential businessmen in Myanmar, as Burma is now called.
A crisp business card identifies him as chairman of Asia World Company Ltd., a conglomerate managed by his son, Steven Law. Their commercial empire includes jade, ruby and teak concessions, real estate in Yangon (formerly called Rangoon), its renovated port buildings, a container shipping business and toll booths on the resurfaced Burma Road winding north to the Chinese border. 
 Mr. Lo has traveled far from his bare-knuckle origins as an opium warlord of the Golden Triangle in the early 1960's, when American drug officials linked him to much of the heroin winding up on the streets of American cities. He later survived seven years in a Burmese prison under sentence of death for treason, but after his release in 1980 he earned the Government's gratitude for brokering a critical cease-fire with ethnic insurgents in 1989.
Now, Mr. Lo says, there's more profit in selling cars across the Chinese border than in smuggling drugs.
The United States views Mr. Lo's prosperity as evidence that Myanmar's economy is awash in laundered drug money and that its military rulers have encouraged those who trade in drugs to invest in its development projects.
"Drug traffickers who once spent their days leading mule trains down jungle paths are now leading lights in Burma's new market economy and leading figures in its new political order," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, knows as Asean, in Kuala Lumpur last July.
Proving Mr. Lo's complicity is more difficult. "There are no smoking guns, no evidence linking him to any investigation whatsoever" at present, a Western official who follows narcotics conceded. "We're going to keep him out there as a target, because there's rampant speculation that he's involved in moving large quantities of heroin."
At 64 years old, Mr. Lo has not lost the nerve that helped him thrive in the opium trade. Told that several American reporters wanted to interview him, Mr. Lo invited them to dinner. He denied any involvement now in trafficking or money laundering.
"I welcome the whole world to investigate me," Mr. Lo said and promised $5,000 to anyone who could link him to drugs in the last 25 years.
Barely glancing at his diamond-studded gold Rolex wristwatch, Mr. Lo fielded questions in Chinese while his chopsticks poked at a succession of sumptuous dishes.
He reminisced about the late 1960's and early 70's when his opium-laden mule caravans stretched several miles across the mountainsides and ravines of Kokang, his ethnic Chinese home region in northeast Burma. What drove him, he contends, was not greed but benevolent concern for Kokang's struggling poppy growers.
"I don't bother about eating, drinking or traveling," he said. "My whole life has been spent just helping the poor."
Mr. Lo is hardly the only reputed drug trafficker to succeed in business in Myanmar. Khun Sa, the world's biggest heroin producer, surrendered his rebel Shan army in January 1996 and moved into a villa in a Government military compound in Yangon.
The Myanmar Government refuses to extradite Khun Sa to the United States, where he has been indicted for trying to smuggle 3,500 pounds of heroin into New York. He has described himself as a real estate agent and his investments are said to include a new resort casino and a bus route between Yangon and Mandalay. Until his health deteriorated, he also played golf with the generals whose army he once bloodied.
Mr. Lo's drug career began when he commanded a home guard unit battling Communist insurgents. The only way to equip and feed his troops, he said, was through the opium trade. "In the Kokang mountains, people earned their living from poppy for over 100 years," he said. "Over that period, poppy-growing and trading was legal. It was the only income for people."
As he tells it, rival traffickers demanded commissions of 25 or 30 percent to take the opium for refining in Thailand. Mr. Lo undercut them by charging 20 percent.
Twice a year from 1963 to 1973, Mr. Lo said, he moved 10 to 20 tons of opium to the Thai border, using his own troops and 800 to 1,000 mules per convoy. "It stretched out for three miles," Mr. Lo said. "If it went smoothly, it took about 26 days."
Mr. Lo waved aside questions about how much he earned. "I was working for the Kokang people and the poor people who were looking for a way to sell their product," he said. "I did so much for them, and I felt it was honorable."
When the Government ordered him to disband his troops, Mr. Lo refused. "The Kokang people needed the opium market," he said. "I was their sole agent, so the Kokang farmers got a reasonable price."
In 1973 he was lured across the Thai border, captured, extradited to Rangoon and sentenced to death. "I didn't think any harm would come to me," he said. "The Government didn't charge me with opium trafficking. They charged me with treason and violating socialist economic law."
He served a month short of seven years in prison before being released in a 1980 amnesty. Mr. Lo opened a bakery in Rangoon, raised livestock in Lashio and mined precious stones, using what he explained were family loans, not drug profits.
In 1989, he persuaded Peng Jiasheng, another opium dealer who led Kokang's rebel army, to accept a cease-fire with the military junta. The junta rewarded Mr. Lo with choice gem and timber concessions.
Since then, Mr. Lo said, "I have done a lot of import-export business, and also Chinese-border trade," delivering new cars from Yangon to China's Yunnan province. Mr. Lo described Asia World as "doing quite well" with an annual profit somewhere "over $1 million." He declined to say how much more.
Mr. Lo said he does not need to traffick in drugs now. "Since the market economy appeared in Myanmar, it is easier to earn money trading vehicles on the Chinese border," he said. He estimated that he turns a profit of about $2,500 on every car he sells to the Chinese.
Moreover, Mr. Lo said, he was shocked to discover so many addicts in his Kokang homeland and wants to stamp out opium. "When a family has a drug addict, the family is totally destroyed," he said. "I realized that drugs are not good."
Col. Kyaw Thein, the head of the Government's drug control program, said of Mr. Lo, "He's been out of the drug business since he was released from prison, because he knows that every intelligence agency will be keeping their eyes on him."
But a Western diplomat charged that the Government let Mr. Lo launder his money in legitimate businesses. "He has the connection with the banks," the diplomat said.
Mr. Lo was upset when his son Steven Law, who travels widely as Asia World's managing director, was denied a visa to the United States in 1996 because of suspected drug links.
"Steven is a genuine businessman," he said. "He doesn't know about drug trafficking. He wasn't born when I was in Kokang." Another son, Henry, lives in Los Angeles, but Mr. Lo said, "I can't remember the details."
Mr. Lo wants to see America himself. "If the United States is a democratic country, why doesn't it allow me to enter?" Mr. Lo asked. "Have I committed any crime?"

HEADLINE: Tobacco Bill Said to Cost 50% More

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
An analysis of anti-smoking legislation released today by the Senate Republican leadership concludes that the bill before the Senate would cost the tobacco industry more than half again as much over 25 years as the amount estimated by the White House and the measure's chief sponsor.
The analysis put the 25-year cost of the bill, approved by the Senate Commerce Committee last month and scheduled to go before the full Senate next week, at $755.3 billion to $868.9 billion. The White House and the bill's sponsor, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, calculate the cost at $516 billion. 
 The main reason for the discrepancy is that the Republican analysis included the expected effect of inflation, at a rate of 2.7 percent a year, over the next 25 years, expressing its conclusion in what economists call current dollars. The White House and Mr. McCain did not count inflation, expressing their estimate in what are called constant dollars.
The bill would impose a tax on cigarettes of as much as $1.10 per pack, strengthen the authority of the Food and Drug Administration to regulate tobacco products, require cigarette makers to pay penalties if the number of teen-agers who smoke does not fall to specified levels and give the tobacco companies little of the immunity they want from lawsuits filed on behalf of smokers.
The study is certain to figure prominently in the Senate debate. The tobacco industry and opponents of Mr. McCain's bill have argued that the measure is so costly that it could put American tobacco companies out of business and lead to a black market in cigarettes.
The industry wants legislation that would embrace the agreement the tobacco companies reached last June with 40 state attorneys general, which was said to cost $368.5 billion over 25 years.
The new calculations also take some of the steam out of the arguments supporters of the legislation made last week after the tobacco industry agreed to a $6.5 billion settlement of a lawsuit filed by the State of Minnesota and health insurers there. They argued that the large settlement showed that the cigarette makers could afford to pay much more money than they had indicated.
The analysis released today was prepared by the staff of the Senate Republican Policy Committee, an arm of the leadership, and was distributed by Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader and a foremost critic of the McCain bill.
"This analysis confirms my suspicions about the high cost of the Commerce Committee bill," Mr. Nickles said. "I don't believe it is necessary to raise taxes and spending by hundreds of billions of dollars to have a good anti-tobacco bill."
Explaining the rationale for counting the effect of inflation, the analysis said, "Americans don't earn or pay constant dollars." The Administration's estimate, the analysis said, "does not reflect actual pocketbook expenses as taxpayers would experience them."
John Raidt, the staff director of the Commerce Committee, accused the policy committee staff of "playing a silly numbers game."
Mr. Raidt said, "They know that the debate has always been in the context of 1998 dollars." He noted that the $368.5 billion cost of last June's agreement was expressed in uninflated dollars and that if inflation were counted, the cost would be $608 billion.
"They want to compare the apple to the orange, and that makes it wildly out of context," he said.
All this will doubtless be hashed out on Tuesday when the Senate Judiciary Committee holds a public hearing on the cost of the legislation. The committee chairman, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, is another critic of the McCain bill.
In their calculations, the Administration and Mr. McCain assumed that levels of smoking among young people would fall to specified levels so the tobacco companies would not owe penalties for not meeting the goals.
The policy committee staff expressed its estimates as a range, with the low figure assuming that no penalties would be assessed and the high figure assuming that the goals would not be met.

HEADLINE: In Haiti, Not All Gifts Well Received

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
When Fritz Martial left Haiti in 1969 to immigrate to the United States, his hometown of Tiburon had one elementary school, no hospital and no potable water to serve the town's 50,000 or so residents. Today, Tiburon, a dusty outpost about 100 miles southwest of the capital, Port-au-Prince, boasts of six schools, including two high schools and one of the best irrigation systems in Haiti.
"It would have remained a backwater," said Mr. Martial, of Uniondale, N.Y., who in 1976 helped create the Committee to Help and Develop the Parish of Tiburon, a New York-based organization with chapters around the country. "We could not stay here, live well and let that happen to the place of our ancestors." 
 The story of Tiburon has been repeated across Haiti as Haitians in the United States, Canada, Europe and Latin America have banded together in regional associations to finance small but critical projects to keep their impoverished country of seven million afloat.
The aid is crucial: money wired from the United States, estimated at $3 million a day, is considered the largest source of hard currency in Haiti, the Western Hemisphere's poorest country. Without it, Haitian economists and central bank officials say, the country's dire financial straits would be far worse.
The Mayor of Tiburon, Adrien Jeanty, said: "Tiburon is a place that has been and continues to be ignored by the central Government. Without the help of the diaspora, I don't know where we would be. They do almost everything."
Still, many in the Haitian diaspora -- particularly those in the United States, where roughly one million Haitians live -- express a deep sense of rejection by the same people they are helping. They say they are constantly reminded that their contributions, however welcome, are largely insignificant. And they say their loyalty to Haiti has come under attack because they are seen as having carved out a comfortable life style overseas, far from the dust-filled cities of their homeland, with their constant power shortages and poor telephone lines.
So when a group of Haitian mayors met to discuss economic development with roughly 40 Haitian-American business and regional leaders -- about a dozen from New York -- in the southern coastal city of Jacmel for three days in late April, the Americans grumbled over and over that the country did not appreciate their contributions.
Organizers held the meeting in Jacmel, a picturesque city whose streets are lined with gingerbread colonial-era homes, in part to coincide with the celebration of its 300th anniversary.
The meeting, the first of its kind, was held outdoors at a large beachfront restaurant, and was significant in bringing together the mayors, private-business owners and potential investors from overseas.
Organizers said that one of the meeting's goals was to help bolster the power of the elected mayors, whose positions have been rendered largely ceremonial because officials in the capital make important decisions without consulting them. Economic alliances with Haitians living abroad, they said, would give the mayors the financial clout to direct aid to their municipalities as they saw fit. Such arrangements would allow organizations like Mr. Martial's to build not only schools but also factories.
Indeed, several mayors brought proposals for projects like restoring maritime ports and building food-processing plants that would not only help meet the domestic need for food, but begin exporting it, particularly tropical goods like mangoes and avocados. Many of the Americans present said they welcomed the proposals.
"What is most important is for us to provide the diaspora a structure to work within," said Gary Mazile, the mayor of Miragoane, a city about 40 miles west of Jacmel. "People can say all they want about them, but they are our best and brightest. Furthermore, because of their strength, they won't accept the perverse exploitation that exists right now."
But other Haitians have a less favorable view of the Haitian-Americans' largess. The stream of cash from the United States, they say, has created a welfare state in which millions of people simply wait for their relatives abroad to wire money. They argue that the money, which could go toward building factories and other job-creating enterprises, is largely squandered. And at times, they add, the Haitian diaspora tends to be condescending and patronizing, acting like foreigners insensitive to the realities of the country.
"The diaspora does care about the people here," said Danielle St. Lot, who organized the meeting. "But they tend to be emotional. They land at the airport and immediately they start handing out money left and right."
Haitians living abroad say that such comments miss the point and at the same time intensify the psychological wounds in a group that has always felt a sense of guilt over the country's pitiful condition. The immigrants, many of them members of the middle class, chose to move away rather than stay to fight the brutal 29-year rule of Francois and Jean-Claude Duvalier, which ended in 1986. It is a fact that many in Haiti are quick to remind them of.
"I hate being called diaspora," said Stanley Barbot, co-host of "Moment Creole" on WLIB-AM, one of the most popular shows in New York. "Because in most circles it is a put-down. It means a lower class of people."
Mr. Barbot and others attending the meeting said that Haitians treated them with the same coldness that Africans often reserve for American-born blacks who flock there for spiritual and cultural connection. Their ties, unlike those of black Americans, are not purely visceral, Haitian-Americans said. "Their attitude is, give us your money and go back home," Mr. Barbot said.
"The absurd part about it is, they know we're not that dumb and they know that the country cannot move forward without us," he said.
Frantz Verella, a former World Bank official and a professor of economics at the State University of Haiti in Port-au-Prince, conceded Mr. Barbot's point.
"If we're able to convince the Haitians overseas that they should invest here, we will create an important synergy," he said. "It will bring a big boost to the Haitian economy. We have one of the largest diaspora in the Caribbean. The possibilities are endless."
But Mr. Verella, a former Minister of Public Works, said that the fundamental question remained: whether Haitians living overseas had the patience and the will to uproot a small clique of businessmen who have monopolized just about every enterprise in the country.
The central Government, while pledging its support to privatize moribund state enterprises and decentralize its bureaucracy in the provinces outside Port-au-Prince, has taken few concrete steps in those directions.
"The democratic process is elitist," Mr. Verella said. "It is being played out in small circles. What the Haitians living abroad can do is to widen that circle."

HEADLINE: For the Apollo, Audits and Anger;
A Landmark, in Eclipse, Faces Questions About Finances

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER and ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Almost two decades ago, Percy E. Sutton had a vision: he would buy the Apollo Theater, a spiritual home of African-American music whose doors had been shut, fix it up and put on shows like the ones he remembered from his youth, which featured stars like Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan.
Mr. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President who owns a chain of radio stations, did rebuild the Apollo in the 1980's. But the Harlem landmark lost money, and in 1992, he turned it over to a nonprofit foundation. 
 Now there are signs that the latest attempt to restore the Apollo may be falling short, too, even amid a strong commercial turnaround on 125th Street. Glass panes were broken on one side of the theater's marquee last week, and capital letters appeared in the middle of words, suggesting that the Apollo's strained budget does not permit an adequate supply of lower-case letters. The theater's terra cotta facade is pulling away from the brick on the building's west wall. Inside, the Apollo is dark most nights.
Last week, state officials sounded a loud alarm about the condition of the celebrated theater. They said they were withholding $750,000 in loans and grants to the Apollo Theater Foundation until serious questions about its finances had been answered. The foundation manages the theater for the state, which owns it.
The announcement unleashed a political furor. Members of Harlem's Democratic establishment accused Republicans in Albany and City Hall of a political cheap shot. The Rev. Al Sharpton called for a community hearing tomorrow to allow Mr. Sutton and others to present information about the theater's finances.
City and state officials spoke ominously about mismanagement and a lack of financial oversight of the Apollo, and they linked its difficulties to the troubled history of other state economic development projects in Harlem over the past 25 years. Audits were ordered and investigations started.
But in the end, the tumult will come down to two questions: Did Mr. Sutton shortchange the nonprofit foundation to which he had entrusted the Apollo, or are his critics relying on a strange reading of the contract that transferred the Apollo to the foundation?
Six years ago, when Mr. Sutton handed over the Apollo to the foundation and nearly $12 million in loans to him from the state and a commercial bank were forgiven, he kept control of his syndicated television show, "It's Showtime at the Apollo." He obtained a five-year licensing agreement, in which his company, the Inner City Theater Group, agreed to pay the foundation for use of the Apollo and its name. The fee was set at $2,000 per taping or 25 percent of the show's profits, whichever was greater.
State officials said Mr. Sutton may have significantly underpaid the foundation. Randy Daniels, a senior vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that owns the Apollo, said the foundation's executives told its board of directors a few months ago that Mr. Sutton owed $3 million under the contract. When the board pressed for payment, it received only $145,000, Mr. Daniels said.
State officials questioned whether the foundation's board -- whose chairman is Mr. Sutton's close friend, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel -- had properly enforced the agreement. "What it really comes down to: Is this foundation capable of being the steward of this national landmark?" Mr. Daniels said. "It's losing money, it's in bad shape and it's failing to collect money that it's apparently due. Now, why is that?"
But Mr. Sutton and Mr. Rangel insisted that the foundation had received everything it was owed. "They're trying to say that, because I am close with Percy Sutton, that there was a sweetheart deal," Mr. Rangel said. "There is no one closer to me, but we've never discussed the contract."
Mr. Sutton, having exhausted considerable capital and energy in trying to save the Apollo for more than a decade, feels aggrieved to find himself accused of having underpaid the theater foundation. "At this time in my life, when I am 77 years old and I have never had any scandal attached to me, to have some stupid political thing," Mr. Sutton said. "The real problem is a misunderstanding on how television syndication works."
During a lengthy interview yesterday, Mr. Sutton said that the show, now in its 10th year, began to make a profit only two years ago. He brought documents to back up his assertions.
The show's combined revenues over the last five years have been about $26 million, according to Mr. Sutton's records. But the first time it showed a profit, $174,222, was in the 1995-1996 season, the records show. The following year, the profit was about $1 million. Mr. Sutton said the profits are split between his company and a syndicator in Los Angeles.
The definition of what constitutes a profit appears to be at the core of the dispute. Page 12 of the contract says that Mr. Sutton's company was required to pay $2,000 per taping or 25 percent of "annual net profits." But on the following page, net profit is defined in a sweeping and highly unusual way, essentially as gross revenues. Profits are usually defined as what is left after expenditures are subtracted from revenues.
Executives of the Apollo Theater Foundation, who would not discuss the contract with reporters, apparently relied on the unusual definition to conclude that Mr. Sutton owed them millions of dollars.
Despite the wording, Mr. Sutton contends that the contract's definition of net profits misstates both industry practice for television and the real intent of the agreement. It was meant to apply only to records, compact disks and other recordings from the Apollo, he said, not to the television show.
"This, sir, is about politics and power," he said. "There is a lady up there who is a good Republican, who they've hired as the executive director. This lady who was to have done so very much, what she has done is to identify with the Republicans who have taken over."
Mr. Sutton was referring to Grace Blake, a veteran film executive who is the Apollo Theater Foundation's executive director. Late last year, as the five-year contract with Mr. Sutton was expiring, Ms. Blake hired a law firm to review the contract and to recommend whether the Apollo's licensing agreement should be put out to bid to other companies. It was apparently in that context that questions about Mr. Sutton's payments were first raised.
Ms. Blake declined to discuss the dispute. "I'm very fond of Mr. Sutton, but I will only respond after publication of the story," she said. "I feel like I'm in the middle of a political struggle. I don't know who is doing what to whom, and I am not interested."
It will likely require teams of auditors to resolve the matter. The Empire State Development Corporation told the Apollo foundation to submit complete financial records by May 19. Dennis C. Vacco, the State Attorney General, has begun a preliminary investigation of the theater's finances. Mr. Rangel and the foundation's board voted last week to hire an accounting firm to comb through their books. Mr. Sutton said he planned to hire a major accounting firm to audit his company's records.
The sudden attention to the Apollo's finances is in sharp contrast to a lack of government oversight over the years. Neither the state development agency nor the State Comptroller's office has audited Mr. Sutton's management of the Apollo's renovation or his operation of the theater. An analysis of the Apollo in 1991 by the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand found that the theater's expenses were within industry norms, but that the operation could not expect to be profitable: the Apollo was too small and its debt too high.
The theater has fewer than 1,500 seats, and since it reopened in the mid-1980's it has seldom managed to attract major stars. Despite various attempts to book the theater creatively, from blues revivals to 1960's singing groups to boxing, the Apollo is in use only sporadically.
The Apollo was in some ways a victim of racial integration. In the 1940's and 1950's, many black entertainers could appear only at the Apollo when they came to New York. Now, they are more likely to be featured at Radio City Music Hall or Madison Square Garden -- and for considerably higher fees.
"The civil rights movement that I went to jail in was the same civil rights movement that killed the Apollo," Mr. Sutton said. "We thought all the people who had started there and gone on to success would come back. But they didn't."
Mr. Sutton was well aware of the Apollo's limitations when he decided to bring it back to life in the early 1980's. His dream was to create a network of cable franchises in major American cities and to broadcast concerts from the Apollo over his cable systems. But he was able to buy only one cable franchise.
"The Apollo was a miscalculation for me," he said. "I really thought that people would use it, that people would come back. I was stupid. I thought I could do that."

HEADLINE: Governor's Budget Vetoes Imperil Legal Aid Programs

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 7

 BODY:
A legal aid office in Buffalo opens its doors at 9 A.M. and closes by 9:45, overwhelmed by requests for free advice. A similar program in Elmira cut its employees' pay last year to avoid curtailing services. And in New York City, legal aid programs can serve fewer than half of the tens of thousands of people who seek their help.
Lawyers for the poor say the situation is about to get substantially worse, because Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed about $12 million in financing for legal aid programs around the state last month as part of $1.6 billion in budget cuts. The cuts will force legal aid programs to close offices, eliminate jobs and reduce services in almost every county at a time when poor people need more help than ever navigating welfare, housing, health care and immigration laws, lawyers for the poor say. 
 "We are the last place people go when they have nowhere else to turn to avoid eviction, escape domestic violence or receive the health benefits they are entitled to," said Anne Erickson, legislative coordinator for the Greater Upstate Law Project, which oversees most of the state's legal aid programs and lost $343,000 as a result of Mr. Pataki's vetoes. "The Governor is creating a system of unequal justice if he takes these services away."
The cuts will also make it more difficult for private lawyers to take on pro bono cases, because many of those lawyers depend on legal aid programs for help understanding complicated laws affecting the poor, Ms. Erickson said.
The Pataki administration has repeatedly pointed out that even after the vetoes, the budget is 6.9 percent higher than last year's, with substantial increases for education in particular. And Mr. Pataki, a Republican who is running for re-election, has indicated he might restore some of the 1,000 spending items he vetoed. But legislative leaders have said they may not pressure the Governor to do so, so they can blame him during his upcoming campaign for the impact of the cuts.
Even if Mr. Pataki does restore certain cuts, some legislators say, the legal aid money is not likely to be among them because poor people are not nearly as vocal a constituency as teachers, environmental groups and others hurt by the vetoes.
State law requires lawyers to turn over the interest earned on escrow accounts they hold for clients to the state, which must spend most of it on civil legal services for the poor. Mr. Pataki included about $15 million from the fund in his original budget proposal, but the Legislature added another $12 million in its own proposal. The Legislature has added money every year since 1993, when interest rates dropped and the fund was not providing nearly enough money for legal services.
The fund still does not provide as much as it did in the early 1990's because of higher banking fees, said Steven Banks, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of New York City, which handles 30,000 civil cases a year and is losing almost $1.9 million under the vetoes. Federal aid to legal services has dropped, too, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to cut New York City's contribution to the Legal Aid Society and another program, Legal Services for New York City.
"We've already been hit pretty hard," Mr. Banks said. "The state money is literally the lifeline to keep our offices running and our clients served."
Of the $12 million Mr. Pataki vetoed for legal aid programs, $4.8 million was for Prisoners' Legal Services, a nonprofit group that provides free legal help to inmates at state prisons. David C. Leven, the group's executive director, said the program depends almost entirely on state aid and will have to shut down if the veto stands. The veto comes as Mr. Pataki is also reducing state aid for prison education programs, he added.
"We cannot survive without this funding," Mr. Leven said. "And without any other outlet for inmates to channel their legitimate complaints, there could be some serious problems in the prison system."
Mr. Leven said that Prisoners' Legal Services actually saves the state money by weeding out hundreds of frivolous lawsuits each year. Most of the cases that go to court involve abuse of prisoners by guards, inadequate medical care for prisoners and questionable disciplinary practices, he said.
But State Senator Michael F. Nozzolio, a Republican from Seneca Falls who heads the Senate Crime and Corrections Committee, said taxpayers should not be paying prisoners' legal fees. Inmates should depend on the law libraries in prisons, or on law students who volunteer to help them, Mr. Nozzolio said.
"Prisoners' Legal Services is a law firm funded by the taxpayers, designed to sue the taxpayers," he said. "I went to law school and frankly, the law library at Auburn Correctional Facility is just as good as the one I had at my law school. Let the prisoners use that."
As for other legal aid programs, Mr. Nozzolio said the state should collect fees from bar associations and corporate law firms to pay for the services. "They are important, but taxpayers shouldn't have to support them," he said. "I represent a lot of working poor in my district, and those folks don't qualify for legal aid. But in effect, they're paying for these law firms with their tax dollars."
Lawyers for the poor say corporate law firms, which have powerful lobbyists in Albany, would thwart any legislative attempt to impose a fee. Instead, they say, New York should pay for legal aid programs through court filing fees, as New Jersey and several other states do. The state collects about $215 million a year in court filing fees, most of which goes into its general operating fund, Ms. Erickson of the Greater Upstate Law Project said.
While Prisoners' Legal Services is the only program in danger of shutting down as a result of Mr. Pataki's vetoes, many other programs are planning reductions of staff and services that even in the least populous counties, will affect hundreds of clients, Ms. Erickson said. Legal Aid of Mid New York, which serves nine upstate counties, is planning to close one of its offices, she said. Chemung County Legal Services, which has offices in Elmira and Ithaca, will eliminate 2 of 10 staff positions, increasing caseloads to well over 300 per lawyer per year.
"The people who will be hurt by these cuts have enormous needs affecting the fundamentals of their lives: shelter, food, family," said Joseph Genova, chairman of the Committee on Access to Justice for the New York State Bar Association. "We would hope any restorations to the budget would be based on who has the gravest need, not who has the loudest voice and the best lobbyist in Albany."

HEADLINE: Dominican Drug Traffickers Tighten Grip on the Northeast

SERIES: LETHAL PARTNERS: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and LARRY ROHTER 

 BODY:
Ricardo is a foot soldier in New York City's drug wars. He has sold thousands of bags of heroin, worn out countless beepers and become a familiar figure on the streets of Washington Heights and Harlem. Now, he and his Dominican-led gang have dramatically expanded their sales operations, moving well beyond upper Manhattan to deliver Colombian drugs in a territory from Maryland to Massachusetts.
In a recent interview on a park bench in Harlem, Ricardo took a break from his routine to describe the new vistas opening to New York's Dominican gangs. 
 "Not long ago Dominicans went no farther than Queens," said Ricardo, who spoke on condition that his surname not be used. "Now Dominicans go everywhere."
For two decades, Colombia's drug lords fiercely guarded almost every stage of their business, from the processing of coca base to the wholesale distribution of cocaine in the United States.
But over the last several years, they have found a new partner in the delivery and distribution of drugs to the East Coast.
While there are no hard statistics on the illegal trade, American law enforcement officials now estimate that Dominican drug traffickers transport as much as one-third of the approximately 300 metric tons of cocaine that enter the United States each year. Officials believe that the Dominicans' share has more than doubled since the early 1990's, and that the Dominicans' involvement in large-scale distribution has also grown sharply.
The emerging leaders of these organizations -- women as well as men -- speak English and Spanish interchangeably and may be as comfortable in a New York nightclub as in a Caribbean village.
Officials say they have camouflaged their operations beneath the legitimate businesses of thriving Dominican immigrants in the United States, taking advantage of the growing trade and financial dealings between the two coun
tries.
This shift in the multibillion-dollar drug trade has complicated American antidrug efforts, which for more than two decades have focused on dismantling highly sophisticated drug distribution networks run from Colombia.
Authorities from Maryland to Vermont find themselves struggling to locate their new adversaries in a sea of hard-working immigrants who have spread across the Northeast in search of a better future for their families.
"The Dominicans are our biggest threat," said George Festa, regional director of the Drug Enforcement Administration in New England. "We've seen things we've never seen before, one group dealing crack, cocaine and heroin. We see them making alliances across the board with everyone, including Chinese and Vietnamese groups. They are versatile."
Many Dominican-Americans have expressed concern that the well-publicized drug dealing by a tiny minority casts a shadow on a much larger group. More than a million Dominicans are estimated to live in the New York City metropolitan area.
"The largest drug operations cracked by the police involve, at most, a hundred people," said Moises Perez, executive director of Alianza Dominicana, a Washington Heights social services agency. "These are small operations when you compare it to the size of the community."
Still, drug seizures around the Caribbean illustrate the changing international pattern of smuggling. In fiscal year 1997, the United States Customs Service in Florida, the main point of entry for drugs from the Caribbean, confiscated 14,000 pounds of cocaine, a 100 percent increase over fiscal year 1996.
In testimony before a Senate committee earlier this year, Thomas A. Constantine, the Drug Enforcement Administration administrator, said: "Criminals from the Dominican Republic have emerged as the dominant force in the wholesale cocaine and heroin trade on the East Coast. Their influence is now spreading beyond the big-city landscape into the smaller cities and towns."
Law enforcement officials say Dominican drug rings have appeared in every major city in New England, from Lowell, Mass., to Manchester, N.H. Documents seized from one ring recently broken up in Worcester, Mass., and wiretaps of phone conversations indicated that it had sent couriers to New York City an average of twice a week for more than two years with cash shipments as large as $80,000 for eventual wire transfers to the Dominican Republic.
In November, 14 members of another Dominican ring were caught establishing bases in apartments in Portland and Old Orchard Beach, Me.
Investigators who arrested them on trafficking charges expressed amazement at the breadth of their operation, noting that through a beeper operated by the suspects, 814 calls had been detected over a 30-day period from possible purchasers around Maine and wholesale suppliers in New York City.
Ricardo's northern Manhattan gang is typical. It once sold cocaine and heroin only to local buyers and small-time dealers who drove to New York City from upstate New York. But over time, Ricardo said, the head of his organization realized that he could increase profits by putting his people on buses and sending them as far north as Boston and as far south as Baltimore with drugs packed inside stuffed animals and resealed coffee cans. (Ricardo is of Puerto Rican origin; the leadership of the gang is reserved for Dominicans.)
As a recent classified Justice Department intelligence report put it: "The expansion of the Dominican distribution threat outward from New York City is especially noteworthy because most state and local authorities are not prepared to handle it. Over half of U.S. states have reported Dominican criminal activity, an indicator that the Dominican drug problem is beginning to assume a national perspective."
 
A Partnership Begins
Plenty of Drug Jobs For Needy Immigrants
 The drug trade involvement of Dominican immigrants, especially those in the United States illegally, goes back more than two decades.
The Dominican migration to New York City began to explode just as a broader range of Americans began to acquire a taste for cocaine in the early 1970's. As the drug flowed in ever-greater amounts from Colombia and as Dominican immigration waves to the United States far outstripped Colombian migrations, law enforcement officials say, Colombian cartel bosses hired the Dominicans, numerous and eager for work, as their couriers, street sellers and hit men.
When the crack epidemic boomed in the mid-1980's, Dominican street organizations based in Washington Heights took advantage of the expanding sales volumes and gradually began to do some wholesaling of their own. Like previous generations of ethnic organized-crime syndicates, they were flamboyant and violent and competed for turf, sometimes by shooting at one another out the windows of souped-up sports cars speeding up and down Broadway and the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx.
But the new generation of Dominican dealers has acquired stealth and sophistication in recent years, law enforcement officials say. They have learned to avoid police attention by tempering their violence and concealing their wealth.
Dominicans have also benefited by offering the Colombian drug lords a cheaper alternative to business partnerships with Mexican gangs. A Mexican-Colombian rivalry was created in the early 1990's when the Colombian cartels began paying Mexican drug gangs in cocaine, in part to avoid having to launder cash, and gave them as much as half of each load transported into the United States. The Mexican gangs began selling it directly themselves.
The Colombians have struck a less generous deal with their Dominican partners, paying in cash or with no more than 25 percent of the cocaine shipments, officials say. The Dominican gangs are much smaller than the Mexican cartels, and for the moment, the officials add, they are no threat to their Colombian partners.
Rene Antonio Aquino, a Dominican who is awaiting trial on drug charges in Hartford, was one of the pioneers in expanding the territory of Dominican gangs, according to Federal drug agents and Connecticut law enforcement officials.
Mr. Aquino, 34, fits the profile of the typical Dominican immigrant to New York City. He arrived as a teen-ager with his parents, learned English reasonably well and became an ardent Yankees fan. Although he never finished high school, he managed to buy a bodega named Diana's on Wilson Avenue in Bushwick, Brooklyn, and enjoyed a middle-class life complete with sports cars and a couple of rental houses in Queens.
But there was another side to Mr. Aquino. He was arrested on minor drug charges in 1989 and 1990, and Federal drug agency officials say he continued as a minor dealer, dodging the law by jumping bail and carrying false identification papers.
By the mid-1990's, the officials said, Mr. Aquino and a series of partners had considerably expanded their operations. They carved out a niche as heroin wholesalers, transporting the drug across upstate New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Rhode Island and Connecticut, according to the officials.
The Connecticut Deputy Chief State's Attorney, Christopher L. Morano, said Mr. Aquino and his partners dispatched runners to Colombia to buy heroin, which was ferried by plane and car to Caracas, Venezuela.
The drugs were carried into the United States by Dominican and Puerto Rican women who traveled to Caracas posing as tourists. After sunning themselves on the Venezuelan beaches at the organization's expense, the women would sew the heroin into the linings of their jackets and shoes for the trip back to New York.
From Kennedy International Airport, Mr. Morano said, the heroin was loaded into a fleet of cars honeycombed with secret compartments. It was bound for distribution not only in Hartford but in cities in Rhode Island, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Massachusetts. According to informers recruited from its ranks, the organization would from time to time ship the cars back to the Dominican Republic, with the cash proceeds of drug sales hidden behind trapdoors, investigators said.
"Tony decided he could cut out the Colombian middlemen in New York and put more money in his pocket," said Michael Edelwich, a Hartford police detective who worked on the case.
Mr. Aquino is awaiting trial in Hartford on charges of racketeering, drug trafficking, conspiracy to commit kidnapping and conspiracy to commit murder. His indictment is sealed. John Tauger, his lawyer, denied that his client was involved in the case.
But Mr. Morano and Hartford police detectives say that in public housing projects there, Mr. Aquino's ring distributed bags of heroin stamped with several brand names, including "Gunfire" and "High Power." They said street dealers sold as many as 3,000 bags a day, sweeping through the projects four times weekly.
It took the Hartford police nearly two years to trace the origins of the heroin. As they began arresting the organization's runners in 1995, detectives said, they noticed an unusual pattern: Every suspect placed a call from the jail to Diana's bodega in Bushwick and asked to speak with a man called Uncle.
Using their informers, the detectives eventually identified Uncle as Mr. Aquino.
Today Mr. Aquino's bodega is shut tight, showing nothing more than a metal gate that serves as a canvas for graffiti.
At a recent bail hearing, he stood emotionless in an orange jumpsuit and spotless white sneakers. His short beard was neatly trimmed, and he held his hands loosely behind his back.
Hartford detectives said he had shown more emotion when they transported him to Connecticut after his arrest on Oct. 9 in Jackson Heights, Queens. In the police car then, he showed off pictures of his family and asked how the police had penetrated his organization.
"He'd squint, as if wondering, 'How did you do that?' " recalled Detective Robert Lawlor. "At the end of it all, he shook our hands."
 
A Network Spreads
Drug Trade Corrupts Legitimate Commerce
The expanding trade between the Dominican Republic and the United States has given rise to a host of new businesses. Moving goods routinely between the two countries, these companies offer drug traffickers a ready network to exploit, provided that the businesspeople involved can be coerced or persuaded to move a different type of product.
The experiences of Jose Rafael Knipping, a failed Dominican fruit canner, show how legitimate commerce can give way to illicit trade, Dominican law enforcement officials say.
Mr. Knipping had long hoped to penetrate the American market with fruit canned in his factory, Haina Agro-Industrial, outside Santo Domingo. But by late 1996 his debts were growing. So he placed an advertisement in the Spanish-language edition of The Miami Herald, offering to sell the company for $1.6 million, and waited for a response.
Dominican officials say they believe that the advertisement caught the eye of powerful Colombian traffickers who made Mr. Knipping an offer: Join the drug trade and save your business.
Mr. Knipping has denied that he was approached by Colombians. But he has told Dominican investigators that his partner was contacted by a Dominican living in New York who offered to buy the factory for about $1 million, on one condition. The prospective buyer asked Mr. Knipping's partner to ship several hundred pounds of jellies, sweets and juices to warehouses in upper Manhattan and the Bronx.
Soon after the request was made, the Colombians shipped cocaine by high-speed motorboats to the Dominican Republic, where it was repackaged at Mr. Knipping's factory into cans of guava pulp, Dominican investigators say. Mr. Knipping has denied any knowledge of this operation.
Then, in March 1997, United States Customs Service agents working in the Port of Newark inspected a shipment of 950 cans of guava pulp. Twenty-six of the cans were suspiciously separated from the others by string and bore serial numbers that ended in 2222.
When the agents opened the cans, they found 253 pounds of cocaine worth more than $2 million, according to a complaint filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. They replaced the cocaine-filled cans with others bearing identical markings, and New York City police detectives followed the shipment when it left the dock. They watched with hidden cameras as the cans were unloaded at a Dominican-owned food distribution warehouse on West 220th Street.
Four Dominicans -- three city residents and one businessman from the island who had learned his English as an exchange university sociologist years ago -- picked up the cans and were arrested as they drove with the illegal shipment down Broadway in a black Ford van. All have been convicted on drug charges and are awaiting sentencing.
Mr. Knipping, who was in New York at the time of the shipment, fled the United States but was arrested in Santo Domingo. He has pleaded not guilty to drug-trafficking charges and is awaiting trial there.
The criminal complaint against him alleges that the cocaine shipment was arranged by Orsi Tineo, the prospective purchaser of the factory. Mr. Tineo, one of those arrested in New York transporting the guava pulp, has pleaded guilty to trafficking charges. But Dominican investigators say this small-time drug dealer, who works as a Manhattan apartment painter, did not have the $1 million to buy Mr. Knipping's factory.
Adm. Julio Cesar Ventura Bayonet, inspector general of the Dominican armed forces, supervised the investigation of Haina Agro-Industrial. He said it is likely that Mr. Tineo or one of his associates was actually an agent of bigger Colombian traffickers, who "just love to snap up failing factories and companies" in the Dominican Republic.
Mr. Tineo's lawyer, David Wickstrom, denied that his client was a front for the Colombians but acknowledged that Mr. Tineo did not have the means to buy a factory.
 
A Market Develops
Money Transfer Outfits Help Launder Profits
 All drug traders face the same difficulty. Sales of illicit substances produce mountains of cash, which must be laundered, some way or another, into the legitimate economy. Dominican drug dealers have several means of moving money back to their homeland. Many Dominican residents of the United States and Dominican-Americans return home several times a year, offering a perfect camouflage if they agree to tape wads of cash onto their bodies. They also mail home millions of dollars in checks and money orders, which could be used as a cover.
The money is just as likely to move through one of the scores of money transfer establishments that have cropped up across the East Coast in recent years, law enforcement officials say.
One of these companies, Remesas America Oriental, was one of the fastest-growing Dominican businesses in the country -- until the arrests and convictions last year of more than 20 of its employees in New York, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Florida and Puerto Rico. They were convicted of laundering more than $800,000 in a series of transactions orchestrated by Customs agents in a sting operation. In 1996 alone, the Treasury Department said, the company handled most of the transfers from New York to the Dominican Republic, $130 million, or almost 24 percent of the total.
A Federal complaint filed in Manhattan last year offered a road map of how Dominican drug gangs laundered their proceeds.
In one August 1994 transaction, for example, an informer went to a Remesas branch on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx and met with Ramon Corporan and Giselle Moya, both managers, to transmit $40,000 to the Dominican Republic.
To make clear that he was in the drug business, the informer, according to the complaint, "advised Corporan that Hartford was a good city to open a money-transmitting business because there was a substantial quantity of Dominicans selling drugs in the vicinity of Main Street."
The employees agreed to handle the transaction, the complaint charges, and a week later two undercover Customs agents posing as recipients of cash went to an office of Consorcio Oriental, Remesas' parent company, in Santo Domingo, where they received the $40,000.
According to the complaint, "The Customs agents were given receipts, which reflected that the cash had been transmitted over a period of six days in eight transactions, each under $10,000." This is important because American law requires banks and other institutions to report all transfers of more than $10,000. "The sender and recipient names on each of the eight receipts were fictitious," the document read.
Back in Santo Domingo, Roberto Lopez, an owner of Consorcio Oriental, was recently doing some paperwork in his office off the parking lot of a hotel. His secretary offered a guest coffee or juice, adding tartly, "We don't poison."
In an interview, Mr. Lopez expressed shock about the bad fortune that had befallen his American operations and blamed his top manager in the United States for the criminal case. "Corporan had worked seven years for Banco de Ponce," Mr. Lopez said. "He's an American citizen. He speaks perfect English. Who could have guessed that he would do such a thing?"
The Customs Service estimates that New York City transfer establishments sent at least $500 million to the Dominican Republic in 1996 and again in 1997, double the amount sent in 1993. Senior agents in New York estimate that one-fifth of the wire transfers come from the proceeds of drug transactions, "and that's very conservative," said John F. Forbes, a Customs investigator.
For the last six months, the Treasury Department required 15 of the largest companies transferring money to the Dominican Republic to report all transactions larger than $750, well below the $10,000 threshold set by Federal law. The move had an immediate effect. In the last four months of 1997, the total value of transfers of $749 or less rose by more than $24 million, to $104.6 million, Treasury Department officials said. Transactions of $750 to $3,000 -- which were now being reported to Federal authorities -- fell by nearly two-thirds, the officials said.
As Mr. Forbes said: "The money laundering is definitely going up as Dominican immigration goes up and the interaction between the Colombians and Dominicans goes up. And New York is ground zero."
