HEADLINE: A Nuclear Threat From India

 BODY:
India's explosion of three nuclear devices in the Rajasthan desert makes the world a more dangerous place. By arrogantly challenging international efforts to control the spread of the most lethal weapons, the new Hindu nationalist Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee may win applause at home from those who confuse military might with self-esteem. But for a paltry and short-lived domestic gain, India now faces a ruinous cutoff in foreign aid, a self-defeating arms race with Pakistan and isolation even from friends.
With an economy that is slowing down, India needs help to ease its crushing poverty and overcome its many ethnic divisions. Yet President Clinton has no choice, legally or morally, but to impose broad economic sanctions, as he said yesterday he would do. Such an action properly is to include a ban on military sales and assistance, foreign aid and bank loans to the Government. Federal law also compels the United States to oppose loans and technical assistance from the World Bank and other financial institutions, which supply billions of dollars in credits vital to India's solvency. 
 Mr. Clinton has sought to improve relations with India and was planning to make the first Presidential visit there in 20 years this fall. But he should now reconsider. India might still clear the way for a useful visit if it stopped testing and signed the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. It could justify such a step by citing China and France, which tested nuclear weapons a few years ago, provoking an international outcry, and then declared they would sign the treaty. It was India's founding Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, who first proposed such a treaty a generation ago, and it is not too late for India to redeem his vision. Pakistan has said it would sign if India goes along.
India has much to be proud of as the world's most populous democracy. But its bitter colonial legacy has made Indian leaders distrustful of outside powers, especially those with nuclear weapons that lecture others about nuclear restraint. India justifies its latest tests by citing the military threat from its neighbors to the north and west. But beyond minor border disputes, China has no hostile designs on India. It is deplorable that China has aided Pakistan with its military program, but Pakistan, with or without nuclear weapons, is more than matched by India's conventional and nuclear capacity. By testing a weapon now, India is likely to provoke Pakistan and plunge both sides into more arms programs that neither can afford.
Less than a decade after the end of the cold war, the gravest threat of nuclear war is now shaping up in South Asia. As if to show sensitivity to global opinion, Prime Minister Vajpayee indicated that India had not yet moved to convert its capability into actual weapons. Mr. Clinton should seek India's pledge to exercise restraint in developing nuclear warheads and in testing missiles capable of delivering them. He can also press China to stop the flow of technology to Pakistan and thus reassure India about its security concerns.
It is fashionable in some circles to say that India and Pakistan are capable of managing their nuclear relationship, just as the United States and the Soviet Union did throughout the cold war. But the superpowers were lucky to avoid a war in 1962, and they built up an elaborate regimen of safeguards to preserve the peace, which India and Pakistan lack. In the end, the Soviet Union collapsed under the weight of its efforts to keep up militarily. For India to avoid that fate, it must seek safety in arms control and restraint, not a nuclear buildup.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Home Loans Discriminate, Study Shows

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 12

 BODY:
Racial discrimination and abuse by lenders of a Federal mortgage program are helping to create pockets of blight in black and Hispanic neighborhoods, according to a study of lending in the Chicago area.
The study, by the Chicago Fair Housing Alliance, an advocacy group, contends that lenders and real estate agents direct a disproportionate number of minority buyers to Federal Housing Administration loans. Since the loans are especially profitable for lenders, unqualified home buyers are given the loans and minority neighborhoods are pockmarked with the foreclosed homes of buyers who should never have been approved for the mortgage, the study concluded. 
 "Were any private mortgage lending or mortgage insurance institutions engaged in activities with such clearly differential impacts for white and minority communities, HUD and the Department of Justice would surely file suit for discrimination under the Fair Housing Act," said Calvin Bradford, a fair-housing researcher who wrote the study, which was financed by the MacArthur Foundation. The study is to be released on Wednesday at a hearing of a House housing subcommittee, where the study's author and others will testify.
A spokeswoman for the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which enforces fair housing laws and oversees the F.H.A., said that the study's portrayal of the agency was "rather extreme," but agreed that elements of the program "require additional improvement and reform."
The F.H.A. was created in the Great Depression to assist homebuyers who could not qualify for conventional mortgages. While F.H.A. loans allow buyers with less money for a downpayment to buy a home, the interest rates are usually higher than those for conventional loans.
Nationally, African-American and Hispanic homebuyers received F.H.A. loans more than twice as often as white homebuyers, which might be expected because minority home buyers have, on average, lower incomes and worse credit ratings.
But the researchers found a surprising pattern: As they looked at middle-income and upper-income minority neighborhoods, the percentage of F.H.A. loans did not decline, as it did for whites, but increased. Even high-income black neighborhoods had higher rates of F.H.A. lending -- 67 percent -- than low-income white neighborhoods -- 32 percent.
Steering by real estate agents explains part of this pattern. In tests of more than 50 real estate firms, agents steered minority buyers to minority neighborhoods, when the buyers had expressed no preference. Many agents also steered minority buyers to lenders that specialized in F.H.A. loans.
This occurred although, in every case, the minority "testers" had higher incomes and were more credit-worthy than the white testers.
The study found that Housing Department policies discouraged lenders from caring whether they were making sound loans. The fees that F.H.A. pays to lenders are twice as high as those for conventional loans. And by guaranteeing full repayment of mortgages, F.H.A. reduces a lender's incentive to make sound loans, the fair housing group contends.
"You have people being steered to F.H.A. who don't need it," Mr. Bradford said, "and at the low end of that market, people are being given F.H.A. loans who don't qualify, who shouldn't really have gotten any loan. We all want more minorities to receive loans. But HUD has never faced the side effects of its programs."
A HUD spokeswoman, Karen Hinton, said that Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo has toughened enforcement since he took office in 1997 and that the department has tightened its standards. Ms. Hinton also said that the high fees for lenders and the loan guarantees are necessary to induce lenders to make the loans. But she denied that they induced lenders to overuse F.H.A.
She agreed with one contention of the Chicago group: that the department could do more to push conventional lenders to lend to minorities.
In general, Ms. Hinton agreed that steering is a problem. "But it's not a problem with F.H.A.'s policy," she said. "That's lenders breaking the law. They see a minority person walk in the door and say, 'I'm not going to make a conventional loan to them.' We're doing everything possible to send a message to the lending committee that they're not going to get away with it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Government Antitrust Push Against Microsoft Picks Up
Microsoft is hoping to start shipping the Windows 98 operating system Friday, but may face a round of lawsuits to halt such a move and limit its freedom to add features to future generations of Windows.
The Federal Government and the Attorneys General of at least 12 states are hoping to file new antitrust suits against Microsoft to stop such a move. A Microsoft competitor, Sun Microsystems, also filed a suit asking a Federal court to block the release. Page A1. 

Former Texaco Executives Cleared
Two former Texaco Inc. executives who had been heard on tape discussing the destruction of documents demanded in a racial discrimination lawsuit against the company were found not guilty on charges they had attempted to obstruct justice. The acquittals stunned and angered civil rights leaders. A1.
 
Stocks Up on Strong Bond Demand
Stocks and bonds rallied after demand for three-year Treasury notes was stronger than expected. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 70.25 points, closing just 30.89 points short of its all-time high of 9,192.66. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 9.15 points, and the Nasdaq jumped 12.09 points, to 1,860.16. Yields on the 30-year Treasury fell to 5.97 percent from 6.03 percent. D9.
 
Hancock Plans to Issue Stock
John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance plans to convert to a publicly held company from one owned by policyholders. D2.
 
Wal-Mart Beats Street Estimates
First-quarter profits at Wal-Mart Stores topped analysts' expectations by 3 cents, coming in at 37 cents a diluted share. D5.
 
Big Fines Voted on Phone Slamming
By a 99-0 vote, the Senate authorized stiff fines and penalties against telephone companies that switch the long-distance service of customers without their permission, a maneuver called slamming. A18.
 
What Is George Soros Up to Now?
Many believe that George Soros, who turned an estimated $1 billion profit betting against the British pound in 1992, is at it again. D9.
 
Body Shop Chief Steps Down
The Body Shop founder Anita Roddick has decided to step down as chief executive. The cosmetics retailer has named Patrick Gournay, whose job will be to improve declining sales and profits at the cosmetics retailer. Mrs. Roddick, 55, has been active in a crusade to stop the testing of cosmetics on animals. D5.
 
Shift Seen on Accounting Method
The accounting method known as a pooling of interest that is being used in many of the recent mega-deals has come under some criticism. But the nation's rule makers said recently that they might offer companies another accounting option, one with all the benefits of pooling and then some, which could accelerate the mad dash to merge in corporate America. Market Place. D8.
 
U.S. Sues to Halt Primestar Deal
The Justice Department sued to block a $1.1 billion plan by MCI Communications and News Corporation to sell direct-broadcast satellite assets to Primestar Partners. D7.
 
Huge Long Island Bond Sale Begins
The Long Island Power Authority began marketing its first batch of tax-free bonds to pay for a $7 billion takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service. B7.

HEADLINE: Bond Bonanza Amid Lilco Takeover

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: SYOSSET, N.Y., May 12

 BODY:
When the largest municipal bond issue in the nation's history went on sale this week, the telephones at the David Lerner Associates brokerage headquarters here began lighting up.
The Long Island Lighting Company, which many Long Islanders have resented for years for its high bills, was being broken up, and some were eager to get a piece of it. 
 At least one buyer said he had been waiting for the opportunity for more than a decade. "I've been overpaying Lilco for 40 years," said the buyer, who would give only his first name, Phil. Maybe, he said, the interest on the bonds being sold by the Long Island Power Authority would help make up for that.
All 150 brokers at the David Lerner offices were doing virtually nothing else but fielding telephone orders for the bonds. In just a day and a half, the brokerage concern had taken orders for about $25 million of the bonds. The gray and burgundy cubicles were still abuzz about the eager client who had come in the week before and ordered $2 million.
Such scenes were duplicated at brokerages around the region and the country as the Power Authority began marketing its first batch of tax-free bonds to pay for a $7 billion takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service.
With savings from lower interest costs, Gov. George E. Pataki has promised to cut local electricity bills by 20 percent by summer. Islanders now pay the highest electricity rates in North America.
"A lot of my clients are calling me because they heard about it and are interested," said one Lerner broker, Ralph G. Haebich. "I had one walk-in client last night who drove all the way from Queens in the rain. The yields are very attractive, based on this market. Most people are yield-hungry, looking for the best interest rate."
The preliminary rates, subject to change when they are formally set on Wednesday, ranged from 3.9 to 5.6 percent, depending on a bond's maturity, whether it is insured and whether it is a variable or fixed rate. The final rate changes are not expected to be more than 0.15 percent.
The orders on Monday and today were limited to individual buyers, with $5,000 being the smallest denomination. Typical sales at Lerner were in the $25,000 to $50,000 range. On Wednesday the sale opens up to large institutional investors like mutual funds, property and casualty insurance companies and banks. Underwriters will market any remaining amount.
Anticipation had been building among the brokers as well as the buyers. On one computer, a sales assistant had designed a spinning LIPABONDS logo in vivid red, orange and green as her screen-saver.
Most brokers were busy until the sale ended at 1 P.M. today, when the office here cleared out a bit for lunch. "At 1, everybody finally took a breather," said Lerner's managing director of trading, William Mason. And when the nationwide sales by all brokerage companies were totaled later in the day, the figure was nearly $807 million -- well over the $500 million to $700 million range predicted by the Power Authority.
If all goes according to plan, by the end of the week the authority will have sold more than $3 billion of bonds. An additional $2 billion or so will be sold within a few months, and the rest will be sold this year or next.
The total of $7 billion would dwarf the largest previous municipal bond issues, $2.8 billion for a New Jersey state pension fund last year and $2 billion for the New Jersey Turnpike several years ago.
The investors who stand to gain the most are New York and Puerto Rico residents, for whom the bonds are exempt from local, state and Federal income taxes -- a triple exemption for New York City residents. Typical customers tend to be older, conservative investors or those in high income brackets avoiding taxes. But the interest rates are high enough to draw some out-of-state buyers as well.
To promote the sale, the Power Authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, went on a tour pitching the bonds to investment analysts and mutual funds and other potential buyers. Cities on his trips included New Orleans, San Francisco, Chicago, Minneapolis, Boston, Hartford and Philadelphia.
"Richie Kessel did a good job in his road show," said William Mason, Lerner's managing director of trading. In staff meetings, the 150 brokers here and at Lerner's branch offices were all briefed on the sale. The company's 35,000 clients received a brochure enclosed with their monthly account statements last week, and the Power Authority promoted the bonds in radio commercials.
"There is a certain pizazz to these bonds," said Lerner's founder and president, David Lerner. Long Islanders, he said, are especially aware of the background, making for easier sales here.
"I am confident there will be a lot of happy investors, that it will deliver exactly as promised," Mr. Lerner said. He added he had followed his own advice. "I've taken a sizable position on the bonds myself," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At David Lerner Associates in Syosset, N.Y., executives conferred yesterday on a huge offering of bonds by the Long Island Power Authority. From left were Ralph G. Haebich, Anthony Meere and William Mason. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE BLUNDERS;
U.S. Blundered On Intelligence, Officials Admit

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The United States' inability to foresee or forestall India's nuclear tests, despite ample warnings, was a failure of both the Central Intelligence Agency and American foreign policymakers, Government officials said today.
After the chairman of the Senate intelligence committee called it "the intelligence failure of the decade," the Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, asked retired Adm. David E. Jeremiah, a former Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to lead a 10-day investigation into the intelligence community's failure to detect preparations at the test site in the Indian desert. 
 The site has been under periodic surveillance by photo reconnaissance and electronic eavesdropping satellites, which recorded increasing activity. But the images and activities they recorded in recent days were not interpreted clearly or quickly by the C.I.A., officials said.
That oversight constituted "a colossal failure on the part of our intelligence agencies," said the chairman, Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama. "Something went wrong. Somebody failed to do their job. To let this slip up on our policy makers, the President, the Secretary of State, without a chance to intervene in some way diplomatically with India was a huge intelligence failure. If we had an inkling that they were going to detonate one or more nuclear weapons, perhaps we could have intervened. We certainly would have tried."
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, former Ambassador to India and former vice chairman of the intelligence panel, said the fault was not just with the intelligence gatherers.
"Why didn't the C.I.A. find this out?" he asked. "The question is why don't we learn to read? What's the State Department for? The political leadership in India as much as said they were going to begin testing. There's a tendency at the State Department to say, 'Gee, the C.I.A. never told us.' "
Administration officials defended their lack of knowledge and action by saying the Indian Government had fooled them into thinking that it would not conduct nuclear testing.
"They didn't just fool the C.I.A., they fooled the entire U.S. Government, and I'm the first to admit they fooled me, too," a senior Administration official said. "We were all just lulled into thinking they wouldn't do anything regarding nuclear weapons. They led us to believe they were not going to do anything precipitous. We made the mistake of assuming they would act rationally."
He added, "We had no clue."
Others said warning signs were everywhere, to be read by diplomats, as well as spies: the announced intentions of the new Hindu nationalist Government to make nuclear weapons part of its arsenal; the published pronouncements of India's Atomic Weapons Commissioner, who said two months ago that he was ready to test if political leaders gave the go-ahead, and recent missile tests by Pakistan that all but dared New Dehli to respond.
A result, Administration officials said, was the biggest breach in the arms-control net in years. United States policy on stopping the spread of nuclear weapons failed to prevent the test, and that could set off a chain reaction.
It is now far more likely that Pakistan, whose arms programs have immeasurably been aided by China, to the bitter resentment of India, will test a nuclear weapon, officials said. They said tonight that they were seeing signs that Pakistan was preparing to conduct a test.
The Indian test also increases the chances, they said, that Pakistan will retest its new medium-range missile, the Ghauri, named after a Muslim warrior who defeated a 12th-century Hindu emperor, Prithvi, which happens to be the name of India's most advanced missile.
George Perkovich, an expert on the Indian nuclear program and director of the Secure World program at the W. Alton Jones Foundation, said: "The Indians have been out there for months at the site. There was activity, but nobody in the United States said, 'Uh-oh, this means something.' "
Diplomatic silence played a role. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was appalled, her spokesman said, that Foreign Secretary Krishnan Raghunath of India met on May 1 with the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, and Undersecretary of State Thomas R. Pickering, but gave no hint of tests.
But in hindsight, the evidence was nearly as clear as it was in December 1995. Then United States spy satellites saw thick electric cables being installed at a hole in the Rajasthan desert, evidence that India was preparing its first nuclear test since 1974. Word went out that Washington was watching, and India backed down. The test never took place.
The test site in Pokaran was buzzing again this month. But the spy satellites missed the clues. They were looking, but not closely enough to see clearly. The Indians disguised the activities. Sandstorms obscured the site, and in any case, neither the machines nor the people who analyze their output are infallible.
It takes decisions by policy makers and millions of dollars a day to adjust the satellites' orbits, so that they can focus intently 24 hours a day on a target. It is unclear whether the United States had round-the-clock coverage of the site. The satellites take pictures with high-resolution cameras and eavesdrop on telecommunications. But they do what their human masters tell them, and they failed to focus on what was really occurring in the Indian desert.
The focus was lacking for American policy as well, said Francine Frankel, director of the Center for the Advanced Study of India at the University of Pennsylvania.
"This crisis has been in the works for a long time," Ms. Frankel said. "We assumed that we could separate our common economic interests and our differences on the nuclear issue. That was never realistic. There were many warning signs that it was impossible to bridge that gap. We are now faced with a question of whether we want to have a hostile relationship with India."
She said, and Mr. Moynihan agreed, that India saw itself as destined to be a global power and that United States policy makers had never understood that vision.
Nor did the Clinton Administration see that its failure to accomplish big cuts in nuclear arms gave India little reason to hold off becoming a nuclear power, Clinton and Bush Administration officials said.
When Pakistan held missile tests last month, the United States completely misread India's fury, Mr. Perkovich said, adding: "The U.S. mistook the silence for calm. They took it to believe the Indians were O.K. But they were coldly angered at the U.S. for, in their view, not constraining Pakistan." On Monday, unnoticed by Washington, that anger reached critical mass.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE POLICY;
CLINTON TO IMPOSE PENALTIES ON INDIA OVER ATOMIC TESTS

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
President Clinton decided tonight to impose a raft of economic sanctions on India's Government on Wednesday for detonating three underground nuclear explosions, senior Administration officials said.
The President's decision -- made aboard Air Force One as Mr. Clinton traveled to Germany -- came after a hectic day in which the Administration had offered India a way to avoid the sanctions if it would disavow any future testing or deployment of nuclear weapons, other Administration officials said. 
 But even as nations around the world condemned the tests conducted on Monday, New Delhi signaled no willingness to consider the Administration's demands, the officials said. By day's end, India's intransigence cleared the way for the harsh punishments called for in the Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act, which Congress passed and Mr. Clinton signed in 1994, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Behind that intransigence is the overwhelming popularity of the tests among Indians. Page A12.
The nuclear sanctions law, never before used, will cut off virtually all aid to India, bar American banks from making loans to its Government and restrict exports of computers and other equipment that might have military uses. It will also require the United States to oppose loans to India by the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund.
"There are no indications from the Indians that they are prepared to take any significant steps," a senior Administration official said tonight. Another official said India responded this evening by merely pleading for more time, without directly addressing the Administration's concerns.
The President's decision to impose sanctions swiftly came as other American Government officials said there were already indications that Pakistan appeared to be preparing a nuclear test in response.
Appearing at the White House this afternoon before he left the country for a meeting with other world leaders, Mr. Clinton said he was "deeply disturbed" by India's tests, although he stopped short of announcing the sanctions. Instead he called on India to conduct no further tests and to sign "now and without conditions" the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, which prohibits all experiments with nuclear explosions.
The President's remarks largely echoed what Administration officials had conveyed to the Indians in private in a late appeal to persuade them to step back from their widely denounced decision to conduct India's first nuclear tests since 1974.
In a letter to Mr. Clinton that was dated Monday but disclosed today, India's new Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, did not address the proposals but simply offered an unrepentant justification for the tests. Although Pakistan has long been India's chief rival, Mr. Vajpayee cited its fears of China, stemming from border disputes, as well as China's support to Pakistan.
"Although our relations with that country have improved in the last decade or so, an atmosphere of distrust persists mainly due to the unresolved border problem," he wrote, referring to China. "To add to that distrust, that country has materially helped another neighbor of ours to become a covert nuclear weapons state."
The Administration's warnings were delivered to Mr. Vajpayee's Government this afternoon by Thomas R. Pickering, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. Senior State Department officials said Mr. Pickering had not explicitly offered the Indians anything, but simply outlined the sanctions India faced and sought to clarify its statement on Monday signaling a willingness to adhere to some terms of a ban on nuclear testing.
The other officials, however, said the National Security Council had resisted the State Department's recommendation to impose sanctions immediately today to allow the Indians time to respond to the appeals. The Administration's efforts underscored the scramble to find an effective way to respond to the tests, which re-ignited fears of an arms race in South Asia.
Senator John Glenn, the Democrat from Ohio who sponsored the sanctions law, said today that it was meant to impose punishment, swiftly and harshly. He said India's tests, in defiance of the international ban on testing, were an enormous setback to efforts to reduce nuclear weapons after the end of the cold war.
American aid and trade with India is relatively small, with about $7.7 billion in American exports and $7.3 billion in Indian imports. And compared with more freewheeling neighbors like Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea, India has relied less on borrowing from international commercial banks.
Still, the sanctions could have enormous political effect that could ripple through India's economy.
"I don't see a huge direct impact on American companies," said Marshall Bouton, executive vice president of the Asia Society, a nonprofit public education organization in New York. "But it's obviously deeply unsettling to U.S.-Indo relations, and there would be a chilling effect on trade in the short and mid terms."
The United States gave $142.5 million in direct aid in the last fiscal year, including developmental and food assistance, and such aid would end in the future. The Pentagon also announced today that sanctions would halt the modest military sales and training programs the United States has begun with India.
More significantly, India is the largest borrower from the World Bank, having borrowed $44 billion to date, including $1.5 billion this year. While the United States cannot unilaterally dictate how the World Bank lends money, it wields enormous influence that can be used to block consideration of India's programs.
At the White House today, Mr. Clinton said the testing "not only threatens the stability of the region, it directly challenges the firm international consensus to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction."
He called on "India's neighbors" -- without naming Pakistan and China -- "not to follow down the path of a dangerous arms race." He then warned that he would impose the sanctions called for by the Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act.
Joining several other nations. the United States recalled its Ambassador to India, Richard Celeste. The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, also suggested that the tests might force Mr. Clinton to cancel his plans to visit India this year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton discussed India at a news conference yesterday. (Reuters)(pg. A1)
 
Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: The Price for India"
India's recent nuclear tests have brought the U.S. to the brink of imposing sanctions as required under the 1994 Nuclear Proliferation Act. Here are what the sanctions would affect.
 
WORLD BANK LOANS
There are 84 projects in India worth $14.5 billion financed by loans from the World Bank. Commitments in the 1997 fiscal year total $1.5 billion. The United States would oppose all loans.
 
I.M.F. LOANS
The United States would oppose all loans from the International Monetary Fund.
 
UNITED STATES AID
Most military and economic aid would be cut off. Aid totaled $142.5 million last year and is estimated at $141.9 million in 1998.
 
EXPORTS TO INDIA
1997 exports to India were $3.6 billion. Sanctions would affect products with military uses.
 
BANK LOANS
American bank loans to the Indian Government would be barred.
 
(Sources: World Bank; India Embassy)(pg. A14)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
PACKARD BELL NEC TO CLOSE 2 PLANTS AND CUT 400 JOBS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Packard Bell NEC will close two plants and slash 400 jobs, or 5 percent of the work force, in an effort to cut costs and turn around the falling market share at the personal computer maker. Packard Bell said its plants in Fife, Wash., and Boxborough, Mass., would close and the notebook computer and sales and service groups and most of the engineering group that were based at those sites would move to the company's 400-acre headquarters in Sacramento, Calif. Last year, unit shipments for Packard Bell, the fifth-largest personal computer maker, fell 8.3 percent, and its market share slipped to 4.8 percent, from 6 percent, according to Dataquest Inc.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE SUBCONTINENT;
India Glows With Pride As Outrage Rises Abroad

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 12

 BODY:
The Indian Government won overwhelming support at home today for three nuclear tests it conducted in the desert on Monday, but senior officials hinted that they might try to soften the international outcry against them by considering signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
Murli Manohar Joshi, one official who hinted at a more amenable Indian position on the test ban treaty, also suggested that the Government was considering moving beyond the tests to the actual deployment of nuclear weapons, a step likely to generate an even stronger international response. 
 "Indian scientists will put a nuclear warhead on missiles as soon as the situation requires," said Mr. Joshi, a nuclear physicist who is the Minister of Science and Technology. He added: "India will not attack any state. The new capability will only deter an arms race."
The test ban treaty, adopted in 1996 and endorsed by 149 nations, has been shunned so far by India and Pakistan. But Indian officials in the Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee attached conditions to any offer to sign the treaty. Mr. Joshi said New Delhi would abandon its opposition to the treaty if it were revised to set a deadline for all nations to eliminate nuclear weapons and to ban computer-simulated tests -- conditions already rejected by the United States and other established nuclear powers.
Endorsement of the tests came from most of India's most influential newspapers, from leading opposition politicians, from student groups, and even from Tushar Gandhi, a great-grandson of Mohandas K. Gandhi, India's apostle of nonviolence, who told the Associated Press that he was "proud it was done in India and by Indians." A leading Hindu nationalist who is the most powerful politician in Bombay, Balasaheb K. Thackeray, was thrilled. "We have to prove that we are not eunuchs," he said.
More cautious Indian commentators saw such reactions as premature, especially since the tests' full consequences could not be reckoned without knowing the reaction of India's arch-rival, Pakistan. Despite hawkish statements by some top Pakistani officials pledging "a matching response," reports from Islamabad indicated that the Government was weighing carefully what many there saw as one of the most critical decisions in the nation's history.
Islamabad's choice appeared to lie between responding with a nuclear test of its own, thereby risking the same economic sanctions that threaten India, or showing restraint, which would earn Western goodwill but risk the wrath of hardline Muslim groups, the armed forces and other powerful factions. Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan's former Prime Minister, has said the country has been ready to test for at least two years.
A measure of the pressures on Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who returned to Islamabad today from Central Asia, came from Pakistan's top nuclear scientist, Abdul Qadeer Khan. "We are like a cook waiting for the orders," Mr. Khan said in a Pakistani newspaper.
Another pointer came from the politically powerful army chief, Gen. Jehangir Karamat. "So far we have not disappointed our nation in respect of our security capability and we will never disappoint our people now," he told reporters.
Prime Minister Sharif said Pakistan would not bow to Western pressures in determining whether to stage a nuclear test. "I will not accept dictation from outside in safeguarding the security of the country," the 48-year-old Mr. Sharif said.
Since a landslide election victory in February 1997, he has been widely criticized in Pakistan for heavy-handed pursuit of enhanced political power, which commentators have said might incline him to reach for the popular acclaim a nuclear test might bring.
But pressures on Mr. Sharif appeared to be finely balanced. As the meetings in Islamabad continued, President Clinton's announcement in Washington that he intended to implement economic sanctions against India set a high price for any nuclear test by Pakistan.
Some financial experts believe that Pakistan's tottering economy makes Islamabad especially vulnerable to one of Washington's economic weapons -- pressure on the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to suspend credits. For years, Pakistan has escaped default on more than $60 billion of debt by taking emergency I.M.F. loans. Indian officials noted pointedly today that India currently has $26 billion in foreign exchange reserves and has no need for I.M.F. assistance.
Such was the support in India for the tests that even church groups seemed reluctant to condemn them outright. An ecumenical group representing India's leading Roman Catholic and Protestant bishops issued a statement noting that poverty in the Indian subcontinent made it "imperative" that the region's resources be devoted to helping people, but it supported one of the Government's rationales for the test. "The infirmities of the test ban treaty have contributed to the arms race among the poorer nations," the bishops said.
Crucially for the Hindu nationalists who lead a fragile 14-party coalition, the explosions seemed also to have been enormously popular with ordinary Indians. Informal interviews in New Delhi found no dissenters. "I was thrilled," said Daksha Rajan, a 27-year-old engineer.
Jaya Srivastava, a 36-year-old history lecturer at Delhi University, said: "It's a good step. Now we can talk as equals with other nuclear powers."
Marendra Haryani, a 52-year-old department store owner, said, "China has nuclear weapons, so why should we not have them?"
Some of the strongest cautions in India came from the financial sector, which has been depressed for 18 months by a sluggish economy and now faces the possibility of further setbacks from sanctions. One measure came on Bombay's stock market, where two leading indexes were down more than 5 percent today before recovering slightly.
But India's Finance Minister, Yashwant Sinha, told reporters that "India is not worried at all" about sanctions, and a spokesman for the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist group, was still more dismissive. "Let them go ahead with their sanctions," said K. R. Malkani. "They cannot blackmail us in this manner. We have to think of our national security first."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Doctors Accuse Insurers Of Bias Against Women

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A doctors' group has accused insurance companies of sex discrimination for covering the impotence pill Viagra but not birth control for women. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists yesterday urged Congress to require insurers that pay for prescription drugs to cover contraception as well.
Contraception is a medical necessity, said Dr. Anita Nelson, a spokeswoman for the doctors' group meeting this week in New Orleans. 
 Insurers said that birth-control coverage was available but that many employers did not offer such benefits because of the cost.
While 9 of 10 employer-based health insurance plans cover prescription drugs, most did not cover prescription contraceptives, the doctors' group said. By contrast, nearly half of the almost 300,000 men who take Viagra each week are reimbursed at least in part, according to IMS Health, a consulting group.

HEADLINE: Buyout Funds Exploring Bid For Polygram

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Forstmann Little & Company and the Thomas H. Lee Company, two of the nation's largest leveraged buyout funds, are weighing a bid for Polygram N.V., the giant music company, several people close to the discussions said yesterday.
The team's investment banker, Allen & Company, has sent letters to both the supervisory board of Polygram and its parent company, Royal Philips Electronics N.V., the giant Dutch electronics company that owns 75 percent of Polygram, saying that they are interested in exploring a bid. So far, there has been no response to the letters, which were sent on Monday, one person close to the discussions said. 
 The Seagram Company, which owns MCA and Universal Studios, had already been in talks with Philips over a possible acquisition of Polygram. Seagram and Philips are believed to have set a deadline of Sunday to reach a deal. The possibility of a rival bid, however, may complicate matters since Philips would be obliged to consider it for the sake of its shareholders.
Officials from both Seagram and Philips declined to comment. The chairman of Philips, Cornelis Boonstra, was in New York yesterday.
Although the price being considered by either Seagram or the buyout firms is not known, Polygram, whose shares trade on the New York Stock Exchange, has a market value of $9 billion.
The letters from Forstmann, which is based in New York, and Thomas H. Lee, in Boston, do not mention a powerful Hollywood figure who could well play a role in a possible deal: Michael Ovitz, the former talent agency chief who was ousted in 1996 as president of the Walt Disney Company. Mr. Ovitz was instrumental in bringing the two firms together, people close to the discussions said.
Mr. Ovitz is a friend of Theodore J. Forstmann, the chairman of Forstmann Little, and is on the board of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, which is controlled by the firm. In addition, in a deal announced last month, Mr. Ovitz invested $20 million in and took control of Livent Inc., the troubled theatrical production company based in Toronto. As part of the deal, he and Mr. Lee, whose firm owns 8.5 percent of Livent, agreed to support each other's nominees for the board.
The possibility that buyout firms would bid for Polygram had some record industry experts scratching their heads yesterday. Seagram, which has a successful record company of its own, can offer economies of scale that are not available to the firms. Seagram could cut marketing, distribution and other costs, for example, that might save it as much as $200 million to $350 million a year, the industry experts said.
A leveraged buyout group, on the other hand, would probably have to put up $2 billion to $3 billion and borrow the balance to buy Polygram, whose artists include Elton John, U2 and Janet Jackson.
Though the numbers are not public, each firm is estimated to have a fund of about $4 billion. In general, leveraged buyout funds by policy do not put more than 25 percent to 40 percent of their funds into a single deal. But in some cases, to raise additional equity financing, they ask investors if they want to invest alongside the fund.
An offer from two buyout firms might appeal to the president of Polygram, Alain Levy, and his management team. They would presumably have a better chance of staying in place under a financial buyer with no management team of its own, than if Seagram bought the company. Both Forstmann and Thomas H. Lee are known to expand companies and then either sell them or take them public.
One reason that the two firms may be attracted to Polygram is that the record industry in general has a relatively predictable cash flow. For 1997, Polygram had revenue of $5.7 billion and cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of $750 million. If not for losses in the film division, the figure would have been $55 million higher.
Mr. Lee, however, was quoted in Forbes magazine earlier this year as saying: "I'm willing to spend 8 to 10 times cash flow in any market for a company with strong growth characteristics." In the case of Polygram, the buyer would be paying at the higher end of that range.
Still, a financial buyer could sell off Polygram's money-losing film operation with its library of 1,500 films. And as one Wall Street investment expert put it, "The leveraged buyout funds are so bloated with capital that they have to look around for deals and they end up expressing interest in more mature companies than they would have bought two years ago."
If there is an offer for Polygram, it would mark the first time that Forstmann Little had joined with another firm to make an offer. 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 14, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a possible bid for Polygram, the giant music company, included an artist erroneously among those who record for it. Janet Jackson is on Virgin Records, which is owned by EMI Group P.L.C.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: IN RUSSIA;
Kremlin Soft-Pedals Its Rebuke to India, and Opposes Sanctions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 13

 BODY:
Russia today reaffirmed its refusal to join other countries in punishing India for resuming nuclear tests, and has so far failed to register an especially strong diplomatic protest.
President Boris N. Yeltsin still plans to visit India later this year. And some top officials at Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy want to go ahead with plans to sell India two nuclear power plants. 
 "Sanctions are an extreme measure, which is not always productive," Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov said. "Therefore, I don't think we shall support any sanctions against India."
None of this means that Moscow is eager to see a nuclear arms race in Southern Asia. Russian diplomats have publicly deplored the blasts and say they hope Pakistan will not respond in kind.
Having decided to stop nuclear testing, the Russian military is not happy to see other nations flout the call for a worldwide ban on nuclear explosions.
"We deeply regret this action," Vladimir Rakhmanin, the chief spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry, said. "We believe we may influence India through political and diplomatic means."
But Russia's complaints have been muted and reflect its close commercial ties with India. Rosvooruzheniye, Russia's Government-owned arms export company, said last week that India was one of its largest buyers, no small consideration for military factories that have fallen on hard times.
The muffled criticism is also a matter of foreign policy. India's rivalry with China makes it a potential counterweight to Beijing in the Russian strategic calculus -- just as it was in Soviet times.
India's strained relations with Washington also make New Delhi a sympathetic partner for the Russian Foreign Ministry, whose influence has shrunk since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
"In Russia's corridors of power they don't allow for the possibility of economic sanctions or the recalling of ambassadors," the newspaper Izvestia observed today. "Moscow seems ready to close its eyes to the violations of international norms."
Moscow's modulated reaction has undercut Washington's effort to teach the Indians a lesson.
The United States' sharp riposte after the blasts almost certainly came as little surprise to India. A tough response by India's friends, however, might have persuaded the Indian Government that its nuclear ambitions meant diplomatic isolation.
President Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin discussed India's tests and other security issues in a long telephone conversation on Tuesday, according to Sergei Prikhodko, an adviser to Mr. Yeltsin. But there has been no indication that Russia is prepared to harden its position.
"Frankly, India is a very good friend of ours and we have very good relations," Mr. Yeltsin said on Tuesday. "During my visit to India this year I shall make every effort to somehow overcome the problem."
India's tests have confronted Russia with a difficult decision: whether to sell nuclear power plants to India in a deal that is worth $1.5 billion to $2 billion. The contract was to be made final this year.
Moscow has argued that the nuclear plants are intended for civilian use and would be subject to international monitoring to prevent them from contributing to India's military potential.
But Washington has protested the sale, saying it violates a 1992 agreement among nuclear suppliers not to sell nuclear technology to aspiring nuclear powers.
The American objections were lodged long before India's latest tests, but the blasts have raised the stakes.
Viktor Mikhailov, the hard-line first deputy minister at Russia's Atomic Energy Ministry, insists the sale should go through.
"Our contacts have deep roots," Mr. Mikhailov said, referring to Russia's relations with India. "And the competition on the global market for construction of atomic stations is very tough. So I hope that the leadership of our country will help safeguard this market for us."
Other Russian aides, however, suggested the sale might only go ahead if India assured the world it would abandon nuclear testing.
But while Russian officials defended their quiet diplomacy, Moscow seems to have no success in persuading India to curtail its nuclear program.
For all the close cooperation, Moscow insisted it had no advance warning of recent explosions.
"This nuclear test came as a big surprise," Mr. Yeltsin said on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Appeal to Indonesia Military to Stop Crackdown

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, concluding that it has almost no remaining diplomatic leverage with the Government of Indonesia to stem the growing violence there, has decided to dispatch a high-level military delegation to demand that the security forces end their attacks on civilian demonstrators, officials said.
They said the delegation of military officers, which is being led by Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, the commander of all American military forces in the Pacific, is scheduled to travel to Indonesia on Thursday to warn their Indonesian counterparts in blunt terms that the country could face collapse without restraint by the armed forces. 
The officials said that Admiral Prueher would make what one described as a "soldier-to-soldier" appeal for restraint to Gen. Wiranto, the chief of the 400,000-strong Indonesian armed forces.
The Indonesian security forces killed at least six students at an elite private college in Jakarta on Tuesday, and there were reports of looting and setting of fires today in the Indonesian capital. At least one person was killed this afternoon, when a runaway truck plunged into a crowd. The looting continued into the night, when crowds turned their anger on the familiar target of ethnic Chinese shopkeepers, with reports of people being trapped in burning buildings.
Administration officials said that the Pentagon hoped that Admiral Prueher's trip not be seen as an effort by the United States to side with the military against President Suharto, or with the military against anti-Government demonstrators.
"Our concern -- plain and simple -- is to do what we can to prevent the violence from spilling out of control," one said. "There is no other agenda. There is certainly no political agenda."
The Indonesian leader, who is facing the gravest challenge to his rule in the 32 years since he came to power, cut short an official visit to Egypt today to return home to deal with the turmoil, which began last summer with the collapse of the Indonesian currency, the rupiah, and has since expanded into a large political uprising against the Government.
While General Wiranto -- like many Indonesians, he has only one name -- is seen as a reliable supporter of President Suharto, he is also described by associates as a thoughtful soldier who would ultimately put the interests of the nation and the military ahead of the interests of the Indonesian President.
The Pentagon's decision to dispatch Admiral Prueher's delegation, which has not been announced publicly, came as Defense Secretary William S. Cohen released a memorandum to his colleagues in the Pentagon in which he barred all routine travel to Indonesia without special approval.
Mr. Cohen said the order was made necessary by "the unsettled political situation in Indonesia and the related prospects for violence and instability."
Administration officials, speaking on condition that they not be named, stressed that the United States military would have no role on the ground in Indonesia unless American troops were needed in the evacuation of the nearly 10,000 Americans who live and work across that vast archipelago nation.
They said that no evacuation order was imminent, and that there appeared to be no special danger to Americans or other Westerners in the country. About half of the American residents of Indonesia live in Jakarta an its suburbs.
One reason for sending a military delegation, officials said, was that there seemed little hope that direct appeals to President Suharto for calm would have much impact given that he has dismissed appeals made in recent months by a series of foreign leaders and high-level American emissaries, including former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.
Mr. Mondale visited Indonesia in March at the request of President Clinton to ask that President Suharto abide by the terms of a $43 billion Western bailout for the Indonesian economy.
Admiral Prueher, the commander-in-chief of the United States Pacific Command and the senior American military officer in the Pacific and Indian oceans, has been warning for months in his public comments of the possibility that Indonesia's economic crisis could undermine its political stability.
"It's the primary discussion point everywhere we go," he said in a meeting with reporters several weeks ago, warning that "the potential for instability has been high on our list for a while."
He is expected to meet both with General Wiranto, who took the post of armed services chief earlier this year, and Lieut. Gen. Prabowo Subianto, President Suharto's son-in-law and the commander of a 27,000-member elite Army unit that is responsible for security around Jakarta.
General Prabowo is widely seen as General Wiranto's chief rival within the Indonesia military, which has a direct political role in Indonesia through its control of a large share of the seats in the national Parliament.
General Wiranto drew cautious praise from many diplomats in Jakarta earlier this month when he announced the formation of a team of serving and retired military officers to study the need for basic political reform in Indonesia. "We agree all these demands should be channeled into the national agenda," he said. At the same time, however, he said that "criminals" were responsible for some of the recent demonstrations against the Suharto Government.

HEADLINE: 4 California Rivals Brawl in First Debate

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 13

 BODY:
The four major candidates for governor of California squared off today in the first face-to-face encounter of a primary campaign marked mostly by the cut-and-thrust of television advertising -- and promptly fell to squabbling over the cut-and-thrust of television advertising.
The 80-minute forum, sponsored by The Los Angeles Times, had no sooner begun than the two Democratic rivals of Al Checchi, a multimillionaire businessman making his first run for elective office, sharply attacked him for breaking his pledge not to run negative advertisements. 
 Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis and Representative Jane Harman both accused Mr. Checchi, who has spent some $30 million of his own money on the race, of lowering the standards of the campaign. Mr. Checchi later dismissed them as professional politicians seeking to further their careers and said he had simply drawn factual comparisons between his record and theirs.
Only State Attorney General Dan Lungren, a Republican whose name will be on the same ballot with the Democrats in the state's new "blanket" primary on June 2, emerged largely unscathed, styling himself as a relaxed California conservative in the Ronald Reagan mold and pre-emptively blunting Democratic efforts to paint him as extremist. The top vote getters from each party will face each other in November.
In an encounter carried live on local and cable television, radio and the Internet, the candidates fielded questions on substantive topics from bilingual education (all agree the current system has failed, but all oppose a proposed ballot initiative that would end it) to a projected state budget surplus (Mr. Lungren wants to cut the state's vehicle licensing tax; the Democrats would invest in education).
But there was no shortage of posturing, even when the posturing took the form of denouncing posturing.
"Too many macho politicians say 'Do it my way or not at all, and if you disagree with me, I'll tell the press something naughty you did when you were 12,' " Ms. Harman said in her opening remarks, summing up what would become a theme of the encounter. If a candidate breaks his promises in the campaign, she added, "you can be sure he's going to break his promises when he's elected."
But the telegenic Ms. Harman, who has veered from front-runner to third-place underdog in the polls since she announced her candidacy this winter, clearly saw the debate as perhaps her last best chance to turn her candidacy around. In her own closing statements she unleashed lacerating critiques of her rivals.
Ms. Harman accused Mr. Checchi of "attempting a corporate takeover of California," branded Mr. Lungren, who opposes abortion, as "out of California's mainstream," and turned Mr. Davis's own words against him, mocking his modest admission that it had taken him 23 years in state government to try to move the 15 feet from the chief of staff's office in the Statehouse, where he served former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., to the governor's suite. She countered, "I think we need bolder leadership."
Mr. Davis, whose grave mien is mocked by his colleagues, appeared relaxed, several times mentioning his service as an Army captain in Vietnam and his work for Mr. Brown, still a major figure but a lightning rod in California politics. He drew laughter at one point by arguing that the state needed to make teaching attractive economically "and, as my former boss used to say, psychically." Asked afterward if he thought associating with Mr. Brown was an asset among Democratic voters, Mr. Davis, who leads his Democratic rivals in the polls, drew laughter again by saying simply, "Jerry Brown is -- Jerry Brown exists."
Mr. Checchi, the former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, who has struggled to rise above 20 percent support in the polls, sometimes appeared nervous and his voice quavered a bit as he read from prepared notes to defend himself against his rivals' attacks and dogged questioning by one of the moderators, George Skelton, a veteran political columnist for The Los Angeles Times.
At one point, Mr. Skelton asked about Mr. Checchi's claim in a television advertisement that he had "marched with Martin Luther King for civil rights" -- which the Checchi campaign earlier acknowledged was a reference to how Mr. Checchi, as a teen-ager, attended the 1963 march on Washington with his father.
"We were looking for a verb," Mr. Checchi said. "I think everybody there thought they were marching." He said he had not meant to equate his participation with the heroic struggles of civil rights workers.
He also said his advertisements about his rivals were "factual" and "comparative" and "a response to the guff I've gotten for a year and a half now," from his rivals and their handlers, who have harshly criticized his record at Northwest.
Mr. Lungren had the easiest job, because his Democratic rivals were busy attacking each other, but he made the most of it. Many political experts in the state say he may have trouble winning the governorship as an opponent of abortion. But he sought to stake out narrow grounds on which he would act on the issue as governor, favoring parental consent for abortions by minors, opposing late-term abortions and favoring tough restrictions on taxpayer-financed abortions, positions that he said put him "in the mainstream."
Mr. Lungren also extended a major olive branch to the state's growing Hispanic electorate, announcing for the first time his formal opposition to the initiative that would end bilingual education, even while praising as worthy its supporters' goal of teaching immigrant children English as quickly as possible.
A recent survey by the Public Policy Institute of California found that 85 percent of likely voters in the state said the candidates' performances in debates would influence their votes. At least one other joint forum is scheduled, a bilingual session to be sponsored on May 23 by La Opinion, a Spanish-language newspaper, and by KMEX-TV, a Spanish-language television station.

(Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Panel to Vote on Measure To Tighten Bankruptcy Law

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
With the number of personal bankruptcies soaring, the House Judiciary Committee considered a controversial bill today, promoted by the banking and credit-card industries to make it more difficult for people to declare themselves legally broke.
By defeating several changes proposed by Democrats, the Republicans in control of the committee signaled that they would pass the bill, probably on Thursday. The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to consider a somewhat less strict version as early as Thursday, and both houses could vote next week. 
 The bill, which the Clinton Administration has threatened to veto, would require an income test of those filing for bankruptcy and would constitute the first major change to bankruptcy law in two decades.
Banks and credit card companies argue that the measure is needed to allow them to recoup money from people who use the bankruptcy system to walk away from payments they are able to make. They estimate that of the 1.37 million people who filed for bankruptcy last year, 15 percent had the means to pay their debts. They said this amounted to about $4 billion in forgiven debt, which is passed on to consumers in higher prices and interest rates.
Critics of the bill -- most Democrats and various advocacy groups for consumers, victims, women and children -- complained that it gives credit card companies equal legal footing with single parents who are trying to recover alimony and child-support payments from someone who has filed for bankruptcy.
They contended that the collection agencies hired by banks, department stores and other creditors would be far more aggressive in recouping money than would, say, a single mother. Battling the credit industry in court for priority would leave the single mother even more destitute, they said.
Democrats cast the bill as "Mom versus Chemical Bank," in the words of Representative Jerrold L. Nadler of Manhattan.
Since 1903, Congress has required that anyone in bankruptcy still provide child-support and alimony payments, regardless of other debts. It has since expanded that requirement to include taxes and student loans.
The committee today rejected a sheaf of Democratic proposals to state in iron-clad language that the bill would not put women and children at a disadvantage. Republicans said the final language, as they amended it, offered such protection; Democrats insisted that it was open to interpretation, but they could not rally enough support for their view.
The 177-page bill would require those filing for bankruptcy to undergo a means test. If they had enough money, they would be funneled into Chapter 13 of the bankruptcy law, where they would be put under a court-ordered repayment plan, instead of being able to file under the more lax Chapter 7, where debt is often simply forgiven.
Debtors would be subject to Chapter 13 if they earned at least 75 percent of the nation's median income (now about $39,000) and had the ability to repay at least 20 percent of their debt over five years. Their child-rearing expenses, including support payments, would be subtracted before calculating the ability to repay 20 percent of their debt.
The Senate version would also take into consideration a person's income when he or she files for bankruptcy, but it would not require judges to send debtors into Chapter 13.
Representative George W. Gekas, the Pennsylvania Republican who authored the bill, argued that bankruptcy has become too easy, its stigma vanishing to the point where some people use it as a financial planning tool. The number of bankruptcies increased by 23 percent from 1996 to 1997, despite the booming economy, and is expected to increase again this year.
The bill has been a sleeper on Capitol Hill for months. But Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded the alarm in her newspaper column last week, writing: "I do quarrel with aspects of the bill that would force single parents to compete for their child-support payments with big banks trying to collect credit-card debt."
The Justice Department has recommended that President Clinton veto the measure, and the President chimed in Saturday with his wife's theme in his weekly radio address.
"If that competition starts," he said, "we all know who will lose the contest -- the children."

HEADLINE: Newest Data Ease Concerns About Rate Increase by Fed

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Retail sales rose for the fifth time in six months in April, while producer prices were hardly changed for nearly everyone except smokers, suggesting little reason for concern about the economy.
The Commerce Department said today that retail sales rose half a percent in April after a flat performance a month earlier. Excluding sales of autos, the increase in retail sales was still half a percent. 
 In another report, the Labor Department said producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first increase in seven months. The core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, also rose two-tenths of 1 percent. Higher tobacco costs accounted for about half of that increase.
Taken together, "it's a Fed policy maker's dream world," said Ken Mayland, chief economist at Keycorp in Cleveland. "We've got strong growth and low inflation."
The Fed's policy committee meets next Tuesday to decide whether the economy's strength means that an interest rate increase is needed to prevent inflation from accelerating. Today's reports offered little reason for concern, analysts said. They described the increase in retail sales as moderate and noted that special factors had driven the increase in producer prices.
"From the Fed's point of view, this makes it easy for them to do nothing," said Robert T. McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank Ltd. in New York.
Today's producer price report showed that tobacco prices rose 3.4 percent in April, the biggest gain since September.
The Philip Morris Companies and RJR Nabisco Holdings raised wholesale cigarette prices by about 5 cents a pack in early April, as they sought to build up cash to pay settlements of health-related suits. The cigarette industry has raised prices more than 20 percent since September.
Colder, wetter weather in March helped push up food prices four-tenths of 1 percent; vegetable costs rose 6.9 percent.
Prices for intermediate goods and raw materials indicated that there was little inflationary pressure. Prices for crude goods fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, and the trend is likely to continue.
In the year's first four months, producer prices fell at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, as they did in the first four months of 1997. The core rate rose at a rate of eight-tenths of 1 percent, up from four-tenths of 1 percent in the 1997 period.
The rise in retail sales in April was broad, with gains in sales of building materials, autos, apparel and general merchandise. Still, April's increase of half a percent was a bit below the six-tenths of 1 percent that analysts had expected.
"We're starting the second quarter on a positive note, but it's not as robust as we saw during the first couple months of the year," said Gary Thayer, senior economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.
Sales of durable goods rose half a percent, and sales of nondurable goods were up six-tenths of 1 percent.
A booming housing market raised demand for building materials, hardware and garden supplies. Dealer incentives helped vehicle sales grow seven-tenths of 1 percent in contrast to February's decline of one-tenth of 1 percent.
Last week, retailers reported higher-than-expected April sales at stores open at least a year.

(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics); "Retail Sales" tracks total retail sales in billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted, over the same period. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: For Wall Street, Big Fees In Bond Sale for Takeover

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The denizens of Wall Street may have been even happier than the residents of Long Island yesterday as the Long Island Power Authority sold $3.5 billion in bonds -- the biggest municipal bond issue ever -- to finance its takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.
The takeover, which is supposed to cut utility rates by 20 percent, will put millions of dollars into the coffers of securities concerns and law firms involved in the deal. And it comes at a time when Wall Street is reaping record fees from mergers, takeovers and the sale of stocks and bonds. 
 In yesterday's installment of the complex Long Island utility takeover, the brokerage firms and banks that sold the bonds to investors were paid roughly $21 million, according to the Power Authority.
The money will be divided among the more than 50 firms that sold the bonds to investors, though the biggest share will go to Bear, Stearns & Company, the manager of the sale. Bear, Stearns, which served as the authority's financial adviser until last December, will also receive $4 million for its earlier work when the takeover occurs at the end of this month.
For some on Wall Street, the fees will be significant. "They'll make a good month's worth in a day or two," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer. But he added that "it's not a real fee fest," given the size of the deal and the very low interest rates that the authority will pay. The interest rates will range from 3.9 percent to 5.57 percent.
Over all, Wall Street is likely to make about $72.5 million as a result of yesterday's sale and a $1.5 billion sale scheduled for the end of this month, said a spokesman for the Power Authority, who added that the final costs could well be lower.
The firms that underwrite the bond issues would receive about $25 million, according to the authority's estimate; the financial advisers, Bear, Stearns and Goldman, Sachs, would get about $8 million; various technical advisers would get $4.5 million, and lawyers, about $3 million.
But the biggest sum, about $28 million, will go to the insurance companies that guarantee $1.95 billion of the bonds, according to the Power Authority.
The authority is buying only part of Lilco, primarily its transmission system and its share of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant, and is assuming the $4.2 billion of costs of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, which never went into operation.
The rest of Lilco will merge with Keyspan, which owns Brooklyn Union Gas. Merrill Lynch, which advised Keyspan, will receive $9 million when that transaction occurs, according to the offering documents; the firm is also a manager of the Power Authority's next bond issue.
Brooklyn Union and Lilco expect to spend almost $32 million on investment bankers, and more than $15 million in legal fees associated with their merger, according to documents they filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
That is just a drop in the bucket for Wall Street, which has been doing a booming business in mergers and acquisitions. So far this year, about $655 billion of deals have been announced, more than in all of 1996, according to the Securities Data Company, which compiles statistics on Wall Street. About $917 billion worth of mergers were announced for all of last year.
Stock and bond sales have been booming as well; if the current pace keeps up, sales this year will easily surpass last year's record of $1.3 billion. Things have been a little quieter in the municipal bond business, but nevertheless, almost $97 billion of bonds have hit the market so far this year, before the Power Authority's deal.
"Things have been going gangbusters," said Richard Peterson, a spokesman for Securities Data. "We're 50 percent ahead of where we were last year."

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE SANCTIONS;
Officials Are Uncertain as to How Punishing India Is Likely to Affect U.S. Businesses

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The sanctions that President Clinton imposed against India yesterday are likely to hurt a wide swath of American industry, but for most of those companies the impact will be small, executives and Government officials said. That is because India, while potentially a huge future market for American companies, is a small market today.
Indeed, the impact on American business is likely to be significantly less than that of the financial collapse in parts of eastern Asia. 
 Exports from the United States to India totaled only $3.6 billion last year, less than half the $8.61 billion to Thailand, one of those countries hit by the East Asian turmoil. Overall, two-way trade between the United States and India totaled $11 billion, a minute part of the overall United States total of $1.2 trillion. And despite the fact that India has more than a billion people, it accounts for only 0.8 percent of Coca-Cola's worldwide sales by volume.
Still, with Southeast Asia facing problems, India has increasingly been looked upon as a promising market and manufacturing site, especially since it has been opened to more trade and investment after a long period of virtual economic isolation.
"The number of companies here at the chamber that have an interest in India has tripled in the last year and a half," said Willard Workman, vice president, international, for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "Given the breadth and immediacy of the sanctions the impact will be significant."
President Clinton announced the sanctions yesterday to punish India for detonating underground nuclear explosions. The sanctions would stop all foreign aid except for humanitarian purposes, ban military sales to India and the export of certain types of technology that could have military uses, prohibit American banks from lending to India's Government and also stop loans and loan guarantees from Federal agencies like the Export-Import Bank.
Companies scrambled to determine how they would be affected. Virtually all the companies contacted said it was too early to tell and declined further comment.
The biggest impact could be postponement or even cancellation of some contracts, like sales of jets by Boeing or the construction of power plants, telecommunications systems and other major projects that a developing country needs. Commerce Secretary William Daley told reporters in Washington yesterday that his department has been promoting about $10 billion worth of projects in India on behalf of American companies.
"That shows a fairly large amount of projects, and I imagine a majority of them in one way or another would be affected by the sanctions," he was quoted as saying by the Bloomberg news service.
Boeing was given an order for 10 737's by Jet Airways Ltd., India's largest private airline, which officials in Washington say depends on financing from the Export-Import Bank and could now be cut off. Mark Hooper, a Boeing spokesman, said the company did not yet know how the sanctions would affect that sale, which was valued at $486 million when it was announced late in 1996. Three planes have been delivered.
Boeing has far more at stake in a potential sale of about 18 planes to state-owned Air India, which could be worth around $2 billion. It is possible the sanctions could tip the order in favor of a Boeing rival, Airbus.
The sanctions would stop new commitments being made to finance projects and exports to India by the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, two Government agencies. But spokesmen for both those agencies said they believed that commitments already made would be honored.
The Export-Import Bank has about $500 million in pending loans or loan guarantees, which are likely to be suspended. It appears that most of that financing is for just two projects -- the Boeing sale to Jet Airways and a contract, valued at more than $500 million, to build a wireless telephone system, which was awarded last month to Hughes Network Systems, part of General Motors Corporation's Hughes Electronics subsidiary.
In addition, companies have shown interest, but have not yet gotten commitments, for projects that would require another $1 billion in loans or loan guarantees, a spokesman for the bank said.
The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which provides financing and political risk insurance, said about 80 American companies have expressed interest in getting help for projects there, making India one of the top five countries in terms of interest. The agency already provides $750 million in loans or insurance related to India to such companies as Enron, Motorola, US West and Bechtel.
Military sales to India, which will be stopped by the sanctions, are tiny because India has generally bought its weapons from Russia. In addition, there have been various restrictions on transferring technology to India, defense industry executives said. A State Department official said licenses were granted last year for about $40 million in military-related sales to India.
Lockheed Martin, the big military contractor, has only two small contracts in India. But it also has a $600 million contract to develop a commercial satellite communications system for a private Indian company. A Lockheed spokesman said the company did not know how it would be affected.
Enron Corporation of Houston is involved in a $2.5 billion power project, which became a political issue some time ago when the Indian Government temporarily canceled it.
Kelly Kimberly, a spokeswoman for Enron, said the company was assessing the situation but added, "We're optimistic about the project." The first phase is already more than 90 percent completed, but financing is still being arranged for the larger second stage.
Mr. Workman of the Chamber of Commerce said it appears that imports from India will not be affected. But companies that have operations in India could be affected if they cannot bring in parts.
