HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
For 'Seinfeld' Viewers, a Super Bowl Party

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
According to the calendar, it's the second Thursday in May. But according to Madison Avenue, it looks a lot like the last Sunday in January -- Super Bowl Sunday.
Tonight's send-off for "Seinfeld" marks the first time that the final episode of a television series has taken on the trappings of a Super Bowl, the annual festival of commercialism that has become as much a day for marketers as for football fans. 
 The characteristics of the Super Bowl being displayed by the "Seinfeld" Bowl include a record commercial price being charged by NBC, expectations of a giant audience and efforts to present spots that viewers will judge to be special.
"I thought it would be pretty big, which is why we got involved," Liz Silver, vice president for advertising at Visa U.S.A. Inc. in Foster City, Calif., said yesterday, referring to a decision to become one of the sponsors of the "Seinfeld" sign-off.
"But it has turned out to be quite an event," she added, "comparable in many ways to a Super Bowl."
Visa and its rival, Mastercard International, rarely agree. But Mastercard will also run a commercial.
"The media interest has been 50 percent greater than during the Super Bowl," said Larry Flanagan, vice president for advertising at Mastercard in Purchase, N.Y., which also advertised during Super Bowl XXXII on Jan. 25.
"There's a Super Bowl every year," he added. "There's only one 'Seinfeld' finale."
The raging debate over whether all the attention being paid to the end of "Seinfeld" is hoopla, hyperbole or hysteria is irrelevant to a blue-chip list of advertisers that in addition to Visa and Mastercard includes the Anheuser-Busch Companies, Apple Computer Inc., the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the General Motors Corporation, the Hershey Foods Corporation and Sony Pictures Entertainment. They have decided that the 169th and final episode of the series supposedly about nothing is actually worth something.
"We thought, 'Wouldn't it be great if we could get on the finale?' " said Lori Moskowitz Lepler, president at Intuition Group in New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C. that is participating with a commercial for the Clairol Nice 'n Easy hair coloring sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb.
"The show has an event-like status," she added, "and the characters -- crazy as they are -- have been embraced by most of America, becoming part of the fabric of our culture in the 90's."
So how does the "Seinfeld" farewell resemble a Super Sunday? Let's count the ways.
SUPER PRICES. Marketers are paying record rates to run commercials during the show just as they do for Super Bowl spots. NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, is charging an estimated $1.5 million to $1.7 million for each 30 seconds of commercial time. That surpasses the $1.3 million that the network charged for such spots during Super Bowl XXXII.
"Everyone's saying, 'Omigod,' " said Paul Benjou, associate media director at ABP Draft Worldwide in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. "But it's not so high if you look at what CBS charged for commercials in the last 'M*A*S*H' in 1983 and add 9 percent inflation a year."
The price for a commercial during "Seinfeld" tonight is more than twice the $650,000 that NBC charged only five years ago for the farewell episode of "Cheers."
"It's a helluva lot of money to pay, no question about it," Steve Sternberg, senior partner at TN Media in New York, a media services agency owned by True North Communications, said of the "Seinfeld" price tag.
"But the 80 million or 90 million viewers are a helluva lot more than you can get anyplace other than a Super Bowl," he added.
SUPER AUDIENCE. As noted by Mr. Sternberg, the estimates of viewers who will watch Mr. Seinfeld say shalom are huge. The biggest audience the series has ever drawn was for the penultimate episode last Thursday, which attracted almost 38.8 million viewers. NBC is projecting that up to 79 million viewers will tune in tonight.
Eisner & Associates, a Baltimore agency that traditionally conducts surveys about Super Bowl advertising, conducted one about "Seinfeld," too. Based on interviews with 1,000 adults from May 2 through May 4, Eisner predicts the audience could reach 110 million viewers.
"We think we're going to reach lots and lots of people, maybe as many as 90 million," said John Payne, vice president at the Animal Health Group of the Bayer Corporation in Shawnee Mission, Kan. His company will run a commercial by Bernstein-Rein Advertising Inc. in Kansas City, Mo., showing pets singing (literally) the praises of Advantage, a flea-control product.
"Our target audience is women 25 to 54," Mr. Payne said, "and it seems to be a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to reach them in such numbers."
That is especially true given the radical remaking of broadcast TV.
"It's so fragmented now," Ms. Moskowitz Lepler said, because of viewer defections to alternatives like cable networks and the Internet. "Events that can garner large audiences are less frequent." That scarcity, of course, makes such events more desirable to mass marketers.
In fact, Ms. Silver of Visa said, just as the Super Bowl attracts an audience that "doesn't normally watch football, or even television very often," the "Seinfeld" exit is likely "to get a broader, deeper, more diverse audience" than a typical episode, expanding beyond the 18- to 34-year-olds who have been "the core 'Seinfeld' audience."
SUPER SURPRISES. Like a Super Sunday, many sponsors are offering spots they hope will be deemed better than conventional commercials. Some spots are appearing for the first time. Some are introducing products or services. Some are meant to surprise jaded viewers.
Visa, for instance, will present the premiere of a fast-paced spot by BBDO New York, part of Omnicom Group, centered on the Attic, a vintage clothing store in Las Vegas, Nev., where "the only thing that's out of style," an announcer declares, "is using American Express."
Intuition Group will run a spot for Nice 'n Easy with that brand's new spokeswoman, Kristen Johnston of another NBC sitcom, "Third Rock from the Sun."
And offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide -- part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of Interpublic -- will introduce a spot for Mastercard, announcing a shopping alliance with the Web site operated by Excite Inc., and a spot for the Buick division of G.M., introducing a campaign for the Buick Century carrying the theme "A luxury car for everyone."
In a departure from most Super Bowls, "Seinfeld"-mania is spilling over from television into print, as some advertisers sponsor singular ads with "Seinfeld" themes for magazines like Entertainment Weekly, People, Rolling Stone and TV Guide.
"So much of the 'Seinfeld' humor is about language, words," said David H. Steward, president and chief executive at TV Guide, a unit of the News Corporation in New York. "The creative directors at the agencies totally identify with it."
One product saluting "Seinfeld" in print is the Pond's Clear Pore Strips brand sold by Unilever Home and Personal Care. An ad created by the Ogilvy & Mather New York unit of WPP changes the product's usual message, "Bye-bye blackheads!" to "Bye-bye 'Seinfeld!' "
Another customized ad was produced by the Arnold Communications unit of Snyder Communications in Boston for the New Beetle sold by Volkswagen of America. The ad shows a yellow Bug above the headline "Never rule out a comeback."
Never say never, indeed. According to the supermarket tabloid The Star, Mr. Seinfeld is talking to NBC about a "Seinfeld" reunion show next year.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE CRISIS;
Pakistan Looks Ready to Test Its Own Bomb

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
Pakistan is preparing for an underground nuclear test that could take place as early as Sunday, American officials said today, citing clear signs from spy satellites, foreign agents and Pakistan's political leaders.
Diplomatic, military and intelligence officials said Pakistan could test a nuclear warhead sometime next week in response to five tests that its regional rival, India, has conducted since Monday. It would be Pakistan's first test of a nuclear device and would add one more country to the list of nations that openly possess a nuclear weapons ability. 
 Despite the certain and severe economic and political consequences for Pakistan, and the effect such a step is bound to have on the already soaring tensions in the region, "no one expects them to not have a test," an Administration official said.
President Clinton hastily sent a high-level diplomatic team to Pakistan today after a discouraging telephone conversation this morning with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif. The President said he asked the Prime Minister "to resist the temptation to respond to an irresponsible act."
But "Sharif was not able to give that reassurance," said Karl F. Inderfurth, the assistant secretary of state for South Asian affairs. "He told the President that he was under tremendous pressure to respond."
At that point, Mr. Inderfurth said, President Clinton offered to send his envoys to Islamabad, the Pakistani capital. The President then assembled a delegation led by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and Gen. Anthony Zinni of the Marines, who commands United States forces in the Middle East and southwest Asia. The group left Washington tonight.
The delegation intends to paint a grim picture of the consequences of a test, especially the severe economic penalties for Pakistan, Administration officials said, and to use political persuasion, diplomatic tact and economic pressure to try and stop a test.
Pakistan would suffer the same financial sanctions as India did today -- a prohibition on private American bank loans, as well as the threat of the loss of World Bank and International Monetary Fund assistance.
The World Bank has $4.4 billion worth of programs under way in Pakistan, and the I.M.F. has offered Pakistan a new $1.56 billion, three-year loan program, only about $208 million of which has been disbursed. The money not already in the pipeline would be barred.
India also lost American military and economic aid, which totaled $145 million this year. The United States already ended all military and economic aid to Pakistan in 1990, after it declared Pakistan capable of making nuclear weapons.
Pakistan has been capable of conducting a nuclear test since the early 1990's, American officials say, and has produced enough fissile material to build about a dozen warheads. The warheads, apparently based on a Chinese design, can be mounted on missiles.
The test would be conducted in the Chagai Hills, a remote site in the Baluchistan desert, near Pakistan's western border with Iran. One of the warheads would be lowered down a deep shaft, attached to cables and sensors, and exploded.
Pakistan's political leaders have made it plain that they intend to respond to India in kind. India's tests "will not go unanswered," Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan told the nation's senate today.
In addition to these kinds of public pronouncements, American spy satellites have detected military equipment and technical personnel making preparations for a test at the Chagai Hills site.
Foreign intelligence agents in Pakistan have also reported that the test could be conducted immediately, for maximum political effect, or later next week, for a greater yield of technological data, officials said.
Few American officials were confident that the delegation sent by President Clinton tonight could stop the test without offering something concrete in return.
The best hope, they said, was for the United States to convince the other seven large industrialized nations who will attend an economic summit this week in Birmingham, England, to place economic penalties on India so severe that they would deter Pakistan from a test.
"We need to bring to bear all of the political will, not only of this country but certainly of all of our allies, to come down very hard on India and to discourage Pakistan from following suit," said the Secretary of Defense, William S. Cohen.
Gary Milhollin, a leading expert on the spread of nuclear weapons, said: "If I were Pakistan's Prime Minister. I would wait two weeks to see what the world does to India. If the world builds such an uncomfortable box that I don't want to live in it, I would hold off. If the world doesn't react, I would go full speed ahead."
But the American delegation intends to offer no economic or military incentives to bargain with Pakistan, officials said -- only warnings of the dangers of a test.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pakistani leaders told American officials that they are under enormous pressure to respond to India's nuclear tests. In Islamabad yesterday, protesters condemned India and demanded that Pakistan test its own device. (Reuters)(pg. A12)

HEADLINE: Software and Hardball

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
For all the attention Microsoft's antitrust confrontation with the Justice Department has received, for all the headlines and all the commentary on the subject, it often seems that the Government is stepping into what is essentially an intramural spat within the software industry.
To most people, the debate quickly becomes a baffling excursion into the arcane language of computing -- Web browsers, operating systems and Internet programming languages. And it is, after all, a dispute that pits the very rich software mavens from the Netscape Communica tions Corporation against the incomprehensibly rich ones from the Microsoft Corporation. 
 At a time when the nation's economy is surging and its high-technology industries are the envy of the world, many people wonder if this a fight Washington should join. And why, they ask, should anyone outside the software business really care about the Government's escalating battle with Microsoft?
The Government and the Attorneys General of more than a dozen states are expected to announce that they are filing broad antitrust suits against Microsoft soon, probably today, on the eve of the company's plan to ship its next-generation operating system, Windows 98. It will then be up to the courts to determine whether the cases amount to an economically wise and legally innovative application of antitrust policy to the information age or unnecessary meddling.
But it is already clear that the impact of the Government's policy toward Microsoft could extend well beyond the software business, potentially to all manner of industries from autos and banking to travel and entertainment.
"Virtually every discussion we have with companies about their strategy begins with one word: Microsoft -- how do you compete against Microsoft in the future?" said David Nadler, chairman of the Delta Consulting Group, which advises corporations in many fields. In industry after industry, executives share a sentiment expressed last year by Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation: "Everybody in the communications business is paranoid of Microsoft, including me."
Such worries about Microsoft have little to do with intricacies of computer programming. They center on the perception that Microsoft, through its near-monopoly in personal computer operating systems, has a chokehold on the PC desktop, as the main Windows screen is known.
What is more worrisome to many people -- and of great concern to the Justice Department -- is that when the Windows desktop is fused with browser software for viewing sites on the World Wide Web, the operating system becomes a portal to the Internet. This makes the desktop extremely valuable real estate. By determining which icons appear by default on its desktop, Microsoft can steer users of Windows computers to its own sites on the Internet or to the sites of companies that pay Microsoft for a desktop position.
The Government, in its suit, is expected to try to break Microsoft's grip on the desktop by allowing PC makers to personalize customers' requests for Internet services and to load those services before shipping the machines. The Government is expected to argue that unless Microsoft's contracts with PC makers are pried open, there is a danger that the company will be able to extend its operating system monopoly into the emerging new markets of Internet commerce and entertainment.
In addition, the Government's suit is expected to ask that Microsoft be prohibited from requiring computer makers to install its browser, Internet Explorer, as a condition of licensing Windows. This would enable PC makers, if they chose, to instead install browsing software from rivals, like Netscape.
It would also calm nerves in a number of other industries, since Microsoft has its own Web sites for travel reservations, car retailing, city guides and personal finance. Its on-line bill-paying service will start later this year.
In Windows 98, the operating system and Internet browsing software are seamlessly integrated with a "channel bar" of featured Web sites, including Microsoft's.
"The broad issue is: Does Microsoft control a bottleneck, and what are the limits to that control?" said Carl Shapiro, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley and a former chief economist of the Justice Department's antitrust division. "How much of Internet commerce will Microsoft manipulate, if not capture? The answer is we don't know. But Microsoft's potential control of the Internet bottleneck is at least scary to anyone trying to set up commerce on the Web."
The business of Internet commerce, information and entertainment is small today but growing rapidly. Forrester Research Inc. projects that it will increase tenfold, to $350 billion, in the United States by 2001. Increasingly, it is expected, people will venture onto the Internet to shop, find information and be entertained -- especially as televisions shift to the digital technology of PC's. Windows 98 includes software to enable users to view its television-and-Internet service, Web TV, on their PC screens.
What businesses from car companies to banks fear is that Microsoft, by controlling the gateway to the Internet, will become an indispensable intermediary between them and their customers. And while the Government suit will also focus on other issues, Microsoft's control of the desktop to direct Internet traffic "was the real trip wire that created this sense of alarm in Washington and in other industries," said David Readerman, a software analyst for Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
Even so, widespread fears about Microsoft's market power do not make an antitrust case. To win, Microsoft's lawyers contend, the Government would have to show not only that Windows is an indispensable gateway to the Internet but also that its only reason for including certain Internet services or links to featured Web sites was to harm competitors.
If Microsoft could show a benefit to consumers or business justification for its practices -- even though those practices harm rivals -- the company insists that the courts should rule in its favor.
"The antitrust laws do not dictate a level playing field," said Charles F. Rule, a former director of the Justice Department's antitrust division and a consultant to Microsoft. "The fact is, many PC users and software developers want the Internet features Microsoft has included in its operating system, both in Windows 95 and now in Windows 98. There is a business justification for what Microsoft has done."
Besides, some analysts say, worries about Microsoft ruling the Internet are probably wildly exaggerated. Mr. Readerman of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities estimated that Microsoft lost $500 million last year on its Internet commerce and programming ventures.
George F. Colony, president of Forrester Research, asserted: "So far, Microsoft has shown itself to be pretty inept at Internet commerce. I think the idea that Microsoft is going to kill General Motors or Disney someday is nonsense."

Antitrust allegations against Microsoft could delay the shipment of Windows 98. Here is a look at some of the features of Windows 98 and the antitrust questions they raise.
 
The Channel Bar -- The Government says it enables Microsoft to steer PC users toward its Internet services and those of preferred partners. This power, the Government believes, could give the company an unfair edge in new markets for Internet commerce, news and entertainment. Microsoft says the channel bar benefits consumers by making it easier to find things on the Net.
 
Internet Explorer -- The Government is expected to ask a Federal court to stop Microsoft from requiring PC makers to include it as a condition of licensing the Windows operating system. Microsoft says its Web browsing software is an integrated feature of Windows, not a separate product that can be easily lopped off.
 
Web TV -- Microsoft's Internet-and-television service is not much of an issue yet since PC makers have been reluctant to install TV tuner cards needed to receive and display TV programming on a PC. (pg. D3)

HEADLINE: Retreat on Times Square Subway Plan

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has allowed the developer of one of four office towers in Times Square to scale back the size of a new entrance to the busiest subway station in the country, at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.
In return for eliminating a requirement to build two escalators, the developer, Rudin Management, agreed to pay the authority $1.3 million. But transit advocates and leaders of civic groups say that the deal shortchanges the city and is only the latest example of how a $160 million subway renovation that was once a centerpiece of the redevelopment of Times Square has been greatly reduced. 
 Under a 1994 agreement governing development of the Times Square tower, the developer is required to build a stairwell at least 12 feet wide with two escalators, as well as the escalator pits and machinery room, and to maintain the escalators for 25 years. But on April 29, the M.T.A. board approved an amendment allowing Mr. Rudin to delete the escalators in return for a $1.3 million payment. According to a report by the authority, the Rudin group, which is in partnership with its main tenant, Reuters America, offered to build an "upgraded marquee and canopy over the entrance" for $250,000 at the authority's expense.
The advocates said they fear the deal would encourage the other Times Square developers to expand their valuable retail space by cutting back subway entrances at the other new buildings, which together would house about 18,000 workers and add to the millions of tourists and New Yorkers who jam the streets and subways of Times Square. Street-level retail space in Times Square now rents for $250 a square foot and more, real estate brokers say.
"The developer got off cheap," Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the New York City Transit Riders Council. "It was very shortsighted to cut the escalators. People who need an escalator now have to cross Seventh Avenue, not the easiest street to maneuver."
More than 250,000 people a day pour through the Times Square subway stations, which are badly in need of capital improvements, even as the old theaters on 42d Street are being revived and as Disney, Warner Brothers and Virgin music store are revitalizing Times Square. Under a plan scrapped in 1994, the developers of the four office towers would have put $90 million into a $160 million renovation of the Times Square stations. Since then, New York City Transit has spent years designing a more modest, $85 million renovation program that is to be put out to bid next winter, without any direct contribution from the developers.
"The original promises are fading rapidly," said Joseph Rappaport, coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign, a subway riders' advocacy group. "In Times Square right now, you've got Disneyland above and Hades below."
William Rudin, who is building a 32-story office tower for Reuters, the giant British information services company, with more than $62 million in tax breaks, contends that the city is getting a good deal. The developer will build a 15-foot-wide subway staircase inside the new building to replace the existing stairwell at 42d and Seventh. Mr. Rudin, and the transportation authority, said that the escalators were not not needed because of the relatively short drop from the street to the subway mezzanine below. Instead, Mr. Rudin said, New York City Transit gets $1.3 million that can be invested in more worthwhile projects.
"You're getting a stairs, a new design for the canopy and a million-plus dollars to do something the M.T.A. thought was more important than putting in an escalator," Mr. Rudin said. "We think it's more bang for the buck for the public."
But Ms. Dolinsky, the local community board and the Municipal Art Society said that the transportation authority got the short end of the deal. Lola Finkelstein, the chairwoman of Community Board 5, which includes the Times Square, added that the deal was approved by the agency without any public comment.
"The M.T.A. has never maximized the potential of what they could get from developers," Ms. Dolinsky said.
Tom Kelly, a spokesman for the authority, was unable to answer specific questions about the deal. But, speaking of Rudin Management's $1.3 million payment to eliminate the escalators, he said, "We felt it was proper compensation."
Mr. Rudin said that the $1.3 million payment exceeds the cost of building and maintaining the escalators. But some experts questioned that estimate. Stuart Lerner, a senior associate at Vollmer Associates and a transportation consultant, said that the escalators alone would cost from $600,000 to $1 million, not including maintenance.
The transit and civic advocates now expect Mortimer B. Zuckerman's Boston Properties, which is buying the rights to develop two other office sites in Times Square, to reduce the size of four subway entrances it is required to incorporate into the two towers.
Robert Selsam, a vice president with Boston Properties, said that he was unaware of Mr. Rudin's new deal with the M.T.A.
"I'm sure there'll be some negotiations with the M.T.A.," Mr. Selsam said. "I don't know what they'll involve at this point."
Conceived in the early 1980's, the Times Square redevelopment plan granted extensive tax breaks to the developers of four proposed office towers in Times Square, who would in turn, renovate nine old theaters and provide $90 million for the $160 million renovation of the Times Square subway stations that state officials at the time said would feature an open subway mezzanine with a two-story rotunda and "access for the elderly and handicapped."
But after a recession and years of delays, the state and the city scrapped that plan in 1994, relieving the developer of the obligation to directly finance the subway renovation, much to the chagrin of the Municipal Art Society and other civic advocates. A new agreement stipulated that a portion of tax revenues from the four office towers would be used to reimburse the authority for some of the subway project's cost.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Narrowly Approves Financial Services Changes
By just one vote, the House has approved far-reaching banking legislation that could eliminate Depression-era restrictions on the financial services industry.
The legislation, approved by a vote of 214 to 213, allows for the merging of banks, securities firms and insurance companies into financial conglomerates able to operate globally with far fewer regulatory restrictions than they now face. The Senate is expected to take up the legislation later this year, but its chances for passage there remained unclear, and it could face a veto from President Clinton. Page A1. 

Stakes in Microsoft Struggle
For all the attention Microsoft's antitrust confrontation with the Justice Department has received, it often seems the Government is stepping into what is essentially an intramural spat within the software industry. At a time when the nation's economy is surging and its high-technology industries are the envy of the world, is this a fight Washington should join? News Analysis. A1.
 
Bay Networks Rises on Speculation
Shares of Bay Networks soared more than 16 percent after it was reported that the company spurned a takeover offer from Northern Telecom. Although the companies would not confirm the report, analysts believed some offer would be made for the data networking concern. Market Place. D8.
 
Retail Sales Robust in April
Retail sales rose half a percent in April, with gains in sales of building materials, autos, apparel and general merchandise. And, wholesale prices were hardly changed, climbing two-tenths of a percent last month, the first increase in seven months. D2.
 
Better-than expected earnings were reported by both Federated Department Stores, the parent of Macy's, Bloomingdale's and Stern's, and Kmart. D3.
 
Dow Tops 9,200 For First Time
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 9,200 for the first time, soaring 50.07 points, to 9,211.84. The previous Dow high of 9,192.66 was reached May 4. Treasury security prices rose for the second consecutive day. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.94 percent, from 5.97 percent on Tuesday. D6.
 
Three Bids for Simon & Schuster
Viacom received three bids for Simon & Schuster, the publishing giant. One offer was from a team led by Knowledge Universe, a company owned by Oracle's Lawrence J. Ellison, and Michael R. Milken, left, who pioneered the use of junk bonds. British publisher Pearson and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the leveraged buyout firm, joined forces on a bid. Another offer came from Primedia, a magazine publisher, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, which controls it. D8.
 
Daimler-Benz Reaches Into Japan
Nissan Motor's president did not rule out the possibility that it may one day make a deal with Daimler-Benz similar to the German auto maker's agreement to acquire Chrysler. D8.
 
Guarding Privacy in the Digital Age
The Clinton Administration has prepared an "Electronic Bill of Rights" to help insure the privacy of medical records, Internet transactions and other computerized personal data. A16.
 
Bankruptcy Bill Is Considered
With the number of personal bankruptcies soaring, the House Judiciary Committee considered a bill promoted by the banking and credit-card industries to make it more difficult for people to declare bankruptcy. The Clinton Administration opposes the bill. A22.

India Conducts More Tests Despite Sanctions Threat
The Indian Government carried out two more underground nuclear tests to add to the three blasts it conducted on Monday. The Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee approved the new tests knowing that the United States, Japan and other countries were preparing to impose economic sanctions for the first series of explosions. A1 

Pakistan is preparing for an underground nuclear test, American officials said, citing clear signs from spy satellites and foreign agents. A1

HEADLINE: Sale of Bonds For Lilco Deal Is a Success

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., May 13

 BODY:
The Long Island Power Authority's first bond sale was a hit on Wall Street. Although the offering was the nation's biggest municipal bond issue ever, demand far outstripped the supply. When the sale ended today on the initial $3.5 billion offering, it had attracted $18 billion in orders.
"It's like nothing the municipal bond market has ever seen," said Daniel Keating, the senior managing director for the lead underwriter, Bear Stearns & Company. "It was a fabulous success. There's tremendous buying support for this deal." A complex priority system will be used to allocate the bonds among the buyers. 
 The sale provided Gov. George E. Pataki with the cash needed to fulfill his promise to lower Long Island's soaring electricity bills, a goal that has long eluded other public officials. Under the Governor's plan, the target date for cutting the bills is just a month away. Mr. Pataki's appointees on the Power Authority plan to use the bond money to buy the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service on May 28 and lower rates almost immediately.
Lilco's bills, the highest in the continental United States, average $100 a month for a typical homeowner. The planned cuts, 19.1 percent in Suffolk County and 20.9 percent in Nassau and the Rockaways in Queens, would save the average customer about $240 a year.
In addition, Mr. Pataki has promised to send, in the fall, refund checks of $101 per customer in Suffolk and $232 in Nassau and the Rockaways. The checks would be part of the settlement of a $1.2 billion court judgment that Lilco won for excess property taxes levied on its never-opened nuclear plant in Shoreham. Lilco has paid those property taxes by raising rates on consumers, who would now receive refunds.
The Power Authority, meeting here tonight, unanimously approved the bond sale, which was the first round of $7 billion in bonds that the agency plans to sell over the coming months for the Lilco takeover, the refinancing of the Shoreham debt and its own operations. The agency also set the final interest rates on bonds sold this week. They range from 3.9 percent for bonds maturing next year, to 5.57 percent for those maturing in 2029. The interest is exempt from local, state and Federal income taxes, making the bonds especially attractive to higher-income residents of New York City and state. The key to cutting the electricity bills is the authority's refinancing of Lilco's debt, most of it for the Shoreham plant, with the lower-cost municipal bonds. As a state agency, the authority would also save money by avoiding corporate taxes and not paying stock dividends.
Opponents of the Lilco takeover said they were preparing new litigation in an effort to stop the deal. Their past challenges have yet to succeed, although some lawsuits are still pending and the Suffolk County Legislature is planning a nonbinding referendum on the deal in November. The opponents contend that the takeover would unduly enrich Lilco, saddle Long Islanders with a huge debt and fail to maintain the lower rates.
Gordian Raacke , the director of a court-appointed watchdog group called the Citizen's Advisory Panel, said at tonight's Power Authority meeting: "A 33-year sentence is being imposed on the ratepayers for a crime we didn't commit." He was referring to the bond repayment and the cost of the never-used Shoreham plant.
The critics also cited the latest of several news reports on political ties to the Lilco deal, an article today in The Wall Street Journal. It detailed "a suspicious pattern" of political donations, political hirings and other connections involving the major underwriters of the bond issue, especially the lead firm, Bear Stearns, which is receiving millions of dollars in fees for handling the sale. The article suggested that political favoritism played a role in choosing the underwriters.
One group opposed to the deal, the New York Public Interest Research Group, sent a letter to the United States Attorney for the Eastern District, Zachary W. Carter, calling on him to conduct an investigation into the allegations.
The Power Authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, denied that there was any political favoritism in designating the underwriters. "The selection of underwriters was based strictly on their qualifications in a highly competitive process, and had nothing to do with politics," he said.
Bear Stearns issued a statement today that did not directly discuss its political activities but said: "Every meeting, every decision, every selection by Lipa has been part of an open process that has been designed to meet the mandate of reducing the crushing cost of electricity on Long Island.
"Based on merit, expertise and past performance, Bear Stearns will successfully bring our portion of the bond issue to market," the statement continued.
Governor Pataki declined to comment on the issue, but said he was delighted with the deal's progress. "Investors clearly recognize this as a great deal," he said in a statement issued in Albany. "But it's even a better deal for the ratepayers who save 20 percent on their electric bills, get significant rebates and avoid massive property tax hikes."
Without the settlement of the Shoreham tax case, Suffolk property owners would have faced higher taxes to refund Lilco's excess property tax payments. Under the Pataki plan, the Power Authority would buy Lilco's transmission and distribution lines, its customer service and billing divisions and its 18 percent share in the Nine Mile Point 2 power plant upstate. Lilco's stockholders have agreed to the deal. The remainder of Lilco -- its top administration, generating plants and natural gas business -- would merge with Brooklyn Union Gas and its holding company, Keyspan.
For the first several years after the takeover is implemented, the Power Authority would hire the merged company to supply the power and run the system. Within five years, all customers would be offered a choice of competing electricity suppliers, but they would have to pay fees for using the Power Authority's grid system.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
U.S. Markets Are Bolstered as Investors Flee Rout in Asia

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market advanced yesterday, but apparently without any real zeal.
The Dow Jones industrial average limped to a new high. Other major indexes, while moving higher, remained below their recent highs. 
 The move came even as Asian markets were falling with riots spreading in Indonesia, worsening the outlook for the country's already troubled economy. While early today the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong was down slightly, 3.7 points, to 9,465.59. it fell 8 percent yesterday. The main Indonesian stock market index fell 6.6 percent yesterday, and the currency, the rupiah, dropped almost 12 percent in value. The Nikkei index in Toyko was up slightly this morning at 15,381.22, and it rose slightly yesterday.
India's stock market dropped 4 percent yesterday after the Government announced that it had completed a second round of nuclear tests.
Jitters in emerging markets tend to spread quickly, and there were some signs of that yesterday in Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Peru.
On the New York Stock Exchange, some of the emerging country funds were among the biggest losers in percentage terms. The Templeton Russia Fund was down 2 1/16, to 29 11/16, the Morgan Stanley India Investment Fund, fell 1/2, to 8 1/8, the India Fund finished down 3/8, at 7 5/8, and the Morgan Stanley Russia and New Europe Fund dropped 7/16, to 20 15/16.
Investors have tended to dismiss the Asian economic turmoil recently, so a revival of their focus on the problem could add to volatility.
"I don't know if this tips the scale" into a new round of concern about Asia," said Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "The reality of the matter is that the investors should never have stopped being concerned."
Mr. Cliggott said that the strong openings of the stock market over the last several sessions may indicate a new wave of capital reallocated from Asia to the United States. He said foreign investors have a tendency to buy in the morning in New York, and there were similar sharp jumps at the market's opening last fall, when many investors worried about the Asian economic crisis.
With the policy makers at the Federal Reserve scheduled to meet next Tuesday to discuss the economy and the direction of interest rates, there is likely to be some restraint in trading, leaving the way open for a stronger rally if the Fed, as many analysts expect, decides to leave interest rates unchanged.
Traders and analysts said yesterday's reports on producer prices and retail sales were unlikely to give the policy makers a reason to move interest rates higher because they neither indicated a resumption in inflationary price pressures or cleared up the question of how strong the pace of economic growth is in the beginning of the second quarter.
Fed policy makers are likely to wait until they have more information on growth in the second quarter before they act because inflation appears under control. They did signal recently, however, that they were likely to raise interest rates if the economy did not soon show signs of slowing from the 4.2 percent pace of growth in the first three months of the year.
The Dow industrial average rose 50.07 points, to 9,211.84, surpassing the previous high of 9,192.66 reached on May 4. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 3.07, to 1,118.86, up only half as much as the Dow in percentage terms. Its high was 1,130.54 on April 22. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index finished at 1,866.18, up 6.02. Its high was 1,917.61, also on April 22. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller company stocks rose 1.35, to 477.48. Its high of 491.91 was on April 21. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing issues by a small margin.
General Motors, American Express, and Hewlett-Packard, led the Dow higher. Microsoft helped push both the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq higher despite the threat of antitrust suits against the company from the Federal Government and 12 states.

Treasury Prices Advance
By Bloomberg News
The price of Treasury securities rose yesterday for a second consecutive day after retail sales and producer price reports soothed concern that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates soon. Investors snapped up $12 billion of new 10-year Treasury notes.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 14/32, to 102 20/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.94 percent, from 5.97 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: A $1 Billion Development Is Proposed For Hartford

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 13

 BODY:
Three major Hartford companies that have seen the value of their property plummet with the city's fortunes unveiled an ambitious $1 billion downtown development plan today that features a convention center and sports stadium.
Still, no private money has been committed to the project, the largest proposed in Hartford in decades. The fact that it was conceived by the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company, the Travelers Insurance Group and Connecticut Natural Gas, whose headquarters are all on or near the site of the proposed project, has given the plan more credence than past proposals here. 
 The proposed project, to be built on 35 acres near the Connecticut River, features shops and housing in addition to the convention center, which would be attached to the stadium. Project leaders said they hoped it would make Hartford more than a rest stop between New York and Boston.
"It really doesn't do us any good to bemoan the fact that we're neither New York nor Boston," said Robert W. Fiondella, the chairman, president and chief executive officer of Phoenix, as he released the plans today at a Hartford Common Council meeting.
With 75 million people traveling on highways through the city each year, he said, "We need to find a way to give a reason for those people to stop a while and enjoy Hartford."
In the past, insurance companies have helped develop the downtown area, including Aetna Life and Casualty, which helped create the Hartford Civic Center Mall, which the company still owns.
Yet so far, none of the three companies involved with today's announcement has committed any significant money to the project. They are paying for feasibility studies and said they would help seek developers. Connecticut Natural Gas has agreed to move its headquarters and steam plant, located in the midst of the site for planned complex, to make room for it.
Despite this, the state last week approved $300 million in funds for development in Hartford, and a good chunk of that money could go toward the waterfront complex. Pending results of a final feasibility study, project leaders said the city could break ground in as soon as a year.
The president of the State Senate, Kevin B. Sullivan, said that he hoped Hartford could have the success that Providence, Baltimore and other cities have had in using their waterfront to revitalize downtown.
"This is the first project of magnitude that has decided to capture the best resource that Hartford has and that we have traditionally pushed away from, and that is the river," Mr. Sullivan said. "It gives an ambiance. It gives a reason to be."
The plan is the largest of several development projects now being proposed for Hartford. Other ideas include building a higher education center downtown to house two community colleges and university graduate programs and renovating the Hartford Civic Center, which contains shopping and a 15,000-seat arena.
Called Adriaen's Landing for the Dutch explorer Adriaen Block, who in 1614 became the first European to reach Hartford, the project aims to make Hartford lively seven days a week, both during the day and at night. Hartford is now often deserted on weekends and at night, unless special events are going on.
The largest piece of Adriaen's Landing, to which the state has dedicated $155 million of the $300 million in bond money, is the convention center, with 893,000 square feet of meeting space, exhibition area and ballroom, as well as the 35,000-seat sports arena, where University of Connecticut teams, among others, might play. Nearby, the plan calls for a 700-room convention hotel.
About a block or so away, the plan provides for an entertainment and shopping complex.
The project also calls for 200 one- and two-bedroom apartments, which are key to bringing life to Hartford outside working hours, said Michael P. Meotti, president of the nonpartisan Connecticut Policy and Economic Council Inc. "What good about it is it's not a real estate project based on building buildings," Mr. Meotti said. "It's based on human activities. Buildings don't make a city. Human activity makes a city."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A development plan for downtown Hartford, featuring a convention center and a sports stadium, was unveiled yesterday during a City Council meeting. The project, covering 35 acres, would also have shops and housing. (By George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
INDIA CARRIES OUT 2 MORE ATOM TESTS DESPITE SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 13

 BODY:
Less than 12 hours after President Clinton appealed for a halt to all nuclear testing by India, the country's Government carried out two underground tests today to add to the three blasts it conducted at the same testing range in the northwestern desert on Monday.
In the defiant spirit it showed with the earlier explosions, the Government of Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee approved the new tests knowing that the United States, Japan and other nations were preparing to impose economic sanctions for the first series of explosions. 
 At a news conference in Berlin less than two hours after the new blasts were announced, Mr. Clinton announced wide-ranging American sanctions, including an end to most American aid to India and a pledge to use the United States vote to deny India loans and other help from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
In other reaction, Japan announced that it had frozen new grants to India and would consider cutting some of its much bigger loan programs. Similar measures halting, reducing or deferring aid were announced by a number of other nations, including Germany, Denmark and Sweden. Page A13.
Appearing before Hindu nationalist supporters who showered him with rose petals in the garden of his New Delhi residence, Mr. Vajpayee said the punishment being exacted by the United States and other nations was part of the price India had to pay for assuring its own defense. He spoke shortly before Mr. Clinton announced the sanctions, but after news reports from Washington that Mr. Clinton had taken the decision to impose the measures during his overnight flight to Germany.
"We have come to understand that we will be denied aid, credit and other assistance, and that we will face problems," Mr. Vajpayee said. "But in the event of such steps, the country will have to face them squarely. If the path ahead is a difficult one, we will not shy away from it."
The new tests were carried out close to the site of the original blasts, near the village of Khetlai in the Thar desert of Rajasthan state, at 12:21 P.M. New Delhi time (2.21 A.M. Eastern Standard Time), less than 48 hours after the first tests.
A statement by India's Ministry of Science and Technology described the latest explosions as having been in the "sub-kiloton range," indicating that they had only a fraction of the combined force of the blasts on Monday. The earlier explosions were measured by an Indian seismic institute at 55 kilotons, more than 50 times as powerful as the American atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
The statement said the new blasts completed "the planned series of tests" that Indian nuclear experts have said were aimed at developing nuclear warheads for a variety of Indian weapons systems developed in recent years. Among these is a ballistic missile with a range of about 1,500 miles, known as the Agni. The missile is thought to have been the intended delivery vehicle for the largest of the devices tested on Monday, identified in Government statements as a "thermonuclear" or hydrogen bomb.
The latest blasts were accompanied by the same olive branch that the Vajpayee Government held out after Monday's blasts -- an offer to "consider adhering to some of the undertakings" in the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty concluded in 1994, which has been signed by 149 nations, but not by India or its archrival Pakistan.
The Vajpayee Government has not said what parts of the treaty it might accept, but it has repeatedly said that it would not give up nuclear weapons unless the five established nuclear powers -- the United States, Russia, Britain, China and France -- agree to the eventual elimination of their own arsenals. This is a condition that all the five powers have repeatedly rejected.
The steps announced by Mr. Clinton appeared likely to hit hard at an Indian economy that has just begun to accelerate under market-driven reforms. In addition to the aid restrictions and the vow to block India's access to funds controlled by the I.M.F. and the World Bank, these included a ban on American banks making loans to Indian state institutions and tight restrictions on the sale of computers and other equipment with possible military uses.
Indian officials vowed not to be pushed off course by the sanctions, but Indian financial markets appeared less confident.
After steep falls on Tuesday in the wake of the first round of tests, the country's three most important stock exchanges registered further sharp declines, with a drop of more than 4 percent in the key Sensex index in Bombay, most of it in the first 30 minutes after the latest round of blasts was announced.
Stock exchanges in New Delhi and Madras each registered a fall of about 3 percent, and the Indian rupee came under heavy selling pressure in the currency markets.
Indian financial analysts said the economic effects appeared to have been more severe than expected by the Government, which said on Monday that it had weighed the possible impact on the economy when it approved the tests. Indian commentators said the country's Hindu nationalist leaders also appeared to have been jolted by the almost universal condemnation of the tests by other nations, which have placed India in an isolation unknown in the country's 50 years as an independent nation.
Indian economists have disagreed on the impact that aid cutbacks will have on the economy, but most have agreed that the most severe penalty would be a cutoff of loans by the World Bank, which has lent more than $44 billion to India. The bank had also planned to lend another $3 billion this year for a wide variety of projects, from programs to fight AIDS to projects for building bridges, dams, highways and power plants. Official statistics put the size of India's economy, measured in terms of the value of all goods and services, at about $270 billion a year.
Some Indian economists have said that all foreign aid amounts to less than 1 percent of this total, and is thus insignificant in the overall economy; others have said that the real risk lies in a collapse of investor confidence that could tip the economy into a downward spiral.
In any case, Mr. Vajpayee, 72, vowed to ride out the sanctions when he appeared before a jubilant crowd that gathered at his official residence in a show of support.
The display by his supporters, who garlanded him with a huge bouquet and waved banners, was symptomatic of the nationalist euphoria that has swept the country in the wake of the nuclear tests. Similar demonstrations have been reported all over India, including one in Bombay at which youthful Hindu nationalists pierced their fingers and signed their names in blood on a charter approving the tests.
An opinion poll published in today's editions of The Times of India said 91 percent of more than 1,000 adults questioned in six of the country's largest cities, including Bombay, Calcutta and New Delhi, had approved the first series of tests. The poll showed that 82 percent favored the deployment of nuclear weapons, a step the Vajpayee Government has said it would take "as soon as the situation requires."
Perhaps most startling, while 52 percent of those polled said they did not think India would fight a nuclear war with Pakistan in the next 10 years, 32 percent said they thought a nuclear conflict was possible.
Sounding more wistful than triumphant, Mr. Vajpayee said the tests were not simply a matter of muscle-flexing by the Hindu nationalists, who ended 50 years as India's political pariahs when they emerged from an election two months ago with the largest parliament bloc, then formed a 14-party coalition Government.
"This was not a political gimmick," he said. "For us, the country's security was paramount. These tests were above politics. Approving them was our right, and our duty."
The Indian leader said he hoped that the United States and other nations that have condemned the tests would rethink their positions and realize that the nuclear treaties that India has been urged to sign, including the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, were discriminatory since they did nothing to force established nuclear powers to give up their own arsenals.
"Our hope is that those nations that want to continue their nuclear monopoly will accept that the same rules should apply to all," he said.
Aides to Mr. Vajpayee spoke more bluntly, accusing President Clinton of double standards.
"The American position is hypocritical," said K. R. Malkani, a spokesmen for the Bharatiya Janata Party, the Hindu nationalist group Mr. Vajpayee leads. "They are sitting on a mountain of nuclear arms, and they are pontificating to India and the world."
Brajesh Mishra, principal secretary to the Indian leader, said that the United States relied on nuclear arms for its own safety, and extended its nuclear umbrella to cover many of the countries that are now condemning India. "Canada enjoys nuclear protection; Australia does; New Zealand does; Japan does; Germany does; Italy does", he said. "They haven't given up their protection, but they want to deny similar protection to us."
Mr. Vajpayee noted that the tests have been broadly supported, or at least not condemned, by most of India's political parties. The opposition Congress Party, which led India to independence and was in power when the only previous Indian nuclear test was detonated, in May 1974, has demanded that the Vajpayee Government spell out the threat that prompted the tests, but has stopped short of criticizing them. "The Government should let us know the seriousness of the threat, and from which quarter it comes," said Natwar Singh, a spokesman for the Congress party leader, Sonia Gandhi.
For some opposition politicians, the tests have posed a bind. Even among those who worry about the destablizing effect of the tests, there has been a reluctance to hand the Hindu nationalists a populist issue that could carry them to a parliamentary majority in the next election from their current position with 170 of the 545 seats.
At the same time, many of these politicians suspect that the tests were part of a strategy by hard-line Hindu nationalists to create a wave of popular support, then maneuver to force a new election the nationalists might win in a landslide.
These suspicions hardened today when Indian newspapers reported that an extreme right-wing nationalist group had published a weekly journal shortly before the tests that strongly suggested that the group knew beforehand that the blasts were imminent. The journal, Organizer, is the mouthpiece of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, or National Volunteer Force, a shadowy nationalist group that has been described by its Indian critics as neo-fascist. Many of the new Government's top leaders, including Mr. Vajpayee, have been members of the group, known as the R.S.S., since they were teen-agers.
The journal devoted its entire issue to a commemoration of the 1974 test, saying that the earlier blast had put the world on notice that India was not a nation to be trifled with. At least two of the articles urging a resumption of nuclear testing were written by top nuclear scientists, including one by Rajendra Singh, the R.S.S. leader, who has made no secret of his wide-ranging influence over the new Government.
"We cannot afford to forego our nuclear option when everyone around is arming himself to the teeth," Mr. Singh wrote.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 15, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about India's nuclear tests misstated the comparison between the force of explosions on Monday and the size of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. The blasts, reported by an Indian seismic institute at 55 kilotons, were about 4 times as powerful, not 50 times.

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1071 words

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE PRESIDENT;
Clinton Calls Tests a 'Terrible Mistake' And Announces Sanctions Against India

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 13

 BODY:
President Clinton sharpened his criticism of the Indian Government today, calling its decision to detonate five nuclear explosions underground a "terrible mistake" as he announced a raft of economic sanctions in reprisal.
On a two-day visit to Germany, the President disclosed the sanctions this afternoon after meeting in Potsdam with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Mr. Clinton decided to impose sanctions while flying here on Tuesday night, before India surprised the Administration with two additional tests this morning. Although they had not expected the tests today, Administration officials had feared that they might take place eventually, because Indian officials had refused to rule them out. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich attacked Mr. Clinton for punishing India while overlooking China's sale of missile technology to Pakistan and Iran.
"Look how angry he is at a democracy and how tolerant he is of a dictatorship." Mr. Gingrich said.
Although Mr. Clinton repeatedly expressed sadness and even bitterness over the nuclear tests, he also sounded a note of understanding, suggesting that India, which he called "a perfectly wonderful country," may have been motivated by a lack of self-esteem because it believes it is "underappreciated" as a world power.
"And they think one reason may be that they're not an out-front out-of-the-closet open nuclear power," Mr. Clinton continued. "Well, I think they've been underappreciated in the world and in the United States myself."
But, as Mr. Kohl chuckled at his side, Mr. Clinton added that to try to "manifest your greatness" by detonating thermonuclear devices and atomic bombs "when everybody else is trying to leave the nuclear age behind, is just wrong."
"It is just wrong," he added.
The Administration had anticipated further tests because Indian officials were evasive when asked about their plans on Tuesday by Thomas R. Pickering, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs. "There was a lot of hemming and hawing," a senior Administration official said today.
American intelligence detected activity at the bomb site after the tests on Monday, one official said, but it was not clear whether the Indians were cleaning up from the first tests or preparing for more.
A Federal law mandates that the President impose sanctions against a nation that conducts such tests, although it permits him to delay acting for 30 days. Mr. Clinton decided against such a delay after learning that Mr. Pickering had not received a straight answer, officials said.
Mr. Clinton said that the Indian tests "clearly create a dangerous new instability in their region." He said that in a telephone conversation this morning he had urged Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan not to respond to India with tests of its own.
But although the Administration continues to press Pakistan not to act, officials said privately that they expected the pleas to go unheeded.
The President did not sound optimistic, saying of Mr. Sharif, "The pressures on him at home are probably enormous."
Even so, Mr. Clinton did not go as far as Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Helms said at a hearing today, "India's actions clearly constitute an emerging nuclear threat to the territory of the United States."
On Capitol Hill, there was widespread criticism of India and, despite Mr. Gingrich, general support for the President's action. But that was combined with widespread criticism of the failure to anticipate the tests.
"Why didn't anyone in the Administration or in this Congress notice that the Hindu national party had campaigned on a promise to make India a nuclear power?" asked Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat who is on the Intelligence Committee.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Kohl made statements and responded to six questions today on the terrace of the yellow San Souci Palace in Potsdam in what was once East Germany. It was while at the Potsdam conference after the defeat of Nazi Germany that Harry S. Truman, the last American President to visit there, learned of the first successful nuclear test in history, by the United States at Trinity site in New Mexico.
Mr. Kohl did not join Mr. Clinton in immediately announcing sanctions. But he said that Germany would "make it very clear that this was the wrong decision for them to take."
Later in the day Germany called off talks set for next week in Bonn.
Mr. Clinton is planning to attend the annual international economic summit known as the group of seven beginning on Friday in England. The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said he hoped that the participants would "issue a very strong and clear statement condemning the action of India."
Mr. Berger called the sanctions "fairly substantial and powerful" and said that the Administration would wait to gauge their effects before taking further steps against India over its tests today.
The sanctions shut off not only direct aid from the Federal Government to India, worth $142.3 million this year, but they also cancel an assortment of Federal loans and loan guarantees worth billions. Further, they compel the Administration to oppose any loans or loan guarantees from international financial institutions to India, which had expected to receive $3.8 billion from pending loan approvals.
The sanctions also affect companies that do business in India, and they cancel licenses of American arms companies to export munitions to India and block pending licenses. The sanctions prohibit loans by American banks to the Indian Government, except to buy food or agricultural supplies.
After his meetings in Potsdam, Mr. Clinton returned here to address German officials in the Schauspielhaus concert hall. Calling the end of the cold war "the opportunity of generations," the President surveyed American-German and American-European relations and laid out new missions for NATO, which was formed to contain the Soviet Union.
Mr. Clinton called for NATO to defend against threats like weapons proliferation and ethnic violence; to promote economic growth; to strengthen democracy, particularly in Russia, and to enhance global cooperation to protect the environment and combat terrorism.
"In a world grown smaller, what happens beyond our borders touches our daily lives at home," Mr. Clinton said. "America and Europe must work together to shape this world."

An article and a picture caption on Thursday about President Clinton's criticism of the Indian Government over its nuclear tests misspelled the name of the site in Potsdam where he met with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. It was the Sans Souci Palace.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Opera
 
NEW YORK GRAND OPERA. For years, Vincent La Selva has been earning the gratitude of budget-conscious opera buffs for his free summer performances in Central Park of complete operas, completely staged, in a budget-conscious sort of way. Mr. La Selva is halfway through a seven-year effort to perform the entire canon of Verdi operas, in order, during his summer series, which is either a bold stroke or insanity. This weekend, the indefatigable and musically knowledgeable conductor will present excerpts from "Puccini's "Boheme" for a benefit concert in Flushing, Queens, to support the Verdi project, which needs all the support it can get. Sunday at 2 P.M., the garden adjacent to Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard, (718) 463-7700. Tickets: $125, which includes a champagne dinner with a French menu (Anthony Tommasini). 

Classical Music
 
ANONYMOUS 4 AND LIONHEART. These two outstanding vocal groups get together for a program devoted to the two outstanding composers of half a millennium ago. Johannes Ockeghem's music is generally magnificent and somber, unable or unwilling to deliver the secrets of the contrapuntal logic its long lines follow. Josquin Desprez's, by contrast, is full of High Renaissance light. Tonight at 8, St. Michael's Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 99th Street, Manhattan, (212) 678-5432. Tickets: $15; $12 for students and the elderly (Paul Griffiths).
BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC CHORUS. Stravinsky's "Symphony of Psalms" is one of the most deservedly respected sacred works of the 20th century. Rossini's "Petite Messe Solennelle," which will be performed with the Stravinsky on a program by the Brooklyn Philharmonic Chorus, may not seem to be in remotely the same class. But Rossini's seldom-heard work is remarkable: a tender, reverent, skillful and elegant mass setting composed in 1863, almost 35 years after Rossini had retired from opera. Douglas March conducts. Tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., St. Augustine's Church, Sixth Avenue at Park Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 633-2479. Tickets: $10 (Tommasini).
CANTICUM NOVUM SINGERS. Finally, the big day. Here, divided between afternoon and evening concerts, are no fewer than 11 of the 25 Bach cantatas the chorus is presenting this season to celebrate its 25th anniversary, including the great "Jesu, der du meine Seele" at night. Harold Rosenbaum conducts with an expert hand, and if the band of period instrumentalists plays as well as the chorus sings, this should be all any Bach lover could want in a day, maybe more. Sunday at 3 P.M. and 8 P.M., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 501-3330. Tickets: $20 for each concert (James R. Oestreich).
CITY OF BIRMINGHAM SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. Simon Rattle leads his orchestra on their farewell tour together, in what should be one of the best concerts of the season. The program includes dances by Rameau, from "Les Boreades," Haydn's Symphony No. 86 and Beethoven's "Eroica." If you think you know the Beethoven, think again. Sunday at 3 P.M. and Monday at 7:30 P.M. Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $25 to $45 (Griffiths).
DESSOFF CHOIRS. For some listeners, the subtle and profound expression of Rachmaninoff's liturgical music is more impressive than all the grandeur, glitter and occasional bombast of the famous instrumental works. The Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, though perhaps slightly less imposing than Rachmaninoff's other great a cappella creation, the Vespers, is well worth knowing, and the excellent choral conductor Kent Tritle is sure to do it justice here. Tonight at 8, Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Ninth Avenue at 60th Street, Manhattan, (212) 935-2551. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and the elderly; $10 for children under 14 (Oestreich).
"ESTHER," Millennial Arts Productions. The ambitions of this production, "a lavish entertainment with singers, actors and dancers," as it calls itself, are laudable. Sometimes deftly, sometimes in ungainly fashion, it combines the Handel oratorio with the Racine play and any number of touches from left field. The music was strongly sung at a preview last week, though the little orchestra, conducted from the keyboard by Bradley Brookshire, one of the few bright lights on the New York early-music scene, still seemed under rehearsed, a problem perhaps resolved by now. Tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 2 P.M., Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts, 172 Norfolk Street, Lower East Side, (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $20 (Oestreich).
KUN WOO PAIK. The program of works by Bach, Brahms, Wagner and Beethoven looks to be conventional, but Kun Woo Paik's recital promises the work of an experienced South Korean pianist whose high reputation among a small circle of admirers is very much at odds with his relative obscurity in the wider world of concert music. Tonight at 8:30, Alice Tully Hall, (212) 875-5050. Tickets: $15 to $25 (Bernard Holland).
STEVE MACKEY. Mr. Mackey is one of a few composers who grew up in the rock era and refused to leave their pop roots, or even their rock instruments, behind when they became serious composers. Mr. Mackey's instrument is the electric guitar, and he has written some striking pieces for it, both on its own and in combination with other instruments. As part of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's three-concert "Music of Our Time" series, Mr. Mackey is collaborating with the cellist Fred Sherry and a performance artist, Rinde Eckert, on a program that will include both composed and improvised works. Tomorrow at 9 P.M., Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 875-5788. Tickets: $17; student rush tickets, $5. (Allan Kozinn).
MIAMI STRING QUARTET. They start with one of Beethoven's early quartets but then go off in more unusual directions, to Dvorak, whose quartets ought to appear on programs more often, and to the Latvian euphonist Petris Vasks, whose Third Quartet is heard in its New York premiere. Tomorrow at 7 P.M., Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 333-5200. Tickets: $20 (Griffiths).
OLLI MUSTONEN, JOSHUA BELL AND STEVEN ISSERLIS. Here is the grand finale of the Finnish pianist Olli Mustonen's three-concert exploration of the ties between the seemingly disparate composers Bach and Shostakovich. "Even more interesting than their differences are the things that unite them," Mr. Mustonen rightly said recently. Mr. Isserlis will play Bach's great Suite in C for unaccompanied cello, and Mr. Mustonen will join Mr. Isserlis in the D major Viola da Gamba Sonata and Mr. Bell in the C minor Violin Sonata, before the three players join forces in Shostakovich's Second Piano Trio. Sunday at 2 P.M., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $30 (Oestreich).
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. The Alexander Zemlinsky revival continues. This weekend, the New York Philharmonic performs "Die Seejungfrau" ("The Mermaid") a little-known work by the Austrian composer, born in 1871, three years before Schoenberg. Zemlinsky taught his younger colleague counterpoint and introduced him to the music of Wagner. But he did not follow Schoenberg into atonality. Zemlinsky's music, greatly respected in its day, remained in the idiom of Mahler and Strauss. James Conlon conducts the program that includes the youthful Rachmaninoff Piano Concerto No. 1 with the brilliant American pianist Garrick Ohlsson as soloist, and Listz's ruminative tone poem "Les Preludes." Today at 2 P.M., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $13 to $58 (Tommasini).
NEW YORK YOUTH SYMPHONY. The musicians in the New York Youth Symphony are 12 to 22 and come from schools in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Not all hope to become professional musicians, but they clearly put considerable effort into their work with the orchestra. In recent seasons, several music reviewers have noted the high level of the ensemble's performances in fully professional, fully demanding repertory. The orchestra has also been a training ground for conductors who have gone on to bigger things; Leonard Slatkin and Samuel Wong are among its past directors. Its current director is Mischa Santora, and his current program includes Rimsky-Korsakov's flashy "Russian Easter Overture," Strauss's "Death and Transfiguration" and Horn Concerto No. 1 (David Jolley is the soloist) and a world premiere, Peter Boyer's "Phoenix." Sunday at 2 P.M., Carnegie Hall. (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $5 (Kozinn).
 
Dance
 
JUILLIARD YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS CONCERT. One of the worst-kept secrets in New York dance is the vitality and professionalism displayed these days by the young performers of the Juilliard Dance Division, who will be seen in a free graduation performance on Tuesday night, featuring Jiri Kylian's "Stoolgame." But the spotlight will be on the school's choreographers in a free Young Choreographers Concert tomorrow night. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 769-7406 (Jennifer Dunning).
STEPHAN KOPLOWITZ AND COMPANY. A cast of dancers, actors and singers, both high school students and adults, brings a great satiric fantasy to life: Karel Capek's "War With the Newts," a Czech novel of 1936 about the attempts of a race of newts to take over the world. As the story unfolds, it becomes a sharp commentary on politics, economics, oppression and the arms race. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077. Tickets $15 (Jack Anderson).
NEW YORK CITY BALLET. This is a good weekend to revisit some old friends in the New York City Ballet repertory. George Balanchine's luminous, mannerly "Tombeau de Couperin" will be performed tonight and tomorrow night, a bow to Ravel, who composed the score, to the 18th-century French music Ravel himself was saluting, and to the all-important but seldom celebrated corps de ballet. Tonight, too, Damian Woetzel is scheduled to dance the lead role in Balanchine's "Prodigal Son" with Helene Alexopoulos as the Siren, on the bill with Jerome Robbins's serenely pretty "Glass Pieces." Kyra Nichols will sweep through Balanchine's "Serenade" on Sunday afternoon, and Peter Boal will make a role debut tomorrow night in "Bournonville Divertissements," whose first-rate cast also boasts Miranda Weese and Jennie Somoygi, two of the company's most interesting dancers. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M., New York State Theater. Information: (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $15 to $68 (Dunning).
AMY PIVAR PROJECTS. Amy Pivar's dances give new meaning to the expression "in your face." Ms. Pivar is a thin, wiry and fierce dancer, and her pieces, created with Freda Rosen, have something of her kamikaze emotional and physical attack. They also tend to be cluttered, unlike Ms. Pivar's performing, but her new work, "These Women," has a promising theme. The multimedia piece, which fuses musical theater and modern dance, looks at a career woman who is motivated by the death of a friend to re-examine her relationships with the women who have influenced her life. Through May 23. Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 P.M. and Sundays at 3 P.M., Here, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 647-0202. Tickets: $15 (Dunning).
OLGA RORIZ DANCE COMPANY. A leading Portuguese choreographer, who has worked with both classical and modern-dance groups, emphasizes lyric beauty in one of her most recent creations, "Our Lady." Tomorrow at 8 P.M., New Jersey Performing Arts Society, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Tickets: $20 (Anderson).
MORGAN SCOTT BALLET COMPANY. The warmhearted new Morgan Scott Ballet Company, founded by Daniel Scott and Edward Morgan, a charismatic former Joffrey Ballet dancer, is just the antidote for all our recent grey rainy weather. Forget about vitamin C. The joyous, intelligent dancers and repertory, a mix of classical ballet, and modern and jazz dance, are the psychic equivalent. Tomorrow at 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M., Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (free shuttle from the Willets Point-Shea Stadium stop on the No. 7 subway line), (718) 760-0064. Tickets: $21 (Dunning).
SENSEDANCE. Henning Rubsam features dances of grace, love and joy in a program called "Moonpaths," to a new score by Beata Moon and songs in a romantic manner by musical artists as diverse as Schubert and Laura Nyro. Tonight through Sunday at 8:30 P.M.; also tomorrow at 3 P.M., St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village, (212) 674-8194. Tickets: $18 (Anderson).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kyra Nichols of New York City Ballet in Balanchine's "Serenade." (Paul Kolnik/New York City Ballet); Enrico Di Giuseppe in New York Grand Opera's "Boheme." (New York Grand Opera)
