PUB-DATE: May 15, 1998,

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 717 words

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Shout From India

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
The decision was made by India, and India will pay the economic price. But Americans should understand that it was the West, particularly the U.S., that built the policy road leading to the Indian underground explosions.
 The utter shock in Washington shows more than an intelligence failure. It shows attitudes about India are the same Western mush of arrogance, ignorance and condescension that they have been for the half-century since Indian independence.
 
 Just as plainly it shows the danger of the new ingredient President Clinton added -- the drive to make China the partner of America in the last years of this century and all the next, partner in trade, technology, honing the capabilities of Chinese armed forces, and in security strategy that will affect all Asia and the Pacific.
Think of yourself as Indian for a few paragraphs -- not a Gandhi Indian, few of those left, but just Indian, one of the millions who delightedly approve of the nuclear tests that put such a startled face on Washington.
Look around. Pakistan on the border, created by the 1947 partition, is almost entirely Muslim, about 132 million. India has about 850 million Hindus and 120 million Muslims. India has been basically democratic since independence, and Pakistan basically authoritarian.
Since partition, three wars have been fought between them. Another is possible any time -- over India's possession of Muslim Kashmir, or religious massacres in either country, or suspicion so deep they bleed for it.
Both have nuclear-weapon capacity and never submitted to no-testing demands from nuclear powers finished with all the tests they needed.
Washington lectures us: Parity should exist between India and Pakistan. Are we fools? Parity between our billion and their 132 million, our huge scientific establishment and their puny one, our democracy and their authoritarianism?
We have a larger army, but these Pakistanis fight like hell. We can defeat them in conventional war -- if only their ally China does not charge in to help them.
And this is the nerve-racking part -- China sells nuclear technology and missile know-how to Pakistan. The U.S. does not penalize China. We like that as Americans would like Mexico getting military parity with the U.S. plus nuclear stuff from Russia.
China sliced up our army in 1962 and took a chunk of our Himalayan border land. China won't give it back. Indian intelligence takes fewer daily naps than American, but are we sure China can never surprise us again and that if it were losing it would never ever use nukes? Our Socialist Defense Minister says China is our most dangerous opponent.
But listen to Mr. Clinton talk of his priority -- American democracy and Chinese dictatorship knitting together in trade and security strategy. What strategy? Was India consulted, even thought about?
I lived four years in India as a correspondent. Washington's policy was a little pat on the head, or a scolding finger -- and still is.
I wish the tests had not been made. They will burden India's economy -- more arms, few foreign loans, less investment, much denunciation.
The nationalist party heading the coalition Government runs counter to my hopes for India. It is xenophobic about foreign investment, has a history of Muslim-baiting and maintains extremist Hindu branches, including one headed by a Bombay nasty who admires Hitler.
Indians say that as a member of a shaky coalition that depends on centrists, the party is more moderate. We shall see.
Certainly, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee has domestic political motives -- strengthening his party so that he does not wake up thrown out by Parliament. But I think he had more objectives for the tests. Gaining prestige among third-world powers was one. Another was to shout into the American ear: "Look at us, speak to us, we are India."
Is Mr. Clinton wise or brave enough to reconsider his frantic pursuit of China and the money U.S. businesses hope Beijing will pour over them? Well, at least he can get the shock off his face about Indian independence of action, the murk out of his mind; it's about time.
Ordinary Indians do have hopes and fears about their country, just as if they were ordinary Americans. They are not in a silence mood. Head-patting decades are over.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Fighting the Drug Trade

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re your May 10 and 11 front-page articles on the Dominican Republic, the Dominican community in the United States and the drug issue:
Less than 2 percent of people of Dominican origin living in the United States have been involved in drug-related crimes. Unfortunately, Dominican migration to the United States has, since 1965, coincided with the growing consumption of drugs in the United States. Thus, unemployed youth found illegal income opportunities in drug distribution.
As you note, two months ago the United States Government said the Dominican Republic was cooperating closely on drug investigation matters with the United States. While you quote a State Department official as saying that under President Leonel Fernandez "not a single drug-related case has been prosecuted," drug-related arrests in 1997 exceeded 1,400, according to the State Department. 
 A United States Embassy survey estimates that only 35,000 Dominicans are users of cocaine and marijuana in my country -- less than 1 percent of our population over 12 years of age, as compared with a 6 percent equivalent figure for the United States.
 
BERNARDO VEGA
Washington, May 12, 1998
 
Ambassador of Dominican Republic

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE SUBCONTINENT;
Pakistan Is Under Growing Pressure Not to Respond to India With Atom Test

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 14

 BODY:
Pakistan came under increasing pressure from foreign governments today to refrain from answering India's recent nuclear tests with tests of its own. Many Pakistanis continued to insist, however, that joining India in the nuclear club is vital to their country's security.
The United States Embassy in Islamabad, the capital, announced that Assistant Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and the American commander for the region, Gen. Anthony C. Zinni of the Marines, would arrive here on Friday for urgent talks with Pakistani leaders. They are expected to bring assurances that Western powers will severely punish India for its tests and will reward Pakistan if it does not conduct nuclear tests. 
 During his visit to Berlin today, President Clinton urged Pakistan to "resist the temptation" to begin nuclear testing.
A spokesman for the Japanese Government, which froze hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to India this week, said Japan had sent a message to Pakistan saying "that we would hate to find ourselves in a position where we would have to do the same to Pakistan."
Prime Minister John Howard of Australia, who announced a suspension of military contacts and an end to all non-relief aid for India, urged Pakistan not to try to match India "tit for tat."
 Jim Steinberg, the United States' deputy national security adviser, said in a briefing in the eastern German town of Eisenach during Mr. Clinton's visit there that a nuclear test would destabilize South Asia. He signaled a willingness to address issues that Pakistan may bring up, but indicated that legislative restrictions might limit what the United States can offer.
There was no indication, however, that these appeals were changing the position of Pakistan, which has fought three wars with India since 1947 and fears another one.
"India's actions, which pose an immediate and grave threat to Pakistan's security, will not go unanswered," a senior Pakistani diplomat, Munir Akram, said today at a United Nations disarmament conference in Geneva.
Domestic pressure on the Government to begin nuclear testing increased as it became clear that India's two detonations on Wednesday were to test weapons that could be used on the battlefield against tank formations or infantry units. Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan called these weapons "Pakistan specific."
The Pakistani Cabinet met today but made no decision on how to proceed. Foreign diplomats in Islamabad said the decision would probably be made by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and his army commander, Gen. Jehangir Karamat.
India and Pakistan have been bitter political, religious and territorial rivals since both states came into being half a century ago. India considers itself a great power and is frustrated by what it perceives as the world's failure to treat it as such. Since countries with nuclear weapons have automatically been treated as great powers, India sees a nuclear arsenal as a psychological and political weapon as well as a military one.
India and Pakistan have long had competitive nuclear programs, but both had refrained from tests that were openly for military purposes. For Pakistan to avoid responding now would be a retreat from its longstanding policy of seeking to match India in every way.
In making their case that Pakistan should not begin nuclear testing, foreign leaders have sought to persuade their Pakistani counterparts that Pakistan's long-term security would be better served if it refrains from becoming a nuclear power.
"The Pakistanis have an opportunity to de-link themselves from India in this area and use the distaste generated by the tests to Pakistan's advantage," said a diplomat in Islamabad who is closely monitoring the debate here.
To many nations -- including the United States, long used to thinking of India as a plucky democracy and Pakistan as a country ruled by unsavory militarists -- India's nuclear tests came as a great shock. For Pakistanis, they were proof that what they have been telling the West for years is true.
India's tests present Pakistan with a remarkable opportunity to be viewed as mature and responsible while India is perceived as a dangerous rogue.
Pakistan has been fighting for years to achieve this status. But Pakistan will be able to seize this moment only if it refrains from conducting a nuclear test, diplomats here said this week.
Domestic political pressures make it exceedingly difficult for Mr. Sharif to choose that course. Emotion-charged demonstrators have taken to the streets in several cities to demand that the Government reply to India's nuclear tests with tests of its own.
Opposition political leaders are demanding quick nuclear detonations. Among them is former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who told a television interviewer in London that without such tests, India "will resort to aggression against Pakistan at its own sweet will."
Beyond these political pressures lie cold strategic calculations. Foreign leaders are able to promise Pakistan the respect and gratitude of the world and to point to sanctions imposed on India as an example of what it will suffer if it proceeds. But in the end, they cannot guarantee Pakistan's security. Many Pakistanis believe that only a nuclear arsenal can now do that.
Some voices are being raised here against the evident surge in favor of Pakistan's entry into the nuclear club. More than a few newspaper columnists and editorial writers have urged restraint.
"Given the fact that the Pakistani economy is entirely dependent on foreign loans these days, an explosion seems a remote possibility," the Peshawar newspaper Frontier Post said in an editorial.
At midday today about 100 demonstrators marched through the streets of Islamabad carrying signs reading, "Schools Not Bombs" and "Pakistan: Respond With Restraint."
"We have a very poor population with a crying need for basic services like health care, housing and clean water," said Nasreen Sultana, one of the demonstrators. "Why not spend our money on those things instead of on bombs?"
A coalition of 12 peace and human rights groups issued a statement condemning India's tests but urging Pakistan to "respond responsibly to the Indian provocation and renounce the path of nuclearization."
"The real strength and honor of a nation lies not in the arsenal of murder and destruction it possesses," the statement said, "but in the prosperity and welfare of its people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pakistani students chanted anti-Indian slogans in Lahore on Wednesday during a demonstration demanding that Pakistan stage its own nuclear tests in response to the explosions by India this week. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Fastest Rise In Six Months For Price Index

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Consumer prices in the United States rose in April at the fastest pace in six months, the Government said today in a report that suggested inflation might accelerate from the 30-year lows reached earlier this year.
Led by higher costs for housing and health care, the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month after remaining unchanged in two of the prior three months, the Labor Department said. 
 "The best news on inflation is behind us," said John Williams, chief economist at the Bankers Trust Company in New York.
In another economic report, the Commerce Department said inventories of goods at American businesses rose five-tenths of 1 percent in March after rising seven-tenths of 1 percent in February. That is an indication companies were building their stocks in anticipation demand would not slow.
A further sign of growth was seen in the Labor Department's weekly report on state unemployment benefits claims, which fell by 2,000 in the week ended Saturday to 307,000. The four-week average for initial claims, closely watched for insights into labor market trends, remained below 315,000 for the 14th consecutive week.
Federal Reserve officials have shown their patience with the economy's strong growth and low inflation, holding the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent for more than a year. Fed policy makers are scheduled to meet Tuesday, but even with the strong economic data released today it remains unclear whether they will raise rates.
For the first four months of the year, the index rose at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent, down from a 1.5 percent annualized rate during the first four months of 1997.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Securities Prices Fall on Fears of Higher Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday after a report on consumer prices kept alive concern the Federal Reserve may increase interest rates, though few expect a move when central bankers meet Tuesday.
The Government's Consumer Price Index rose more than expected in April when food and energy prices were excluded. "It's the first bad C.P.I. number we've had for a long time," said Charles Parkhurst, head of government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney Inc. "People are a little concerned that this could be the beginning of a trend." 
 Even so, there is little expectation Fed officials will increase interest rates next week, according to a survey of economists, bond strategists and traders at the 36 primary dealers, the only firms that deal directly with the Fed's securities trading desk. Only one of the firms predicted a rate increase.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 , to 1021/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.98 percent, from 5.94 percent on Wednesday.
 "I don't think inflation's running away, but it would be wrong to get overly optimistic," said Todd Barre, who helps manage $10 billion at Harris Bank in Chicago. "I lean toward being a touch nervous."
Signs of faster inflation might lead the Fed to raise its target for overnight lending between banks in the months ahead, after holding it steady for more than a year, traders said.
Some investors also said bonds might benefit from any further turmoil in Indonesia or elsewhere in Asia, because that would increase the attractiveness of fixed-income securities and make it harder for the Fed to raise rates.
"A big piece of recent gains is the flight to quality vis-a-vis the unrest overseas," said Patricia Larkin, who oversees $35 billion of money market securities at the Dreyfus Corporation. "That's going to continue."
Federal Reserve officials meet Tuesday, and again at a two-day meeting that ends July 1. While few expect any rate move next week, "there will be a lot more pressure going into the July meeting," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio,l adding, "The policy discussion will intensify."
In the corporate market, Owens-Illinois Inc. led today's borrowers, selling $1.1 billion of bonds. A dozen companies crowded into the market yesterday to sell $6.4 billion of bonds.

LENGTH: 2121 words

HEADLINE: Sneaking U.S. Jets to Iran: The Canadian Route

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA with LOWELL BERGMAN; Lowell Bergman is the senior investigative producer for CBS News.

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Colombia, May 14

 BODY:
Several times over the past few years, Reza Akrami, an Iranian, left his home in the Vancouver area and flew to San Francisco to see a mysterious man who spoke in Persian and called himself Dr. Afshar.
They met at a swank hotel or an expensive restaurant. A few times they lunched on a private yacht docked in the bay. There were thick steaks and fine wines. 
 Eventually, a shadowy deal was put on the table. Dr. Afshar would arrange delivery of American-made jets and military parts, including electronics to guide antiaircraft missiles. The destination for the parts was Iran, and the suggested payment was a large shipment of heroin, according to a fax sent from Iran to Mr. Akrami that outlined the arrangement.
The deal never came off. "Dr. Afshar" was an undercover agent for the United States Government posing as an arms dealer bent on evading the American embargo against Iran.
Mr. Akrami and an associate were arrested in Vancouver this week and are being held pending extradition to the United States. They face charges of conspiring to smuggle sophisticated military parts to Iran in violation of the United States embargo.
A joint investigation by The New York Times and CBS News has found that this is not an isolated case. A significant portion of the American-made weapons and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and the Canadian Government's decision not to support the American embargo.
The result, say American officials and the Iranians involved, is a steady flow of American-made military parts across the border into Canada and on to Iran. "Sanctions against Iran make no sense because they get everything they want through other countries," Mr. Akrami said in an interview here before his arrest.
According to an indictment returned this week by a grand jury in San Francisco, Mr. Akrami, 60, told undercover agents the Iranian Government wanted to buy as many klystron tubes -- the heart of missile guidance systems -- as he could find.
"There is a significant amount of circumvention of our sanctions through Canada," said Raymond W. Kelly, an Under Secretary of the Treasury, who is awaiting confirmation as the new head of the Customs Service. "Because of the relaxed border situation that we have with Canada, the potential for abuse there is greater than perhaps with other allies."
Among the Iranian arms deals involving Canada are these:
*A Long Island man was arrested in February by United States Customs agents as he tried to deliver engines and parts for F-14 Tomcat fighters to Iran; some of the items were to be routed through Canada. He is awaiting trial.
*A Canadian businessman was indicted in Washington, D.C., last year on 27 counts of shipping embargoed aviation parts to Iran by way of Canada and then Germany. He is currently a fugitive.
*In Miami in 1994, an Irish businessman pleaded guilty to charges of attempting to send military night-vision goggles to Iran by way of Canada.
And Iran is not the only destination for embargoed American military equipment from Canada.
Several Americans and Canadians were arrested last August and charged with attempting to sell to Iraq 35 American-made military helicopters that Canada had declared surplus. The buyers had asked that some helicopters be outfitted with chemical-spraying equipment. Two Canadians have already pleaded guilty; the other defendants are awaiting trial.
Last fall a Toronto businessman pleaded guilty to selling $6 million worth of jet parts to Libya, including some that could have military uses.
"I'll be honest with you: Canada does not pretend that it is enforcing a U.S. embargo," said Lynda E. Watson, director of the export controls division in the Canadian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Trade. While Canada tries to make sure it is not used as a decoy to get around American export restrictions, she explained, its efforts are limited.
"It's not our embargo," she said, "and it's not our job to enforce a U.S. embargo."
 
The Middleman
From Army Doctor To Refugee
There are many unanswered questions about Mr. Akrami: Precisely on whose behalf was he shopping for parts? What did the Iranian Government knew about his activities?
And while American agents were luring him into their sting, Canadian intelligence agents were using him as their informant.
Mr. Akrami said in an interview before his arrest that he was merely a purchasing agent for Iran. "I cannot stop them to fax me what they want," he said, "but it doesn't mean I can do something or I want to do something."
Mr. Akrami's lawyer, Irvine E. Epstein, said his client had exaggerated the importance of his contacts in Iran and expected Dr. Afshar to arrange the necessary export permits if the deals went through.
"He's absolutely adamant that he has not committed any crimes in Canada or the United States," Mr. Epstein said of his client. "If anything, what we have is perhaps some overzealous undercover agents trying to make something out of nothing."
Before coming to Canada, Mr. Akrami said, he was a colonel in the Iranian Army and a cardiac surgeon in contact with many of Iran's most powerful people. He boasted to friends that he had once treated the Ayatollah Khomeini.
Mr. Akrami said he had received his medical degrees in Germany and returned to Iran just a year before the 1979 revolution. His foreign training made him suspect in the turmoil of fundamentalist, post-revolution Iran. He was imprisoned but was allowed to see patients, he said.
Soon after being freed from prison, Mr. Akrami married an Iranian woman with family in Vancouver. In 1991 he emigrated to Canada, where he quickly fit into Vancouver's substantial Iranian refugee community.
"I'm connected to everybody," he said during the interview at his office.
He does not practice medicine in Canada but gained notoriety when his mother-in-law won a divorce settlement that was the equivalent of $12 million, one of the largest in Canadian history. He helped her invest the money in various ventures, and made no secret of his intention to do business with Iran.
In the interviews, he said he helped arrange for the delivery of two shiploads of American chemicals to Iran about four years ago, which he believed did not violate terms of the embargo. He also said he regularly received faxed messages from Iran requesting help in purchasing everything from Braille typewriters and spare parts for jumbo jets to a fleet of used civilian aircraft.
People close to the investigation said he once told undercover agents, "Canada is Iran's free-trade zone."
The United States first imposed economic sanctions on Iran after the hostage crisis in 1979. In 1995, after Iran was linked to terrorist attacks, a total ban was imposed on all American trade with the country. Before then, certain items, including some chemicals, could be exported from the United States.
 
The Introductions
Linking Heroin To Fighter Jets
Mr. Akrami might not have come to the attention of American authorities if not for another Iranian immigrant to Canada who was arrested by drug agents in San Francisco in 1994 and charged with a conspiracy to distribute large amounts of heroin.
Prosecutors in San Francisco had substantial evidence against the man, Abrahim Hamidi. But after he developed medical problems, they let him return to his home in Langley, a Vancouver suburb where he lived in a modest house and grew Iranian sour plums in the backyard.
Shortly after his return to Canada, Mr. Hamidi held a dinner at his home and invited a young Iranian friend, Mohsen Lessan, and Mr. Akrami, who said he was looking for new business opportunities.
But this was apparently more than a social engagement. According to officials familiar with the investigation, Mr. Hamidi was cooperating with American agents who wanted to broaden their investigation into the Iranian heroin connection. The charges against Mr. Hamidi in California were dismissed in April 1996, but within a few days he was arrested on a similar drug charge in Canada. In an unusual move, the records in that case were sealed, and it is not possible to learn its outcome.
Mr. Lessan, now a 30-year-old real estate salesman in Vancouver, said in an interview that he and Mr. Akrami had flown to San Francisco and met the man they knew as Dr. Afshar. They lunched in grand style on a yacht they believed was his. They discussed the purchase of up to 30 used jets for Iran, as well as parts and other items.
Mr. Lessan said he felt he was in over his head. While Mr. Akrami returned to San Francisco at least twice, Mr. Lessan never again met Dr. Afshar. He was arrested this week along with Mr. Akrami and is being held pending extradition to San Francisco, where a United States Attorney, Michael J. Yamaguchi, plans to prosecute him and Mr. Akrami on the smuggling conspiracy charges.
Mr. Lessan's lawyer, Jamie Paez, has refused to comment.
 
The End of the Deal
A Disputed Fax, An Angry Ex-Wife
In his first interview with The New York Times and CBS, Mr. Akrami denied knowing Mr. Hamidi. But at a subsequent talk in his high-rise apartment, he admitted that he had gone to Mr. Hamidi's house, but only because his wife liked the sour plums that Mr. Hamidi grew.
Mr. Hamidi did not respond to several phone calls or visits to his home.
Mr. Akrami eventually admitted he had discussed several deals with "Dr. Afshar," adding, "Ninety-nine percent of the discussion was about planes."
But he said one fax he received from his contact in Iran -- a man known as Sultanipour whom American officials have linked to the Iranian Government -- requested sophisticated military parts, including the American-made klystron tubes used in missile guidance systems.
At the meetings in San Francisco, which were monitored by United States agents, Mr. Akrami openly discussed military parts and displayed a detailed knowledge of how they worked. Once, he even commented that the suitcase-sized klystron tube the agents had brought was a slightly different color than those he had seen before.
During this period, officials said, Mr. Akrami also met regularly with the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, Canada's spy agency, which sometimes uses recent immigrants to gather information. He insists he never told them about the San Francisco meetings.
Mr. Akrami acknowledged there were other faxes as well, including one that mentioned paying for the parts with a "shipload of heroin." But he insisted that although he presented the faxed letter to Dr. Afshar, he never had any intention of actually going through with the deal.
"This was nonsense," said Mr. Akrami. "How can I have drugs to offer to someone for something like that?"
After repeated contact and telephone conversations with the undercover agents, Mr. Akrami abruptly backed away from the deal last summer. He said things had changed because of the tightened American embargo and because of the more moderate Government that had come to power in Iran's elections. But there appeared to be another reason: his recently divorced wife, who had some of the faxes from Iran, was threatening to expose him.
He said his former wife had shown the faxes to authorities in an attempt to discredit him. People close to the investigation confirmed that the Canadian Security Intelligence Service, a local prosecutor and a member of Parliament had talked to the woman.
 
The Loophole
An 'Exception' For a Neighbor
Although Mr. Akrami is not charged with actually shipping any embargoed parts to Iran, recent incidents indicate that plenty of American military goods leave Canada's shores, largely because of "the Canada exemption."
For decades it has been policy of both Canada and the United States that Canada would purchase major arms systems from the United States instead of developing its own military industry. For this reason, such goods being shipped to Canada are exempt from the licensing requirements that apply to every other country.
"Since we don't issue a license here, there's no trail to follow," said John Hensley, the former head of enforcement for the United States Customs Service. "Therefore we can't tell how much is leaving Canada en route to other countries."
Canada does $1 billion a year in legitimate trade with Iran. While Canada has regulations to keep Canada from being used to hide shipments to Iran, officials here make it clear that the embargo is America's fight, not Canada's.
"We feel that we are taking very responsible and strong steps to deal with this," said Ms. Watson, the Canadian customs official, "but we're not 100 percent effective."

But "Dr. Afshar" was an undercover agent, and now Mr. Akrami is in jail in Canada. (CBS News)

HEADLINE: In Germany, Clinton Voices Hope for Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: EISENACH, Germany, May 14

 BODY:
President Clinton, speaking to a group of auto workers here, said today that his most urgent foreign policy goal before leaving office was to secure "a peace agreement in the Middle East that will last for a long time."
Foreign travel -- which usually, as it did today, produces adoring crowds and splendid backdrops -- often puts Mr. Clinton in an expansive and even philosophical mood, as it frees him from sticky legal and political travails at home. 
 On the second of two cloudless days in Germany in the company of his friend, Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Mr. Clinton spent today reflecting on American accomplishments in Europe and reaping the gratitude of Germans. This morning, he celebrated the American role in the Berlin airlift at the start of the Cold War, then came here this afternoon to tour a General Motors plant and celebrate the American role in rebuilding Germany after the cold war .
Asked by one German auto worker at a forum beside the plant about his aspirations and achievements, Mr. Clinton reeled off a list of each.
He named "turning the American economy around in ways that benefit ordinary Americans" as his top domestic accomplishment. Abroad, he said, "I hope that putting America in the center of the future after the cold war will be a lasting achievement." He also described that achievement as "not letting America withdraw from the world."
As his top domestic goals, the President named helping the inner cities and protecting retirement and health-care programs.
Later, before a crowd of thousands packed into the cobbled square here, in the former East Germany, Mr. Clinton seemed to revel in his role as a spokesman for democracy. "On this beautiful Thuringian day in the spring," the President said, "we are bathed in the light and the warmth of freedom."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged that Germany was still struggling to rebuild, but said: "Do not underestimate what you can do with your dreams as free people." To Mr. Clinton's slow, stately wave, the crowd responded with whistles and a blur of thousands of waving hands.
Mr. Clinton then toured the city with Mr. Kohl, despite sharp lower back pain he has felt since he injured himself stretching on Monday. "Motrin was the order of the day," said Michael D. McCurry, the press secretary. Next on Mr. Clinton's itinerary is England, where he will attend an economic summit meeting.
Mr. Kohl, who is campaigning for his own re-election and basking in Mr. Clinton's popularity, told the auto workers that he thought German taxes were too high and were discouraging foreign investment. But, with words that might not sound so inspiring to American workers, Mr. Clinton assured the audience that "most manufacturers in America are prepared to go anywhere there is a work force that can be trained," and will work hard in teams.
Before flying here, President Clinton appeared at Tempelhof Airport in Berlin to commemorate the eleven-month Western air campaign that kept West Berlin supplied with coal and food after Stalin cut off overland supply routes on June 24, 1948.
Mr. Clinton received thunderous applause from the thousands of invited German guests as he recalled President Truman's words in a White House meeting on June 28 of that year: "There is no discussion on that point. We stay in Berlin, period."
The crowd was gathered in a giant amphitheater formed by a semicircular hangar that was open to the runway. Mr. Clinton and Chancellor Kohl faced the audience from a podium on the tarmac, standing before a new American C-17 cargo jet christened The Spirit of Berlin today that was parked nose-to-nose with a gray C-54 transport plane.
It was the C-54 that flew most of the American missions into Tempelhof Airport. French and British planes operated from other airports. Flying no higher than 10,000 feet in every kind of weather, with windows open to thin the dust emitted by the cargo of coal and flour, crews made two round trips to Berlin every 16 hours from bases in Europe. They stayed on the ground in Germany for just half an hour.
"A plane every 90 seconds, at its height," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Kohl said that the airlift taught Germans "what it meant not to be alone in our hour of need," declaring that Berlin owed its survival and freedom to the United States and its allies.
In his speech this morning, Mr. Clinton committed a rare gaffe. He singled out an American pilot from the airlift, Gail Halvorsen, but mistakenly assumed that Mr. Halvorsen was a woman. "She is here with us today," Mr. Clinton said, "and I'd like to ask her to stand." Once Mr. Halvorsen stood, Mr. Clinton realized his error. "Thank you sir," he said. "Thank you. He's here."
Mr. Halvorsen, 77, flew 126 flights in the airlift and became known as the "Rosinenbomber," or raisin bomber, because he dropped dried fruit and candy for children. Before Mr. Clinton spoke, Mr. Halvorsen said of his experience: "It was a hard time, but a good time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chancellor Helmut Kohl, left, and President Clinton looked out of a window in the Wartburg, a castle in Eisenach, Germany, yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Profit Warning by Hewlett Helps Push Dow Down by 39.61

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday after a profit warning by Hewlett-Packard pushed the Dow Jones industrial average down from Wednesday's record high, but failed to rattle the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 39.61 points, to 9,172.23, a day after closing at a record high of 9,211.84. 
 The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks was down 1.49 points at 1,117.37. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.82, to 1,865.36.
"Considering the news background, the market took it all with a big yawn," said Michael Metz, a managing director at the CIBC Oppenheimer Corporation.
Investors faced a shock in an earnings warning from Hewlett-Packard, Indonesia's worst riots in three decades and a rise in United States core inflation.
"It's still a market that is looking for opportunities rather than exits," Mr. Metz said. "The perverseness is that people are saying there is no market except the U.S. market, and that's where they want to be."
Arthur Cashin, a New York Stock Exchange floor trader for Paine Webber, said many investors were taking a wait-and-see attitude regarding the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Tuesday, and Indonesia's problems.
"There is a buyers' boycott today, with people waiting for a little better definition of what the Fed's posture will be, and what the influence of whatever is happening in Asia is going to be," Mr. Cashin said.
Wall Street is still betting that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates unchanged.
Asian markets were battered as the worst rioting in three decades ravaged the Indonesia capital of Jakarta.
The technology stocks were the big story. International Business Machines jumped 3 15/16, to 125 13/16, in New York Stock Exchange trading, a day after its chief executive forecast double-digit revenue growth in the coming years.
Several brokerage houses also upgraded their ratings and price targets on I.B.M.
Hewlett-Packard plunged 1 15/16, to 70 5/16, after the printer and PC personal computer maker said late Wednesday that its second-quarter profits would fall short of Wall Street's expectations.
Hewlett-Packard had been viewed as one of the latest success stories in the personal computer market, posting strong market share gains this year.
Microsoft rose 2, to 88 15/16, buoyed by news that it was in negotiations to head off threatened state and federal antitrust action.
In return, Microsoft agreed to delay until Monday the shipment of its Windows 98 operating system to computer makers.
"What you're seeing is the Street is hopeful there can be some resolution that doesn't compromise the Microsoft business model and at the same time minimizes any government intervention," said David Readerman, an analyst for Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
Other technology stocks managed to avoid posting the same kind of declines as Hewlett.
The Intel Corporation was off 1/4, to 84 9/16. Applied Materials Inc. fell 15/16, to 38 9/16.

HEADLINE: A Chip Maker Says It Expects More Bad News

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14

 BODY:
The National Semiconductor Corporation delivered bad news to Wall Street today for the fourth time in four months, warning that revenues will fall below analysts' estimates and that it expects a loss for the current quarter and possibly the next.
The chip maker's announcement also marked the latest sobering setback for Silicon Valley's high-technology industry, coming one day after the Hewlett-Packard Company warned of an earnings shortfall because of price cutting in personal computers. 
 As it has in the three earlier announcements, National attributed the weakness to a number of problems, including production difficulties at its Cyrix subsidiary, the slowdown in PC sales because of bloated inventories at some manufacturers, and the effect of the Asian economic crisis on sales of chips used in cellular telephones.
But National executives said the company also suffered from the shift to sub-$1,000 PC's, which hurt sales of components for midpriced machines, and from technology changes in network adapters, in which it has fallen behind rivals.
In February, National announced it would report a shortfall in earnings for its third fiscal quarter, which ended Feb. 28. In March, it said fourth-quarter results would be weak. Last month, it said it would cut 1,400 jobs worldwide, or about 10 percent of its employees, through a combination of layoffs and attrition. The cuts will result in a one-time charge of between $60 million and $70 million in the current quarter.
National made its latest announcement after the close of the market yesterday. National shares closed at $18.875, down $1.9375 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Problems with Cyrix, which National acquired in July for about $550 million, arose late last year. But at least at that time, National reported healthy sales in its core business, specialized chips for networking cards, cell phones and other devices mixing analog and digital functions. Now those businesses are weak as well, casting into doubt National's whole strategy of moving away from high-volume, low-cost chips to microprocessors and other higher-value products.
National began its new strategy in 1996, after Brian Halla took over as chairman, president and chief executive from Gilbert Amelio, who left to head Apple Computer Inc. Mr. Halla, a former executive of the LSI Logic Corporation, spun off the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, its low-cost chip business, and acquired Cyrix, which designed microprocessor clones of the Intel Corporation's market-dominant products. But analysts who once praised the moves now question them.
"They have a troika of difficulties," said Jonathan Joseph, an analyst with Montgomery Securities, referring to Cyrix, the networking business and the Asian economic crisis. "The question is how much of this is National's problem and how much is an industry problem. I have to say a lot of it is National's problem. These guys are going to continue to lose money."
National said it expects sales for the fourth quarter to decline by as much as 20 percent compared with a year earlier, when it reported sales of $599.2 million. The sales decline will result in an operating loss, and National said that with uncertain first-quarter demand there is also the likelihood of an operating loss in that quarter.
National said shipments in the current quarter have been slowed by inventory adjustments in the personal computer market, as manufacturers slowed their production rates.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Housing Units Will Replace Armory

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The 14th Street Armory has stood like a fortress for the last 27 years between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. But in 1995 the state-owned building closed, leaving its fate in doubt.
Now the state is selling the four-story hulk to a group of investors. By summer, the group intends to bulldoze the armory and under a redevelopment plan supported by community groups, build a 275,000-square-foot mixed-use complex of 7 and 12 stories on the site, which extends to 15th Street. 
 The new complex will have 119,000 square feet of retail space, with a movie theater and stores, in its basement and on its first and second stories. On the 15th Street side, the complex will have 7 stories and contain 40 luxury condominiums. On the 14th Street side, it will have 12 stories and 140 apartments for the elderly. These units will offer tenants hotel-style services, including meals, transportation, housekeeping and social activities.
The $85 million project will be developed by a joint venture between the Orda Management Corporation, the Plaza Construction Corporation, both of Manhattan, and the Care Matrix Corporation of Needham, Mass. The architect is Costas Kondylis of Manhattan.
The partners, who expect to close on the sale by summer, were selected to redevelop the property over three other competitors last month by the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development agency. The purchase price, $15 million, was the highest of the four bids.
The armory, built in 1971, has not had a permanent tenant since the National Guard marched out three years ago. In late 1995, the city opened a job placement center for welfare recipients at the building, but neighborhood groups protested, fearing crime would increase. The center operated at the armory until 1996, and since then the building has been leased to organizations and movie production companies. Films, including "The Object of My Affection," have been shot in the old drill hall.
In April 1997, the state development agency sought proposals from developers. Though the American Institute of Architects guide to New York called the building "gross and overbearing," developers have said the site is well located. It borders a newly resurgent Chelsea neighborhood to the north and the lively commercial strip on the south side of West 14th Street.
To insure that the redevelopment will be compatible with the neighborhood, the state development agency, working with community groups, established use and design guidelines. For example, an interior courtyard will be built over the base of the complex to allow light and air to enter the residences. Also, the entrance to the commercial space will be on 14th Street to lessen the impact of noise and crowds on the neighborhood. The entrances to the housing will be on 15th Street to maintain that street's residential character.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the state development agency, said the process allowed the state to get the best value for the property, put it back on the tax rolls and help stimulate the redevelopment of the area. But most important, he added, the result is a project "that will fit in with its surroundings and the community will like."
Edward Kirkland, chairman of the Chelsea Preservation and Planning Committee of Community Board 4, which helps guide growth in the area, said, "If the developers live up to their commitments, we can live with it."
Explaining why the partners became involved with the project, Morton F. Silver, president of Orda Management, said: "This area is flourishing, but somehow 14th Street has been excluded. So when the armory site came up for redevelopment, it represented a great opportunity."
Care Matrix, a national developer of housing for the elderly, is making its first foray into the Manhattan housing market. Michael Zaccaro, the company's executive vice president, said, "Our approach here is to become part of a larger project that includes straight residential, which is in demand, allowing the senior housing component to be more competitive."
New York City also needs such housing, he said, noting that about 36,000 people age 65 or older live in neighborhoods surrounding the project.
The studio, one- and two-bedroom units for the elderly will range from 400 to 1,000 square feet. Mr. Zaccaro said rents are expected to be $3,200 to $5,200 a month, including meals and services. Common areas, like a dining hall, fitness center and health education center, are planned. He said plans also include working with a local hospital to make health care available to tenants at an extra cost.
The condominiums are expected to average 1,500 square feet, large enough to appeal to families, Mr. Silver said. He said most would be two- or three-bedroom units, which are in demand in the area. Although prices have not been set, he said that if the units were on the market today, they would sell for $400 to $550 a square foot, or $600,000 to $825,000 for the average size condominiums.
Financing is to come from the partners' equity and private lenders. The project is expected to be completed by spring 2000.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 14th Street Armory, between Seventh Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, will be replaced by a retail and residential complex. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Farmers Suing Government to Restore Legal Production of Hemp

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 14

 BODY:
More than 25 years after hemp was last grown legally in America, a group of farmers and trade organizations will file suit against the Federal Government on Friday to make hemp a lawful crop again.
The plaintiffs intend to argue in Federal District Court here that the illegal status of hemp, by definition of the Controlled Substances Act of 1972, violates a 1937 determination by Congress that the plant causes none of the psychoactive effects that its cousin, marijuana, does. 
 The plaintiffs will say in their lawsuit, the first of its kind, that Congress had stipulated hemp, which has many commercial uses, was different from marijuana and that hemp's prohibition by the Drug Enforcement Administration violates the Constitutional doctrine of separation of powers of government.
But the central thrust of the legal action is economics, with thousands of farmers throughout the South and Midwest looking at hemp as another crop to include in their annual rotations that now involve grains, vegetables and tobacco.
For many farmers, particularly those here in eastern Kentucky who are almost wholly dependent on tobacco for their income, hemp would provide a viable hedge as a disease-resistant plant -- especially when the future of tobacco is so uncertain.
As the region's most valuable crop, tobacco can generate as much as $5,000 an acre in gross sales. Most food crops like corn, soybeans and wheat do not have anywhere near that kind of return. But farmers like Jim Barton, whose family raised hemp when it was legal during a "Hemp for Victory" drive in World War II, predicted that an acre of hemp could gross as much as $1,200.
"Hemp is no more controversial today than tobacco is," said Andrew R. Graves, who will be a plaintiff in the suit as president of the Kentucky Hemp Growers Council, a group of 60 would-be hemp farmers. "You go into any store and you can buy hemp products. But he and I as farmers" -- he pointed to Mr. Barton -- "get no portion of that money. That makes no sense to me."
Terry Parham, a spokesman for the drug administration, said the agency had not seen the lawsuit and, as a result, would have no comment.
The frustration of would-be hemp farmers and marketers in the United States -- and the basis of the lawsuit -- centers on the long-standing policy of the Department of Justice and the D.E.A. to make no distinction between hemp and marijuana because they contain the same psychoactive chemical -- delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol, commonly known as THC. Government officials fear that hemp would provide camouflage for growing marijuana.
But the lawsuit will argue that Congress in 1937 recognized the differences when it passed the Marijuana Tax Act and excluded hemp from any prohibition. And scientists have determined that THC constitutes less than 1 percent of hemp's weight, not enough to cause any psychoactive effects.
Despite the 1937 law that made a distinction between hemp and marijuana, hemp farming virtually died out over three decades that followed, except for the wartime program.
The farmers' lawsuit will ask that the court rule that it was illegal for the executive branch of government to ban hemp, that chemical distinctions between marijuana and hemp should be recognized and that states should have the right to regulate hemp production.

HEADLINE: A Pregnant Candidate Discovers She's an Issue

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, May 12

 BODY:
As she ordered a morning latte in Boston's Faneuil Hall Marketplace today, Jane Swift made a point of making the point that it was only a decaf.
"For some people, I can't do anything right these days," she said, only half-joking. 
 Ms. Swift is running to be the lieutenant governor of Massachusetts. She is also 17 weeks pregnant.
That makes her the first expectant mother to run for statewide office in Massachusetts. And -- to her outraged surprise -- the focus of a swirl of local debate about pregnant women in politics and in the workplace.
Experts on women in politics say Ms. Swift, 33, is not the very first statewide candidate in the country to alternate stumping from a podium with racing against morning sickness to the ladies' room. Judi Dutcher was pregnant when she was elected Minnesota's state auditor in 1994. And that is not to mention Federal officeholders who became pregnant as incumbents, like former Representatives Susan Molinari of Staten Island and Blanche Lambert Lincoln of Arkansas.
But judging by the fuss created over Ms. Swift's condition since she announced it two weeks ago, she is still breaking very new ground, says Ms. Swift, a Republican who is the running mate of A. Paul Cellucci, the state's acting Governor, and faces a possibly tough primary in September.
"I knew it would be a story," she said. "I knew people would be interested. I did not expect we would be getting involved in a debate as to whether or not women should work when they have children."
Then she observed: "Even if we're going to focus on the pregnancy, I wish we could shift the debate to about, 'What, then, do Jane Swift and Paul Cellucci think they can do on day care and creating more opportunities for flextime and meaningful part-time work?' But we really haven't gotten there yet."
Instead, attention has been focused on the very fact that Ms. Swift is due to give birth just two weeks before the November election.
"It's generated a lot of controversy," said Elizabeth A. Sherman, director of the Center for Women in Politics and Public Policy at the McCormack Institute of the University of Massachusetts at Boston.
"On the one hand, a lot of people have been saying, 'This is great, it's as it should be; of course, we have more and more women candidates, naturally we'll inevitably have a woman who's pregnant.' On the other hand, there's been a backlash by the more religious and traditional organizations who've said, 'This is wrong, she shouldn't be doing this.' "
Evelyn Reilly, executive director of the Christian Coalition of Massachusetts, said on Wednesday that she was not telling Ms. Swift how to live, but on hearing the news: "My first reaction was, 'Thank God she's not having an abortion,' and my second reaction is, 'I hope she'll have enough time to spend with the child.' This is a good opportunity for us to discuss the broader issue, which is, does institutional day care compare with a parent caring for the child in the home?"
But the backlash against the backlash began immediately as well.
"I'm so angry, I'm shaking," a Boston Herald reader wrote today, condemning a local conservative women's group leader for daring to "talk about what is in the best interest for someone else's child."
In hard-core political circles, meanwhile, talk has centered on more pragmatic speculation about what a pregnancy does for a ticket. And there, too, is some debate.
One camp includes the likes of Kevin Sowyrda, a Republican political analyst and friend of Ms. Swift, who calls her pregnancy "a political advertiser's dream come true."
Ms. Swift's condition means that if she wins the primary, Democratic opponents will have a harder time portraying the Republican ticket as anti-women or anti-children, Mr. Sowyrda said, and will probably need to treat Ms. Swift gently in debates. "Do you really want to be the candidate who beats up on an eight-month-pregnant woman?" he asked.
The other camp argues that pregnant politicians should be treated like any other politicians, and proceeds to point out that Ms. Swift's candidacy is not exactly immaculate. Although her opponents in the primary have assiduously avoided criticizing her pregnancy, she has drawn fire for adjusting her positions on the death penalty and an assault weapons ban to conform to Mr. Cellucci's tougher stances, as well as for taking large -- though legal -- tax deductions when she was a legislator. Some critics also say she is too young for the job.
In a way, Ms. Swift's youth is the point in all of this. She was the youngest woman ever to serve in the Massachusetts Senate, which she did for six years beginning at the age of 25; and in her current young ambition, students of women in politics say, she represents the new generation who get involved in politics much earlier than the last generation -- and who are thus likelier to get pregnant. Ms. Sherman of the McCormack Institute noted that Massachusetts women on average get into politics 10 years later than men.
Politics is not a field in which it is easy to stop for a few years and have children, then pick right up again, said Debbie Walsh, acting director of the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University. So the desire to have a family, along with exclusion by old-boy political machines, were the main factors keeping women's political involvement low in the past, she said.
Women hold just 25 percent of statewide elective offices nationwide, Ms. Walsh said, but their presence in high-level politics has been expanding noticeably. Even in Massachusetts, which has elected only one woman to a statewide office -- a lieutenant governor in 1986 -- this season is looking up: at least six women are running statewide races this year, more than ever before.
Ms. Dutcher, the Minnesota state auditor, said that toward the end of her campaign, when her pregnancy started showing, "I made it part of my speech -- that I'm not only sensitive to financial issues, I'm sensitive to family issues, obviously."
She accepted with aplomb a comparison to Marge Gunderson, the very pregnant small-town sheriff in the movie "Fargo," and cheerily recalled retching in parking lots before popping a breath mint and entering meetings of potential supporters.
But neither Ms. Dutcher, who found out the day after she announced her candidacy that she was pregnant, nor Ms. Swift makes light of their very personal decisions to continue their campaigns.
Ms. Swift, a moderate Republican who supports gay and abortion rights and plans to emphasize education and economic development in her campaign, had waited four years for a positive pregnancy test, she said, and was thrilled when it came.
"Then reality set in," she said.
Not only of morning sickness, but of the starkness of the choice she faced as a less-than-famous former legislator from remote North Adams, Mass.
"Jane Swift, who lives in the far western corner of the state, is not going to get the opportunity to run with a very popular sitting governor on a ticket a lot of times, and maybe never again," she said. "And that was really the choice. It wasn't, 'Do you do this now or not do this now?' My husband and I looked at it as, 'Do you ever do this?' The one thing I want people to understand is that it was not a decision we made lightly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jane Swift, who is running for lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, says she is outraged that her pregnancy has eclipsed important issues. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ever a Pragmatist, Microsoft Compromises

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Microsoft's last-minute gesture toward the Justice Department, a new-found taste for compromise in the hopes of avoiding a major antitrust suit, speaks volumes about the company.
It may have a take-no-prisoners corporate culture and an antagonism toward Washington but, as any accomplished capitalist, the Microsoft Corporation is ultimately guided by the pure logic of business. 
 "Microsoft is extremely tough-minded and willing to act on the edge of brinkmanship, but pragmatic at its core," David B. Yoffie, a Harvard Business School professor, said.
Clearly, William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, and his lieutenants have decided that some of the concessions the Government is seeking can be made without posing a real threat to the company's remarkably lucrative business.
On-and-off talks between Microsoft and the Government have taken place over the last several weeks. But it was only in the last day or so that the company showed a willingness to negotiate in earnest with the Justice Department over concerns about anticompetitive practices raised by the Government and several state attorneys general.
The Justice Department canceled a noon news conference yesterday when it had been expected to announce that the Federal Government and several states were filing antitrust suits against Microsoft. The fact that both sides had begun an effort to reach a settlement without going to court should not be interpreted as a sign that an accord will in fact be reached, a person involved with the talks said.
Microsoft's strategy of fiercely resisting an accommodation with the Government and then finally coming to the negotiating table is precisely the approach the company took when it reached an earlier settlement with the Justice Department -- a consent decree signed in 1994 and approved by a Federal court the following year.
"It was unmistakably clear to Microsoft then, just as it is now, that if we didn't get a resolution, we'd sue them," recalled Robert Litan, then a senior Justice Department official who worked on the consent decree.
That round of discussions began with a meeting on June 21, 1994, in the main conference room of the Justice Department's antitrust division, attended by Mr. Litan and others.
Three weeks later, the Government and Microsoft signed a consent decree. It prohibited Microsoft from striking certain deals with personal computer makers for licensing the company's Windows operating system software that were determined to be anticompetitive. But the accord had little effect on Microsoft's business, and more than 90 percent of personal computers sold today are loaded with Windows.
"This time, the stakes are much higher," said Mr. Litan, who is now director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. "Now, the battle is over who owns the keys to the Internet and not just the operating system."
The Justice Department wants to insure that Microsoft is curbed from using its Windows monopoly unfairly both to maintain that monopoly and to gain an unfair advantage in the emerging markets of Internet commerce and software.
Specifically, the Government wants to protect competition in the market for Internet browsers, the software required to view World Wide Web sites. It also wants to restrict Microsoft's freedom to use its control of the computer desktop -- the main Windows screen that personal computer users see -- to steer consumers toward Internet shopping and entertainment sites owned by Microsoft or its favored business partners.
Microsoft's position has been that it should be free to put anything it wants in its operating system, and that any curbs on that freedom constitute a threat to innovation in the software industry. Giving Government a role, however well intended, would mean "the Justice Department or the courts would become economic regulators who fine-tune product decisions," said Charles F. Rule, a former head of the Justice Department's antitrust division who is a consultant to Microsoft.
Still, the company is now apparently willing to agree to some restrictions, probably in a new consent decree, if those concessions will persuade the Government not to intervene further. Yet it is the details of any proposed remedies that will be crucial in determining whether there will be a settlement, and what effect, if any, such a settlement might have in the marketplace.
Take the case of the browser. The Government wants to leave the door open for competition in the browser market, where Microsoft's main rival is the Netscape Communications Corporation.
Microsoft insists that its browser, the Internet Explorer, is not a separate product, as Washington contends, but an inseparable feature of the Windows operating system -- especially in Windows 98, its next-generation product. Microsoft thus requires personal computer makers to load Explorer as a condition of licensing Windows.
To encourage browser competition, the Government could order that Microsoft unbundle its browser from Windows, enabling PC makers to load Netscape's Navigator browser, if they choose. But Microsoft charges nothing extra for the browser, so there is no incentive for PC makers to take the unbundled version of Windows.
To insure competition, though, the Government must go further, according to Robert H. Bork, a former Federal judge who is a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. One step, he says, would be to insist that Microsoft load another browser, like Netscape's Navigator, on Windows along with Explorer in a "must carry" order.
"Any remedy that does not let the consumer make the ultimate choice will not be effective because of Microsoft's enormous power, often coercive power, in the computer industry," said Mr. Bork, who is also a consultant to Netscape.
But a Government must-carry order for the browser could set a troubling precedent, Mr. Litan of Brookings said. "If you do that for the browser, do you do the same for other software innovations in the future? It's a really tough issue," he said.

HEADLINE: MICROSOFT SEEKS ACCORD WITH U.S. AND DODGES SUIT

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Less than an hour before state and Federal governments were set to file sweeping antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation, the company announced today that it would postpone the release of its new operating system, Windows 98, for three days so that settlement talks could proceed.
The Justice Department had scheduled a noon news conference to announce its new suit, and attorneys general from several of the 20 states that were going to file a joint action had flown to Washington to stand with Janet Reno, the United States Attorney General, for the announcement. Politicians' statements had been drafted, and press releases had been printed. 
 It was only then that Microsoft, demonstrating the steel-nerve brinkmanship that has marked its negotiating strategy and spurred its growth over the years, called a cease-fire. Page D1.
As lawyers waited at the court house with the filings in hand, Microsoft offered significant new concessions in its marketing practices, and both sides immediately took steps to allow the talks to continue.
The Justice Department and states agreed to delay their filings, and Microsoft announced that although "all work on Windows 98 has been completed," initial shipments to computer manufacturers, scheduled to begin on Friday, would be delayed until Monday. Plans to begin selling the new operating system in stores on June 25 have not changed, the company said.
Microsoft and Justice Department lawyers had actually been talking for the last week, but as has often been the case in the battle over Microsoft's business practices, the two sides offered drastically different views of those talks.
Mark Murray, a Microsoft spokesman, said that many of the concessions offered today had been offered before. But a senior Government official said Microsoft had been unwilling to make significant concessions until the last moments, when lawyers for the two sides spoke by phone.
Shares of Microsoft closed up $2 today, to $88.9375, in heavy trading.
Officials and executives involved with the talks said that Microsoft had suggested a general willingness to modify or abandon several of its marketing and presentation arrangements that prosecutors find objectionable. The company might, for example, drop demands that computer manufacturers feature Microsoft products to the exclusion of competitors' products. It might also modify the terms under which its programs must be displayed.
But, these people said, the company remains steadfast in its refusal to modify the programs -- or to stop adding features to its operating system. Most notably, it insists that its Internet Explorer, the browser software that enables users to view the Internet's World Wide Web, is an essential part of Windows.
The lawsuit prepared by the states -- similar in style and scope to the proposed Federal suit, several officials said -- would have attacked a broad range of Microsoft's business practices.
Among its points, the suit would challenge what it calls "tying," a practice that in recent years allowed Microsoft to dominate the markets for word processing, spreadsheet and other programs by bundling them in software "suites." It would also block the company from forcing manufacturers to incorporate certain features on the Windows main screen, or desktop, when the computer is first turned on.
On these points, Microsoft has suggested some flexibility.
But the suit would also seek to block Microsoft from including WebTV for Windows, its electronic program guide for television and Web sites, and Outlook Express, its E-mail program, with Windows 98.
What is more, it would ask the court to require Microsoft to allow manufacturers to replace the Internet Explorer browser with another browser when installing Windows 98. On these points, Microsoft is unlikely to give in. In fact, Microsoft insists that Internet Explorer is so deeply embedded in Windows 98 that it would be impossible to separate it without completely redesigning the program
Still, Dan Lungren, the Attorney General of California, called this "a moment of encouragement."
"I don't view the prospect of litigation as always a good thing," Mr. Lungren said. "I would hope that we can work things out."
Scott Harshbarger, the Attorney General of Massachusetts, a leader of the group, said that the states were trying to resolve "serious concerns on behalf of consumers and other members of the software industry."
Supporters and opponents of Microsoft in Congress offered opposing views of today's events. Senator Orrin Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said, "The fact that Microsoft is negotiating with the Justice Department and apparently is prepared to make substantial concessions certainly undermines any argument that Justice has no case." Delaying the release of Windows 98, he added, "undermines its prior rhetoric that any such delay would have dramatic consequences for the industry."
But Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat from Washington, where Microsoft has its headquarters in the Seattle suburb of Redmond, said: "I remain concerned that a further delay in the release of Windows 98 will impact our nation's economy. Ultimately the marketplace and its consumers should determine what innovations they want included in software, not the Government."
Mal Ransom, senior vice president for marketing for Packard Bell NEC, the computer maker, said, "We believe any further delays in delivering Windows 98 may cause disruption and confusion for our consumers."
Talks over a proposed settlement are scheduled to begin in Washington on Friday. At the table will be three Justice Department lawyers, three representatives of the state attorneys general and the Microsoft team. Assistant attorneys general from New York, Texas and Wisconsin will represent the states. Tom Miller, the Attorney General of Iowa and the chairman of the Antitrust Task Force for the National Association of Attorneys General, will also be present though not an official member of the negotiating team.
The number of states prepared to file suit has grown to 20. They are California, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, South Carolina, Utah, West Virginia and Wisconsin, plus the District of Columbia.
Both state and Federal officials stressed that their suits could still be filed if the parties did not reach agreement, and both sides predicted that no conclusion would be reached by the Monday deadline.

HEADLINE: Sunset for President Suharto

 BODY:
There are no magical answers to the political and economic troubles engulfing Indonesia. A lethal combination of corruption, irresponsible economic management and autocratic leadership has brought the world's fourth-most-populous nation to the brink of chaos. But it is now clear that recovery cannot begin as long as President Suharto remains in power.
Like the Shah of Iran two decades ago, and Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines in 1986, Mr. Suharto faces a popular rebellion and can retain power only through the use of military force against his countrymen. Eventually, even the army may turn against him to end the bloodshed. He can spare Indonesia further turmoil by yielding office to a government that quickly sets a date for free and fair elections. 
 Little about President Suharto's 32-year rule would suggest he will act with compassion or in the public interest. Since Indonesia's economic meltdown began last year, he has moved primarily to protect his family's financial interests and to preserve his own power. There was no reservoir of public support to carry him through the price rises produced by the collapse of the currency and the end of expensive subsidies -- a reform demanded by the International Monetary Fund as the price of its bailout. Indonesians are particularly angry because Mr. Suharto has not been as willing to close insolvent banks controlled by his family and business partners.
The only way for Indonesia to make needed reforms is to carry them out under a new government made up of trusted leaders. In South Korea a newly elected President, Kim Dae Jung, has persuaded citizens to accept measures that his predecessor could not. Mr. Suharto's suffocating rule has stunted Indonesian politics and left the country without seasoned opposition leaders. There is a danger that one of his obedient associates will try to hold power if Mr. Suharto steps aside or that the army will try to run the country. The best way to avoid that is to move swiftly to elections.
The military should refuse to repress peaceful protests and turn its attention to stopping looting and mob violence, offering special protection to Chinese shopkeepers, who are a common scapegoat in troubled times. Some army units mingled peacefully with protesters in Jakarta yesterday, a sign that they might resist further orders to shoot demonstrators. The United States, for its part, should immediately end all military training for Indonesian soldiers and freeze all transfers of weapons.
President Clinton has dispatched several delegations to Jakarta in recent months to press Mr. Suharto to reform. The only message left to send is to urge Mr. Suharto to resign and to tell his successors the hour for democracy in Indonesia has come.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE POLICY;
As Strife Grips Indonesia, U.S. Asks Citizens to Leave and Delays Aid Payment

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The United States today urged most of the nearly 11,000 Americans living in Indonesia to leave the country immediately, citing the worst political violence there in more than three decades.
The warning to American residents of Indonesia's two largest cities -- Jakarta and Surabaya, which are home to about 6,000 Americans -- was one of several moves announced by the Clinton Administration to deal with the fast-deteriorating situation in Indonesia, where thousands of people have taken to the streets in protest against the 32-year rule of President Suharto. 
 The Administration also today joined European nations in delaying a $1.4 billion emergency aid payment and ordered the evacuation of all nonessential employees of the United States Embassy in Jakarta, the Indonesia capital and the scene of the worst violence this week. It also called off a planned mission to Indonesia by a high-ranking American military delegation.
Violent demonstrations have also been reported in recent weeks in Surabaya, which like Jakarta is on the central Indonesian island of Java.
In its warning to Americans living in Jakarta and Surabaya, the State Department said that they "should depart the country as soon as possible" given that "widespread protests have increasingly been accompanied by violent confrontations with security forces."
"Live ammunition has been fired at protesters, and several deaths have occurred," the department statement said. "American citizens in other parts of Indonesia may also wish to consider departure at this time. In the meantime, American citizens should avoid large crowds and demonstrations."
If Americans in the two cities follow the State Department's guidance, it will amount to one of the largest evacuations of American citizens from a foreign nation in recent years.
Today's moves by the Clinton Administration reflected a view now widely held within the United States Government that President Suharto's rule over the world's fourth most populous nation may be coming to a quick, violent end.
The $1.4 billion payment was supposed to be approved today, the latest installment in a $43 billion Western-led rescue package for Indonesia. But European nations urged a delay in the payment by the Asian Development Bank. The United States agreed, despite promises earlier this week that the Western aid package for Indonesia would not be affected by the rioting in Jakarta.
The objective of the aid package was to restore the confidence of the markets and bring investors back into the country. Now, many in Washington are arguing that there is little use in continuing to pump money into an economy that was nearing collapse because of the growing political turmoil.
Clinton Administration officials said the visit to Jakarta by the military delegation led by Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, the commander of all American military forces in the Pacific, was called off at virtually the last minute when it became clear that the roads into Jakarta from the international airport were so insecure that the admiral could not travel on the ground in safety.
"Given the deterioration today in the situation in Jakarta, including the fact that the road to the airport is closed, there was a literal question of getting into the country and then the question of who do you meet with when you get there," said Stanley O. Roth, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.
Officials said that Admiral Prueher, the commander in chief of the United States Pacific Command in Honolulu, had been scheduled to meet with his counterparts in the Indonesian military to demand that they end the use of violence against anti-Government demonstrators. More than two dozen people, most of them civilians, have been reported killed in the rioting this week.
In testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Roth said that the State Department had begun planning for the evacuation of American citizens from Indonesia.
"Given that the situation in Jakarta has become very dicey, with a lot of rioting, we can't guarantee the security of American citizens there, and neither can the Indonesian authorities," he said. "This is not panic, but we all take very seriously our obligations to protect American lives."
The State Department said that it had ordered all "nonessential" employees of the United States Embassy to leave the country immediately and warned American citizens not to travel there.
