HEADLINE: Capitalistic Sideline Drives China's Army

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 15

 BODY:
The Chinese Army, a colossus of three million soldiers, is a sprawling organization that controls or owns parts of a vast array of businesses, from arms dealers to airlines, pharmaceutical makers to vegetable growers.
Of all the military forces in the world, the Chinese Army is by far the most entrepreneurial. Its businesses earn billions of dollars each year, though they are so numerous and disparate -- their role often kept secret -- that no one inside or outside of China can accurately estimate their full scope. 
 Although China's military often looks like a stern-faced monolith, the army's role in moneymaking is clearly not part of any central government plan, experts say. Rather, army officers often take broad advantage of their leading positions in China's political apparatus to build lucrative operations.
"At the end of the day, this is an army that is more interested in making money than it is in being the guardian of the national interest," says Jonathan D. Pollack, a specialist on the Chinese military at the Rand Corporation, the research organization in Santa Monica, Calif.
Liu Chaoying, a lieutenant colonel who has been accused of making contributions through middlemen to the Democratic National Committee in 1996, is a senior executive at one such operation, China Aerospace International Holdings.
China Aerospace, incorporated in Hong Kong and listed on the stock exchange here, develops satellite technology, launches commercial satellites and manufactures a range of mechanical and electronic equipment, including television sets and telephones. It is a subsidiary of the China Aerospace Corporation, a state-owned corporation in Beijing.
Colonel Liu is one of innumerable high-ranking army officers who devote their time to business. Yet she is a member of Beijing's "princeling" elite -- the sons and daughters of China's most powerful leaders -- many of whom are hired by companies in order to trade on their personal connections, which can be critical in conducting business in China.
Colonel Liu is the daughter of Gen. Liu Huaqing, who was one of the top five men in the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, and vice chairman of the all-powerful Central Military Commission until he retired last year.
The upper ranks of the army companies are full of the relatives of senior officials. A son-in-law of the late leader Deng Xiaoping, He Ping, for years headed a major arms company, the China North Industries Group, which sold armored vehicles, infantry weapons, ammunition and radar.
Yet army-controlled businesses are not limited to military-related businesses. They include countless electronics companies, a commercial airline run by the air force, a movie studio that produces feature films, and crews of fruit and vegetable growers.
Military commanders have opened coal mines, karaoke bars and massage parlors. In many parts of China, they dominate real-estate development, building luxury housing complexes, hotels and office towers. In general, there seems to be virtually no area of moneymaking that military forces are kept from.
The pirating of American movies, music and software in China, investigators have often complained, is particularly hard to control because so many of the culprits have been military-owned or controlled companies, which can easily deflect prosecution.
The army's business operations spread so far that it sometimes seems almost humorous. In 1996, Gen. Chen Tianlin, chief of the Guangzhou Military Region's general logistics department, bragged in an army newspaper that every regiment, every brigade and every company under his command, in addition to their military duties, was setting up "production bases" to raise vegetables, fish, pigs and chickens.
General Chen said an artillery brigade sold 10,000 pigs last year for a profit of more than $40,000; and during the first eight months of this year, a military base on Hainan Island made $36,000 selling chicken feed and eggs from its chicken farm.
Those are small amounts of money, compared with arms sales, for example. But General Chen's comments underscored how widespread and entrenched business operations are in the military.
Aware that moneymaking has thoroughly infiltrated the army, the Communist Party's leaders have made feeble attempts to limit it, at one point ordering that military units below the group army level should keep out of business. But it is difficult to enforce.
It is even more difficult to gauge exactly how much its preoccupation with business undercuts the Chinese military's ability as a fighting force. International experts point to many glaring weaknesses in China's military readiness. With few exceptions, experts say, China's armed forces are poorly equipped and trained, and would be easily defeated in any encounter with modern forces outside the mainland.
Yet without an immediate threat to their borders, China's military leaders seem content to keep the troops focused on what is clearly the more pressing concern: how to keep making more money.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: IN PAKISTAN;
No Decision On Testing, U.S. Is Told

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 15

 BODY:
Pakistani leaders told a high-level American delegation today that they had not yet decided whether to test nuclear weapons, as India did this week, and suggested that they might still be dissuaded.
The delegation, which was led by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and Gen. Anthony Zinni, the chief Pentagon officer responsible for South Asia, met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and other officials. Mr. Talbott is to fly to Birmingham, England, on Saturday to brief President Clinton, who is attending a summit meeting there. At that meeting, the leaders issued a statement condemning India's nuclear tests, but did not go beyond that. 
 As the delegation was beginning its meetings here, Mr. Clinton said in Birmingham that he hoped to find a formula within which Pakistani leaders "will find it possible, politically possible, not to proceed" with nuclear tests. He said such a decision would be "an act of great statesmanship on their part."
Soon afterward, Prime Minister Sharif told reporters in Islamabad: "We are in no haste to test the bomb after India tested the bomb. I think we are a responsible nation."
American officials said after their meetings here that Pakistani leaders were facing the fateful decision with "a sense of anguish."
"We have not heard anything that says that the Pakistani leadership has rushed to a conclusion, not to mention a conclusion we would regret, with respect to what its next steps will be," an official said. "They want to see a continuing improvement in U.S.-Pakistani relations in a number of areas, but there was absolutely no sense in our conversations today of a wish list on their side in exchange for which they would not test."
"One of the concerns they have is that this will be just a temporary issue and that it will soon be back to business as usual with India," the official said. "They want the United States and the international community to take what they see as the Indian threat as seriously as they do."
In Washington, James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said: "We're very aware of the political pressure that exists in Pakistan. But we hope that as a result of this mission, that the Government there analyzes the situation and concludes that not going forward with the testing program will redound to the advantage of Pakistan and testing will not."
Although Pakistani leaders did not say precisely what gestures would persuade them to decide against testing, American officials said the Pakistanis hoped for a lifting of American restrictions on military aid as well as diplomatic support in their disputes with India over Kashmir state and other issues.
An editorial today in The Nation, an Islamabad newspaper with Government connections, suggested that foreign powers should offer a write-off or reduction of Pakistan's debt obligations, a pledge of greater economic support and what they called "cast-iron nuclear-umbrella guarantees against the Indian threat," a demand that remained vague.
R. James Woolsey Jr., a former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate hearing this week that the campaign to persuade Pakistan not to test "is considerably less likely to succeed than not, but it's worth a good college try." Diplomats and political experts agreed that it will be difficult for Pakistan to refrain from conducting nuclear tests in the near future.
Zafar Iqbal Cheema, the influential chairman of the department of defense and strategic studies at Quaid-e-Azim University in Islamabad, said: "The Government must immediately work out a plan for a credible response, which should include testing a fission nuclear device, a thermonuclear device and a sub-kiloton test. If Pakistan prolongs its response, this would create suspicion about its nuclear capability."
At a meeting of the Pakistani Cabinet on Thursday, sentiment was reportedly in favor of a quick test. Pakistani newspapers said, however, that the Minister of Finance, Sartaj Aziz, had warned about the devastating effect of international sanctions that would certainly follow a test, and urged, "Let's wait and see."
Some Pakistani business leaders are also lobbying against a quick nuclear test, warning that resulting sanctions could devastate the economy. This week Pakistan presented international donors with a list of development projects it would like to finance in the coming year, at a cost of $1.69 billion. Nearly all of them would have to be scrapped if Pakistan were punished with sanctions like those imposed on India.
Other sanctions might include a possible cutoff of World Bank aid, which totaled $858 million in the last fiscal year, and aid from Japan, which was $550 million last year.

HEADLINE: Sold China 'Spirit Tree' May Have Been Stolen

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 15

 BODY:
Chinese officials charged with protecting relics are investigating the possibility that a spectacular ancient bronze candelabra recently sold in New York for a reported $2.5 million may have been illegally unearthed last year in south-central China and smuggled out of the country.
Last fall stories began circulating among Chinese archeologists and officials that a rare bronze funerary candelabra, known as a spirit tree, had been secretly unearthed from a tomb along the Yangtze River, in the region to be inundated by the Three Gorges Dam, and sold to a smuggler. The theft was never verified, although officials acknowledge that looting of artifacts in the dam area and nearby construction sites is a problem. 
 In late March a spirit tree, four feet high with dozens of branches and a blue patina, was offered for sale at the International Asian Art Fair, held at the Seventh Regiment Armory in New York City. It was sold to Leon D. Black, a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, for at least $2.5 million. Mr. Black is the founder and president of Apollo Advisers, a New York investment firm that owns stakes in many corporations, including Vail Resorts in Colorado; Samsonite, the luggage maker; Converse, the shoe manufacturer, and Telemundo, the Spanish-language television network.
Only two other intact spirit trees have been described in professional literature, according to Elizabeth Childs-Johnson, an art historian at New York University and expert on archeology in the region of the dam, in Sichuan and Hubei Provinces. Like the other examples, it almost certainly originated in the Three Gorges region, she said, and dates from the Eastern Han dynasty, of the first to third centuries A.D.
The possibility that the item sold in New York had recently been smuggled out of China has been publicized by international opponents of the Three Gorges Dam. In a press release on Thursday, the California-based International Rivers Network cited as evidence an Oct. 7, 1997, article in a Chinese newspaper, Southern Weekend.
That article quoted Yao Jiong, head of the Cultural Relics Unit in Fengjie County, Sichuan, as saying that an intact spirit tree had been unearthed and sold on the black market for about $25,000.
But Mr. Yao, in a telephone interview today, said only that he had heard rumors that a spirit tree had been found in neighboring Wushan County and sold illegally. Government regulations, only spottily enforced, forbid export of older and significant artifacts.
Yu Weichao, the Beijing-based director of the Government's program to protect cultural relics in the Three Gorges area, is in the region investigating the charges.
Reached by telephone in the town of Zongxian, Mr. Yu said he had heard stories of a smuggled spirit tree last fall, and, after becoming aware of the sale in New York, decided to pursue the matter with local officials. Until recently Mr. Yu was also director of the National Museum of Chinese History in Beijing.
The sale in New York was arranged by a Belgian art dealer, Giselle Croes. Ms. Croes's office said today that she was traveling and could not be reached.
A spokesman for Mr. Black, Steven Anreder, said today that according to Mr. Black the seller was a reputable Hong Kong dealer and that the item came with all the proper papers. No one has suggested that Mr. Black did anything illegal or improper in buying the object in New York.
Mr. Black came into public view in the 1980's as co-head of corporate finance at Drexel Burnham Lambert, the defunct Wall Street firm that was dominated by Michael R. Milken, the junk-bond king. Now, besides his investment activities, Mr. Black is a well-known collector of Chinese bronzes and works by such 19th- and 20th-century European masters as Picasso, Cezanne, Degas and Bonnard. He also sits on the board of the Jewish Museum and the Mount Sinai Hospital, and recently endowed a Shakespeare Studies chair at Dartmouth College, his alma mater.
His firm is said to be considering bids for Polygram, the record company, and Simon & Schuster.
The narrow canyons above the Three Gorges Dam are sprinkled with subsurface and standing tombs, temples and other historical sites. Chinese historians have openly lamented the shortage of money and time to assess what will be lost when the dam is closed and waters start rising five years from now. They warn that a crucial, little-studied aspect of early Chinese history as well as the entire record of at least one ancient culture will be lost forever.
Another problem has emerged just above the future water line, where bulldozers are erecting new towns for the displaced populations and have little time for "salvage archeology." What the machines do not destroy is taken by local people for sale to antique dealers.
Since the dam construction began in 1992, according to an article last January in the Three Gorges Public Security Newspaper, "antique traders converged on Wushan from different parts of the country and from Southeast Asia," and local looters shifted from trailing bulldozers to actively prospecting for artifacts. In May 1997 the police in Wushan County formed a special task force to deal with looting and smuggling, some by organized gangs.
Reached by telephone today, Luo Zhihong, Director of Cultural Relics for Wushan County, said that because of the lack of resources, "a lot of relics have been sold to private dealers." He said his entire 1997 budget for protection was only about $3,600, while he had to offer that amount to entice local farmers to turn in even a single valuable relic they found.

HEADLINE: Hoboken to Hollywood and Beyond, Mourning the Man and His Magic

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
From Hollywood to the back streets of Hoboken, from seats of power in Europe and America to gritty barrooms where the old romantic ballads still intoxicate the soul, they mourned Frank Sinatra yesterday, not only as one of a century's most influential singers but as someone who had touched them intimately with a voice, a mood, a poignant memory.
There was an avalanche of remembrance and tribute to go with the sorrow. It came from presidents, prime ministers, fellow entertainers, personal friends and countless ordinary people who recalled the Sinatra magic: crooning at the Dorsey microphone or the Paramount for swooning bobby-soxers, drinking alone in the wee small hours, going down under Fatso's blows in a cell in Honolulu. 
 "The world has now lost one of the most precious commodities," the actor Ernest Borgnine, whose Sergeant Fatso Judson battered Sinatra's Oscar-winning Maggio to death in the 1953 film "From Here to Eternity," said of his old friend. "It's pretty hard because, you know, we loved each other. The world has lost a hell of a man."
Across the nation and halfway around the world, word that the 82-year-old vocalist had died of a heart attack on Thursday night in Los Angeles prompted an outpouring of headlines, news broadcasts, musical tributes and countless personal expressions of grief and admiration for the man and his music.
Fans placed flowers and lighted candles on his three stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Purple bunting was draped from City Hall in Sinatra's New Jersey hometown, Hoboken. New York's tabloid newspapers issued rare extra editions. A flood of specials were broadcast on television. Radio stations everywhere devoted hours to the Sinatra repertory. And a black-bordered Web page appeared in cyberspace.
In Birmingham, England, where he was attending an economic summit meeting, President Clinton described himself as an "enormous admirer" of Sinatra's and said, "I think every American would have to smile and say he really did do it his way."
The British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, also attending the meeting, called Sinatra "one of the greatest performers of this century," and added, "People like me of a younger generation have grown up with him, and he will be deeply missed."
In Paris, the President Jacques Chirac, said that millions around the world were saddened by Sinatra's death. "There was certainly his talent, his charisma and his voice -- which set the rhythm for, accompanied and made our whole era dream -- but there was also his warm and enthusiastic personality," he said.
The director Martin Scorsese, attending the Cannes Film Festival, said: "He was an idol of mine and millions. A great Italian-American, a great American, and a great actor, by the way, a great, great actor." The actress Jeanne Moreau, also at Cannes, said Sinatra would "sing with the angels."
In Italy, where Sinatra's parents were born, television stations flashed bulletins across the screens, the state RAI broadcasting network showed Sinatra specials and led news programs with announcements of his death. Paparazzi, with whom Sinatra had endless feuds, recalled him as a glamorous, temperamental figure on the glitzy Via Veneto during the era of La Dolce Vita.
In Lumarzo, a town near Genoa where Sinatra's mother, Natalie Garavente, was born, Mayor Silvio Lercari spoke of "the pain of thousands," and said: "This is a sad day. We've lost a person who is famous the world over." Sinatra's father, Antonio, was a fireman and amateur boxer from Sicily.
In Hoboken, where Sinatra was born in 1915, his presence seemed to be everywhere yesterday, although he had shunned the town for more than a decade because some residents had spoken to the writer Kitty Kelley for her 1986 unauthorized biography of Sinatra, "His Way."
Besides Sinatra street signs, Sinatra plaques and a Sinatra museum, there were bouquets yesterday at the rubble that had been the Sinatra birthplace. Nearby, vendors offered Sinatra T-shirts. But Piccolo's Clam Bar, which usually plays nothing but Sinatra records, was silent. "The Voice is silent, so there won't be any music today," said Pat Spaccavento, the owner.
Across the Hudson in New York, where television and radio stations aired the news and music of Sinatra, one announcer spoke of "Heartbreak in Hoboken," and a forecaster, gloating over a sundrenched day, said: "Skies are clear, except for the small black cloud over Hoboken."
Nonchalant New Yorkers, who ordinarily regard visits from Presidents and potentates as little more than traffic obstacles, were overheard on streets and in elevators and offices talking about Sinatra. The town learned of his death in big tabloid headlines and radio and televison news programs laced with Sinatra music.
"Extra! Extra!" The New York Post blared in red, and hit the streets with an early-morning edition -- its first since the O. J. Simpson verdict in 1995 -- with the news: "Death of a Legend." The Daily News announced "Sinatra Dead" on Page One, and mustered a 24-page Sinatra supplement in its first extra edition since the 1991 Persian Gulf War.
Institutions as well as people expressed a sense of loss. The Friars Club mourned its "beloved Abbot Emeritus Frank Sinatra," and compared him to Jack Benny, George Burns, Enrico Caruso and George M. Cohan. Other tributes, reflecting Sinatra's wide philanthropy, came from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Carnegie Hall and the American Friends of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
Gore Vidal, the writer, offered a social commentary on Sinatra and America: "I would say that half the population of the United States over the age of 40 was conceived while their parents were listening to his records. He played a great romantic role in the country. Most singers are pretty bland, mellifluous. Bing Crosby put you to sleep. Sinatra got the blood flowing."
Some, as might be expected, perceived in Sinatra's death a renewal of the commercial engine he had fired for decades: record companies and retailers foresaw a bonanza in album sales, as did publishers of books on Sinatra and those in possession of Sinatra memorabilia: autographs, photographs, concert and movie posters.
At the other end of the spectrum, many of the most touching tributes came from entertainers who had been close to Sinatra. Mel Torme, the jazz singer, spoke of the "ultimate balladeer," and what he called an "everyman, a singer whose style touched a chord in the broadest part of the American psyche."
Vic Damone said: "He was my role model, my mentor, and most importantly, my friend. There will never be another Francis Albert Sinatra. Nobody will ever come close."
The singer Eydie Gorme and her husband and singing partner Steve Lawrence, longtime friends of Sinatra, went to his Bel Air mansion to pay their respects to his family. Afterward, Ms. Gorme called it "the saddest day of my life."
Outside the Sinatra home, many fans gathered, including Brian McCray, 22, who was clad in black and held a candle. "He's my favorite," Mr. McCray said. "I've listened to him since I was 6 years old. I have every Frank Sinatra CD. I used to hide them so my friends wouldn't know, but now everyone in my generation seems to like Frank. I just had to come here."
Mia Farrow, who was Sinatra's third wife, said: "Frank was the first love of my life, and he remained a true friend, always there when I needed him. I will miss him more than words can say."
The comedian Steve Allen spoke of "a day when American lyrics were coherent and civilized and clever, and when there was a glorious melody characterizing most of our popular songs." "He was the No. 1 salesman," he added.
At the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach, where Sinatra wintered in the 1950's and 60's, Floyd McSwaine, a bellhop, remembered them all: Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr., Peter Lawford, Joey Bishop and Sinatra. "When he walked in the lobby, people would stand up and say, 'Hey, Frank,' " he said. "They were crazy about him. He could have been the President of the United States."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Although Sinatra had shunned his native Hoboken in recent years, children from the city's Brandt Intermediate School were eager to pay tribute yesterday at the rubble that remains of his birthplace. Jean Valentin wore a photograph yesterday that preserves her memory of meeting Sinatra in 1968 at Carnegie Hall. (He kissed her, she says.) (Photographs by John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Russia Resists I.M.F.'s Strategy for Reducing Budget Deficit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 15

 BODY:
Russia is at odds with the International Monetary Fund over the politically charged question of how to reduce the nation's huge budget deficit.
The dispute has emerged as a major challenge for Russia's new Prime Minister and comes at a sensitive time for the Russian economy. 
 On one side of the debate is the Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, who has embraced the same strategy Washington has used to attack its deficit: slash billions of dollars in spending without raising taxes.
I.M.F. officials, however, are skeptical about the Government's ability to make such deep cuts. Instead, they are urging Mr. Kiriyenko and his team to draft a politically unpalatable series of tax increases.
The debate has cast a shadow over the I.M.F.'s next infusion of money in its three-year, $10 billion Russian loan program. So far, the fund has disbursed $5.2 billion.
But the next $700 million installment has been delayed by the wrangling. An I.M.F. team is scheduled to renew negotiations here on Monday and top fund officials are expected to come to Moscow for talks summer.
Nervous foreign investors are anxiously following the deliberations. The Russian stock market has slumped in recent days because of a general concern over the strength of the nation's economy. The central bank's reserves for defending the ruble also have been shrinking.
The dispute not only underscores the monumental budgetary pressures confronting President Boris Yeltsin's new Government but also raises searching questions about the strategy of the I.M.F., which is already being scrutinized for its handling of the economic crisis in Asia.
Critics here say Russian taxes are already very high and there is no chance that the Communist-dominated Parliament would raise them. Also, Mr. Kiriyenko's position would be weakened if he proposed tax increases just as his new, pro-reform Government is trying to overhaul the nation's archaic tax system and get down to work.
Yegor T. Gaidar, a pro-capitalism reformer and former Prime Minister, said the I.M.F.'s position "is politically unrealistic and economically not very sensible."
Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary of the United States, indicated on Thursday that Washington had some sympathy for the Russian position, though he was careful not to publicly criticize the I.M.F.
"The current economic team is more cohesive and more united in its commitment to economic reform than any government Russia has had in the last five years," Mr. Summers said after meeting with Russian officials here. "I think there is large scope for expenditure reduction."
The I.M.F. and Russia have long had a rocky relationship. Economists say that the I.M.F. has helped Russia control its money supply and reduce inflation. But the fund has sometimes been wrong, as when it sought unsuccessfully to make the ruble a common currency for the former Soviet republics.
One critical matter on which the two sides agree is the need to reduce Russia's budget deficit. Finance Ministry officials estimate this year's deficit will be around 150 billion rubles (about $25 billion), or around 5 percent of Russia's gross domestic product.
Financing such a deficit has required Russia to issue high-yield treasury bonds and take out loans. The result is that about a third of the Government's spending is devoted to interest payments.
"If we cannot solve the problem of Government debt servicing within the next two to three years, it will be a major blow to the defense capabilities and economic security of the country," Mr. Kiriyenko told his Cabinet earlier this month.
Where the I.M.F. and the Yeltsin Government disagree is over how to attack the deficit. The I.M.F. wants a stronger crackdown on tax delinquents, in addition to budget cuts. The Russian Government puts more emphasis on spending reductions.
The fund says Russia should raise 315 billion rubles (about $52 billion) in tax revenue in 1998. But the Finance Ministry says Russia can expect to raise only about 290 billion rubles (about $48 billion). Those figures do not include money raised through non-tax sources, including the sale of gold and state property.
The difference between the two revenue targets is significant because it comes on top of other serious budgetary problems. Even if Russia met its revenue target, it still would have to cut Government programs.
In insisting on additional cuts, the Russian Finance Ministry is saying there are still enormous inefficiencies in the budget. The 1998 budget passed by Parliament this year is 493 billion rubles (about $82 billion). The Finance Ministry would like to reduce it to 432 billion rubles (about $72 billion).
To accomplish that, the Russians are considering laying off 200,000 Government workers, closing underutilized universities and cutting subsidies.
"We should have the right to decide what course we need," Oleg V. Vyugin, the Deputy Finance Minister, said in an interview. "It should not be the job of the I.M.F."
I.M.F. officials, however, doubt that the solution can be found in spending cuts alone. One big risk in relying on cuts, they maintain, is that Government agencies will agree to go along with the budget reductions but will avoid tough decisions, and instead delay payments to workers or let bills go unpaid rather than lay off employees or take other harsh measures. Wage arrears and postponed payments have been a chronic problem in the Russian economy.
The I.M.F has told Russian officials in confidential negotiations that it is wiser to make less severe spending cuts, allowing for a budget of about 467 billion rubles (about $78 billion), according to Russian participants in the negotiations.
The fund has argued that the Russians should draft an emergency package of tax increases to make up the difference if tougher tax collection does not raise additional revenue. Specifically, the I.M.F. says, the Russians should be prepared to increase the value-added tax, excise taxes on gasoline, and import tariffs.
But Mr. Gaidar said that increases in the value-added tax and excise taxes cannot be put into effect without the approval of the Parliament, or Duma, and would embroil Mr. Mr. Kiriyenko in a debilitating and ultimately unsuccessful legislative battle. One casualty, Russian officials say, would be tax reform, which the Government wants desperately to push through the legislature.
"Of course, there should be improvements in tax administration and tax collection," Mr. Gaidar said. "But there is substantial evidence that tax increases will not be supported by the Duma and cannot be implemented. Import tariffs are the only thing that can be changed without the support of the Duma."
Rory MacFarquhar, an economist with the Russian-European Center for Economic Policy, says that the problem is not that Russia as a whole does not collect enough taxes. The problem, he says, is that regional governments get more than their fair share.
Some Western bankers say that the Russians should be given leeway in dealing with the budget crunch, as long as Moscow and the I.M.F. agree on the overall goals.
"What is important now is that the Russians get serious about their fiscal problems," said Charles Blitzer, the director of emerging markets research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The new Government is younger and more vigorous and committed to reform. It should decide what is the feasible way to meet the deficit target."

HEADLINE: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE AMERICANS;
Navy Ships Put on Alert for Evacuation

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
More than 10,000 American troops and a flotilla of United States Navy ships now steaming through the South China Sea are ready to help evacuate American citizens from Indonesia if a planned airlift becomes impossible because of the chaos there, Clinton Administration officials said today.
The Defense Department alerted the ships that they might be needed for an evacuation after it became clear there were not enough seats available aboard commercial jets for the thousands of Americans and other foreigners seeking to flee Jakarta, Indonesia's riot-torn capital. 
 On Thursday, the State Department urged the estimated 6,000 Americans living in Indonesia's two largest cities, Jakarta and Surabaya, to leave the country as soon as possible, citing the worst political violence in Indonesia in decades.
Administration officials said they hoped that most Americans leaving Indonesia could be accommodated aboard two Boeing 747 jumbo jets flying from Jakarta to Singapore and Thailand beginning Saturday.
But they said that the United States was ready to use troops, military helicopters and Navy ships if the turmoil shut down airports in Jakarta.
Three American amphibious ships, helicopters and 10,600 troops are expected to participate early next week in long-scheduled military exercises in nearby Thailand, and the Navy ships were reported today to be en route to Thailand in the South China Sea, near Indonesia.
The Administration continued its calls today for political reform in Indonesia, which has been under the iron rule of President Suharto since the mid-1960's, and defended the International Monetary Fund from criticism that the rigorous package of economic reforms demanded by the fund in recent months had helped spark this week's violence, in which more than 200 people had been killed.
"We do not believe that the I.M.F. program is the source of Indonesia's troubles," said James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman. "We continue to believe that a key component in restoring economic growth in Indonesia will be a vigorous program of economic reform as proposed by the I.M.F."
A spokeswoman for the I.M.F. at its headquarters in Washington would not comment when asked whether the fund intended to go forward with its multibillion-dollar rescue package for Indonesia, in light of this week's violence.
"That's not something I can give you any guidance on right now," said the spokeswoman, who under I.M.F. rules agreed to be interviewed on condition that she not be identified by name. "The I.M.F. is monitoring the developments in Indonesia very closely and clearly hopes that all sides will exercise restraint."
She said that the fund believed that its reform plan for Indonesia remained "very much appropriate for Indonesia's economic situation and for restoring confidence and for bringing about a resumption of economic growth."
Still, if there was confidence at the I.M.F. about Indonesia's future, it was not in evidence today at the fund's office in Jakarta, which was shut after the entire local staff was evacuated out of the country.
The World Bank, which is also participating in the Western-led rescue plan, said it had chartered a plane to evacuate its international staff from Jakarta, although the office director and a handful of senior managers planned to stay in the country.
"We want to insure the safety of everyone who works there and their families," said Graham Barrett, a World Bank spokesman.
Clinton Administration officials said they still planned to send an American military delegation led by Adm. Joseph W. Prueher, the commander of American forces in the Pacific, to Indonesia to urge military leaders to use restraint in dealing with anti-Government demonstrators.
The mission was canceled at the last minute on Thursday because of concern that the violence in the streets of Jakarta made it impossible to guarantee Admiral Prueher's safety in the city.
"Our diplomats are obviously pressing the Indonesians for restraint," said a White House official. "But in a crisis like this, the generals in Indonesia are more likely to listen to somebody else in uniform."

HEADLINE: UNREST IN INDONESIA: THE DIPLOMACY;
8 World Leaders Urge Suharto to Show Restraint in Handling Indonesian Turmoil

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, England, May 15

 BODY:
The leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies and Russia called on Indonesia's leader today to show restraint in responding to the country's growing unrest, and said a solution would have to involve political as well as economic changes.
President Clinton said President Suharto should "open a dialogue with all elements of the society" in an attempt to create "a genuine sense of political reform and reconciliation" while continuing to overhaul Indonesia's economy. 
 Mr. Clinton also scrambled tonight to assemble a united front to protest India's nuclear tests. Finding scant support for economic sanctions of the type the United States is imposing, Mr. Clinton won agreement on a toughly worded statement but received only vague promises of concrete action to punish India for escalating its arms race with Pakistan.
At the annual summit meeting of the eight nations, Mr. Clinton also said he was looking for a diplomatic formula that would convince Pakistan not to to move ahead with nuclear tests of its own.
Mr. Clinton suggested that one element of that formula might be the resolution of a long-running dispute in which the United States has blocked delivery to Pakistan of 28 F-16 jet fighters and refused to return the $650 million Pakistan paid for the planes.
Mr. Clinton and the leaders of Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Canada, Japan and Russia -- meeting tonight over dinner with only their interpreters present -- spent considerable time discussing Indonesia. Earlier, Mr. Clinton had called on President Suharto and his military "to avoid violence and exercise maximum restraint," and suggested that the Indonesian leader's best option was to respond to the unrest by moving toward democracy.
Mr. Clinton said Mr. Suharto should "open a dialogue with all elements of the society" in an attempt to create "a genuine sense of political reform and reconciliation" while continuing to overhaul Indonesia's economy.
"Giving the people of Indonesia a real voice in the country's political affairs can make a real contribution to restoring political order and stability based on human rights and the rule of law," Mr. Clinton said.
Although the summit's formal agenda is packed with items ranging from combatting international crime to reducing unemployment, it was clear today that the crises in Asia would dominate the proceedings.
Administration officials said Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott had finished meeting in Islamabad with Pakistani officials including Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, and was heading to Birmingham to report to Mr. Clinton. The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Talbott had been told by the Pakistanis that they had not yet made a decision on whether to proceed with their own tests.
"At the same time," Mr. McCurry said, "there weren't any assurances one way or another given to the U.S. delegation."
American officials said that any resolution of the F-16 dispute would be only part of any effort to convince Pakistan not to go ahead with its own testing, which American intelligence reports have suggested Pakistani officials are preparing to do. Any deal on the fighters would likely involve finding another country to buy the planes and then passing the money along to Pakistan.
The Administration has been trying to find a buyer for the planes for years -- a plan at one point to sell them to Indonesia fell apart because of objections in Congress to Mr. Suharto's human rights record -- and Administration officials said today that they had no other potential buyer lined up.
Delivery of the fighters was blocked by President George Bush under a 1990 nonproliferation law after he could not certify that Pakistan was not developing nuclear weapons.
White House officials had to Birmingham resigned to the lack of support among American allies for the kinds of sanctions against India demanded by American law against countries that test nuclear devices. Mr. Clinton has already announced that he will invoke the sanctions, which include cutting off direct foreign aid, withdrawing Government help for trade deals and working to stop loans and other assistance from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
France and Russia had already made clear their opposition to sanctions, raising the possibility that those nations and their industries would win trade deals with India as the United States withdraws. British officials said that they would not invoke sanctions against India because of their historical ties to that nation. Of the eight nations here, only Canada and Japan -- the only nation to have experienced a nuclear attack -- have moved to cut off aid to India.
But American officials said they believed other nations would take steps short of sanctions to make clear to India their displeasure with the nuclear tests.
The decision by the United States not to even make a case for the imposition of formal sanctions may also have reflected the Administration's inability to win international support for sanctions required by American law against energy companies that invest in Iran.
Faced with strong opposition to the sanctions from the European Union, the Administration is expected to announce within a few days that it will waive sanctions under the law against French, Russian and Malaysian energy companies that plan to help build a pipeline in Iran.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Indonesian Meltdown

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
You can learn everything you need to know about Indonesia's problems by catching a blue taxi when you arrive at Jakarta airport and then riding into town to the Grand Hyatt Hotel. The taxi company is owned by one of President Suharto's children, so too are the toll roads that you have to pass through to get from the airport to Jakarta and so too is the Hyatt. Nice roads. Nice tolls. Nice hotel. It's no wonder that Indonesians say about the Suharto family that they are so lucky. They have everything in the world. Except one thing -- a sense of shame.
And it is that lack of shame that finally caught up with them. When Indonesia was booming there was just enough growth and corruption spilling over the top of the glass to keep Indonesia in some kind of balance. But the minute the boom slowed, and the glass became half full, the game couldn't go on. The gap between the haves and the have-nots became too wide. And the only way to refill the glass was with painful economic reform and institution building. And the only way to do that was for President Suharto to say to his people: "Friends, we've got to tighten our belts. We're all in this together." And when he tried that last week, the answer came back in a violent spasm: "Mr. President, we all weren't in the toll roads and taxi companies together." 
 The recent U.S. approach to Indonesia was based on a false premise: that our only choices were either supporting Indonesia economically, even though this might be exploited by Mr. Suharto to prolong his 32-year reign, or letting the country slide into chaos by withholding I.M.F. assistance. The U.S. thought that demanding political change was not an option.
Wrong. There will be no stability in Indonesia -- economic or otherwise -- without fundamental political change. The only question now is whether political change in Indonesia is directed by Mr. Suharto as his last act or simply explodes from below. If the U.S. wants to use economic aid through the I.M.F. as an incentive for President Suharto to immediately begin the political transition, that's fine. Because, unfortunately, Mr. Suharto has so decimated every other institution and potential political actor in the country that there is a vacuum under him. But the U.S. message to him has to be blunt: "Convene an assembly to re-write Indonesia's 1945 Constitution, establish a real parliament with real opposition parties, not the rubber stamp Indonesia has now -- and then be gone."
But if Mr. Suharto will not direct this political transition now, or if it's too late, then the U.S. has to completely disengage from him, because he's toast. Indonesia, Thailand and Korea were like 50-watt bulbs in the 250-watt socket of the global market. When the power surge came from that market last fall, these three bulbs blew up. But Thailand and Korea, precisely because they were democracies, were able to begin adjusting by voting in new surge protectors and software. That is, more democratic leaders and the beginnings of institutional reform -- with popular support. Indonesia, because it is a corrupt autocracy, couldn't just vote in new software and new institutions, and that's why it's melting down.
There was a time when we thought we had to tolerate the Suhartos as a bulwark against Communism, which was the strategic issue. No more. The relevant issue today is how your country relates to the opportunities and challenges of the global market -- whether you are building law-based institutions that enable you to get the most out of that global market and the institutional software to modulate its ups and downs. Therefore it is a prime interest of U.S. foreign policy to help countries face up to this challenge -- to help them become open enough and internally strong enough to both tap the global marketplace and protect themselves from it.
The big split in the world today is no longer between centrally planned Communist regimes and free-market democracies. Rather, it's between free-market kleptocracies (Mafia regimes) and free-market democracies. Those building the institutional software, and those who aren't. U.S. foreign policy should be devoted to helping the free-market democrats and stifling the free-market kleptocrats. The Suhartos are kleptocrats. As long as they remain, Indonesia will be unstable, because the Suhartos are a bulwark against the very reforms needed for Indonesia to thrive in this new era.

HEADLINE: Jerry Brown, in New Incarnation, Brings Celebrity to Oakland Race

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15

 BODY:
Over the course of his unconventional adventures, Jerry Brown has popped up in many places, wearing many faces: India, where he ministered to the wretched with Mother Teresa; Japan, where he sought Zen enlightenment; Sacramento, where he spurned the Governor's mansion for a private apartment with a mattress on the floor.
But of all of Mr. Brown's incarnations, there is perhaps none more unexpected, if such a word can even apply to him, than the current one. 
 Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former two-term Governor of California and three-time Presidential candidate, is not only running for mayor of this troubled, unglamorous city, the seventh most populous in the state. He is, by all estimations, winning, although he is the only white candidate among 11 men and women vying for leadership of a place long perceived as an African-American stronghold, cradle to both the Black Panthers and ebonics.
With less than three weeks until an open primary on June 2, there are political analysts and a few of Mr. Brown's opponents who say that he stands a chance of getting more than 50 percent of the vote, eliminating the necessity of a runoff in November between the top two finishers.
The explanations they offer are varied and include the complicated demographics of Oakland, where no one racial group actually represents a majority, and Oaklanders' tradition of ignoring racial lines at the polls.
But more than anything else, they say, Mr. Brown's strong showing speaks to Oakland's fierce desire for national stature and the envy with which its residents have always gazed at San Francisco, the busier, taller, richer city just across the bay.
State Assemblyman Don Perata, whose district includes about two-thirds of Oakland, noted that San Franciscans have a celebrity mayor of sorts in Willie L. Brown Jr. and said that Oaklanders want one too.
"Willie Brown has bestowed upon San Francisco a certain fame that San Franciscans feel they deserve," Mr. Perata said. "I believe that people think this is what Oakland has in store for itself with Jerry Brown. If Don Perata was mayor of Oakland, I wouldn't be on 'Larry King.' Jerry Brown will. That cuts across every strata in every neighborhood."
Mary King, a member of the Board of Supervisors for Alameda County, which includes Oakland, said its residents are just plain flattered by Mr. Brown's courtship, an appraisal borne out by dozens of interviews with Oaklanders.
"Oakland has a longstanding sense of itself that's a kind of inferiority complex," said Ms. King, who is running against Mr. Brown. "And it's like the prince finally showed up and asked for a dance."
It is less clear to Mr. Brown's opponents and some voters why he wants to tango, although he has always been given to quixotic, offbeat gestures, one of which earned him the moniker Governor Moonbeam: when he held the state's highest office from 1975 to 1983, he proposed that California launch its own space satellite.
Mr. Brown said that six years after his last failed bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination, he felt the need to "get back into the action." He has spent the last several years running his grass-roots nonprofit organization, We the People, and being the host of a radio talk show. Two years ago, he defected from the Democratic Party, which he said had become too much of a fund-raising machine, and subsequently declared himself nonpartisan.
He said that while national and state politics had been corrupted by money and influence peddling, a city the size of Oakland, which has about 388,000 residents, would afford him a chance to have a more direct connection to voters and a more tangible effect on their lives.
"This is a place that's small enough that I can make a real impact, yet it's large enough that it's significant," Mr. Brown said in an interview on Monday at the three-story tin-shelled loft across from the Amtrak station in Oakland that serves as his campaign headquarters, his home and a community center of sorts.
He lives here with about 10 volunteers and friends who take their meals at two long picnic benches next to a communal kitchen. Some are newcomers to his pro-environment, power-to-the-people gospel; a few, like Jacques Barzaghi, the French mystic who has been Mr. Brown's longtime adviser, are holdovers from the past.
There is an herb and vegetable garden on the roof; tai chi and yoga classes are held in the auditorium, and the wheelchair-accessible ramps that twist up the structure's hollow center give it the look of an ersatz miniature of the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan.
Mr. Brown, 60, sold his house in the tony Pacific Heights section of San Francisco and moved into this building in 1995. He said that he could not recall if he had the mayoralty in mind but that he had chosen Oakland for its frustrated but formidable potential.
"I could make a mark in Oakland in a way that's impossible in San Francisco," Mr. Brown said as he ate his lunch, a vegetable stew complemented by a misshapen hunk of bread.
Oakland has long been synonymous in California with crime and urban blight, and residents complain bitterly about its failing schools, its unattractiveness to businesses and the flight of retail establishments from its downtown, where the most upscale department store left is Sears.
But Oakland's unemployment rate of 6 percent is no higher than the state's, and its population, which declined between 1970 and 1980, has grown by nearly 50,000 people since then. The city has expansive pockets of affluence and, despite its history as a hotbed of black nationalism, is extraordinarily integrated. Blacks represent about 43 percent of the population, while non-Hispanic whites represent slightly more than 25 percent, and Asian-Americans and Hispanic people about 15 percent each.
Political analysts and city leaders said that the presence of eight black candidates in the mayoral primary, which throws candidates from all parties together, promised to disperse the black vote, but they also pointed out that Oaklanders have frequently voted in a strikingly race-blind fashion.
Although blacks outnumber whites, the nine-member city council, which includes the current mayor, Elihu Harris, an African-American who is not running for re-election, has one Hispanic, one Asian-American, four white and three black members.
None of Mr. Brown's opponents has a particularly high profile, and two of his best-known opponents, Ms. King and a City Council member, Ignacio De La Fuente, carry heavy political baggage.
They approved a much-touted deal to bring the Oakland Raiders football team back from Los Angeles, which ended up costing taxpayers tens of millions of dollars. Many Oakland residents expressed fury at this turn of events, which they described as one more dashed hope and broken promise in a city weary of both.
Although there have been no published polls since mid-March, that survey, commissioned by The San Francisco Chronicle, showed Mr. Brown with 38 percent of the vote and his nearest challenger, Mr. De La Fuente, with 5 percent. More than 40 percent of voters were undecided.
Although the poll did not break down the results by race, analysts and candidates said that Mr. Brown seems to be getting significant black support, as he has in past campaigns. This is a reflection in part of his record. As Governor, 49.8 percent of his executive appointments went to women and minorities.
One of Mr. Brown's more visible campaign aides is David Hilliard, who was prominent in the Black Panthers, and signs promoting Mr. Brown's candidacy appear in many corners of the city, which Mr. Brown strides through in his trademark casual dress -- no necktie, collarless shirts sometimes unbuttoned at the top.
But Mr. Brown readily acknowledged that of the $250,000 he has raised in campaign donations, at least 60 percent has come from outside the city.
After Mr. Brown announced his candidacy in November, he drew fire from the press and opponents for his expressed vision of Oakland as what he called an ecopolis, or a haven for environmentally friendly businesses, modeled after an Italian hill city. Perugia, he said, came to mind.
He subsequently began putting more emphasis on nuts-and-bolts issues like crime and education. In truth, the Oakland mayor has limited power, functioning as a figurehead and as president of the City Council. The day-to-day administration of city affairs is left to the city manager, who is hired by the City Council.
Many Oaklanders cited that as another reason to vote for Mr. Brown, saying that his celebrity would enable him to stand taller than anyone else could in what is essentially a bully pulpit.
Some voters also said that Mr. Brown could trade on his prominence and connections to lure Federal and state dollars and private investment to Oakland. Mr. Brown encourages this viewpoint.
"I know people all over America," Mr. Brown said. "I've raised money. I raised money for Al Gore for the Senate. I introduced him to Linda Ronstadt," the pop singer, whom Mr. Brown dated when he was Governor.
"You have to have a mayor who can be heard," Mr. Brown added. "There's a lot of clutter out there. There's a lot of noise. You have Texas and you have L.A. and San Francisco and Chicago. There's a lot of competition for attention."
The logic that Mr. Brown would be good for business contradicts his reputation as a politician not particularly friendly to corporations. But Joseph Debro, an Oakland contractor who worked in the Brown administration, said it made sense, even though Mr. Debro indicated he would not vote for Mr. Brown, whose professed interest in Oakland he distrusts as self-promoting.
"Oakland has not advanced because it is perceived as being a black town," said Mr. Debro, who is black. "Unfortunately, it's a racist country. I think the perception is that Jerry Brown will open a window to Oakland that people otherwise wouldn't look through. Business will probably come because if there's a white mayor, it must be an O.K. thing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jerry Brown speaking at the Allen Temple Baptist Church in Oakland, Calif. The former Governor was seated between Shannon Reeves and Mary King. "It's like the prince finally showed up and asked for a dance," said Ms. King, who is running against Mr. Brown in the mayor's race. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)(pg. A10)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Fall a Second Day On Worries Over Asia
 Stocks fell again yesterday as investors reacted to a warning from National Semiconductor, one of the nation's biggest computer chip companies, that it would lose money through August because of slowing sales, an indirect result of economic weakness in Asia. The company's announcement aggravated concern already caused by a drop in Hewlett-Packard earnings and caused a broad selloff in the shares of chip makers. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 76.23, to 9,096.00. leaving it only marginally higher for the week after having hit a record 9,211.84 on Wednesday. Broader market indicators also fell sharply, leaving them little changed for the week. Page D3.
 
Treasury prices ended little changed. The 30-year yield fell to 5.97 percent from 5.98. D3.
 
Hewlett-Packard's Profits Fall 13%
Hewlett-Packard reported a 13 percent decline in quarterly earnings, two days after it warned of unexpectedly weak results. D14.
 
Microsoft Antitrust Talks Start
The Federal Government and representatives of 20 state attorneys general began negotiations with Microsoft, a first step to try to reach a settlement and avoid filing an antitrust suit against the dominant personal computer software company. D14.
 
Setback for Baby Bells
A Federal appeals court upheld regulations that restrict regional Bell operating companies from electronic publishing. BellSouth had challenged them. D2.
 
Financial Paralysis in Indonesia
Indonesia's financial markets ground to a halt as the riot-torn country's central bank stopped acting as a middleman in foreign currency transactions. The currency, the rupiah, has fallen 20 percent during the last week. A6.
 
Industrial Output Edges Up
Industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April as manufacturing output increased for only the second time this year. The factory-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, fell slightly in April. D14.
 
Limited Impact of India Sanctions
United States sanctions imposed on India for testing nuclear bombs may have only a limited impact on India but could do lasting harm to American business interests there. A5.
 
Russia in I.M.F. Dispute
Russia and the International Monetary Fund are wrangling over how to reduce the nation's huge budget deficit, delaying the next $700 million installment of the I.M.F.'s $10 billion program. Foreign investors are anxiously following the deliberations. A3.
 
Waste Hauler Cuts Dividend
Waste Management will slash its dividend to a penny a share from 17 cents to conserve cash and will take a second-quarter pretax charge of $70 million to $90 million for costs related to the year 2000 software bug. D3.
 
Former Clinton Aide Named Dean
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the former chief economic adviser to President Clinton, has been appointed dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. Ms. Tyson, the first woman to lead the White House Council of Economic Advisers, will be the only woman dean of a major American business school. D2.
 
Mercury to Seek Bankruptcy
Mercury Finance, a troubled provider of automotive loans to borrowers with spotty credit, said it would file for bankruptcy-law protection as part of an agreement with its own lenders aimed at returning the company to profitability. D3.

HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: THE OVERVIEW;
SUHARTO REVERSES HIKE IN FUEL PRICE DEMANDED BY I.M.F.

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Saturday, May 16

 BODY:
Bowing to his countrymen's anger and a death toll from rioting that has grown into the hundreds, President Suharto has rolled back fuel-price increases he imposed only days ago at the insistence of the International Monetary Fund.
Returning hurriedly on Friday from a trip to Cairo, the President conferred with his advisers and top generals about his nation's turmoil as calls for his removal grew on the streets and from public figures here in the world's fourth-most-populous nation. 
 Today, as tanks guarded the suddenly quiet streets of the capital and the Presidential Palace, wisps of smoke continued to rise from four department stores in which more than 200 looters died when other rioters set the stores on fire. In the chaos of the rioting, the arsonists may not have realized how big the fire would become, or that it would be so deadly. Officials said they expected the death toll from the rioting to rise.
Young men still roamed the streets today, breaking into shops and homes. Some attacked firefighters who tried to douse the flames of burning buildings. More rioting was reported in the cities of Jogjakarta, Solo and Ugung Pandang.
The outbreak of anger caused by rising prices, unemployment and economic hardship in this nation of 210 million people threw into question the I.M.F. austerity package to which Mr. Suharto, 76, reluctantly agreed in return for a $40 billion economic rescue package.
His imposition on May 4 of increases of up to 70 percent in the prices of fuel and electricity, which came at the height of student protests, and his about-face under the pressure of social unrest, also raised questions about Mr. Suharto's sensitivity to the public mood and his grip on fast-unfolding events here.
As thousands of troop reinforcements took up positions around the city, military leaders warned again on Friday that strong action would be taken against looters and rioters.
This week's violence is the worst since the mass killings of 32 years ago, when Mr. Suharto took power from the country's founding President, Sukarno. At that time as many as half a million people died in an anti-Communist purge.
With the public now watching to see how the military will react to the crisis, Lieut. Gen. Prabowo, the President's son-in-law, went out of his way to assert that there are no splits within the armed forces.
Ethnic Chinese citizens, more than a dozen of whom were burned to death when their shops and homes were attacked in recent days, took refuge in hotels or gathered at the airport seeking to flee the country.
Foreigners also thronged to the airports, after the American Embassy issued a directive that United States citizens should leave the country. The embassy said it would provide two chartered aircraft today to evacuate people who could not find seats on commercial flights. But some Americans said they feared to leave their homes.
Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia, France and the Netherlands were also preparing to evacuate their citizens.
President Clinton, speaking at an economic summit meeting in Birmingham, England, said the political future of Indonesia is for the people here to decide. "What we do believe is important is that the present Government open a dialogue with all elements of society and that it lead to genuine political reform," he said.
In Indonesia, political reform has increasingly come to have only one meaning for the people in the streets: a change in leadership.
With the military clamping down and the city's rioting seeming to pause, "the real action is about to begin," said Sabam Siagian, a political analyst. "I think this movement is unstoppable. It is not only the students now."
In one sign of the spreading opposition, a group of senior officers from Mr. Suharto's own revolutionary generation issued a statement today calling on the President to resign.
The statement proclaims support for the demands of student demonstrators "to carry out the reformation in the political, economic and legal fields."
As for the President, Mr. Sabam said: "I think Suharto is sitting back and assessing the situation. He has tried to buy time by reducing the fuel prices, but it won't work. We don't know what he will do next.
"It is like a Javanese puppet show," he added. "It's a slow buildup, and the climax comes in the early morning. You and I will still be sleeping, and when we wake up, we will be told the good guy won."
Meanwhile, the country's ailing economy has come to a standstill. Most banks and shopping malls were closed on Friday, many with their windows shattered. Smashed masonry and rocks hurled by rioters were scattered across some streets.
Many homes and shops flew the red and white Indonesian flag at half-staff in mourning for those killed. Black banners were hung on walls near the University of Indonesia bearing slogans like: "Is there still any law, justice or truth in this republic?"
The police said 800 looters and rioters in Jakarta had been arrested. In one instance, witnesses said, the police humiliated looters by forcing them to take off their clothes.

COMPANY: INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (92%); INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (84%);

HEADLINE: GIULIANI PLANS CUT OF 1,000 WORKERS WHO AID HOMELESS

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration plans to cut as many as 1,000 positions from the Department of Homeless Services -- roughly half of the agency's total -- as it presses on with efforts to contract out the counseling and shelter that is provided to the city's homeless.
Administration officials said the cuts were a natural reflection of changes at an agency that is handing over more and more responsibilities for the homeless to nonprofit groups. But news of the proposed cuts prompted expressions of outrage from union leaders, who said they did not learn of the vast extent of the cuts until Thursday, during a meeting with officials of the homeless agency that was punctuated by shouts of shock and anger. 
 Most of the jobs at stake are the all-purpose positions well known to homeless shelters, filled by people who serve the food, clean the dishes and wash the laundry. But many of the affected workers are also those who counsel and nurse the homeless, including the families living at so-called welfare hotels.
Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, an umbrella organization representing 120,000 city workers, said yesterday that the affected employees are the "guts of the agency," and that he hoped to negotiate with city officials so that no jobs would be lost.
But the proposed cuts come at an awkward time; a recent agreement between Mr. Hill and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to preserve jobs at the city's hospitals seemed on the verge of collapse last night. Page B1.
Charles Ensley, the president of Social Services Employees Union Local 371, was more critical. "This is outrageous behavior to even contemplate layoffs during this kind of surplus," he said, referring to expectations that the city would end the 1998 fiscal year with a surplus of $2 billion. "These are our lowest-paid workers, almost all black and Puerto Rican, and it's incredibly insensitive to even discuss laying them off."
Mr. Ensley also questioned whether the layoffs were part of a larger plan to replace union workers with workfare workers, as the Giuliani administration struggles to find jobs for people who are removed from the city's welfare rolls.
High-ranking members of the Giuliani administration declined to comment yesterday. But Susan Wiviott, an associate commissioner for the homeless services department, said that workfare did not figure in the planned cuts. Rather, she said, the cuts reflected the agency's long-planned transformation.
"We are moving from being an agency that actually runs homeless shelters to an agency that essentially manages nonprofit contracts and oversees how they provide services," Ms. Wiviott said. "Our function has changed and it requires a very different staffing level."
Since the 1980's, the city has been contracting with nonprofit groups to take over shelters and services for the homeless. But the approach gained momentum in 1992 with the endorsement by the New York City Commission on the Homeless. In fact, Ms. Wiviott said, when the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins created the Department of Homeless Services in 1993, it was with the intention that the agency would gradually hand over shelter operations to nonprofit agencies.
In 1994, she said, the city operated 34 shelters. Now it runs 15: 8 shelters for single adults and 7 for families. The agency's goal is to winnow the number of city-run shelters to six.
By doing so, she said, the agency has managed to develop its own template for how to provide shelter around the city. In addition, she said, many shelters are designated for people with particular needs, from substance abuse to mental illness.
Also, proponents of privatization -- and many homeless people themselves -- say the nonprofit groups have made the shelter environment much more tolerable, providing better food and more secure surroundings than what the city's shelters had offered. On any given night, Ms. Wiviott said, the shelters run by both the city and its contractors serve as many as 7,400 single adults and 4,500 families.
George McDonald, the president of the Doe Fund, said that his nonprofit agency operates two shelters, in Harlem and in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, that have various programs designed to help clients reach self-sufficiency.
"It was a crack den when we took over," he said of the Harlem shelter. "Now, it's a beehive of economic activity. People move out of the condition they were in. They get jobs.
"Under the city," he added, "the shelters were crisis warehousing."
Not everyone agrees that privatizing shelters is the best approach. Some advocates say the city is allowing people to stay in the shelters for a longer time, to take advantage of the improved services. As a result, they say, there is less pressure to create permanent housing, the ultimate cure for homelessness.
In addition, the changes come at a cost, particularly to the city employees. In 1994, the agency had 3,000 workers; now it has 2,170. In addition, homeless advocates have complained that the Giuliani administration has cut the agency's budget; the current proposal calls for a $20 million reduction, to about $370 million.
Union officials said they knew the agency planned to make some cuts. But they said they became alarmed by the comments of its Commissioner, Gordon J. Campbell, before the City Council earlier this month about extensive plans to contract out various jobs, including cleaning, food-handling and laundry services.
Those comments prompted Thursday's meeting, during which city officials laid out their plan to cut 1,000 positions over the next year or two. Union officials said the timing of the news was almost as distressing as the news itself: a clause in the contract with Local 371, assuring that jobs would be found elsewhere in city government for these workers, expires at the end of June.
"We are furious," said Faye Moore, vice president of grievances and legal services for Local 371. "This is dangerous work. And to have our members treated as though they're disposable, we find it downright degrading."
The news also alarmed Steven Banks, the coordinating attorney for Legal Aid's homeless rights project, because among those slated to be laid off are the workers who, he said, "are responsible for locating shelter space and providing counseling at the initial point of entry in the shelter system."
"Those are not positions that the city can contract out," he said. "I think the overall plan is to make the process of seeking assistance so miserable that they won't seek it, and eliminating city workers who provide those services at a time when vulnerable adults and children need help more than ever. These families and adults need more help, not less help."
But Ms. Wiviott countered that although city jobs may be at stake, privatization has improved the services provided to the city's homeless. "Everyone will tell you that it's better than it was," she said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Singapore Airlines Orders Airbus Jets

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
Singapore Airlines agreed yesterday to buy 10 wide-bodied A340-500 aircraft from the European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie for a total of $2.2 billion. The deal consists of five firm orders and five options, with deliveries to begin in 2002. The long-range aircraft, which have four engines and can carry more than 300 passengers, would be used for nonstop flights between Singapore and Los Angeles and San Francisco. The planes will be powered by Rolls-Royce engines. 
 The Singapore flag carrier also said its net income edged up by seven-tenths of a percent, to $1.04 billion (Singapore), or $630 million (United States), in the fiscal year that ended in March. But it warned that its prospects for the current fiscal year were poor because of the Asian financial crisis.

Indonesian Price Rises Are Rescinded After Riots
President Suharto of Indonesia, bowing to popular anger, rolled back fuel price increases that he imposed only days ago at the insistence of the I.M.F. Tanks guarded the newly quiet streets of the capital and the Presidential Palace as the death toll from four days of rioting reached into the hundreds. More than 200 looters died in four department stores when other rioters set the stores on fire. A1 

The leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies and Russia, meeting in England, urged Mr. Suharto to show restraint in responding to the growing unrest, and said a solution would have to involve political as well as economic changes. A7
