HEADLINE: NUCLEAR ANXIETY: IN INDIA;
New Delhi Premier Indicates Resolve to Produce Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 15

 BODY:
Only 48 hours after India ended a series of five underground nuclear tests that stunned the world, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee indicated today that India would not hesitate before deploying the nuclear weapons the tests were designed to perfect.
"We do not want to cover our action with a veil of needless ambiguity," Mr. Vajpayee said in an interview with India Today, a news magazine. "India is now a nuclear weapons state. We have the capacity for a big bomb now, for which a necessary command-and-control system is also in place. Ours will never be weapons of aggression." Both the magazine and the Government released transcripts of the interview. 
 Indian nuclear experts said the "big bomb" Mr. Vajpayee mentioned was apparently a reference to the largest explosion, on Monday, of what India described as a "thermo-nuclear device," meaning a weapon with many times the explosive power of the atomic bombs that the United States dropped on Japan in 1945.
Mr. Vajpayee's remarks, which took the form of written responses to questions from India Today, did not indicate that India had already deployed nuclear missiles, or even that deployments were imminent. Rather, he seemed to emphasize that India, having demonstrated the ability to detonate nuclear warheads designed to be mounted on missiles, would not now be persuaded to stop short of producing them when it is ready.
The remarks appeared to close off a crucial avenue for diplomacy that American officials had hoped to explore as they seek to persuade Pakistan, India's arch-rival, not to respond with tests of its own. A delegation sent by President Clinton arrived today in Islamabad, Pakistan's capital, and met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and other top officials, who indicated they had not yet decided whether to conduct a test and suggested they might still be dissuaded.
And at a summit meeting in Birmingham, England, Mr. Clinton won agreement on a firm statement criticizing India, but failed to mobilize other nations to take punitive action against New Delhi.
In the interview, Mr. Vajpayee, leader of a Hindu nationalist party that came to power at the head of a 14-party coalition Government only two months ago, was alternately blunt and conciliatory. He said the blasts proved that "we mean business" about becoming a full-fledged nuclear power, and vowed that India would not be "cowed down" by economic sanctions from the United States, Japan and half a dozen other nations. "India has the sanction of her own past glory and future vision to become strong," he said.
The Prime Minister called India's critics, including the United States, "hypocritical," adding: "Some of the countries which have talked of sanctions, or have otherwise criticized our action, have themselves not only conducted far more nuclear tests than we have done, but they have also built huge stockpiles of nuclear weapons and delivery systems. Many of them are enjoying the shade provided by somebody else's nuclear umbrella."
But the harsh words were accompanied by reassurances regarding India's resolve to be a responsible member of the "nuclear club" it gate-crashed with its tests.
"I would like to assure the people of the world, especially in our part of the world, that there is no cause for worry at all, much less any alarm, on account of India's action," he said. "All that India has done is conduct five nuclear tests. You place this fact in the context of the hundreds of nuclear tests that have been carried out by several countries so far, and it becomes obvious that India's action does not in the least warrant consideration of worst-case scenarios."
American officials had hoped that even if Pakistan did stage a nuclear test, they could still head off an arms race by persuading India and Pakistan to forgo military deployments of nuclear weapons. Mr. Vajpayee's remarks today did not ultimately exclude that option, since his Government or a successor could conceivably change India's policy as the economic sanctions begin to bite.
Another possible avenue of appeal appeared to have been closed off when Sonia Gandhi, leader of the Congress Party, India's main opposition group, announced that the party supported the tests. In remarks that were reported today, Mrs. Gandhi abandoned the equivocal stand that had been taken by other party officials earlier in the week.
"The nuclear question is a national matter, not a partisan one," she said. "On this, every Indian stands united."
Western weapons experts have estimated that it could take India anywhere from months to several years to deploy nuclear-tipped missiles in any numbers. Starting in 1993, India has test-fired three versions of the Agni missile, designed to become an intermediate-range nuclear missile, able to hit targets up to 1,500 miles away. A shorter-range missile, the Prithvi, with a range of 250 miles, has been more extensively tested, and Indian forces also have artillery capable of firing nuclear-tipped shells at battlefield range.
Together, these weapons would give New Delhi the power to hit targets anywhere in Pakistan and in southern regions of China, the country Mr. Vajpayee identified as India's primary security concern. Shortly before the tests, India's Defense Minister, George Fernandes, described China as India's "potential No. 1 enemy," and said some of China's fast-growing arsenal of nuclear missiles were targeted on India.
Mr. Vajpayee confirmed the role that national pride played in the decision to carry out the tests. His Bharatiya Janata Party, or Indian People's Party, leads a movement that has worked for 70 years to persuade Indians that an assertive Hindu pride is the solution to India's problems. That stance has alarmed India's minority of 120 million Muslims, as well as Pakistan, a Muslim state created out of the partition of British India in 1947.
"India has never considered military might as the ultimate measure of national strength," Mr. Vajpayee said. "It is a necessary component of overall national strength. I would, therefore, say that the greatest meaning of the tests is they have given India shakti, they have given India strength, they have given India self-confidence." Shakti is a Hindi word meaning power, commonly used when referring to Hindu gods.
He noted that Hindu nationalists had been advocating "the cause of India going nuclear" for 40 years, and had done so because of "a stark regional and global reality," meaning that China and other major powers had nuclear weapons stockpiles and showed no sign of abandoning them.
"The world knows the truth about the progress -- or rather, the lack of it -- made by the nuclear powers in the direction of nuclear disarmament," he said. "The world community should appreciate the fact that India, the second most-populous country on earth, waited for five decades before taking this step."
He said his Government, like all Indian governments since the 1950's, preferred a "nuclear-free world," but had concluded that efforts by the United States and other nuclear powers to prevent the transfer of nuclear technology were "singularly ineffective." This was a reference to reports, confirmed by United States intelligence, that China has transferred missile-building and bomb-making technology to Pakistan. As a result, he said, India's tests were "a minimal response necessary" to protect India's security.
Mr. Vajpayee renewed his Government's pledge to "discuss certain provisions" of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty that 149 nations, but not India or Pakistan, have signed. But he said the treaty should require nuclear powers to abandon their nuclear weapons programs, a condition certain to be rejected.
On the effect of sanctions, Mr. Vajpayee was dismissive. "Yes, our action has entailed a price," he said. "But we should not worry about it. India has an immense reservoir of resources and inner strength. If we tap this reservoir, this benefit will be a hundred times more than any price that we may have to pay in the short term."

HEADLINE: Preaching to the Converted

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke; Richard L. Berke is the national political correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

LESSONS LEARNED
 THE HARD WAY
 A Personal Report.
 By Newt Gingrich.
 Illustrated. 229 pp. New York:
 HarperCollins Publishers. $25. 
 At the mere mention of his slippery name, voters laugh. They roll their eyes. Often they shake their heads in disappointment. In random interviews around the country in recent years, I've found that among Republicans and Democrats alike, no politician arouses deeper or more negative passions than Newt Gingrich. Rehabilitating him to the point where he is more liked than loathed would take far more planning, positioning and perseverance than House Republicans managed in cooking up their vaunted "Contract With America" -- the very vehicle Gingrich rode to become Speaker of the House after the 1994 elections.
Whether his intention is to run for President, to fend off members of his own party who are campaigning for his job or to advance a revisionist view of his tenure for historians, "Lessons Learned the Hard Way: A Personal Report" is a first step in Gingrich's effort to remake an image so bruised that Democrats could not resist featuring his mug relentlessly in television commercials during the 1996 campaign.
It may take more than one book to persuade most Americans that the smiling, newly svelte (well, almost) man on the cover is just a humble, dinosaur-loving softy -- not the hostile rebel who savagely stepped over both Democrats and Republicans in his quest to rule the House. This is not your garden-variety politician with an enemy here and a rival there; this is a politician, remember, who had become such an outcast that fellow Republicans came close to toppling him last year.
"Lessons Learned the Hard Way" follows the familiar formula of politicians trying to refashion themselves: Offer a sanitized version of events. Admit some mistakes. Find a compliment or two for your rivals. Sound candid without actually being too candid. And, by all means, do not create new enemies -- or say anything that could haunt you later.
After re-establishing credibility with "Six Crises," Richard Nixon was elected President. More recently, another White House hopeful, former Vice President Dan Quayle, devoted an entire chapter of his comeback book to how he misspelled "potato." And Dick Morris, who was forced to quit as President Clinton's top political adviser, confessed in his book that his relationship with a prostitute came about because he was "out of control, driven by my ego."
While Gingrich's book lacks the self-deprecating humor of Quayle and the juicy (albeit self-aggrandizing) inside details served up by Morris, he deserves some credit: he is not so self-delusional that he cannot admit mistakes. He even manages to compliment the Democrats' political wiles as he revisits his humiliating defeat on the budget and Government shutdown. "Among our several miscalculations, in some ways the most dangerous of all," Gingrich writes, "was to underrate the communications prowess of William Jefferson Clinton."
Gingrich elicits perhaps the greatest sympathy when he talks about the challenge of graduating from a rabble-rousing backbencher in the House minority to presiding over (and trying to control) the first Republican majority in 40 years. As described by Gingrich in personal detail, the journey would have been forbidding for any politician.
But too often Gingrich's mea culpas sound as if he were merely embracing the conventional wisdom about himself. He has been so pilloried, so publicly, that the bar for self-redemption may be higher for Gingrich than for other politicians. In fact, Gingrich's writing betrays itself and assures us that this is the same Newt the public loves to hate. Gingrich careers from self-criticism to self-inflation, as when he cites those he seems to view as his peers in history. "I have studied the transformational leaders of the past," he writes, "most especially among them Andrew Jackson, Abraham Lincoln, Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Delano Roosevelt." Turns out they all had challenges similar to his.
And for all his confessions, Gingrich still retreats repeatedly to the age-old technique of blaming "liberals in the press" for his predicament. Yes, reporters were ready to pounce -- not because they are members of some ideological cabal intent on bringing down the Republicans, but because reporters will always aggressively scrutinize a fast-rising leader who trumpets dramatic change. Clinton knows this all too well.
The book would have been more enlightening had Gingrich displayed more candor rather than merely the impression of candor. Though he writes at length about the ethics charges against him, he essentially skims over them, blaming himself for leaving the matter to his lawyers. ("I was really shocked," he says, "to discover how little research and investigation these lawyers had done.")
Nor does he offer any sense of drama about last year's coup attempt. When did he find out? How did he feel about his loyalists' betrayal? Instead of being treated to Gingrich the Man, we get a bellyful of Gingrich the Politician. The reader is to believe that he has no ill will toward those whom others in his orbit have denounced as traitors. "How could I, who had spent years trying to move the party faster than its senior leadership wanted it to move, stay truly mad at someone who was driven by the same passion?" he asks. "If I had been one of the militant sophomores, my heart might very well have been with them."
The only people who would buy that explanation are die-hard Gingrich devotees -- the few who are left. This is a book that will win favor with those who already toe the Gingrich line. It won't help the Speaker make new friends -- or build a new image.

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: Being 13

BYLINE: By Charles McGrath; Charles McGrath is the editor of The Times Book Review.

 BODY:
Why 13-year-olds? You could make a case that in America now adolescence really starts at age 10 or 11, and that it continues well into the 20's. We have both intensified and elongated what used to be a simple biological transition, and have turned it into an arduous rite of cultural passage. To say that kids nowadays grow up too fast is a truism; it's equally true that we have made such a fetish of youth that not only adolescents but also many of us ostensible grown-ups dwell in a perpetual state of immaturity. But as an arbitrary cutoff, 13 has the virtue of standing at the beginning of what continues to be the heart of the journey -- the teen-age years -- and as these photographs amply document, 13 is the age that may most vividly embody all the paradoxes and contrasts of adolescence. These kids are still recognizably children, even as they are also premature grown-ups. Sometimes they're both at once -- children trying to act grown-up -- and sometimes you sense a younger self clinging forlornly to an older one. Many of the kids seem to be in a state of constant transition, slipping back and forth from one extreme to the other, as in Lauren Greenfield's pictures of suburban girls getting ready for a party in Edina, Minn. They're teeny-boppers one minute, miniature cocktail-dressed matrons the next.
The demographers already have a name for these kids: Generation Y. Together with their slightly younger counterparts, now biding their time in elementary or middle school, early in the next century they will swell the ranks of the nation's teen-agers to some 30 million, or more than at any time since 1975, when their parents, the tail end of the baby boom, were themselves pubescent. These youngsters are of surpassing interest both to doomsayers (who point out, for example, that they are bound to wreck more cars and drive up auto insurance rates) and to people in the marketing and media businesses. "They don't work," Joe Roth, the chairman of Walt Disney Studios, points out. "They don't have families to raise. They're available consumers with money." Teen-agers, and teen-age girls especially, already have considerable economic clout. They spend about $122 billion a year, and not all of it on going to see "Titanic" again. Teen-agers account for more than 10 percent of supermarket sales, for instance, and though exact figures are harder to come by, they are also significant buyers of drugs and illegal guns. 
 This generation ought to be of interest even to those of us who aren't selling them anything. They are our children, after all -- literally and metaphorically -- and in the not-too-distant future, when we have shuffled off to our retirement communities, they will in a sense be our parents as well. They will be making the rules -- or trying to. (Luckily, unless we die with unprecedented swiftness, we will still outnumber and outvote them.) One characteristic of adolescents, however, is that they do not readily lend themselves to inspection.
Our collective sense of our teen-agers, I sometimes think -- our composite picture of them -- may be as unbalanced as my own family archive. In my house we have volume upon volume of photos of the kids when they were little, a vast, overdocumented record of birthdays, holidays and Kodak vacation moments. But as the children get older, they turn up in the family photographs less and less, until, when they're teen-agers, they're almost invisible. They were seldom around anymore when the camera was out, and when they did consent to pose, it was usually stiffly or self-consciously; in the finished pictures their eyes are invariably disfigured by that coppery, demonic glow caused by flashbulb burn. How come that never happened when they were small?
Teen-age pictures, though far less cute, are all the more poignant, it seems to me, for being so hard to capture. All babies, you could argue (and all baby pictures), are more or less alike; it's only when children approach adolescence, and begin to become social beings, that they start to develop private, inaccessible selves -- and it's just at that moment that they tend to disappear or go out of focus. They stop turning up in our photo albums, that is, almost at the same moment that we stop comprehending them. We look at them, but we don't always see who's there.
This spring, The Times Magazine commissioned roughly a dozen of the country's best photographers to take pictures of 13-year-olds all over America. (Some of them will no longer be 13 when the issue appears, and some will be turning 13 just after it comes out; all will be 13 at some point in 1998.) The results, reproduced in the pages of this special issue, bring these kids back into focus, at least for a moment, and they're eye-opening: they restore adolescence to view. This is what our teen-age children really look like, when they let us look at them. And, for good and for ill, these pictures are a substantial clue to who our children are.
In a lot of these pictures we see kids trying on various identities to see how they suit. We even see them trying on their own bodies, so to speak -- as if they were uncertain about the fit. In some of the pictures we almost sense the subjects morphing in front of our eyes, boosted by a sudden jolt of hormones. Not the least of the anxieties of adolescence, we're reminded, is that it's an age of spurts and eruptions. Here's a zit -- like, so gross! -- that wasn't there last time we looked in the mirror; those jeans that fit so great yesterday are now three inches too short and won't snap at the waist. The persistence of the werewolf theme, in literature and in movies especially, must owe something to this adolescent sense of the body as slightly out of control, suddenly and without warning enlarging itself and sprouting hair in unaccustomed places.
With all these hormonal surgings comes sex, of course, and sexual awareness, though that's a muted theme in these pages, present for the most part in an occasional daring flash of belly button. Most of these kids, you sense, not only aren't ready yet -- they know they aren't ready and are temporarily parked in a kind of androgynous rec room filled with posters of Hanson. In many ways, they're younger, and more sweetly innocent, than we may have imagined.
The really powerful feeling here, the emotion animating almost all these pictures in one way or another, is not so much physical desire as simply the wish to connect: to belong, to fit in. It may not be too much to say that all these kids are looking for surrogate families, for people who will take them in and accept them without question, and what's fascinating is how much of the process is reduced to symbols and uniforms -- the right clothes, the right hairstyle. Viewed from a certain distance, the rituals of a gang initiation in Los Angeles don't seem any stranger or crueler or more arbitrary than the elaborate pecking order among middle-school cliques in Edina. Both are systems that in order to work have to exclude as well as embrace; you can't have an in crowd, we learn from some of these pained faces, unless you also have that most dreaded category to those in their teens: "losers." To note that these designations mean nothing in the long run -- that the world is full of losers turned winners, and vice versa -- would surely do no good. The whole point about adolescence is that you live it in the moment.
A couple of things may be missing from these pictures, or are at least underrepresented. Violence, for one -- which, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, is the major source of anxiety among young people. And teen-age optimism as well. According to the same poll, most of today's teen-agers, unlike the slackers of Gen X, actually believe that things are improving and that they will lead even better lives than their parents. Finally, these pictures are eerily silent, when teen-agers, as we know, are anything but. Some of our 13-year-olds' words are here, in the form of transcripts from interviews, but to get the full picture, so to speak, readers may want to imagine a soundtrack, composed of equal parts Puff Daddy and the Spice Girls, booming from bedroom stereos and seeping from the headphones of countless Walkmen.

HEADLINE: Leaving the Freeway, Paying a Price

BYLINE: By DEANNE STILLMAN; DEANNE STILLMAN is writing "The Murders at Twentynine Palms," a book about a crime on the modern frontier (Avon).

 BODY:
SOME say that the frontier closed in 1867, when barbed wire was first patented. For others it was 1869, when the transcontinental railroad was completed. In 1893 Frederick Jackson Turner declared it closed in a seminal paper presented at a meeting of the American Historical Association. Entitled "The Significance of the Frontier in American History," it argued that "The existence of an area of free land, its continuous recession, and the advance of American settlement westward, explain American development. . . . The true point of view in the history of this nation is not the Atlantic coast, it is the Great West." This region, he suggested, was made up of a series of frontiers -- the trader's frontier, the miner's frontier, the rancher's frontier, and lastly, the farmer's frontier.
Not mentioned in his paper was the internal frontier, the personal landscape -- in the American imagination, wide-open space with a few itinerant tumbleweeds -- that is imprinted at the time of birth on every citizen's slate. Although I read in high school that the frontier, my birthright, was closed, I never believed it. 
 I used to escape the gray skies and frozen shores of northern Ohio by huddling under my covers with a flashlight and reading Zane Grey. I'd breathe easier, then go to sleep. In no time I was ordering desert plants from a mail-order house called Cactus Jack's. Finally, with driver's license in hand, I transformed my inner journey into a geographic one, joining the endless wagon train and hitting the trail.
Although the land was now hobbled by strip malls, housing developments that all ended with the word "View" and surreal establishments featuring characters named Chuck E. Cheese, I still didn't buy Turner's thesis. Call me a wide-eyed gal from the Buckeye State, but I could see and feel right past these fetters and deep into virgin territory. I wanted to go back and tell Turner that he didn't know what he was talking about. Didn't he understand that you couldn't erase space, no matter what happened?
Alas, a few months ago, everything changed. That was the day my life in this wide-open land got smaller, my space was encroached on, my breathing was once again labored. For me, the frontier finally closed. It was Oct. 27, 1997. That day, I was issued a traffic violation for an infraction I did not know I had committed. This came as a result of publicly placed Radio Frequency Identification equipment -- similar to technology used by the United States military to keep track of supplies in "conflict zones" overseas.
I was heading north from Dana Point, perhaps the most sparkling of the sparkling coastal communities in Orange County, about 60 miles from where I live in Los Angeles. Usually I take the Pacific Coast Highway until it stops in Long Beach and then head east to the 405, or I simply get right on the 405 and take it all the way to my exit, which is the 90 heading west. But this night I wanted to do something different.
I had spent the weekend at the grand beach house of my cousin and his wife, high atop the cliffs with a view to Hawaii, Asia, Hale-Bopp and beyond. Because of El Nino, or maybe just because they felt so inclined, the ocean waters this fall were unusually warm. By day we bodysurfed a pristine beach. By night we watched shooting stars; who needed a blinking light at the end of a pier to signal American resurrection? This was it, westward ho, as far as you could go, as good as it gets, let's order takeout and have some imported beer. I finished the giant prawns in the sauce of some police state on the far side of the Pacific, happy that my address was here on this side, and headed home from my weekend adventure.
I decided to try a shortcut called the San Joaquin Hills Corridor. This is a toll road that opened in 1996, directly linking San Juan Capistrano with Costa Mesa on a route that distills the essence of freeway travel in Southern California: It's faster and more scenic than the 405, cutting driving time by up to 40 minutes. Generally I am against toll roads, particularly in California, just as I refuse to pay for "beach parking," another perverse feature of latter-day travel in the Promised Land. Aren't our taxes high enough to merit unlimited access to any path, however pretty, that takes us through time and space to either land or water?
But tonight I did not want to get mired in traffic, not after my weekend of unrestricted movement. I could not bear the idea of getting hung up on the Y where the 5 and the 405 intersect, a junction so busy that it is marked by signs whose pictographs might translate as "Beware of fleeing stick figures" -- actually a reference to illegal immigrants who may be stealing across the freeway in front of your vehicle.
I turned east off the Pacific Coast Highway to Crown Valley Parkway, then left onto Alicia Parkway, left at Aliso Creek Road, and after five or six lights, there I was on the 73, "Your Roads, Your Way," heading home, having resigned myself to the $2 I would have to pay for the privilege of fast and scenic driving. But no tollbooth invited my deposit; no bucket blinked for quarters.
I slowed to double- and triple-check, confirmed my luck and headed home, convinced that the road gods, maybe even the ghost of Zane Grey himself, saw me coming and took pity on this solitary traveler living a hundred years too late. There I was on the open range under the stars, driving fast, getting away with something, fleeing, escaping, going, in pursuit of happiness; this was freedom of speech, religion, assembly -- exactly what the Founding Fathers had in mind. I floored it.
SEVERAL weeks later, I received a bill with the return address of Fastrak Service Center. Under "Toll Due," it explained that "The vehicle identified below failed to properly pay the toll amount due upon entering the toll plaza, in accordance with Section 30843 et seq . . ." The notice listed my license-plate number, make of car, date and time of violation, and place where the camera had recorded my transgression: San Joaquin Corridor, Catalina View North, Northbound Lane 12. Evidently, in my euphoria at exercising my birthright, I had missed a lane marked specially for me ("all other traffic") and headed for the Fastrak lane for cars with transponders issued by Fastrak.
Actually, I think I did see the Fastrak sign, but took it as a signal that I was now permitted to travel fast, faster than the poor slobs stranded on the 405, which for all the delays still lives up to its billing as a "freeway." I quickly dialed the 800 number on my ticket. No, there was no mistake; my visit to the American Dreamtime had been memorialized by a kind of technology that is also being used on the battlefield. Maybe Saddam Hussein really won the Gulf War after all: we still had his neighbors' oil, and we probably always will, but so what? We had to pay if we used it on the wrong roads.
The American frontier is now officially closed, I thought as I mailed in my toll . . . at least until I find it again, somewhere, by accident.

HEADLINE: Tourism Thrives on the Coattails of Kykuit

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
THE jewel in the crown, the magnificent mansion, the big fish, the cash cow. No matter how Kykuit is described, the Rockefeller family estate in Tarrytown has become a national and international tourist destination, bringing economic benefit in its wake.
"Kykuit, opened on May 1 for its fifth season, has become the catalyst for an unprecedented revival of interest in tourism in the Hudson Valley, which translates into an increase in revenue for businesses in the region," said Burns Patterson, marketing director for Historic Hudson Valley, the nonprofit organization that administer Kykuit, a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, and five other sites in the Hudson Valley. 
 Kykuit has been so successful in attracting visitors, Mr. Patterson said, that the site has become a victim of its own success. "During our first year of operation, we had 116,000 visitors," he said. "Last year the number more than doubled to 243,000, and since each tour is limited to a fairly small number of visitors, getting reservations was difficult. But this year we've expanded in several directions in order to accommodate more people."
This season at Kykuit, Mr. Patterson said, visitors have two tour options, one of which is the special garden and sculpture tour, introduced last year on a limited basis. It is now available full time through Nov. 1, expanding the site's capability to handle more visitors. The other is the house and garden tour.
Susan T. Greenstein, Kykuit's new program director and formerly with the New York Botanical Garden, said the Garden and Sculpture tour is a guided walk through the gardens, fountains and modern sculpture on the estate. "The focus is on the fabulous sculpture, breathtaking landscape and the Beaux-Arts garden design of William Welles Bosworth, which is one of the few intact Beaux-Arts gardens in America," Ms. Greenstein said. "The Rockefeller family were very involved with the planning of the gardens, and the evolution of the gardens is illustrated during the tour."
Parts of the estate, which were not available on the original tour but are now open, include the Morning Garden, the Grand Staircase and the Italian Garden, she said.
As for the art on display, it is remarkable.
"Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's extraordinary collection of 20th-century sculpture, including the works of Picasso, Alexander Calder, Henry Moore and Louise Nevelson, are on display throughout the gardens," Mr. Patterson said. "Some pieces, including Picasso's 'Bathers,' Isa Noguchi's 'Black Sun' and Karel Appel's 'Mouse on Table' have never been shown in public before, a real feast for art lovers."
Ms. Greenstein recommends the house and garden tour for first-time visitors.
"The rooms are furnished with fine English and American pieces, portraits and family photographs," she said. "However, it is apparent that this is a family home, not a museum. Visitors, especially those from overseas, often are surprised that the house is so livable."
Tourism has been growing in importance every year as a source of revenue in the county, said Georgia G. Kalayjian, president of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau in White Plains.
Efforts to attract European tourists who have a penchant for visiting gardens and historic houses have been increased, Ms. Kalayjian said.
"We're gong to promote Kykuit at an upcoming meeting of select foreign tour operators in Chicago," she said."We're also going to market the site at a world travel meeting in London.
"The Rockefeller name is known around the world." People want to see their home. Kykuit is the big fish that draws tourists in, and the smaller fish eventually benefit. Larger numbers of European and Asian tourists are now eager to travel outside Manhattan. They want to see the countryside. They visit our attractions, stay at our hotels, eat in our restaurants, shop at our stores. They bring in new dollars, which are very good for our economy,"
Estimates show the average Kykuit day tripper spends $59 in the county on gas, restaurants, and the like, Ms. Kalayjian said. And for every overnight hotel stay, $189 is the average amount spent besides the cost of the room.
This season, for the first time, the Castle at Tarrytown is offering two getaway tie-in packages, the Sleepy Hollow and Rockefeller tours to Kykuit and Sunnyside, the home of Washington Irving, combined with a two-night stay at the authentic turn-of-the-century castle, now a hotel.
Rates range from $770 for a king-size double room to $1,490 for a large suite with a living room and a wood-burning fireplace. Packages include a Continental breakfast each morning, a dinner for two at the Equus restaurant in the hotel, a picnic lunch for two on the day of the tours and admission to the historic sites. The package is available until Oct. 31, but it must be reserved in advance.
The Castle also has a lunch-lecture package tie-in with Kykuit, which is new this year. The package, titled "Relive the Golden Age," is available on May 27 and June 3. On those days, the tour of Kykuit will be followed by lunch and a lecture by Ms. Greenstein at the Equus restaurant in the Castle. For reservations for all events, the number to call at the Castle is 631-1980.
The Renaissance Westchester Hotel in White Plains is also offering promotional tie-ins with Historic Hudson Valley. "We're advertising with them, and we're hooked up to their Web site," said Fred J. Heintz, director of marketing of the Renaissance Westchester Hotel. "During the week our occupancy rates are good, running about 80 percent. But weekends are slow, averaging about 55 to 60 percent. We'd like to bring that up to 70 percent. Maybe the expanded program at Kykuit will stimulate business."
For ease in obtaining reservations to Kykuit, Mr. Patterson said: "Visitors can now reserve tickets on the Internet rather than by phone. And they will get a saving of 10 percent or more when they do."
Tickets to Kykuit may also be bought through New York Waterway, which offers a combination package including a Kykuit tour and a Hudson River cruise. Ticket prices, which include Kykuit and admission to Philipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow, the round-trip cruise and ground transportation, are $60. The number to call for information on the New York Waterway packages is (800) 533-3779.
Kykuit is open every day except Tuesdays through Nov. 1. Each tour costs $18, $17 for people older that 65 and $16 for children 12 and older. Tours are not recommended for children younger than 12. Tickets are available by phone at 631-9491 or on line at www.hudsonvalley.org.
"I hope those who come to see Kykuit will also visit our other historic sites," Mr. Patterson said. "Sunnyside, Philipsburg Manor, Van Cortlandt Manor, Montgomery Place and the Union Church are all unique and wonderful in their own way."

HEADLINE: A Century of Art on a Blackboard Canvas

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN; Samuel G. Freedman is an author whose books include "Small Victories: The Real World of a Teacher, Her Students, and Their High School."

 BODY:
ONE century ago, the man selected to lead the public schools of newly consolidated New York City delivered an acceptance speech. William Henry Maxwell had earned a reputation for eloquent oratory long before assuming the office of superintendent on March 15, 1898, and on that morning he turned his bass voice to a suitably grand theme.
"New York is the largest and wealthiest city on the continent," he declared. "But if New York is to be and remain a truly great city, it can only be through the education given to her children in the public schools. If public education is to do its perfect work for its community, it must be the best education that modern civilization can afford." 
 During that same inaugural year, a cameraman named G. W. Bitzer took over a Manhattan studio to make a silent movie entitled "The Nearsighted Schoolteacher." In Bitzer's version of the educational enterprise, a hapless teacher is flouted by his pupils and terrified by a toy spider.
The congruence of Maxwell's speech and Bitzer's film could hardly have been more appropriate, or more prophetic. For in the 100 years since, New York's public schools have been inextricably entwined with cultural expression, both producing it and serving as its object.
As Maxwell suggested, the schools forged much of New York's civic culture, its ideals of meritocracy and immigrant ascent. And from the Bitzer film onward, the schools have provided irresistible material for creative artists ranging from photographers to playwrights, authors to filmmakers to pop songwriters.
In just one timely reminder of the connection between culture and public education, the privately financed Arts Education Week opens tomorrow in nearly 500 schools. Last month, New York University convened a major conference on the centennial of the public schools, and next fall the Board of Education will mount an exhibition of archival photographs.
"In New York, there has been a particular debt acknowledged to schools and teachers," says Kenneth H. Jackson, the historian who edited the Encyclopedia of New York. "It's a city of immigrants, and it's a city with an ethos of achievement. There's always been a sense in New York that if you worked hard, you had a way to make it. The immigrants didn't have the money for private school, didn't have the connections, but they had the desire. And they passed that desire on to their children."
Bel Kaufman, a former teacher who wrote the definitive novel of New York's schools in "Up the Down Staircase," puts Jackson's thesis in both pedagogical and artistic terms. "The word 'possible' is a very important word," Ms. Kaufman says. "It's possible in even the most dismal surroundings to have the thrill of touching at least one student. That's often enough to make up for all the difficulties. The thrill of knowing who you touch. And why. And how."
That sense of possibility -- and the enormous obstacles conspiring against it -- collided at the very birth of New York's school system. In 1898 and for 40 years thereafter, immigrants constituted almost one-third of the city's population. Yet the concept of compulsory education, of sending children to the classroom instead of the sweatshop, was just beginning to take hold in the early decades of the century. Society demanded that the public schools not simply educate the unlettered but Americanize the alien.
In one emblematic event caught in a photograph from about 1910, a group of Lower East Side pupils, clad in the garb of their homelands, gathered worshipfully around a teacher decorated as the Statue of Liberty. "In teaching civics the aim should be to train for citizenship," the Board of Education's 1914 syllabus held. "Good citizenship depends not so much on a knowledge of the governmental forms . . . as upon the practice of civic virtue." Less idealistically, the 1934-35 edition of the school board's annual report attributed juvenile delinquency partly to Old World parents "with habits and attitudes fixed by tradition, prejudice, superstition and ignorance."
What New York offered in exchange took the form of schools designed to impart a sense of majesty. Like Gothic cathedrals looming over medieval cities, these edifices dominated immigrant neighborhoods. Erasmus Hall featured towers, Bay Ridge a landscaped courtyard, Seward Park a principal's office with fireplace and wood inlay.
"Just in their physical presence, schools became a representation of the American ideal that we the people have provided you with this magnificent opportunity to learn," says Stephan Brumberg, the author of "Going to America, Going to School," a study of Jewish immigrant students in New York. "The schools were more awesome than any building an immigrant child would have come into contact with. And in their grandeur, their attractiveness -- the marble wainscoting, the stained glass -- they were an invitation to become an American."
That invitation found many takers. High school enrollment in New York soared from 11,072 in 1898 to 154,512 in 1928 and doubled in the decade thereafter. The finest graduates proceeded to City College, the self-styled "poor man's Harvard." Hundreds of thousands of parents thronged to evening lectures on topics ranging from hygiene to history or enrolled in courses like "American Manners, Customs and Conduct."
At the time, however, art did not especially celebrate these achievements. Jacob Riis photographed New York schools around 1900 primarily to demonstrate their overcrowded conditions; one such print appeared in his muckraking manifesto "How the Other Half Lives." In her 1925 novel "Bread Givers," the Jewish immigrant author Anzia Yezierska bitterly described teachers "just peddling their little bit of education for a living, the same as any pushcart peddler." The socially conscious movies of the Depression years, whether melodramas like "Hell's Kitchen" or the early black feature "Reform School," focused on teen-agers who slipped beyond education's grasp into lives of crime. Richard Brooks's 1955 film "The Blackboard Jungle" shocked audiences with its combustible mix of delinquency and rock-and-roll.
It fell to the actual schoolchildren of the 1920's and 1930's, once they reached adulthood, to create a body of work celebrating their educations and educators. Kate Simon, in her acclaimed memoir "A Wider World," recalled a teacher named Mr. Brandon at Monroe High School in the Bronx who liberated her from a loveless household with lessons in Shakespeare, Keats and Wilde. Joseph Dorman's 1997 documentary, "Arguing the World," presented City College of the Depression years as the proving ground of renowned intellectuals like Irving Howe, Irving Kristol and Daniel Bell.
Many of these public-school alumni saw their teachers forever through the admiring eyes of the poor, ghettoized youngsters they had once been. "In an immigrant neighborhood, the teacher was someone who had succeeded, not so much economically but culturally, someone who was the epitome of America," says Kate Rousmaniere, the author of "City Teachers," a study of New York City educators in the 1920's. "Teachers were learned; they were articulate; they seemed refined. And teachers were expected -- demanded, really -- to be caring individuals, because that absolves the system of responsibility. Teachers feel they have to be superhuman. That's a romanticized view, but it's also true. And it's a potent, dramatic dynamic."
Bel Kaufman gave the dynamic memorable form in "Up the Down Staircase." An immigrant who had arrived from Russia at age 12 and ultimately taught English in New York's public schools for 35 years, Ms. Kaufman drew heavily on her own experiences as pupil and pedant. Her career linked the melting-pot metropolis of the pre-World War II years to the city being altered by the influx of Puerto Ricans and African-Americans in the postwar decades. What remained constant, at least in her rendering of urban education, was the alchemy of teacher, students and classroom.
"Up the Down Staircase" began as a short story entitled "From a Teacher's Wastebasket," which was published in The Saturday Review in 1962. As the title implied, the story consisted entirely of scraps of regulations, homework assignments, doodles and, finally, a young teacher's desperate and unsent plea to her principal for help. Ms. Kaufman extended the same narrative device across 340 pages in the novel, creating in her heroine, Sylvia Barrett, the enduring portrait of a New York teacher -- beleaguered, a bit intimidated, yet capable of changing at least one student's life.
"I wanted people to close the book and laugh and then say: 'Wait a minute. ' " Ms. Kaufman recalls. "I wanted the kind of humor that has a tear behind it."
Since its publication in 1963, "Up the Down Staircase" has sold more than six million copies, been translated into 16 languages and gone through 47 printings. Robert Mulligan's film adaptation, released in 1967, influenced many subsequent films and television shows about New York schools.
Without the supple hands of Ms. Kaufman and Mr. Mulligan, however, the results veered toward the formulaic. Alan Parker's 1980 musical film, "Fame," set in the High School of the Performing Arts in Manhattan, surrendered its grittier instincts to the happy-ending conventions of Hollywood. In the 1970's television series "Welcome Back, Kotter," the co-producer Gabriel Kaplan modeled fictitious Buchanan High on the school he had attended in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. His class of charmingly crude "sweathogs," led by John Travolta, resembled nothing so much as updated versions of the mischievous lads in Bitzer's silent movie "The Nearsighted Schoolteacher."
Slapstick and sentimentality hardly reflected the conditions in New York City's actual schools. Buffeted by white flight, fiscal crisis, unstable leadership above and social chaos below, the school system of the last quarter-century has struggled to equal its gilded reputation.
The chasm between past and present cracked open in 1968, when black parents and a largely white, disproportionately Jewish teachers' union warred over community control of the schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn. Under the combative leadership of Albert Shanker, the United Federation of Teachers struck three times in the fall of 1968, bringing the school system to a near-total halt and the city to an apogee of racial tension.
Just as the decentralization struggle was subsiding, racial strife engulfed City College. Its practice of admitting applicants on the basis of their high school records alone -- an act of principle in earlier decades, when Ivy League schools put quotas on Jews -- now came under attack as being racist in effect. Reeling from protests by blacks, Puerto Ricans and their leftist allies, the college switched to open admissions.
Taken together, the battles at City College and in Ocean Hill-Brownsville challenged the faith that public education in New York could teach and uplift all those willing to learn. "There was a profound loss of belief in our institutions," says Diane Ravitch, author of "The Great School Wars," the authoritative history of New York's public schools. "The belief in merit had been strong. But in the late 60's, you get an analysis saying merit is just a cover for privilege, for a system that protects certain groups. Up until the 60's, this city had believed in the central idea of the melting pot, even as we had vibrant ethnic communities. Then came this kind of rejection and contempt for the melting pot. And that was important for the schools, because they had always seen themselves as the primary agency of the melting pot."
The convulsions of the late 1960's, which shake public education in New York to this day, yielded art as despairing as an early generation's had been buoyant. It was art forged in the furnace of the moment, not crafted at a remembered distance, art resonating with the anguished ineloquence of public schools' losers rather than the elegiac tones of its triumphant graduates.
Herbert Kohl's 1967 memoir about teaching in Harlem, "36 Children," helped catalyze the modern school-reform movement. Another New York City teacher, Stephen Joseph, shaped the poetry of his inner-city students into the 1970 musical "The Me Nobody Knows," part of a boomlet of Broadway shows like "Hair" that forced social issues into a once escapist medium.
MR. KOHL and Mr. Joseph, as products of an idealistic, radicalized decade, at least trusted the power of documentary truth to stir the public conscience. More recent writers like Emily Sachar ("Shut Up and Let the Lady Teach"), Stephen O'Connor ("Will My Name Be Shouted Out?") and Cristina Rathbone ("On the Outside Looking In") have portrayed students and teachers as all but discarded by the larger society, left to negotiate their own path amid drugs, crime and familial collapse. What hope existed in their works was purely of the existential sort, the hope of mere survival.
"Through the kids' eyes you see what society expects of them, and it's grim," Rathbone says of her experience at West Side High in Manhattan, a last-chance school for 800 students. "It treats poor, urban kids as, at best, someone else's problem and, at worst, downright inhuman. And the kids internalize that, feel it's right and proper and normal."
No work of art more bleakly conveyed New York's education crisis than Shirley Lauro's play "Open Admissions," which was based on her years of teaching speech at various branches of City University. In the late 1960's, a veteran professor advised her: "Don't judge the open-admissions kids by the same standard. If their attitude is good and they try, just slide them through." By the time Ms. Lauro resigned in the early 1980's, students praised her simply for remembering their names.
Later produced on Broadway and broadcast on CBS, "Open Admissions" first reached the stage in 1981 as a 25-minute one-act presented by the Ensemble Studio Theater. The entire action occurs in the office of a college speech teacher named Ginny Carlson on the night a black student with a fifth-grade reading level demands to know why she keeps giving him B's. When Ginny puts off his request for extra help, he screams and seethes, curses and pleads, throttles her and then throws himself to the floor of her office, literally begging to learn.
The spectacle wracked audiences all too familiar with the play's historical backdrop. "I walked out of the theater one night," Marilyn Rockafellow, who played Ginny, recalled in a 1984 interview, "and this man and this woman, who were both obviously teachers, were in an argument. I felt sure it would become a fistfight. She was saying: 'Don't you see? We are to blame. We do it. We perpetuate it." And he said, 'No, you cannot tell me it's my fault, when I have these students, these jerks, who can't do anything.' It was a collision. The play caused a collision."
The aftershocks from that collision rumble all the way to the present. In the last weeks, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has demanded that the City University system drastically reduce its remedial courses, the inevitable result of open admissions. Reckoning with high schools in which barely half the students graduate with their class, Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed halting social promotion in the lower grades.
Hearing the horror stories, and having them replayed through the tape-loop of art, someone who has never set foot inside a public school might be stunned to find Chinese and Dominican immigrants analyzing "The Great Gatsby," blacks and Puerto Ricans of the underclass taming the iambic pentameter of "The Tempest." Such things actually do happen; they just go unrecognized amid the city's enveloping pessimism about public education. These days, it takes a media event like "Principal for a Day" to entice the entitled into a public school. Even the woman who runs the program has her children privately educated.
Meanwhile, in a storage room of the Museum of Natural History rest the pieces of a statue of William Henry Maxwell, the founding superintendent of New York's public schools. The rendering of Maxwell in his academic robes, sage as a Supreme Court justice, was built about 70 years ago with teachers' donations and stood for decades on a marble pedestal in an exhibition hall. Why and when the statue was removed and disassembled nobody seems to know.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Richard D. Parsons;
From Law to President of Time Warner

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
RICHARD D. PARSONS, Nelson A. Rockefeller's personal lawyer and prodigy, was someone the former Vice President thought should someday be a nominee to the Supreme Court of the United States. But Mr. Parsons's career went a different way. He gave up law, became a chief executive officer at a bank and in 1994 was made president of Time Warner. As such, he played a key role in the negotiations that led last year to the media giant's purchase of Ted Turner's cable network, including Cable News Network.
Today he is what Newsweek -- a rival of Time Warner's Time magazine -- called "arguably America's most influential black executive." On Wednesday, Mr. Parsons, who maintains homes in Pocantico Hills and Manhattan, will be the keynote speaker at the Westchester Community College Foundation's Annual Medallion Awards Dinner. The event will honor Frank S. McCullough Jr., a Rye lawyer and past chairman of the foundation's board of directors, for community service, the college's Prof. Douglas Kenny for education and Gannett Suburban Newspapers for corporate support of the college. The dinner, which raises funds for student scholarships, starts at 6:30 P.M. at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown. Tickets are $175 each. The number to call for further information is 785-6670. 
 Mr. Parsons, who graduated first in his class from Albany Law School in 1971, went on to work for the State Legislature and then Governor Rockefeller. When Mr. Rockefeller became Vice President under President Gerald R. Ford in the aftermath of Watergate , Mr. Parsons went to Washington with him. When Mr. Rockefeller returned to civilian life, Mr. Parsons became his personal lawyer.
In 1977, he stopped practicing law. Before joining Time Warner, he was chairman and chief executive officer of the Dime Savings Bank, one of the largest thrift institutions in the country. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Parsons:
Q. What will you speak about at the Westchester College dinner?
A. I'll probably talk about why I think the role community colleges are playing, particularly in Westchester County, is so important to people who come from less than advantaged backgrounds. I won't necessarily call them disadvantaged because I don't like the phrase. It sounds mildly demeaning, because lots of those people have other kinds of enrichment in their backgrounds; it doesn't mean they're disadvantaged. But they may not have had all the opportunity to develop their own potential and to acquire skills. I think the mission of the community college, particularly as we approach the 21st century, is critical from an equity-in-society perspective.
Q. Did you come from a disadvantaged background?
A. I personally would answer that question no. But if you looked at the demographics, you would say yes. I was born in the Bedford-Stuyvesant part of Brooklyn, raised in what's called South Jamaica, Queens, both of which are heavily minority communities. I went to the New York City public schools, had a one-income family -- but an intact family, and that's an important thing. My father probably never earned more than $7,500 a year when I was a kid, but at the time I had absolutely no idea that we were statistically working poor. We were like everybody else on the block; it didn't seem so bad to me.
Q. Was it your parents and your schools that instilled in you the drive that got you where you are today?
A. I owe a lot to my parents, to be sure. And, of course, I owe a lot to the schools because -- good intentions not withstanding -- if you don't get quality instruction and a certain amount of discipline and accountability that comes to the instructional process, you don't learn things. And if you don't learn things, you won't have anything to offer.
Q. How do you see your role as the president of Time Warner to influence public debate on these issues?
A. Well, that's a good question, and I don't have a spiffy answer for you. Or at least I don't have a packaged or canned answer. I do think that simply by virtue of the shoulders that I'm standing on I have some visibility and an opportunity to at least be heard above the din. First, you have to decide: to what extent do you want to join into the public chorus on one side or the other? Generally, I try, although I'm not always successful, to stay below the radar on most things outside whatever it is I happen to be doing for a living at a point of time -- with the exception of the educational arena. That's because I'm a big believer both from a humanistic point of view and also from a practical point of view in what I'll call societal equity. We have to have a society, if it's going to endure, where the bounty of that society is shared on a fair basis with the participants in the society. If you have a system where we kind of get put into two camps -- haves and have nots -- sooner or later whatever holds those two together will break. Then you will have a collapse of society.
From an equity-in-society perspective, I'm a big believer in public education as a necessary mediating ingredient. And that's something that I have some experience with, as a product of it, and some passion about because I think in many respects the schools are failing their mission.
Q. Was race a handicap to you along the way or not a factor?
A. That's another tough question to answer. There is perception, and there is sort of a larger reality. I have said and have been criticized for this that in my case I never personally thought race was a handicap. And that has a lot to do with who I am and how I have interacted with the world. There are others who take a dimmer view of American society and say it's always a factor and it's always a negative. I think a large part of the answer for individuals is: you can allow it to be a determining factor or you can take the reality of your race in stride, like the reality of the weather. You know, some days it rains, some days it doesn't. You can't let those factors determine what you're going to do with your life.
Q. You had a close association with Nelson Rockefeller. We frequently hear that Rockefeller Republicans are a dead breed.
A. It's not true.
Q. So you would still give yourself that label?
A. Absolutely. I think that if you define a Rockefeller Republican as I do as someone who -- well, the easy way used to be as someone who was fiscally conservative and socially liberal. It's someone who believes in fiscal discipline and believes that you can't solve problems simply by throwing money at them. You can't solve all the problems by manipulation of the financial structure. You've got to adjust the institutions of society to help promote social equity, but you have to do that within the context of sound economic discipline and policies. You know a lot of those people who now call themselves conservative Democrats are really starting to spout that message, including the current President.
Now, nobody wants to call themselves a Rockefeller Republican because in the Republican Party that's a kind of kiss of death. That's because you have these crazy right-wing Republicans who reign terror on anybody within the party who doesn't subscribe to their doctrine.
Q. Rockefeller had talked about you as a possible Supreme Court nominee. Looking back, would you have liked to have gone that route?
A. You don't get do-overs in real life. So I don't spend a lot of time thinking about that. It was something that intrigued me at the time, but it was something I consciously moved away from when I moved out of law.
Q. Vice President Rockefeller died so you lost your main advocate.
A. That's true.
Q. How have things changed at Time Warner now that Ted Turner is part of the empire?
A. It's an even more interesting place to work. This was always an interesting company. We have probably the best collection of the media and entertainment assets of any such company; adding CNN into our world globalizes the company by an order of magnitude of what it was. And CNN is an important global institution. Ted himself is a larger-than-life figure who is brash and bold, captivating, and an interesting guy. I like him.
Q. Please define your job. You are not the one who decides who will be on the cover of Time, or what the lead story will be on CNN. How do you fit into those decisions, if at all.
A. Just think of Time Warner in essence as a holding company with all these operating units under it. What we do at the corporate level is make sure that each of our businesses is running on a sound basis, both financially and operationally. And we make sure the whole is worth more than the sum of the parts by effectively shepherding the profit collaborations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard D. Parsons, president of Time Warner, in his 75 Rockefeller Plaza office in Manhattan. He lives in Manhattan and Pocantico Hills. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1474 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Hotels;
Will the Former Ritz-Carlton Thrive as a Westin?

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
FOR six months it was a hotel with no name. After a bitter, protracted dispute with the then-owner of the hotel at 112 Central Park South, the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company lowered its trademark lion flags from the front of the building last August and severed its agreement to manage the property.
Although ITT Sheraton quickly took over the management, the corporate name was not attached to the hotel. Telephone operators greeted callers with the phrase "the luxury collection." 
It was not until late January, after the Starwood, which owns several hotel chains including Westin and Sheraton, took ownership of the property, that the hotel was renamed the Westin Central Park South. It is the first time Westin, an international chain of 120 properties, has operated a hotel in New York under that name. The parent company does, however, own other hotels in the city, including the Doral, the St. Regis and the three Sheraton properties.
Now the new managers of the property are trying to lure back old customers who shifted their allegiance during the interregnum and attract new ones. Whether they will be able to do so without the magic of the Ritz-Carlton name is questionable in the view of many hotel industry analysts.
Ritz-Carlton, after all, is the only hospitality company to have won the Federal Government's Malcolm Baldrige Quality award. The company's system of recording the service preferences of each guest so the services can be available whenever a guest checks in at an affiliated hotel anywhere in the world, and its insistence that "certainly" and "my pleasure" are the only acceptable responses to guest requests, are cited routinely in management books and articles.
Mark Spadoni, the general manager of the Westin here, said he planned to offer most, if not all, the amenities of a Ritz-Carlton, but in a different way. He said the company's Westin Premier program included a computerized guest preference program similar to Ritz-Carlton's, along with a points system and airline miles credits that can be redeemed for additional benefits and travel.
Mr. Spadoni said there was a conscious difference in the way the two hotel chains operated. "There is a spectrum of service that ranges from formal and stuffy service to casual service," he said. He said Ritz-Carlton was toward the formal end of the spectrum, while he described Westin as "friendly and professional."
He also noted that most of the approximately 200 people on the hotel's staff were holdovers from the Ritz-Carlton era. Only the top managers are from Westin, so a hotel guest with a favorite desk clerk or concierge will see familiar faces.
But some industry analysts say the Westin name simply does not have the cachet of Ritz-Carlton. "Ritz-Carlton is five-star brand, Westin is a four-star brand," said Michael Fishbin, a hospitality consultant with E&Y Kenneth Leventhal. He said Starwood was planning to use the name of the St. Regis hotel, which it also owns, as its five-star brand nationally and internationally.
Since the St. Regis name is already established in New York, he said, the parent company apparently decided to hang the Westin label on the Central Park South property.
Brand loyalty is a major issue in the hotel business, analysts say. "A Westin is not considered at the level of a Ritz-Carlton," said John A. Fox, senior vice president of PKF Consulting, a hospitality consulting company. "There are some people who when they travel only want to stay at a Ritz-Carlton or a Four Seasons, which are interchangeable in the top luxury segment."
Nevertheless, Westin is charging Ritz-level prices. The corporate rate for a standard room facing the city is $330 a night, with rooms overlooking the park renting for as much as $490. The Presidential Suite, an 1,800-square-foot multiroom space that includes a whirlpool bath and a balcony overlooking the park, goes for $3,500 a night.
Because of the six months of uncertainty, Mr. Spadoni said he had some catching up to do. "There was a slow deterioration of the business from August on," he said. "Some loyal customers kept coming here anyway, but we definitely lost some business."
THE effort to remarket the hotel -- which has included offering juice, coffee and danish pastries to taxi drivers so they would recognize the new name -- comes at a time when the hotel business in New York is as good as anyone can remember. The occupancy rate last year, according to figures compiled by Coopers & Lybrand was 82 percent, which hotel executives describe as very close to full.
The average room rate increased 11.1 percent during the year to $187.91 a night, an indication that hotel operators are using the tight market as an opportunity to increase prices.
Combining the increased occupancy with the higher daily rates produces a number dear to the hearts of hotel operators, the revenue per available room. That increased 12.6 percent during the year to $154.09.
Mr. Spadoni said the previous owner, a Saudi businessman named Sheik Abdul Aziz bin Ibrahim al-Ibrahim, had been dissatisfied with the financial performance of the hotel and had not invested in its upkeep. He said Westin would inject capital to "freshen up" the property.
That freshening up will include new bed covers and other so-called "soft goods" in the guest bedrooms, new carpets in public areas and the replacement of metal keys for guest room doors with an electronic system. In addition the building will be reconfigured so that office and other space on lower floors facing the park will be turned into 20 guest rooms, which will be added to the 208 now in operation.
Most of the work will be done during the traditionally slow period during the summer, Mr. Spadoni said, so the renovated hotel is expected to be ready for fall.
As the rebranding of the hotel indicates, there is very little connection between who owns a property and who manages it. Ritz-Carlton, for instance, owns none of the 34 hotels it operates around the world. Marriott and Hilton own some of the hotels they manage, but analysts say most hotels are owned by groups of investors and operated under contract by a management company or via a franchising arrangement. Despite having voluntarily withdrawn from the city, Ritz-Carlton is anxious to reestablish its presence in New York, analysts say.
"I think it violates no confidences to say Ritz-Carlton wants to get back into New York," said Arthur Adler, a hospitality consultant with Coopers & Lybrand. "It is a significant hole in their portfolio."
The disconnect between image and reality is also illustrated by the company's corporate structure. Although Ritz-Carlton carefully cultivates its image of, as Mr. Spadoni puts it, "ladies and gentlemen taking care of ladies and gentlemen," it is 100-percent owned by Marriott Corporation. "Ritz-Carlton would never market itself as a Marriott product," said Stephen Rushmore, the president of HVS International, a hotel consulting company.
One reason for the reluctance to advertise the corporate affiliation, Mr. Rushmore said, is that hotel chains, in general, have been more successful in establishing down-market brands than those in higher priced brackets.
He said Holiday Inns had successfully established the Hampton Inn brand at a point below the parent chain, but had struggled to make its upscale Crowne Plaza successful with travelers. "When people want to stay at an upscale hotel, they don't want to stay at a Holiday Inn," he said.
Branding is the talk of the hotel industry, according to the consultants, as companies like Starwood and Patriot American, another large hotel real estate investment trust, seek new market niches. According to a report by Coopers & Lybrand, new lodging brands have "stretched the concept of limited service from economy/budget to midprice/upscale, introduced the concept of all-suites and created the dedicated midprice or economy extended-stay hotel."
Nevertheless, trying to establish new hotel brands is expensive and risky. The Coopers & Lybrand report counted 113 new brands that were introduced between 1980 and 1996, and noted that almost half had failed. Among the brands that were introduced were Embassy Suites, Courtyard by Marriott and Holiday Inn Express.
Nevertheless, analysts say Starwood executives have signaled that they plan to launch a new brand of urban high-style hotels that incorporate, in the words of one, "the best of Ian Schrager." Mr. Schrager is the owner of the Royalton and other hotels in New York.
The new brand is to be called, simply, W, said Mr. Fishbin of E&Y Kenneth Leventhal. A likely candidate for conversion in New York is the Doral, analysts said.
Barry Sternlich, the chief executive of Starwood, said the new brand would be a sister to Westin but "high in design content and extraordinarily cool."
