HEADLINE: Writers Falling for the Lull of the North Fork

BYLINE: By LORRAINE KREAHLING 

 BODY:
"I WROTE half of 'Plum Island' in six weeks on the North Fork," said the best-selling author Nelson DeMille. "The summer I rented on the South Fork in Sag Harbor, I wrote like 10 sentences of 'Cathedral,' because I was going to summer parties in the Hamptons.
"The North Fork is so quiet, physically, deathly quiet," he added. "You can write into the night, because there is nothing else to do." 
 The smaller of the two pincers of the lobster claw that forms the Eastern End of Long Island, the North Fork is separated from the South Fork by Peconic Bay, in which Shelter Island is trapped like a Little Neck clam.
Any North Fork writer, therefore, who wants to partake of the Hamptons summer social scene, where literary agents meet clients and editors read manuscripts on the beach, must make a journey that includes two ferry rides and some driving.
"In the summer, writers don't go to the South Fork to write, they go there to schmooze," Mr. DeMille said. "Writers go to the North Fork to write."
If Mr. DeMille chooses to spend part of the season on the North Fork again, he will be part of a growing group of writers who say they prefer isolation to the glamour of the South Fork society that buys and markets their wares.
North Fork writers opt for a landscape of old farmlands and new vineyards, that some say is reminiscent of the bucolic Hamptons of 50 years ago. They point out that like the Hamptons in the 1950's, the North Fork's year-round population offers a politically correct mix of classes and incomes, which includes mariners and farmers.
And while the North Fork cannot boast of crashing waves and spectacular dunes, it does have beaches on the Long Island Sound and Peconic Bay. It is also a lot cheaper than the Hamptons.
"I spent a summer in the Hamptons," said the screenwriter Terry Reed. "I don't care to do that again. We had black tie parties on Saturday night. It's another competitive kind of environment like the one you live in in Manhattan. Why go back into it when you are trying to get away from it all?"
Ms. Reed wrote her first screenplay, "Cherry," currently being made into a feature film, in a cottage she rents in Rocky Point, which looks out over the Long Island Sound .
"The North Fork is not glamorous at all, but it's very gratifying to look at something beautiful when you are trying to generate ideas," Ms. Reed said.
The novelist Sandra Scoppettone sold her Soho loft in Manhattan and has just finished renovating and winterizing a waterfront cottage in Southold that will be her permanent, year-round residence.
"I like the fact that where I am isn't the Hamptons and it isn't Soho or Greenwich Village," said Ms. Scoppettone, whose 17th book is a mystery that takes place on the North Fork.
"It's not chic, because we don't have the beach," Ms. Scoppettone said. "It could be opening night of 'Titanic' in July, and you would still get into the local theater."
The memory of the ocean apparently haunts many of these writers, but none said they would trade their rocky, waveless beaches for the infamous traffic jams that come with the South Fork's sandy seaside.
"Every summer I make two or three trips to go to the Hamptons to go to the beach," said the novelist Connie Schraft, who owns a second home in Orient. Ms. Schraft is at work on her third novel, "No More Street."
"I walk out onto the sand, and nearly cry, 'I'm missing the beach, the light, the water!' " Ms. Schraft said. "Then I pull back into the traffic on Montauk Highway, and I think, nothing can be worth this hassle."
Of course the North Fork's miles of public and private waterfront property along the sound and bay do offer the writers some consolation.
"Everywhere you look, the street ends in water," said the novelist Abigail Thomas, whose book "Herb's Pajamas" has just been published.
Ms. Thomas spent summers as a child in Amagansett with her father, the writer Lewis Thomas, but she now lives year-round in the village of Greenport, which is the Shelter Island ferry's north port. Ms. Thomas said she visits her children and grandchildren on the South Fork only on weekdays in the summer.
"East Hampton used to be the quietest, most boring little town," Ms. Thomas said. "It's now become a stage set for everyone from Manhattan."
To writers like Rob Buchanan, who reports on his participation in extreme sports for both Outside and Details magazines, the North Fork is an affordable, year-round paradise.
"In a nautical sense, we are totally surrounded by very usable water," said Mr. Buchanan. "I can fish at the end of my street. You can sail 25 miles to Montauk and you are in the open Atlantic. In October you can put on a mask and grab up your quota of scallops in 10 minutes."
Real estate brokers may enthuse about the North Fork's being "the next Hamptons." But most writers said this gave an unrealistically bullish gloss to a strip of water-lapped, economically depressed farmland where the income of the leisure class is separated from the wealth in the Hamptons by more than the Peconic Bay.
"That book 'Heaven on Earth' is the Norman Rockwell version of things," said the journalist Greg Palast, referring to a volume of photography that portrays the North Fork as a hybrid of the French countryside crossed with Nantucket.
"Those photographs don't include the migrant workers or the marine equipment that's been sitting and rusting in your neighbor's backyard for 10 years," said Mr. Palast, who writes on American white collar crime and government regulations for The Guardian in London.
"Greenport is the kind of place where two guys buy a big old Victorian house together and spend a lot of money fixing it up, while next door to them someone is moving a refrigerator onto the porch so they have more space to store beer," said John D. Williams Jr.., who moved to the village 25 years ago.
Mr. Williams has had two screenplays optioned and published "Everything Scrabble," a guide to the game.
"The North Fork doesn't demand financial or worldly success or status, and yet it's not provincial," said Peggy Gormley, a sreenwriter and actress who is a partner with Harvey Keitel in The Goat Singers film production company.
"There's a middle class, a professional class and a working class," said Ms. Gormley, who rents an apartment as a year-round retreat in Greenport. "Theoretically, if we could afford the Hamptons, we wouldn't go there."
The novelist Alan Furst, who lives among the burgeoning South Fork community of writers in Sag Harbor, confirmed that when the summer crowd leaves in the fall, Sag Harbor's frenetic social pace ebbs, and full-time writers-in-residence go back to work.
"The line of Mercedes in front of Caldor's disappears, and Sag Harbor Village becomes a village of working people again," Mr. Furst said. "There are a lot of writers here in the winter, and it's quiet socially."
But for those North Fork writers who are full-time residents, the isolation of the winters is not always inspiring or enchanting.
"It's bucolic and it's isolated, but it is also isolating," said Mr. Palast, who confessed that he may eventually move with his wife and children to a more cosmopolitan setting.
"The phone doesn't ring, and there are no art openings," said Mr. Buchanan. "It's quiet as the tomb, and that's really good when you're on deadline. Social opportunities in the winter, however, seem to be limited to the Whiskey Wind Bar."
But as the quality of coffee improves on the North Fork, andwords like merlot and chardonnay pass into local parlance and more farms stands offer organic produce, many reclusive North Fork writers wonder if things will change.
"I found a Prada dress for $3 marked down from $6 in our secondhand store, the Opportunity Shop," said Ms. Reed warily. "But there's still only one French restaurant and nowhere to shop."
"I was in the I.G.A., when a guy pulled up in a Mercedes," said Mr. Williams. "He left the car running and forced his way into the cashier's face to ask, 'Do you have mesquite?' She said, 'Mosquito spray?' and he said, 'No, mesquite, mesquite!"'
The television writer and performer Billy Kimball, who spent summers on the North Fork as a child and keeps a full-time residence in Cutchogue, took a more jaundiced view of the rumors of the demise of the North Fork's glamourless bucolic charm.
"The government put up money to erect a beautiful hand-painted wooden sign, that says, 'Welcome to Long Island Wine Country,' " Mr. Kimball said. "Underneath it, a farmer had nailed a piece of cardboard that said, 'Pigs for Sale,' with his phone number.
"No matter how much they try to Hamptonize the North Fork," said Mr. Kimball, "it's always going to be the kind of place where a local farmer has a new litter of pigs and can't see the point of a perfectly good signpost going to waste."

GRAPHIC: Photo: North Fork writers: Peggy Gormley, Sandra Scoppettone, Greg Palast, Terry Reed and John D. Williams Jr. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1401 words

HEADLINE: Q&A/Bishop Peter Rosazza;
A Mission in the Archdiocese of Hartford

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
SINCE 1978, Peter Rosazza has served as auxiliary bishop for the Archdiocese of Hartford, which encompasses about 220 parishes and 800,000 Roman Catholics in Hartford, New Haven and Litchfield counties.
Bishop Rosazza, 63, was born in New Haven and raised in Torrington. After his ordination in 1961, he served as parish priest in West Hartford and taught Spanish, French, and Italian at St. Thomas Seminary in Bloomfield. He began his ministry to the Spanish-speaking community in 1972 at Sacred Heart Church in the north end of Hartford, where he became a voice for the poor. Bishop Rosazza now works from the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven. 
 In a recent interview, he discussed his work. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How did the experience of being a priest in a poor Spanish-speaking parish influence you?
A. It was a turning point in my life. It was from riches to rags in a sense. I saw urban poverty. People came from a place which was so different, Puerto Rico, with beautiful sun and sea. They never had to put up with the winter before. Whole families would show up at the end of October with clothes that one would wear in July. So we had all sorts of social services -- clothing, food, furniture, counseling and advocacy.
In 1986 the U.S. Catholic bishops published a document on the U.S. economy called Economic Justice for All. I made the motion to have this study done. If I hadn't had the experience at Sacred Heart in Hartford, I don't think I would have been ready for that economic critique.
Q. What are your duties as bishop?
A. My main commitment is the ministry to the Spanish speaking. We have about 20 parishes that have services in Spanish in the archdiocese. On the national level, I'm the bishop advisor for the National Catholic Student Coalition and I'm on two committees of the Bishops Conference -- home missions and migration and refugees.
Q. What issues does the migration and refugees committee deal with?
A. Anything legislatively that concerns immigrants or migrants. We mounted a big lobbying effort about cuts to legal immigrants. Since the cuts were made, there has been a constant effort to get legal immigrants covered at least by food stamps. We work very hard to show that the image of the immigrant shouldn't be a negative one.
We have counselors for refugees and migrants throughout the U.S. We have a ministry for truckers, people on the move, gypsies. We have coordinators that work with many different communities -- the Vietnamese, the Hmongs, the Chinese, the Koreans, the myriad Spanish-speaking countries, Brazil.
Q. What issue concerns you most in Connecticut?
A. I was very concerned about welfare reform. The bishops of Connecticut worked hard to make sure that what was supposed to be reform wasn't a disaster.
The A.F.D.C. grant is gone now, and in its place there is a 21-month period maximum. We're a watchdog on that, to see how poor people's lives are being affected.
Q. You have spoken out against physician-assisted suicide. Why shouldn't someone suffering from a painful, terminal illness have the right to assistance in ending his or her life?
A. Tough cases make bad law. Do we make law because of a few extremely difficult cases? A woman whose husband has abused her for years finally shoots him. Perhaps she was justified. But does society make a law saying that under these circumstances a wife may kill her husband? Hospice care givers say that the terminally ill and those in pain want pain control and to be surrounded by family or others who will support them in the dying process.
It's a slippery slope. Once you start, what happens? A very powerful point is the intrusion into the consciousness of people, especially the frail elderly. One can imagine an elderly mother saying to herself, "Do they want me to ask for euthanasia now?" when she sees the family come in and knows that they're angry because their inheritance is being dissipated. And no society should ever let that happen to people.
The American Medical Association is opposed to it. The doctor wants to be seen as a healing person. But now, if I get old, and here comes the doctor; what does that mean?
Q. In January, you were one of a group of 54 bishops who called for an end to sanctions against Iraq. Why do you favor an end to sanctions?
A. We have a large body of Catholic social teaching and ethics. People have basic rights -- to life, food, clothing, shelter, basic education, medical care and a job. If sanctions are imposed, then the basic needs of people somehow have to be assured. In this case they are not. A million people have died as a result. UNESCO says that every month 4,500 children die of malnutrition. There's no potable water outside of Baghdad.
Bishop Thomas Gumbleton of Detroit went over to Baghdad with a group and they talked to Church leaders. There is a sizable Catholic community there too, the Caldeans. They're very upset about the lack of food and medicine. Some of us undertook a fast. Several times I woke up very hungry at night. I could have eaten if I had wished to, but the Iraqi children can't.
Since that time, there was the whole question of military intervention. My position is to make sure that all diplomatic means have been exhausted, because the people have already suffered too much.
Q. What is your position on women in the priesthood?
A. If you want to talk about women in ministry, as a bishop of the church I have to be obedient to the Pope. But separate from the ordination question is the number of women in ministerial roles in the Catholic Church that we never saw 35 years ago -- in hospitals, in prisons, and as campus ministers. There are women who work full time in many parishes. And some of the priestless parishes now have women administrators. So the people are getting used to this. The involvement of women raises consciousness about the importance of women as they use their many beautiful talents in ministry.
Q. You have been active in promoting cooperation among the different religions. Why is that important?
A. If we worship God, we should work together for the common good. I like to avoid the concept that all religions are the same. But there's a lot of good in each. We're children of the same God.
The other reason is to face down secularism, which is a very prevalent philosophy -- you know, there shouldn't be any kind of rules anywhere. This might be a time of revival -- even that million man Promise Keepers event was very powerful. Most wives would be very happy if their husbands promised to be faithful to them and to spend more time with them and the kids. Maybe there is a fundamentalistic thrust here, but so what? Maybe we're heading for a time of revival now in the face of blatant secularism.
Q. There are people who believe they are living spiritual, moral lives outside of organized religion. What do you say to them?
A. Fine. But I wonder how long people can continue to live that kind of life without the sustenance of a community of faith.
All religions are communitarian religions. They were always communities. People got together to listen to God's word. The values were held by tradition. As the years go on, as we've seen in the last 25 years, you have an invasion of other thinking, and so values often dissipate.
There are exceptions. For example, persons who are not members of any organized religion but are very generous with time and talent and are prayerful. There are also some atheists who are very principled. Organized religion at least is a help to a lot of people, including myself. To listen to God's word, to be confronted by it day in and day out, to try to live it in such ways that I do put God first, to love my neighbor as myself. That is not easy.
Q. What challenges face the Catholic Church as we enter the next millennium?
A. No. 1 is lack of clergy -- because the priesthood is limited to celibate males. In the archdiocese, we're going to need 50 priests within the next five years because of retirement. This year we'll ordain 5. Our average age is 59. There are some dioceses where things are worse. The indifference of a lot of young people to religion is another challenge, though they're not indifferent to God. I can see it in the students in the National Catholic Student Coalition. One notices a deep spirituality in many students.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Rosazza, auxiliary bishop for the Archdiocese of Hartford. "If we worship God, we should work together for the common good." (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Interview

ORGANIZATION: ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH

PUB-DATE: May 17, 1998,

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2357 words

HEADLINE: In an Anniversary Year, Quest for Land Heats Up

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
The youngish couple were strutting along the matted-down carpet of leaves that rolled through the woods beyond the house they had just bought. Yes, strutting. They were marveling at the turn their lives had taken: the deal, the house, the pool, the ocean a bike ride away, the woods as fresh and as fine as when Indians padded along trails like this one. Even the birds: happy, fluttery creatures with small red and yellow stripes on their blue-black wings.
Flying rep ties, the wife said. The husband laughed. 
 Their Sunday afternoon reverie lasted a few hundred yards. The trail ended at a freshly paved cul-de-sac where they could smell the tar, or so it seemed, and they could see the bright red fire hydrant. Above their heads, signs had been nailed to the trees: Lot 21, Lot 22. They spent the rest of the weekend in a panic that their view would be ruined by new houses.
Oh, the things people worry about on eastern Long Island when the midafternoon fog rolls in, creeping across what used to be potato fields, crossing what began as unpaved colonial-era thoroughfares. These roads are now dotted by restaurants that stay open almost all year, a sign that the "season" keeps getting longer. For in this year of anniversaries, when East Hampton celebrates its 350th, and Montauk the centennial of Theodore Roosevelt's encampment there at the end of the Spanish-American War, the real estate broker's mantra of location, location, location has given way to something more basic: land, land, land.
Indeed, land is to eastern Long Island what earthquakes are to California and tsunami are to Hawaii: the subtext of everyday conversation, if not every conversation. This is the case on streets whose residents' names appear in bold-faced type in the newspapers: the road in East Hampton where the fashion designer Donna Karan and the rap impresario Sean (Puff Daddy) Combes have houses -- she two, he one. And there is the block where the life style doyenne Martha Stewart and the real estate developer Harry Macklowe have taken their backyard border war to court. Centuries ago, neighbors who could not agree on where one's land ended and the other's began had muskets. Now they have lawyers.
Sorry, glitterati (and literati), but eastern Long Island is more obsessed with land than with celebrity, and that has led to a peculiar conversational shorthand: "one point two" is money, not miles. "Routinely I get inquiries for $1 million, $1.2 million," said a man who bought a five-bedroom, four-bath house on one acre south of the Montauk Highway for $175,000 in 1978 and now, sounding somewhat sheepish about his good fortune, did not want to be identified. "To me, that's astonishing. I bought it because I liked the house. It was significant money to me, but still. If I didn't have this house, I couldn't buy this house, even though I have more money now. A million-two would be too much of a stretch."
Yet much as he loves his house, this man understands that its bankability, its appeal to would-be buyers, is not its architectural charm but the little acre beneath it. He explained: "Ten years ago, I said to the guy who handles my insurance, 'do I have enough insurance on my house?' He said: 'Don't worry about it; your house could burn down tomorrow. The land is what the real value is.' "
It is difficult not to encounter others who say much the same -- just take a random Sunday afternoon walk along a beach on the South Fork, where sea birds race-walk along the sand, and the waves look like churning lace. Peggy Sheehan, a Manhattanite who was visiting friends in Sagaponack, lamented that there are "fewer and fewer fields and more and more houses." The ultramodern houses overlooking the beach? "They've been there so long, I kind of accept them," she said.
And the beach itself? "The beach is narrower, but they tell me it will come back by summer," she said. "I know it was wider than this last summer."
And her dog, a 6-year-old Maltese? "Sophie is like a toxic waste dump every summer," Ms. Sheehan said, reciting a litany of shampoos and rinses, fleas and collars and oils. Two summers ago, when she rented a house near Gardiner's Bay in East Hampton, she and Sophie dashed off to the beach for a quick, early-in-the-season romp. "Sophie got six ticks stuck to her, including one on her eyelid," Ms. Sheehan said.
Whine, whine, whine: there is an uneasiness on eastern Long Island, a sense that the city worries people came to escape are catching up. Like the erosion that shrinks backyards by the water, the process is subtle, not something dramatic and instantly noticeable. It is subtler than the Gatsbyesque gossip of outsized deals and oversized blueprints, which inevitably leads to some mention of the 29-bedroom house with the 20-car garage that conforms to zoning regulations. (If you're going to have a 53,000-square-foot house, you need a garage that large, don't you?)
And then there are the complaints about traffic and tank-sized Mercedeses that go roaring by: just try making a left turn on 27. (Some call it the Montauk Highway, but others spit out just the number: "27," the way they call another much complained-about highway, the Long Island Expressway, "495.")
There are also the fears that the distinct identities of individual communities are being blurred. Old-money Southampton used to be proud that it was not nouveau-everything, like parts of East Hampton. The areas were as different from each other as rural Sagaponack was from Sag Harbor. Now, fast-track houses are appearing almost everywhere.
Some longtime residents speculate that the tangle of power lines, telephone poles, flat residential streets and magazine-quality houses originated with land purchases made years ago. The boom may be a sign of pent-up demand, with much of the hammering and sawing taking place on plots developers bought earlier and held onto during the recession after the 1987 and 1988 stock market plunges.
In other words, the anxiety comes down to land, land, land. It is true that zoning is tighter in many parts of eastern Long Island. It is also true that more acreage than ever has been protected from real-estate development, thanks to easements and other long-term arrangements worked out by organizations that promote land conservation, including the Nature Conservancy, the Peconic Land Trust and the Group for the South Fork.
Still, the real-estate columns in local newspapers are filled with megabuck transfers -- every week, the prices seem higher. The pressure to sell has land-preservation advocates worried that without open spaces and scenic places, there will be no tourism, no recreational economy.
"We really depend on recreation and tourism," said Marcia Kenny of the Peconic Land Trust, a nonprofit group that has arranged to protect 2,500 acres since the mid-1980's. "Once there's nothing left, nobody's going to want to come out here because it's not going to be pretty and charming and restful."
Some fun seekers complain that it already isn't. Vincent Manzo, who first encountered East Hampton in the early 1980's, when he was in his 20's, talks of "this Riviera feeling," which he says has disappeared.
"I felt glamorous and young and rich," said Mr. Manzo, who now runs a store in East Hampton that sells vintage goods, from furniture to housewares. "Well, I was young. We'd end up at Calvin Klein's house. Steve Rubell would pull up in a limo. Now it's different. Now it doesn't have that fantasy feel. The New York City vibration is coming out here. They've got to drive with their brights on. They've got to be aggressive. They don't know how to leave all that behind."
The information age has only made things worse, he said as he straightened a $10 stack of red-and-white bread plates ("red and white's getting hotter than blue and white"): fax machines and personal computers have let dashboard-pounding New Yorkers live on eastern Long Island year round.
"The only thing I can compare this to is the California gold rush," Mr. Manzo said. "Carpenters kiss the ground they walk on."
No wonder that Adam Janovic, the scion of a Manhattan paint-store chain, is opening a store in Wainscott this summer. "I don't hold myself out there as a prophet," Mr. Janovic said, "but as long as the stock market stays strong, the Hamptons will stay strong. I'm hoping that will last a couple more years." That is plenty of time for him to do some in-store celebrity watching. "We carry the Ralph Lauren paint and the Martha Stewart paint," he said. "They're both locals. We can sell them back some of their own product."
Historians observe that the transformation of eastern Long Island into a series of second-home communities has been going on for most of the 20th century. How different the weekenders are from the original colonial-era farmers and fishermen, who arrived not over the land from New York City, but across Long Island Sound from Connecticut. This year's 350th anniversary in East Hampton, for example, celebrates the arrival of nine settlers who took possession of 30,000 acres. Nancy Hyden Woodward, an author and Hamptons historian, said that the grant of that land from the colonial governors of Connecticut resulted from a deal with the Montauk Indians for "the whole breadth from sea to sea."
The price was a bit more than what Peter Minuit paid for Manhattan: 20 coats, 24 hoes, 24 hatchets, 24 knives and "24 looking glasses," among other things. The nine named their plantation Maidstone; some had been born in the town of that name in England. But soon they were calling this new place Easthampton, one word.
There was a building boom even then: chimneys rose on 8- to 12-acre parcels. "Invitations to settle in Maidstone are extended to persons who can supply a trade that the town lacks," Miss Woodward writes in her book "East Hampton: A Town and Its People, 1648-1994" (Fireplace Press, 1995). "A carpenter from Weathersfield, Conn., a blacksmith from Huntington and a weaver from Southold accept such offers. For moving to Maidstone, each man is given a home lot, acreage for farming and pasturing and exemption from paying taxes."
But the settlers' lives were hardly worry-free. In April 1649, Indians scalped Phoebe Halsey in the herb garden outside her Southampton home. Lion Gardiner, who lived nearby, volunteered to be a hostage to the local tribe while Wyandanch, the sachem of the Indians on eastern Long Island, journeyed to Southampton. On the way, Wyandanch encountered two Pequots from Connecticut, disguised as Long Island Shinnecocks, whom he quickly determined were Halsey's killers. Miss Woodward writes that Lion Gardiner's reward for his bravery was an invitation to live in East Hampton. Robert David Lion Gardiner, his descendant, lives there still; one of Phoebe Halsey's descendants, John Halsey, heads the Peconic Land Trust.
This year's other anniversary marks the Spanish-American War, when the communication age was already beginning. Miss Woodward reports that word that President William McKinley had signed a war resolution reached East Hampton surprisingly rapidly. A correspondent from The Brooklyn Eagle called the drugstore there less than half an hour after McKinley put his name on the document.
Eastern Long Island was involved in the end of the war: Camp Wikoff in Montauk, where Theodore Roosevelt was photographed in his colonel's uniform of high leather boots and broad-brimmed hat, was set up in four days in August 1898 as the debarkation center for about 25,000 troops. The Army hoped to send them home on the Long Island Rail Road, but about 40 miles of track remained to be laid before their troop ships landed.
Camp Wikoff turned out to be as much a medical center as a military camp: in addition to battlefield wounds, the Army had suffered heavy casualties from diseases like malaria and typhoid. There were contaminated water problems at Montauk, too: healthy solders got sick until several 6,000-gallon railroad tank cars rolled in, carrying fresh supplies.
Later, the head of the Women's National War Relief Association appealed for women in East Hampton to make apple sauce ("a good substitute for butter") and care packages for the 9th and 10th Cavalry regiments, which were made up of black soldiers who had not been given the kinds of care packages the Rough Riders had received.
"There must be a screw loose somewhere," The East Hampton Star said in an editorial Miss Woodward quotes in her book, "when Uncle Sam's soldiers, backed by a country of unlimited resources, are allowed to starve on transports and compelled to depend on charity for food when they land upon our shores."
Camp Wikoff sent the last troops home in late October. But the transformation was on: the summer people had found a new destination. Now, a couple of generations later, James Brady, the author of last summer's page-turner "Further Lane" (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95) and the forthcoming "Gin Lane," said another transformation was on.
"The acres and acres of potato farms have become 1-acre or 4-acre or 11-acre mini-estates," he said. "There was a real estate photograph in the newspaper 10 days ago that showed a house on Further Lane from the air on an 11- or 12-acre plot that is up for sale for $19 million."
Still, Mr. Brady said that all the talk about free-spending celebrities in the Hamptons may be just talk: privacy is still possible. "Steven Spielberg is out there," he said, "but I have never in all of those years seen him. I have seen Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger once in the grocery store, in Dreesen's, the famous place where they make the doughnuts. I used to see Jann Wenner a lot because he rode a motorcycle. Bruce Wasserstein lives on Further Lane. I don't know what Bruce Wasserstein looks like. I know who he is." (Mr. Wasserstein is an investment banker and takeover specialist.)
At least, Mr. Brady said, Further Lane has not been cursed with Hollywood-style tour buses cruising past homes of the rich and famous, "with the guy on the loudspeaker saying, 'Here's the writer James Brady's house. That's Mr. Brady pulling weeds.' "
Yet.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Hamptons Old Hat? Try a Nassau Summer Rental

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
TIRED of coping with traffic jams on roads leading to the Hamptons, some city dwellers looking for a summer getaway are renting houses much closer to home -- in the bedroom communities of Nassau County, a short commute from midtown Manhattan.
What they are finding on the North Shore is a rural countryside criss-crossed by quiet roads and still dotted with horse farms and vegetable stands and large estates that add to the feeling of seclusion and privacy. 
 Moreover, residents have access to beaches that either are town-owned or are maintained by incorporated villages and homeowners' associations. And because the beaches are on Long Island Sound, many have docking for boats.
While the South Shore is more congested, renters can find houses there within a few minutes' walk of ocean beaches in communities that are less than an hour from Manhattan by train.
Unlike many houses in the Hamptons that are purchased as investments to be rented out, houses available for rent in Nassau tend to be the permanent residences of owners who either have vacation houses elsewhere or who travel. Rentals run the gamut from co-ops and condominiums to mansions.
An investment banker who spoke on condition of anonymity said he used to rent in the Hamptons, but now rents on the North Shore for several reasons.
"The commute is a lot shorter, but the biggest issue for me is that I really prefer the relaxed atmosphere and the privacy of the North Shore to the hype of the Hamptons," he said. "The Hamptons are a lot more glamorous, for sure, but what's the point of having all that summer entertainment if you can't get a reservation in a restaurant?"
Brokers say that because the popularity of summer rentals on the North Shore has been growing, their main problem is finding houses for their customers. Most have only a handful of listings available.
Adding to the demand are families who rent a house for the summer because they want to become familiar with the area before purchasing a house, said Jean Mansueto, the owner of Century 21 Coast in Bayville.
The healthy economy has also helped the market.
"Last year, customers started calling me in March and April for rental properties," said Lori A. Grafstein, an associate broker who is in charge of the rental department at the Douglas Elliman-Jane Hayes brokerage in Locust Valley. "For this year they started calling right after Christmas and I haven't had that much to show them,"
And rents are up 20 percent over what they were a year ago, she said. A house that last year rented for $12,000 a month is now $15,000 a month, she said.
Still, Nassau rents are still much lower than those in the Hamptons, brokers say.
Typical of houses Mrs. Grafstein rented for this summer is a seven-bedroom, six-and-a-half bath contemporary in Lattingtown priced at $15,500 a month from Memorial Day to Labor Day.
The nine-year-old house, which is on four acres, has an indoor racquetball court, a new pool and a new tennis court. In addition, as town residents, the tenants have the right to use local beaches and public golf courses. Many of her customers already belong to private country clubs on the North Shore, Mrs. Grafstein said, which is another reason that the idea of having a house there is so appealing.
Among houses she still has available is a 24-room estate in Centre Island with a private beach, sweeping views of Long Island Sound, a pool and a deep-water dock. It even has a helicopter landing pad. The flying time to Manhattan is 12 minutes. By car, the city is about an hour away. The rent, which includes maintenance of the grounds but no utilities, is $37,500 a month for the summer season.
On the same 35-acre gated estate as the mansion are seven smaller residences ranging in size from two to four bedrooms with rents of $4,500 to $12,000 a month.
THE smallest, a two-bedroom, one-bath cottage renting for $4,500, is one of two still available. Though rustic, it has a very private setting surrounded by lawns with unobstructed water views. The lawn leads down to a private cove. The house shares two tennis courts with the other rental houses.
Mrs. Grafstein's other properties include a four-bedroom, two-bath contemporary in Lattingtown, overlooking a golf course, which is available for August for $7,000. Another is a six-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath turn-of-the century Victorian on two acres in Laurel Hollow, which is available for $10,000 a month.
Margaret Faughnan, the owner of the Laurel Hollow house, who is a Manhattan real estate broker, said she and her husband, Henry, are renting the home, which they have owned 26 years, because they plan to spend the summer in Europe.
The house is a five-minute drive from a private beach with docking for boats and it is a mile from the Long Island Rail Road Station in Syosset; the trip to Manhattan takes 50 minutes. Yet riding trails are across the street, and the house has a paddock where horses can be kept, Mrs. Faughnan said.
"We have so many calls coming in from people who don't want to do the Hamptons any more because of the crowds and the Sunday night traffic," said Vera J. Wiedenhaefer, a broker with the Daniel Gale agency in East Norwich. "So they are coming to this area, preferably to a place near the water. Oyster Bay Cove, Cove Neck, Cove Spring and Laurel Hollow are very popular."
One of the houses she is showing is a 34-year-old colonial in Cove Neck with four bedrooms and three bathrooms, a library and a family room. All the rooms have water views. The house is available for $60,000 for the season. The property includes a pool, a tennis court, a private beach and a dock.
Another house, this one listed by Connie Kelly, who is in charge of the rental department at the same Daniel Gale agency, is a restored three-bedroom, two-and-a-half barn in Laurel Hollow in a secluded setting near the beach. It is available, but only for August, for $6,000, and it is her only current listing, Mrs. Kelly said.
Brokers say that because so few houses come on the market just for the summer, tenants sometimes rent them year-round at a much reduced monthly rent, and use them on weekends as well. The Laurel Hollow barn, for example, is available year-round for $2,600 a month.
Although year-round rentals are seldom furnished, furnishings can be rented through companies like International Furniture Rentals in Jericho, which charges about $400 to $800 a month for furniture for a four-bedroom house, with the price dependent on the length of stay.
Summer renters are often required to pay as much as one month's rent for security. The minimum security is usually $5,000. Tenants also pay all utilities and the broker's fee, which can amount to 10 percent of the total rental amount. Landlords usually provide a landscaping service, but monthly pool maintenance is often left up to the tenant. The full summer's rent is paid before the tenant moves in.
Summer rentals are more plentiful in Long Beach and other resort areas on the South Shore where condominiums and co-op apartments in oceanfront buildings also become available.
Like their counterparts on the North Shore, many of the homeowners are not professional landlords. They usually rent out their houses or their apartments because they live elsewhere during the summer season.
For example, Georgeann and Noel Corpuel, who own a three-bedroom, three-bath colonial in Lido Beach, run a children's camp in Pennsylvania, so they are away all summer.
"Since we are never here, we decided that renting our house for the summer would give us some nice income, and we've been doing that for 25 years," Mrs. Corpuel said. "In all that time, we have had only one bad experience." The house rents for $15,000 for the season and they already have a tenant.
Prices in Long Beach and its neighboring towns start at $8,000 for the summer season for small two- and three-bedroom cottages on the city's west end and range up to about $25,000 for the season for a three- to four-bedroom house, said Richard B. Nunziata, the manager of the Century 21 Petrey brokerage in Long Beach.
Typical of his listings is a four-bedroom, two-bath house in Point Lookout, which is two blocks from the beach. It rents for $20,000 for the season. A two-bedroom, one-bath house in Long Beach, on a canal with docking for a boat, can be rented for $24,000. And a one-bedroom, one-and-half-bath duplex condominium apartment with two terraces overlooking the ocean is available for $18,000.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Giving a Suburban Sprawl a Sense of Community

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LIKE other developing suburbs in New Jersey, Washington Township in Mercer County is a sprawling community with a patchwork of tract houses and a highway shopping strip, but no communal heart.
"We do not have a center point, a place people can go to meet or congregate," said Glen E. Beebe, a 10-year resident who is the township's Mayor. 
 Determined to change that, local officials are advancing a plan, adopted last year, to bring that slice of traditional small-town America, the town center, to suburbia. The plan outlines a mixed-use development within walking distance of businesses, a community in which home buyers can choose from residences of many styles and prices.
In the process they hope that the plan -- the result of 12 years of discussions and negotiations with landowners, developers and government agencies -- will turn the tables on suburban sprawl, preserve open space and give their township not only an identity distinct from its neighbors, but, said Mayor Beebe, a sense of community as well.
The new town center will eventually contain up to 250,000 square feet of retail space and professional offices and up to 1,350 residences -- from town houses and rental apartments to duplex houses and detached homes -- spread over 330 acres in the western sector of this 20-square-mile community of 8,500 residents. It is to be developed at an estimated cost of $250 million over the next 10 to 15 years.
Two builders have already committed to the project. One is Sharbell Development Corporation of Hamilton Township, which has been working with Washington Township officials on the plan for the last five years. The other is Westminster Properties, the new construction arm of the Kushner Companies of Florham Park, which came aboard in the last year. Principals of both companies said they expected to begin construction by the end of this year or early in 1999.
The plan also calls for bike lanes, public squares, a major anchor attraction such as a theater for live performances -- to keep the communal center lively at night -- and a greenbelt around three-quarters of the development area, bordered on the east by Route 130 and bisected by Route 33. The township's municipal complex already sits along Route 130 on the eastern edge of the area, and there is a shopping strip on the western edge.
The local middle school stands just outside the town center. Within it is Robbinsville -- with Windsor one of two historic cores around which the township grew up during its early days as a farming community. Those agrarian roots, which are still present today (6,000 of the township's 13,000 acres are farmland or open space), are what the town-center plan will help to preserve.
All of this, said Robert F. Melvin, the township's director of planning, will be accomplished in ways that strive to make growth an equal partner with preservation. When the town center project is completed the hope is "that grandparents will live on the same block as their grandchildren," he said.
To achieve a visual sense of nostalgia the homes will be in traditional styles popular between 1890 to 1930, with design principles that call for, among other things, such evocations of the past as front porches. The houses will sit on 2,000- to 7,000-square-foot lots. While prices have not yet been set, they are expected to be $150,000 to $300,000 for individual homes, said Mr. Melvin.
The rental apartments -- the number and rents have not been determined -- will be above the stores. So that the development becomes part of the entire community, there will be no gate, homeowners' association or even a name for the development, he added.
That Washington Township took the lead on the project, rather than a developer, which traditionally has been the case, makes it distinct in New Jersey, industry professionals said. It is also significant, they added, because it breathes life into the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan.
The state plan encourages growth in established areas where sewers, highways and mass transit links are available. In less developed areas where those facilities are lacking, the plan tries to manage growth by encouraging mixed-use and compact development such as in designated town centers. Last month Washington Township became a designated town center, making it one of 36 in the state, but the only one that is basically being built from scratch.
State agencies give priority for approvals and financing for physical plant improvements to designated centers because they are in compliance with the state plan, which Mr. Melvin said would be helpful "in taking the plan to the next level." That level includes making the improvements necessary to accommodate the project, he said.
THE Office of State Planning calls Washington Township's town-center plan a model. "In terms of suburban development it shows that the state plan is not just rhetoric, but that it really works," said Herb Simmens, executive director of the semiautonmous agency, which is the staff arm for the State Planning Commission.
The town-center plan also won the community development award last year from the Middlesex Somerset Mercer Regional Council, a nonprofit planning organization in central New Jersey.
"We have been promoting the concept of town centers since the mid-80's as a vision for a different future," said Jon A. Carnegie, the group's vice president of planning. "Essentially, it rearranges growth in a different land pattern."
If there is no change to the familiar development pattern of subdivisions and shopping centers the region, like the state, "will see the same old sprawl" and more traffic that potentially could choke off growth, he said. Those concerns are what prompted Washington Township to pursue the town-center plan as an alternative to sprawl. Through the proper arrangement and design of public spaces and buildings, the township "is better able to accept growth while creating a sense of community character," Mr. Melvin said.
As such, the new town center reflects the principles of neotraditionalism, also called the New Urbanism, which says that walkable streets, attractive public spaces and a close-by town center can help define a community. One of the largest such communities is Celebration, the enclave that Disney is creating on a former cow pasture in Orlando, Fla. Eventually it will contain 8,000 homes.
Getting to this point has not been easy because to a large degree their plan preceded the state plan, Mr. Melvin said, adding that the recession also slowed progress. Now all the people involved -- from the developers to every level of government -- "are rowing in the same direction," he said.
How home buyers will respond to the concept remains to be seen. But the developers involved with the town-center plan are betting it will catch on.
Jeffrey Freireich, a principal of the Kushner Companies, said his concern became involved with the town center project because "the concept is exciting, different." He also said that the township's central location, including access to Interstates 95 and 195 and Route 130, was a plus. "And the approval process goes faster, because you're not fighting with the town," said Mr. Freireich.
As now planned, Kushner will build up to 275 residences and 50,000 square feet of commercial space. Construction is to start in 1999.
"Our position is to create a competitively priced alternative to conventional suburban subdivision," said Thomas Troy, senior vice president of Sharbell Development, "and in that context this plan makes a lot of sense."
Mr. Troy said his company still had a "bit of reluctance because we don't control our own destiny." But, he added, the plan "is an opportunity" to do business in Washington Township "versus other towns that throw up a brick wall of no development."
Under the plan Sharbell can build some 550 homes and 170,000 square feet of commercial Space. Mr. Troy said he expected to present plans for 110 initial homes by this fall, start pre-construction sales in the next nine to 12 months and then begin construction.
"It is not for everyone," Mr. Troy said of the town center plan. "But there will be enough buyers who recognize the appeal of living in place with neighborhoods and a sense of community."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Blocked in Stamford, Cendant to Move to Wilton

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
THE Cendant Corporation's decision last month to move from here to Wilton shows the level of maturity that the Stamford office market has reached. With a vacancy rate of around 6 percent, the city cannot accommodate companies that need to expand.
"Space here is tight," said Robin Stein, director of land use planning for the city. "No buildings have any significant empty spaces." 
 Cendant is the name adopted last year by CUC International of Stamford and HFS Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., following their merger. Among other things, the merged company is a franchiser of hotels and real estate brokerages and owns brands such as Avis, Days Inn and Ramada Inn and Coldwell Banker real estate brokerages.
Since 1981 Cendant and its predecessor have been renting space in Stamford. The company has a total of 143,000 square feet scattered through four Summer Street buildings owned by four different landlords.
In an effort to consolidate by building a 440,000-square-foot office complex on 28 acres off Long Ridge Road in Stamford, Cendant applied for a zone change from residential to commercial in 1997. But the plan was strongly opposed at public hearings and rejected by Stamford's Planning and Zoning Board last May.
"I think Cendant's attempt to change the zoning was ill-advised," said Mayor Dannel Malloy, "and led to some hard feelings on their part, so they took their plans elsewhere. Stamford is not a major campus setting. We don't have locations for that. We're sorry to see Cendant go, but we win more than we lose and many of the 500 to 600 jobs involved will be retained by local residents."
Kip Bergstrom, Stamford's Director of Economic Development, noted that it had been a "longstanding policy of the city to locate development downtown."
"That comes at a price occasionally," he said. "When the planning board made the decision it knew that Cendant would leave the city. But it's part of Stamford's function to be for the rest of Connecticut what New York has been for Stamford -- a means of capturing jobs and, after a period of 10 to 20 years, passing them on to outlying towns like Shelton, Trumbull and now Wilton."
Notwithstanding the buoyant attitudes of developers who are building and quickly renting up speculative office buildings in outlying towns, developers of the two prime downtown Stamford locations are not prepared to follow suit.
"We don't believe that in the 90's it's prudent to build on spec," said Scott Toombs, head of Toombs Development Company in New Canaan. He owns the vacant four-acre tract called Parcel 38 behind the Stamford Town Center mall. Nicknamed "the hole in the ground" because Mr. Toombs has excavated the tract in anticipation of construction, it has stood empty for two years waiting for an anchor tenant.
"Tenants are watching their cost factors," Mr. Toombs said, "so I don't think it's smart to pay so much for money that rents have to be higher." He was referring to the fact that construction loans on speculative buildings are higher than those for new buildings that are preleased. According to Mr. Bergstrom, rents approaching the mid-$30's per square foot in Stamford are still a bargain compared to $50 a square foot in midtown Manhattan.
The other prime downtown property, at Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard, is owned by Hines Interests L.P. Plans for a 480,000-square-foot office tower designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill have received the required municipal approvals. What is lacking is a major tenant. "We are encouraged by the continued strengthening of the market and hopeful about a tenant," said Thomas M. Craig, senior vice president of the Houston-based company.
But the Louis Dreyfus Property Group, the real estate arm of S.A. Dreyfus & Cie in Paris and developer of Cendant's new home in Wilton, has broken ranks with its more conservative counterparts here. It will proceed with construction of a speculative building designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill on Washington Boulevard, opposite Swiss Bank's new Stamford headquarters.
With a minor change in zoning regulations Louis Dreyfus -- whose parent deals in commodities, among other things -- can build up to 500,000 square feet in 25 stories. "We will start as soon as we have our approvals," said Jeffrey I. Sussman, president of Louis Dreyfus, "and we will go for the maximum space. We believe that there are one or two large users seeking up to 400,000 square feet." Groundbreaking is targeted for the fall.
"I don't think Stamford had reached saturation," Mr. Sussman said. "It will definitely be a growth market for quite some time -- not just from the exodus from New York, but from tenants in Greenwich where restrictions on the size of buildings force tenants to look elswhere for more space."
For the last 10 years, Louis Dreyfus has maintained its American headquarters in Wilton, sharing a 200,000-square-foot office building on a 57-acre tract with two tenants -- the world headquarters of Deloitte & Touche accountants and CSC Weston Group, a marketing and consulting firm.
In 1990, plans by Dreyfus had been approved for two additional office buildings on the same tract totaling 323,186 square feet, plus an additional 13,778 square feet for a cafeteria, fitness center and structured parking, according to Wendy Johnson, planning director for Wilton. She said all approvals were valid for 10 years.
AT the time the Cendant deal presented itself, said Mr. Sussman, "we were in the process of making a decision to build without a commitment and probably would have gone ahead with one building."
"We certainly had enough interest," he said. "We consider ourselves a small to mid-size company and since we can't purchase existing buildings in competition with the REIT's, we must make money by going the value-added route -- develop, build, lease and manage." Louis Dreyfus owns and manages more than 3 million square feet of office space in Europe and North America, and has approvals for constructing 1.4 million square feet more in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, and 2 million square feet here and abroad. Its partner in this and other projects is Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund II.
The Wilton site, 10 Westport Road, is on Route 33, just off the junction with Route 7. A long entrance driveway becomes a winding road lined with stately trees and leading past woods, dry stone walls, rocky outcroppings, a large pond and a meadow where Canada geese and their spring hatchlings forage for food. The existing building, designed by Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo & Associates of Hamden, also designers of the Cendant project, is surrounded by plantings of specimen trees, shrubs and flowers.
The two new buildings of 156,000 square feet each, costing a total of $70 million, will be joined by an enclosed connector and called 20 Westport Road. Cendant expects to take 100,000 square feet in each building and Dreyfus will lease out the rest.
Cendant's recent problems with accounting irregularities in some of its units sent its 1997 earnings down by $100 million to $115 million, resulting in a precipitate drop in its stock price and a number of management changes. But the episode is not expected to affect its plans in Wilton.
"We are a very strong company with very strong cash flow," said Eliot Bloom, spokesman for real estate at Cendant. "We just acquired National Parking Corporation in Great Britain for $1.3 billion."

HEADLINE: Adieu, My Beloved House, I Knew It Well

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA DREIFUS 

 BODY:
WHAT I remember most about the December 1979 afternoon that I went to closing on a three-bedroom ranch in the pine woods outside Sag Harbor was the alternating sense of excitement and dread I felt.
In the late 1970's it was rare for a single woman to buy property on her own. Banks routinely discriminated in their lending policies, making mortgages tough for women to obtain. Moreover, the entire emotional landscape of home ownership seemed linked to marriage and couplehood. Wasn't it men ---husbands, boyfriends -- who had an almost genetic understanding of carpentry and plumbing? Didn't one need four sets of hands and two stable incomes to keep home and acreage from turning to rot? 
 I, Claudia Dreifus, was a city-bred divorced journalist, deeply ignorant of lawn seed and electric wiring. I longed for a place where I could write, cook, hike and bike -- and not answer to anyone for it. But I feared the responsibility. At the house closing, I kept hearing the voice of my dead father, Henry H. Dreifus, a lifelong socialist, whispering, "Property is theft -- property is theft." What on earth was I getting myself into?
A lot of fun, it turned out. At least, at first. Decorating the place with yard-sale odds and ends was a kick. Once the gray-shingled ranch was furnished, I gave it a name -- "Mandalay" -- after the grand mansion in Daphne Du Maurier's "Rebecca." Next I bought myself an electric drill and a book called "The You Don't Need a Man to Fix It."
Also: I learned about bird watching. I purchased hiking boots -- and investigated the flora and fauna of the undeveloped forest behind my house. I bought a car, a blue Toyota, and swore I'd learn how to drive it -- though I never did. And yes, this city kid planted the beginnings of a garden. Sunday mornings, I'd dig around the soil in front of the house humming the theme song from the film, "Exodus."This land is mine, God gave this land to me.
On the downside, one didn't have to be on the East End long before running into the class war between the local merchants and the weekend homeowners from New York. Property may have been "theft," as my socialist father claimed, but in the Hamptons it was property owners who were stolen from.
During my first Hampton years, a large number of my business contacts involved -- um, how to put it? -- deception: padded grocery bills; insurance coverage that was nothing like what the broker said it was; a phony repair on my water-well; billing for yard work that was never done, endless charges for goods and services never rendered.
And what could a busy person do? Spend the weekend fighting these genial crooks? Waste a midweek navigating the Suffolk County court system? If you didn't want to negate the whole reason for owning a country house -- relaxation -- you shut up and moved on.
Or you grumbled. At posh Hampton dinner parties, the main topic was usually thieving contractors. At East End brunches you'd meet best-selling authors obsessing about their plumbing bills. The name of a great carpenter -- and I eventually had one, Yves LePine of Noyac -- was a prized secret shared only with closest friends.
I should have known this -- but in the country, the outside grows. This insight came to me when a friend guesting at my dacha reported a flood of water streaming out the toilet. A $1,200 plumber's house call netted this astonishing diagnosis: vines from the forest were eating the sewer pipes. Indeed, if one didn't apply a little judicious Agent Orange, the forest was likely to creep up and envelope the entire homestead.
Vines from the woods grew like mutants from a horror movie -- as did colonies of carpenter ants, who snacked on my wooden deck, forcing me to replace it repeatedly. Indeed, the only thing that didn't grow at Mandalay was the front lawn, which was as bald as Kojack's head and the shame of the neighborhood.
In the 1980's my jouralistic career took a sharp turn. I began working on stories that took me to far-flung places throughout the U.S.A. and also abroad. The more I traveled, the more of a burden the house became. I hated being in bad-phone countries like Nicaragua, Chile and South Africa, and ringing up East End real-estate agents or plumbers with house emergencies.
After a while, with my new stepped-up work life pressing, and with travels, renting out the house began began to make economic sense. But putting the house up for rent was a serious life-experience.
For a small deposit, this landlord was lending tenants thousands of dollars worth of house, antiques and appliances. Anything could go wrong. The most astounding things did. One year there was a famous tennis pro who took the place and let his cat use it as a urinal. Another summer, a horsewoman left me fleas. There were tenants who didn't like my tchotchkes and tossed them out. There were others who liked them very much and took them home.
One winter I let the house to a man with immpecable references (Pierre Franey and Joseph Heller). References or not, this gentlemen was so spooky that my Sag Harbor neighbors were soon wondering if he wasn't the serial rapist then terrifying Long Island. My tenant man wasn't a rapist; he was just weird. After he had vacated the place, I found huge black footprints on the master bedroom ceiling. How the footprints got up there is an interesting question.
More positively, two babies were conceived by summer tenants at Mandalay. A terrific book -- Samuel G. Freedman's "Upon This Rock" -- was written there.
And I did get to use the place periodically -- including full time for a delicious two-year period where I got a lot of writing done.
I'm not sure exactly when I decided to sell my little dacha. It might have been three years ago when I was dashing off to Myanmar, formerly Burma, while worrying about some leaking pipes. More likely, it was after I returned from Asia and saw that most of the forest behind the house had been cut down, replaced by a row of ultra-tacky vacation homes. This wasn't the worst ecologic atrocity that had happened in the Hamptons. But still, it broke my heart.
When I first moved to the East End, it was a place that mixed social glitz with spectacular natural beauty. In the 1980's one could avoid the glitz; now it overwhelmed and was the whole scene. Camera crews from "Access Hollywood" and "Hard Copy" were all over the towns -- as they searched out Kim Basinger and Billy Joel. One had the feeling that one was living in Beverly Hills East.
Keeping the house going had always been a struggle for me; it no longer seemed worth it. There would be people I'd miss and whom I would probably see less of -- like the Knab family who lived next door and who had taken me in as one of their own and some friends from town: Mary Alice Kellogg, Star Black, David Alpern.
But on the whole, I had come to think of Mandalay as a failed experiment. It turned out that "you do need a man to fix it." Single-home ownership is no wiser than single parenthood -- and pretty much for the same reasons: it is just too big a responsibility for one person, especially a globetrotting one.
The house was sold on Feb. 23 to a young local couple. It's their first home. She works at one of the shops in the Bridgehampton mall and he's a carpenter. At the bank closing, they were giddy with joy to take over Mandalay, a house they may not bother to name. Instead, they are likely to fill it with hand-crafted furnishings and babies -- and that feels rather right.

HEADLINE: Airport Changes Under Debate

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
AVIATION experts say they will never know for sure if approach lights would have made the difference last month when Charles Gunzburg of Jericho, N.Y., apparently missing a runway in fog and driving rain, crashed his single-engine plane into an Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport parking lot and died.
But the crash, on April 19, has restarted the decades-long debate about proposed improvements that would add safety zones to the two runways as well as a sophisticated approach light system at the Stratford airport. 
 The airport, in the Lordship area of Stratford at the edge of Long Island Sound and the Housatonic River, is owned and operated by the city of Bridgeport, which supports a plan for $12 million to $15 million in improvements. (The Federal Aviation Administration would pay 90 percent of the cost, the state 7.5 percent and Bridgeport 2.5 percent.)
"Every time there is a crash there are all these hysterical calls for airport expansion and improvements," said a member of the Stratford Town Council, Susan A. Collier, a Democrat whose district includes the Lordship area. "But each time we get a final report on the crashes from the National Transportation Safety Board we find out that pilot error was the main reason for the crashes. If the airport is unsafe it should be closed down, if not, it should remain the way it is."
Supporters of improvements -- including airport administrators, the F.A.A. and pilots -- say that there have been four crashes on the same runway within the past decade (each time in rain and dense fog) and that the proposed upgrades might have saved some lives. Eight people, including the pilot, were killed in April 1994 when a charter twin-engine plane from Atlantic City struck a steel fence at the end of the runway and burst into flames. Two months earlier a consultant had proposed extending the runway and eliminating the fence.
"For years we have wanted to bring the airport up to current F.A.A. standards for safety and design, but local opposition had kept that from happening and we're still trying to get it done," said Kurt Fendlein, superintendent of operations at Sikorsky. "We still don't know what happened in this latest crash, but approach lights might have made a difference."
Opponents of expanding the airport say that the crashes were all caused at least in part by pilot error and improvements probably would not have prevented them. They also say expansion would be costly and have a negative environmental impact on the Great Meadows Marsh. A proposed rerouting of Main Street to add safety zones would also have a negative impact on the community, opponents say. A study on the environmental impact of airport improvements is to be presented shortly to the Town Council and a town committee studying the issue.
An F.A.A. and Connecticut Department of Transportation report last year recommended creating two 1,000-foot safety zones at the end of the 4,677-foot runways, rerouting Main Street away from the runway where several crashes have occurred, and installing approach lights to help pilots land. The agency stopped short of saying the improvements are crucial or that the airport is unsafe.
"As part of restructuring airport runways, it is our policy to improve areas where they do not now meet the F.A.A. safety standards," said Vincent Scarano, an F.A.A. regional airports division manger in Burlington, Mass. "Part of that process is to add runway safety zones and approach lights. While it is not always possible to achieve these standards and we make these decisions on a case-by-case basis, they are usually preferable."
The Sikorsky Airport manager, John Ricci, has long sought the improvements, arguing that the runways have been the same since 1956 and are not adequate for an airport that serves more than 45,000 passengers a year and is expected to generate more than $80 million a year for the region by the year 2003.
"Airport improvements would not only bring the airport into accordance with F.A.A. safely standards, it would also be good of the region's economy," said Mr. Ricci, who also recently suggested that approach lights might have helped the pilot in last month's crash.
Opponents of expansion say the airport is safe for the twin engine turboprops, which carry between 19 and 47 passengers, and they fear any airport upgrading would lead to larger planes and increased activity in the Lordship area. Some residents say the town would be better off without the airport at all.
"Because the airport is owned and operated by the city of Bridgeport, the town of Stratford doesn't benefit at all from it. We don't get taxes or anything else out of it other than increased traffic and pollution and this never-ending debate," said a Stratford Council member, Patricia A. Kronenberg, a Republican. "I would prefer to see the airport closed and the land given back to the town."
Pilots who use the airport say it provides an economic boost to the Bridgeport region. "The airport is one of the economic engines for the region, and every viable major city has a viable airport that can meet the increasing travel needs of its citizens as we head into the 21st century," said David Faile, a pilot who is president of a group called Friends of Sikorsky Airport. "The improvements are so long overdue it is hard to believe they weren't made years ago."
Neighborhood opponents disagree. "Our position is that we have several nearby airports like Tweed Airport in New Haven, that already have longer runways than Sikorsky, and that there isn't any need to expand or make other changes," said Marcia Stewart, president of Protect Your Environment, which has been fighting airport expansion for 30 years. "Rather than using these crashes to argue for airport expansion, we should be asking why in this latest crash was a pilot unfamiliar with Sikorsky trying to land there during bad weather conditions?" (Mr. Gunzburg, flying alone, was apparently trying to return to his home airport in Farmingdale, N.Y., but because of weather conditions there was directed instead to Sikorsky.) The chairman of the Stratford Town Council, Debbie Rose, a Democrat, said that because the issue has been so divisive for so long she will soon propose another townwide referendum to let the voters, who have rejected expansion before, decide again.
