HEADLINE: Closely Guarded Secrets: Some Islands You Can't Get to Visit

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
STANDING on the shores of the East End, you can see across the water to some of Long Island's greatest treasures, tantalizingly close yet forbiddingly inaccessible.
They are privately owned islands, and although just a short boat ride from the main body of Long Island, they are off limits to the public. Visits are held to a handful of guests, by invitation and special arrangement. 
 A mystique as thick as an East End ocean fog envelops the islands, and it is well earned. These islands -- Gardiners, Great Gull, Little Gull, Plum and Robins -- have been the setting of some of Long Island's most exciting historical chapters.
Captain Kidd buried pirate treasure there. One Island woman was tried for witchcraft decades before Salem's trials. Another was so beautiful that she dazzled Washington society, married the President and inadvertently saved his life. And during the cold war, one island was used for secret research for a germ warfare attack on the Soviet Union.
Today, by an odd combination of design and chance, the islands have evolved into land preserves, sanctuaries from the suburban highways, malls and subdivisions that continue to gobble up Long Island's remaining open spaces.
"These island oases near populated resorts are phenomenal," said Sara Davison, executive director of the Long Island chapter of the Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit group that has been in the forefront of the preservation movement. "Especially as more and more people come to the East End, we've got to have" refuges for wildlife.
Naturalists prize the islands, with their coastal cliffs, freshwater ponds and glacial boulders, as home to an abundance of creatures and vegetation. The bounty includes the world's largest tern colony, ospreys with wingspans up to six feet, turkeys, seals, deer, the state's healthiest eastern mud turtle population, tiny voles, one of the biggest stands of white oak in the northeast, swamp maple and beach plums, to name but a few.
Despite their idyllic image, the islands have figured in conflicts dating back to the Indian wars. Disputes over control and use of the islands have prompted court battles among feuding owners and bitter political fights involving preservationists, developers and government officials.
An island is no small financial commitment. Louis Moore Bacon, a reclusive hedge fund manager and currency trading star, paid $12 million for Robins Island in 1994. And the annual cost of taxes and maintenance at Gardiners has been estimated at $2 million. Guests on the islands have included the likes of Dag Hammarskjold and Ernest Hemingway.
Culturally, the islands have inspired naturalist painters and contemporary authors. Nelson DeMille's current best-selling novel "Plum Island," published by Warner, is about a detective investigating the murder of a couple who may have been engaged in germ warfare research. In one passage, the detective describes his arrival on Plum:
"Here I was on a restricted island with this blond SS lookalike, an armed helicopter circling around, armed guards all over the place, and I'm feeling like I somehow stepped into a James Bond movie, except that this place is real. I said, 'When do we meet Dr. No?' "
Steven Gaines devotes a big chunk of his new book, "Philistines at the Hedgerow, Passion and Property in the Hamptons," due next month from Little, Brown & Company, to colorful tales of the Gardiner family, which has occupied its island for 359 years. His book calls the island "a sanctuary not just for wildlife but from the 20th century as well."
Raising the issue of public access during a debate five years ago over what to do about Robins Island, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the problem was "how you preserve it but allow people to enjoy it without trampling on it."
For Ms. Davison and many other environmentalists, the answer is to keep people away and let them appreciate the vulnerable islands from afar. "I don't think the lack of public access is a big deal," she said. "There are plenty of other places -- parks and preserves -- where people can go."
Outsiders are clearly unwelcome at the private islands, as no-trespassing signs attest. The owners of Gardiners Island have gone so far as to advertise its off-limits status in public notices in The East Hampton Star.
The owners of all the islands are silent about their caretakers and security measures to keep out intruders, although Mr. Gaines's book says that Gardiners Island's "please leave" signs are enforced with shotguns and dogs.
One man rowed ashore at Plum Island and was caught breaking into the abandoned lighthouse, recalled Carlos Santoyo, the assistant director of the Federal Agriculture Department's Animal Disease Center there. Because the man's boat was not very seaworthy and the center was legally responsible for his safety, "we were nice and even took him back, but we told him not to return without permission," said Mr. Santoyo.
Regattas are sometimes held near the islands, and tourist cruises also pass by to view the flourishing seal population, whose varieties include harbor, gray, harp and hooded.
Boaters are free to sail around the islands, of course, and depending on the season, those who stop to fish may be rewarded with fluke, flounder, porgies, bluefish, blackfish, striped bass or weakfish. The waters are also noted for oysters.
For people intent on setting foot on one of the islands, the best bet is Plum Island, which is Government property. For many years, it was the most tightly guarded of the islands, because of the classified work done there. But now the center has occasional tours for outside groups, by arrangement.
Perhaps people are drawn to the islands as much by the lure of the forbidden as by their history and natural beauty. Mr. DeMille, the novelist, recalled how he became interested in Plum Island: "Growing up, I used to see it from boats, and you saw those signs that said: 'No landing.' It always intrigued me."
Today he has mixed feelings about access to the islands. "In one way, I like seeing them go back to nature, but I'd still like to have them opened to people, in a very limited way."
 
GARDINERS ISLAND
With 3,300 acres and 27 miles of coastline, Gardiners Island is said to be the nation's largest privately owned island and oldest family estate.
But after a reign of more than three centuries, the Gardiners are not one big happy family. After prolonged litigation, two feuding relatives have been forced into shared custody of the island, and they alternate their stays to avoid crossing paths.
One is Robert David Lion Gardiner, who proclaims himself the 16th Lord of the Manor. The other is his niece, Alexandra Creel Goelet. In Mr. Gardiner's obsession to control the island's destiny, he once searched out a distant relative in Mississippi and tried to adopt him as a son to inherit the property, but the man declined.
Despite the hostilities between Mr. Gardiner and Mrs. Goelet, both say they are dedicated to preserving the island. They can well afford to do so, although Mr. Gardiner stopped paying his share of the upkeep years ago. Mrs. Goelet recently paid to help preserve the abandoned farm buildings, the oldest dating to 1690. The complex, which once housed slave quarters, includes a windmill.
Historians, naturalists and other academics are sometimes given tours, and when Mr. Gardiner is the guide, he relishes telling the island's stories.
In 1639, the original Lion Gardiner, over six feet tall and red bearded, bought the island from the Montaukett Indians, bartering a large black dog, blankets, a gun, powder and shot for it. Hedging his bets, he also obtained a land grant from King Charles I of England.
The Montaukett tribe's wiley sachem, the legendary Wyandanch, had decided to make allies and trading partners of the English after white soldiers killed hundreds of fierce Pequots in Connecticut.
But the sachem and the Englishman also became dear friends -- some say blood brothers -- especially after an enemy tribe kidnapped Wyandanch's daughter and Gardiner personally arranged her safe return. When Wyandanch died, Gardiner was grief stricken.
Gardiner's daughter was the first child of English descent born in New York. She died as a teen-ager, and in her terminal delirium accused an unpopular local woman, Goody Garlick, of witchery. Soon a tribunal was convened, and others accused her of causing several premature deaths by sorcery.
Lion Gardiner did not believe the charges and had the proceedings moved to Connecticut, where she was acquitted. By some accounts, she returned to Gardiners Island to live out her years.
Late in the 1600's, Capt. William Kidd, a privateer who had been declared a pirate, landed on the island to bury his plunder of gold and jewelry, then turned himself in and sought to clear his name.
The authorities ordered the Gardiners to return the treasure, which they did, except for one large diamond, or so the story goes. In London, Captain Kidd was convicted of murder and was hanged twice, the second time because the rope broke the first time.
Perhaps the most colorful of the Gardiners was Julia, whose looks and charm earned her the description the Rose of Long Island. Overseas, she broke the hearts of an English nobleman and an Italian prince. That was just a rehearsal for her assault on Washington, where she dated two Congressmen and three Supreme Court justices, among others, while in her 20's.
Invited to a White House party, she proceeded to captivate President John Tyler, a widower. One account said that "by evening's end, the President, 30 years her senior, was chasing Julia down the stairs and around tables."
Julia's mother frowned on the President's courting, because he was not rich enough for a Gardiner. In 1844 the Gardiners were invited to the ceremonial firing of a large gun, the Peacemaker, on a Navy ship. Unfortunately it exploded, killing the Secretaries of State, Treasury and the Navy and Julia's father, a State Senator. She and the President would have been likely victims, too, except that they had slipped below deck for champagne together. Soon after, they wed.
 
GREAT GULL AND LITTLE GULL ISLANDS
These are the smallest of the private islands. Great Gull is a 178-acre sliver of land, and the adjoining Little Gull is a tiny islet, both east of Plum Island.
Thanks to naturalists who restored a habitat that had been destroyed by military fortifications, the Gull Islands are today home to the world's largest tern colony.
In the 1800's, the Federal Government used Little Gull as the site for a lighthouse, and Great Gull was farmed by the lighthouse keeper. In that era, the Gull Islands became a refuge for terns, who were being slaughtered in more accessible locations so that their feathers could be harvested for the millinery trade.
But the terns eventually lost their refuge. In the Spanish-American War, Great Gull was transformed into Fort Michie, which was not abandoned until after World War II.
In 1949 the American Museum of Natural History and the Linnaean Society, a bird-lovers group, bought the property and began enticing terns to return. By 1955, there were 25 pairs. Volunteers began the tradition, still followed today, of counting and banding the birds and checking their nests and eggs.
Today, thousands of pairs nest every year, and the program is so successful that some people have given Gull Islands a nickname: Guano Islands.
Terns are sea swallows distinguished buy their black caps and forked tails. Other birds on the islands include ospreys, double crested cormorants, bald eagles, oyster catchers, mergansers, loons, sandpipers, tufted titmice and song sparrows.
 
PLUM ISLAND
As Government property, Plum Island is not privately owned. But access to it is strictly controlled and it has the tightest security of all the islands. The 105 workers there commute by the Orient Point ferry.
Unlike the secret germ warfare project in the 1950's, the first Federal project on Plum Island was quite open and ordinary. In 1826, the Government belatedly bought 3 of its 800 acres for a lighthouse that had originally been authorized by President George Washington. In 1869 it was replaced by another, which still stands today, more or less. Since the Coast Guard closed the lighthouse in 1978, it has deteriorated, and erosion keeps gnawing at the cliff, which moves ever closer.
About the time of the Spanish-American War, the Government bought the rest of Plum and built Fort Terry as the headquarters for artillery batteries at Montauk and on Gardiners, Great Gull and Fishers Islands. In World War II it was used for training and for arming torpedoes, and then the fort was closed. Boarded-up military buildings, fortification ruins and overgrown gun placements remain, but no guns.
Suffolk County was in the process of buying the island for tourism when Federal officials backed out and converted the site to the Animal Disease Center in 1954. The island was chosen as a safeguard against accidental contamination. Since 1929, the country's only outbreak of the dreaded foot-and-mouth disease was in 1978, when it spread to animals outside the laboratory buildings.
For ecades, officials denied rumors of biological warfare experiments. But in 1993, Newsday unearthed previously classified documents on plans to disrupt the Soviet economy by spreading diseases to kill its pigs, cattle and horses. Most of the diseases studied, like African swine fever and rinderpest, affect only livestock. But one, Rift Valley fever, also occurs in humans.
The warfare plans ended long ago, officials say, and now the laboratory focuses exclusively on preventing diseases. To satisfy their own concerns, Russian scientists inspected the center in 1994.
Although there is no formal conservation program on Plum Island, the laboratory occupies only a small part, leaving the rest untouched. "We don't call it preservation," said the center's assistant director, Mr. Santoyo. "It just happens." Some conservation advocates say that Plum would benefit from an organized program like those on the other islands.
 
ROBINS ISLAND
Robins Island has changed hands many times, from its early Indian inhabitants to the King of England to a series of private owners. A few years ago it was almost bought by Suffolk County and New York State for a public preserve.
Instead, the 435-acre island ended up as the family retreat and hunting domain of a multimillionaire financier, Louis Moore Bacon. He decided to complete a house on the island whose construction had been abandoned by a previous owner, a New York City businessman, when his wife died in 1918.
But otherwise Mr. Bacon appears committed to conservation of his densely wooded isle. He has agreed to restrictions preserving the island forever, and his foundation set aside $1.1 million for the Nature Conservancy to oversee the program and pay for the new job of Peconic Baykeeper to safeguard the surrounding area.
In the island's long and checkered history, King Charles I granted ownership to the Earl of Sterling in 1615. Later it was sold to the Wickham family, but was wrested from their control after the American Revolution because they had sided with the Tories.
After a series of owners used the island as a retreat and for hunting, German investors took over in 1979 through the Southold Development Corporation. Fearing that the island would be built up, Suffolk County tried to buy it for $9 million, and Governor Cuomo agreed to have the state share the cost.
But then another company, Robis Corporation, made a $16 million bid and promised to develop no more than 22 luxury houses on 33 acres, leaving the rest of the island pristine. County Executive Robert Gaffney provoked a political furor by endorsing the Robis plan, which many others attacked. The issue figured in the defeat of one county legislator in the next election.
When Southold Development fell into arrears, litigation abounded and Mr. Bacon emerged at the 11th hour to snap up the island for $12 million in bankruptcy court. Critics were skeptical of his intentions at first, but so far he appears to be true to his word.
Besides the Bacon family's guests, the only visitors allowed onto the island are Nature Conservancy workers and students from the New Suffolk School District.

HEADLINE: A Stage Where the Homeless Star

BYLINE: By ROBERT DUBROW 

 BODY:
ONE man is in recovery from crack-cocaine addiction. Another recently completed a four-year prison term. A woman struggles with manic depression.
They are all members of New Haven's Homeless Theater Troupe, a collaboration between homeless and formerly homeless individuals and Yale University students. The troupe's new play, which recently had its premiere in a church basement before an enthusiastic audience, offers the message that through faith in God, human beings can overcome addictions and other demons, to fulfill their potential as individuals. 
 The troupe, a project of the Inner City Community Coffee House, was founded in February 1997 by a Yale student, Jane Chen, to give homeless people the opportunity to develop self-sufficiency by getting involved in theater, to give them a voice in the community, to break down stereotypes, and to educate audiences about homelessness.
Having first gotten to know homeless people through the Yale Hunger and Homelessness Action Project, Ms. Chen began recruiting troupe members in the soup kitchens and homeless shelters of New Haven. It was not easy. On some days as many as six people would attend rehearsal; on other days nobody would show up.
In July, Ms. Chen and other Yale students who had gotten involved began providing transportation to rehearsals. That turned out to be an important breakthrough. Nevertheless, Ms. Chen says, "the troupe is always in flux in terms of people -- an unstable population sort of coming in and out; but through it we've definitely had commitments from people for some extended period of time."
The juxtaposition of instability and commitment that has characterized the troupe was recently demonstrated when it lost two homeless actresses less than a week before the premiere performance of the new play. The remaining five performers pulled together to make major last-minute revisions.
One of those performers was Andree Thompson, a 28-year-old man who has been with the troupe for over a year. When he joined, he was staying at the Columbus House shelter. He moved into his own apartment in December, after being homeless for 10 years. A month later he was hired as actor-director of the troupe, through a grant from the Haymarket People's Fund. Ms. Chen, who graduated in December with a dual major in theater studies and American studies, has remained in New Haven to train Mr. Thompson.
"One of the consequences of using crack cocaine is to become homeless," said Mr. Thompson, who completed a drug treatment program shortly before joining the troupe. "A lot of times people come out of homelessness and forget where they came from. This keeps everything right up front for me. It's amazing to see the talent that everybody has, and a lot of times that talent is lost. It makes me feel good to know that I'm having a positive impact on the community instead of having a negative impact that I had before God helped me get my life together."
Mr. Thompson says the plays, developed through improvisation, are based on experiences of the troupe's members: "None of our plays are script written. We go from a blank stage; how you're feeling and what you've been through -- we act it out. Everybody puts in their ideas and we come up with a play."
A troupe member who became homeless in February, Denise Potter, explains, "This isn't structured. This is something that you have to base on yourself, and I find it very difficult. It's a lot harder than just reciting a couple of lines from Shakespeare. It's something that touches the very soul of your being. It's kind of like therapy. You're able to do things and say things differently than you did the first time." The troupe has three-hour rehearsals, three nights a week. Rehearsals take place at Dwight Hall, the center for public service and social justice at Yale. Dwight Hall also provides the vehicles for transportation and some financial resources.
Thursday is a work night, when members work with Yale students to accomplish the administrative tasks of the troupe, including writing press releases, producing posters for performances and composing fund-raising letters. The students provide tutoring on computer and word-processing skills, resume writing, and use of E-mail, photocopy machines and facsimile machines.
There are also discussions about issues related to homelessness. "We end up having pretty heated discussions about where homelessness comes from and what to do about it," says the troupe's producer, Laurie Kennington, a sophomore.
Students tend to place the roots of homelessness in the political and economic system, whereas homeless people tend to focus on bad choices they made in their lives or on unfortunate circumstances.
"I had a college background and I'm homeless," says Judy White, who became homeless two years ago, when losing her job, apartment and custody of her daughter sent her into a deep depression. "It doesn't matter who you are. Situations can occur in your life that you cannot handle, and you fall down."
But both students and homeless agree that homeless people cannot be stereotyped. "Homeless people come in all shapes and sizes," Ms. White says.
Being involved with the troupe has changed the way Connor Martin, a sophomore, looks at homelessness. "You meet very interesting people who all have different stories," she says. "It's just a myriad number of things in people's pasts that leads them to be homeless."
Despite the instability in troupe membership, strong bonds form. "It's kind of like a family," Ms. Potter says. "You know you're not alone. It helps to be with people that are in the same position as you are."
For Krissy Clark, a sophomore, the most important aspect of working with the troupe has been the personal connections with homeless people -- "just having them be my friends, rather than people I helped or pitied or felt awkward around."
In addition to participating in work nights and providing transportation, students help with such diverse tasks as set and costume design, lighting and sound, grant writing and baby-sitting.
While the troupe aims to increase student involvement, it does not want to have to rely on students, who, like the homeless, tend to be transient, according to Connor Martin, who will take over as producer in the summer. Ms. Martin said she would seek to recruit non-student volunteers, to find rehearsal space apart from the university, to raise funds to buy a van and to provide stipends to homeless and formerly homeless troupe members, and to begin to form partnerships with other groups that provide services to the homeless.
A long-term goal is to transfer leadership from students to homeless and formerly homeless people themselves. The hiring of Mr. Thompson as director was a step in that direction.
"The Family Angel" is the troupe's third production. The premiere performance took place before 60 people at St. Mary's Unison Freewill Baptist Church on Goffe Street. The cast included Mr. Thompson, Ms. Potter, Ms. White, Grafton Riddick, who has been with the troupe from the start and Al Vasseur, who lives at Davenport House, a transitional home.
The next performance, a benefit for the Downtown Evening Soup Kitchen, is scheduled for Saturday. In late June, the troupe will perform at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven. A discussion between audience and cast follows each performance.

HEADLINE: Investing to Cover College Cost

BYLINE: By JARRET LIOTTA 

 BODY:
FOR Townsend Smith, a second grader from Darien, the future is a shining sea that he intends to sail across. "When I graduate from college I want to be in the Navy," he said. "I like boats a lot. I'd like to be a captain."
While his mother, Eileen Smith, noted that he seems to change his mind every week about his ambitions, one probable bet is that Townsend will be pursuing higher education. "He's a very bright kid and I think he wants to go on to college," she said. 
 Like many parents, however, Eileen and her husband, Tad, are expecting the cost of putting their son and twin 6-year old daughters -- Ella and Tori -- through college to be sizable. And hope for their future won't necessarily translate into a practical solution.
In January, the Connecticut Higher Education Trust was created by the State Treasurer's office. The tax-deferred savings and investment program is designed to offer state residents variations in the allocation of assets according to the age of the child, and a flexibility in the use of the money upon withdrawal. More than 600 accounts have been opened, with more than $3 million invested by participants.
The Smiths, who had some equity investments earmarked for college, are among those 600. "What's good about it is the fact that the money will come out and it will be taxed at the child's tax rate," said Mrs. Smith. (The college-age student's tax rate is likely to be substantially lower than that of the parents.)
In the portfolios, Lazard Freres & Company has been designated to handle small-capitalization equities, Aeltus Investment Management Inc. large-cap stocks, J. P. Morgan Investment Management fixed-income investments and Montgomery Asset Management international investments. "What I wanted to do was have the average taxpayer have a chance to access top-notch asset managers," said the State Treasurer, Paul J. Silvester, who is overseeing the program. "We have a tremendous amount of investment expertise here."
Part of the managers' responsibility is to orchestrate the investments so that they will gradually change from riskier equities into fixed-income investments as the children get closer to the time they need to withdraw the money. A tentative model shows that 90 percent of the account will be held in diversified equities when the child is 5 years old or younger. By the time the child reaches 17, only 10 percent will still be in stocks.
Mr. Silvester acknowledged that risks remain. "There's market risk," he said. "But I always say that the only investment that's kept pace with higher education is the stock market."
"What we used to do is issue zero-point municipal bonds," said Mr. Silvester, but these ultimately lost purchasing power. This new investment portfolio, he said, is designed to keep pace with inflation.
The price of college education has outpaced the cost of living in recent years. According to the Federal Department of Education, the average tuition, room and board at a four-year institution has nearly doubled in 10 years, to $10,825 last year from $5,964 for the 1986-87 school year. The treasurer's office predicts that costs will increase at twice the rate of inflation in years to come.
Kathy Houlihan, assistant director of financial aid at Housatonic Community-Technical College in Bridgeport, said that schools are trying a variety of ways to help parents with the costs. "Schools have come up with all sorts of creative, innovative ways to meet costs -- freezing tuitions, prepaying tuitions," she said. "They've had to get very creative because the burden keeps getting heavier every year."
Financial aid administrators from schools as diverse as Yale, the University of Connecticut and Housatonic agree that the biggest mistake parents make is waiting too long to start to save.
"It needs to be done when the children are really small," said Ms. Houlihan. "I guess it's never too late, but the earlier you do it, the much better position you're in."
Though saving for college has an effect on students' ability to receive financial aid, often, she said, the only aid that is available is in the form of student loans. "Colleges do not have the deep pockets that people think they do," she said. Students now leave school with an average of $17,000 in student loans, she said.
Any Connecticut resident is eligible to open a Connecticut Higher Education Trust account, regardless of income. The money, and there is no limit on the amount invested, can then be used at any higher education institution.
An account may be opened with an initial investment of $500, or a minimum of $50 a month if a payment plan is used, either through payroll deduction or a checking account. Accounts can be opened through any First Union bank in the state.

HEADLINE: Tempest Brews Over Development in Scarsdale

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA ROWE 

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
CHANGE comes slowly to most small places, but the growing pains here are legendary. For more than 30 years, residents of this seemingly tranquil suburb have been locked in bitter wrestling matches over everything from the disposal of autumn leaves to the very future of their village.
After rejecting 23 studies, reports and proposals to revitalize Scarsdale's low-key downtown, nearly everyone seems to understand that something must be done with the large parking lot on the Freightway site, which sits like a gaping hole next to the Metro-North train tracks. The proposal would also link the village's two separate shopping areas. 
 There is also general agreement that the village's traffic and parking problems are in desperate need of a solution. But all that accord has not been enough to get a consensus on the next move. And in Scarsdale, consensus is everything.
The current proposal -- which will be discussed at a public hearing on Wednesday -- is a hyped-up version of a concept originally offered by 29 citizens in 1995. It would mean building 215,000 square feet of parking, stores, apartments and walkways alongside the Metro-North tracks, and it would turn the Freightway parking lot into the second story of a two-and-a-half-floor garage by digging under the present lot and adding a floor above it.
Above the garage would be a landscaped plaza, with small shops and apartments -- some built directly over the tracks. Commuter trains to and from Manhattan would race beneath them in less than five seconds and emerge on the other side of Popham Road, where there would be more stores and a second plaza above the tracks.
Not surprisingly, there are some who feel the estimated $30 million plan would change the character of Scarsdale forever.
"My observation is that this is the kiss of death to the village being a village," Richard Behr, an architect, said. "How does this gigantic thing relate to a small village area? This is not flowers and little benches. It will make this place an urban development."
Even the likely builder, Sam Klein of Fairchild Properties in Manhattan, conceded that the Scarsdale project was more involved than typical developments. "This is going to have a visual impact on the community," he said. "Not everybody understood that initially, but now they do, and it's moving forward quite rapidly." Already, he is picking out lobby furniture and paintings.
Mayor Edward A. Morgan hopes to sign off on the zoning and environmental papers by the end of June, and optimistic supporters like Mr. Klein say they would like to see a shovel in the ground by next spring. But most people questioned randomly about the plan on a recent Friday just shrugged at the thought.
"Development? It can't happen -- not in this town," Anthony Rende, owner of Homer Rich Opticians, said. "There's like 200 cars looking for spaces here already, so tell me how more stores and more people are going to create any solution to the problem."
Driving around Scarsdale, even on sleepy weekday afternoons, can be a nightmare. A quick shopping trip easily turns into an hour of negotiating sludge-like traffic and searching for a parking space.
The proposal would add about 300 parking spaces but would fall 121 short of the number required by code. Mayor Morgan said the village planned to grant waivers allowing the smaller number.
Some of the residents, who were appointed by the village and labored for 18 months on the downtown building concept, are incensed. The village government, by ignoring their more modest outline, will make Scarsdale's worst problems -- traffic and parking -- worse yet, they say. So far, only a few vague sketches of the grand plan have been offered -- nothing on which to base a firm agreement -- but they are complaining loudly about being shut out of the process.
It would not be the first time. Earlier development plans have been scuttled in the face of community outcry so violent that Village Trustees were forced to throw up their hands. Each of the six Trustees, and the Mayor, were chosen through the village's unusual, nonpartisan system -- a clubby style of government in which certain residents are invited to serve rather than running in a traditional election. Campaigns are frowned on and only recently were candidates permitted to discuss specific issues. The village does hold a pro forma election, but it is rarely contested.
On paper that might sound nice. A genteel village of 17,000 people who know one another well enough to organize without party politics or divisive campaigns -- a government built on consensus rather than conflict. But in practice it can mean endless community discussions, decisions made by committee and compromises that go nowhere -- hence, the 30-year plan, still in its infancy, to develop Scarsdale's downtown.
"Development? It's almost laughable because they've been talking about this forever, it seems," said David A. Pravda, a lawyer with an office in the village center. The concept, he said, sounded excellent, adding that he was not holding his breath.
"The nonpartisan system has basically served this village well," Mr. Morgan said. "We don't have people yelling at each other. We're elected without having promised to do anything on the premise that we're going to listen to people and then try to make the right decision. And no personalities. We're not going to say a bad word about anybody. The premise is you beat on the issues instead of beating on the people."
That may have been true in 1911, when the system was designed. But 87 years later, some Scarsdale residents have grown mistrustful of that old-fashioned style.
"Generally, Scarsdale runs very well -- it's Nirvana," said Mike Anastas, co-chairman of Scarsdale Responsible Citizens, which is spearheading opposition to the downtown plan. "Everybody's happy -- except when something goes wrong. Because the system doesn't involve the community in discussions that matter like, for instance, the future of our village."
Les Levin, 70, complained that despite all the community committees, real dialogue between the village and its residents was nonexistent. About 50 people attended a public meeting on May 5 to complain. In typical fashion, the two-hour discussion grew into a four-hour confrontation, and by midnight people were still waiting to speak. Many were unhappy with the downtown building plan and feared that the village leadership would barrel through with it.
"We do not want, nor do we need, housing over the railroad tracks creating the first and only subway station in Westchester," said Phyllis Rozans, 76, who has lived in the village for more than 40 years. Another man stood up to complain that he had not left Manhattan to move next door to a shopping mall.
But there are others -- particularly the Mayor and the six Trustees -- who are tired of noodling over endless proposals and insist that the time has come for action. Village Manager Alfred A. Gatta shook his head in undisguised disgust at the idea of more opposition. "There are those who believe we should still be operating as if Eisenhower were in his first term," he said. "Small towns are tough. The people are just not much into government. They don't trust it."
That is the way it has always been in Scarsdale, said Lowell Tooley, Mr. Gatta's predecessor, who managed the village for 34 years. For much of that time, he worked with Brad Perkins, the architect who has been trying since 1984 to hammer out a design the town can embrace.
"I like the nonpartisan system," said Mr. Perkins, who has lived in Scarsdale for 25 years. "There are times, though, I'll admit, when you'd like a more clear-cut decision-making process. The whole thing has gotten more and more tortuous, but when this thing is finally up, people will say, What was all the fuss about?"

HEADLINE: In Bridgeport, It's Time to Play Ball Once Again

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
ON Thursday, a new sports era begins for Bridgeport when the Bluefish play their first professional baseball game in the new Atlantic League. An opening-day sellout is assured; all 5,300 seats in the new stadium, the Ballpark at Harbor Yard, have been sold for the 4:05 P.M. opener against the Newark Bears. Pre-game ceremonies with Gov. John G. Rowland and Mayor Joseph P. Ganim will begin at 2:15.
The ball park is the first component in a sports arena and transportation complex along the city's waterfront. About $125 million in state money, along with additional millions in city and private money, is expected to be allocated over five years for the project, known as Team Bridgeport. Included is $12.5 million from Zurich Reinsurance, which had planned to build a new headquarters in Bridgeport but decided to move to Stamford instead. In addition to baseball, Team Bridgeport could also bring professional hockey and basketball to a city that has been struggling since its factory base began to erode about 30 years ago. Indeed, Bridgeport was an industrial hub when its last minor league team, the Bridgeport Bees of the old Colonial League, played their home games at Candlelight Stadium in the city's North End in the late 1940's. 
 Since the Atlantic League, unlike most minor leagues, is a brand new independent circuit with no major league affiliations, no one quite knows what to expect in terms of playing caliber. For the most part, rosters, include a handful of players with major league experience as well as minor leaguers who never made it to the big show and are, for the most part, are likely in the twilight of their playing careers.
"I think the quality of play will be slightly above Double A standards, and you'll see some of these players go up to the big leagues," said Mickey Herbert, one of the team's four principal owners and the founder and a chief executive officer of Physicians Health Services Inc., based in Trumbull. Other members of the ownership group are Jack McGregor, a Bridgeport lawyer and civic leader who founded the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League; his wife, Mary-Jane Foster, also a lawyer, and their firm, Bridgeport Waterfront Investors. Stressing that the Bridgeport Bluefish Professional Baseball Club is very much a local operation, Ms. Foster said, "About 76 percent of the people we have hired" -- the total number is between 200 and 250, she said -- "are from Bridgeport." She continued: "And we have already spent more than $1.5 million in the Bridgeport area on various equipment, including the scoreboard, which was made in Norwalk."
No matter the caliber of play -- expected to be like Class A minor league baseball, a step below Eastern League teams in New Haven, New Britain and Norwich -- the cozy and attractive ball park at Broad and Main streets is likely to enchant spectators.
So, too, is the spectacular view from inside the ball park that includes ferryboats of the Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamship Company entering and leaving Bridgeport Harbor, Amtrak and Metro-North trains above the right field fence, the Bridgeport skyline and the Connecticut Turnpike bridge, about a quarter-mile behind third base and left field.
The new stadium, which was built on the site of the Jenkins Brothers Valve Company plant off Broad Street in the city's South End and whose brick exterior evokes Bridgeport's past as a major industrial city, is similar to Dodd Stadium in Norwich.
That three-year-old ball park, where the Norwich Navigators of the Eastern League play their home games and which has drawn rave reviews, was built by C. R. Klewin Construction of Norwich, which also built the Ballpark at Harbor Yard.
Asked to compare the two ball parks, Gerry Chaiffre, the superintendent in charge of the Harbor Yard project, said, "This one is nicer. It has wider aisles between the seats and the concessions, more amenities, grander entrances and more space overall."
The Bridgeport ball park also has a huge edge in its surroundings. Dodd Stadium is in an industrial park several miles from downtown Norwich. Harbor Yard, by contrast, is about a five-minute walk from the heart of downtown Bridgeport. "You can park your car downtown and walk to the ball park," said Steven Schoenfeld, the public relations director for the Bluefish. "It's close to everything."
About 1,200 parking spaces, including a 600-car paved lot just beyond the left field fence, have been created. Some fans may not have to concern themselves with parking at all. The ferry terminal, which links Bridgeport to Port Jefferson, N.Y., and the Amtrak and Metro-North railroad station, are only minutes away by foot; so, too, are the exits from the Connecticut Turnpike and Routes 8 and 25 from the north.
Charlie Dowd, the team's general manager, thinks the stadium's location will be one of the keys in attracting fans. By the time the Bluefish had signed their first player, Brian Cornelius, a 31-year-old outfielder, in March, almost 100,000 tickets had been sold. Now, with the opener only four days away, the team has sold more than 130,000 individual game tickets and about 1,300 season tickets, including all 100 club seats (at $1,050 per seat) behind home plate.
Another lure, Mr. Dowd believes, will be ticket prices, which are far less expensive than for major league games but comparable to those at the state's three Eastern League ball parks in Norwich, New Haven and New Britain as well as in Waterbury where the Waterbury Spirit of the Northeast League (also an independent circuit) play their home games.
In Bridgeport, single-game prices range from $10 for premium box seats, which are directly in front of the sold-out club seats, to $4 for reserved seats ($2 for children under 12 and people over the age of 65).
Spectators in the club seats will be able to take advantage of a buffet dinner in the enclosed Harbor Club, directly behind their seats, and then place food and beverage orders while watching the game, the trains, the traffic on Interstate 95 or the ferryboats plying Bridgeport Harbor.
Nineteen of the 20 skyboxes, which accommodate up to 20 people and cost $20,000 for the season, have been sold, mainly to corporations in Fairfield County, Mr. Schoenfeld said. Most of the signage space on the outfield fence -- 325 feet down both foul lines and 400 feet to dead centerfield -- has also been sold. Just beyond the 8-foot-high "home run fence," a second fence, 16 feet high, has been erected to display advertising signage on the top portion.
In keeping with a popular trend in minor league baseball, there will be a heavy focus on families. At Harbor Yard there will be a picnic area, a supervised play area and a concession where Bluefish merchandise can be purchased.
Before a spadeful of dirt was dug at Harbor Yard, nearly $200,000 in Bluefish merchandise -- including caps, jackets, sweatshirts and pennants -- had been sold, all with the team's navy blue and sea green logo of a tenacious-looking bluefish wielding a baseball bat.
"We placed ads with the logo in Baseball America and Baseball Weekly, and the response was tremendous," Mr. Schoenfeld said.
The site that Harbor Yard occupies had been purchased by Donald Trump, with a view toward building a gambling casino.
But after being rebuffed by the state legislature, Mr. Trump transferred ownership to the city for $1 in lieu of back taxes.
The stadium project, which was coordinated by the Kasper Group of Bridgeport and designed by Design Exchange of Newark, Del., cost $17.2 million.
Mr. Schoenfeld said the team's owners have spent between $2 million and $3 million on amenities, including a 60-foot-high scoreboard.
Still in the planning stage is an intermodal transportation center and a sports arena with construction at least a year and a half away, says Michael Freimuth, the city's director of economic development. Mr. Freimuth said the arena -- it is expected to cost $35 to $40 million and to seat 8,000 to 10,000 -- could be used for games and for events including concerts and circuses.
"There've already been inquiries from two hockey leagues and one professional basketball league," Mr. Freimuth said. "And both Fairfield and Sacred Heart universities could also use the arena for basketball and hockey games."
For now, though, Mr. Freimuth and other Bridgeport officials are focusing on the Ballpark at Harbor Yard and a Bluefish team that did not begin spring training until last Monday, 10 days before opening day and the day after the Atlantic League's draft in Plant City, Fla. Since then, the team has been practicing at the former Cincinnati Reds' training site in Plant City before heading to Bridgeport yesterday. From today on, the Bluefish will work out daily at Harbor Yard.
The roster includes three former major leaguers -- outfielders Mike Felder, who spent 10 seasons in the big leagues with four different teams and Dwayne Singleton, who has played for Milwaukee and Detroit, as well as catcher Terry McGriff, who has seen service with four big league teams. The Bluefish had also signed a fourth former major leaguer, second baseman Jose Lind, but he was dropped from the roster last Monday when he failed to appear at training camp in Florida.
The Bluefish manager, Willie Upshaw, is a veteran of 10 years in the major leagues who later spent six seasons as a hitting coach with Toronto and Texas. For Upshaw, who also spent two seasons playing in Japan, the managerial situation is ideal since he lives in Fairfield, where all four of his children go to school.
The Atlantic League is one of about a dozen independent leagues that have been established in recent years as minor league baseball, on the verge of extinction in the 1970's, has surged in popularity, in large measure because of the expense of going to a big league game.
"We're going to provide family entertainment at affordable prices, and we're going to do it in a beautiful setting," said Dowd, the general manager, who came to the Bluefish from the New Haven Ravens. "And you'll see good baseball."
And perhaps a good omen for Bridgeport. "The ball park is symbolic of the city's comeback," Mr. Freimuth said. "And there's much more to come."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Using Thin Air To Let Buildings Grow Taller

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
MORE and more, the castles in the air rising around New York City are a combination of one landlord's castle and another landlord's air.
Unused development rights -- widely called "air rights" -- are a keystone in almost every big project under way or being planned. 
 Consider the Planet Hollywood Hotel that is soon to rise at Broadway and 47th Street, developed by Robert Gladstone. It would ordinarily be limited to 182,640 square feet of floor area by zoning rules. Through the transfer of air rights from the adjacent Lunt-Fontanne Theater, it will have 320,131 square feet.
Or take the luxury apartment tower at 515 Park Avenue developed by Arthur and William Lie Zeckendorf. Zoning rules would permit 72,000 square feet on that site. By transferring air rights from neighboring buildings on East 60th Street, including the Lighthouse, the tower will have more than 165,000 square feet. Ground is to be broken tomorrow.
In a hot market, air is money; $50 a square foot or more for development rights from Broadway theaters, maybe as much for those of Public School 191 at Amsterdam Avenue and West 61st Street.
The city's Economic Development Corporation is negotiating the sale of most of the air rights from P.S. 191 to Laurence Ginsberg, who would build two 30-story apartment towers next door. The project would grow to 600,000 square feet, from 400,000 square feet, through the transfer.
This would evidently be the first such transfer from a public school. The city agency hopes it will not be the last. It has identified 80 public buildings in Manhattan -- schools, police stations, fire houses and libraries -- whose air rights might be marketable, depending on the appropriateness of receiving sites.
"Early on in the Giuliani administration, a decision was made to try to take assets like these and put them in private hands," said Charles Millard, president of the corporation. The process is painstaking, he said, but the result is "better development sites and more property on the tax rolls for the city."
Some government officials, however, are alarmed by the P.S. 191 transfer. "Not only are we overbuilding but we're finding additional ways to do it," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, in whose district the school is located. "It's very scary."
Another project using air rights from a public property is 150 East 57th Street, a 32-story apartment tower nearing completion between Lexington and Third Avenues, developed by Bernard Spitzer and Louis Brause. They paid $1.2 million for the rights from a subway power substation in a deal with the Economic Development Corporation and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Five floors in the tower are attributable to that transfer. Between the air rights from the substation and another large adjacent property, the developers are expanding their project by 72 percent.
The Pataki administration is also looking to exploit air rights where it can. Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said five developers have responded to a request for proposals for a new building atop the Port Authority Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street, using about 1 million square feet of its untapped development potential. The five are the Forest City Ratner Companies, LCOR Inc., Park Tower Group, Silverstein Properties and a team composed of the Lawrence Ruben Company, Starrett Corporation and Vornado Realty Trust.
This project embodies the traditional definition of "air rights" -- building in the air directly over the property that generates the development potential.
More commonly today, air rights are shifted from one property to another. This is the heart of a proposal before the City Planning Commission that would allow the owners of 25 Broadway theaters to transfer their air rights -- totaling 2.4 million square feet -- almost anywhere within a 60-block area from Eighth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas, 40th to 57th Street.
USING those air rights, developers could construct buildings 20 to 44 percent larger than zoning would ordinarily allow, without having to go through public review. Theater owners who took advantage of this liberalized procedure would be required to preserve their structures as playhouses and pay $10 a square foot from the sale of air rights into a building maintenance and theatrical development fund.
Indirectly, the four office tower sites at the Times Square crossroads -- including the Conde Nast and Reuters headquarters -- also exploit the unused development potential from nearby theaters, in this case the historic houses along 42d Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
A stated goal of the government-sponsored 42d Street Development Project in 1984 was to "maintain the low-scale character of the mid blocks and limit new tower construction to the avenue ends of the project area." This was to be achieved by shifting development to Broadway, Seventh Avenue and Eighth Avenue.
With a total of 8.1 million square feet, the overall project is no greater in size than would be allowed by special permit under current zoning rules. But on the office tower sites, the density will be much higher.
The four sites together could accommodate up to 2.8 million square feet of floor area by special permit under current zoning rules. As built, the towers on those sites are to have a total of 3.9 million square feet (even more -- 4.1 million square feet -- if mechanical space is counted).
And officials are expecting the developers to lobby for even greater density. "Of course, there'll be pressure," Mr. Gargano said. How would he respond? "The simple answer would be, 'No,' " Mr. Gargano said. "The planning and density which was approved in 1984 gives us a size to go by and that's what we're staying with."
That precludes building over the New Amsterdam Theater. "Any build-over would diminish its presence," Mr. Gargano said.
Across town, a deal is near for the first transfer of air rights from Grand Central Terminal in almost 20 years. From the standpoint of contemporary zoning, a tower on that site could have about 1.7 million square feet more floor area than is contained in the Beaux-Arts landmark.
The landlord, the Penn Central Corporation, sought to build a skyscraper over the terminal in 1968 but was turned down by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Ten years later, upholding the landmarks law, the United States Supreme Court ruled that Penn Central had not suffered a "taking" of its property in part because it could still transfer development rights.
In 1991, after only 74,655 square feet of those development rights had been drawn down (for the Philip Morris headquarters at Park Avenue and 42d Street), the planning commission created a special 22-block subdistrict around the terminal to which its air rights could be transferred. A similar nine-block district already existed to absorb the development potential from the historic buildings of the South Street Seaport.
The first development to take advantage of the expanded Grand Central transfer district would be the headquarters planned by the Bear Stearns Companies at 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets. That 43,300-square-foot site is zoned for a building with a floor-area ratio of 15, or 649,500 square feet. The addition of 285,800 square feet of air rights would yield a tower with 935,300 square feet of floor area (equal roughly to the Municipal Building), with a floor-area ratio of 21.6, the highest allowed.
About 50,000 square feet of air rights might be transferred to Harry Macklowe for a 1 million square foot building he plans at Madison Avenue and 42d Street to replace the 310 Madison Avenue building.
Even if those transactions occur, however, Penn Central's successor company, American Premier Underwriters of Cincinnati, will still be left with nearly 1.5 million square feet of development rights.
"The market seems to be strong and there seems to be interest from a limited number of buyers," said John A. Anderson, vice president of the company. "The problem is that there aren't enough soft sites to put a major dent in the air rights."
That is the same problem faced by the owners of Broadway theaters: plenty of air rights but almost nowhere to send them.
"All of the value is locked up," said Samuel H. Lindenbaum of Rosenman & Colin, a lawyer representing the three major owners, the Shubert Organization, Nederlander Organization and Jujamcyn Theaters.
Edward I. Koch, in whose mayoralty many Broadway theaters were made landmarks -- over the objections of their owners -- said there ought to be some form of compensation. "I've come to the conclusion," Mr. Koch said last week, "that the proposal to expand the area within which they can sell their air rights is reasonable."
On April 22, Borough President C. Virginia Fields of Manhattan broke with the two local Community Boards and most of Manhattan's City Council members by offering conditional support of the zoning proposal.
"In some instances," she said, "zoning is an appropriate mechanism to preserve specific industries." She did, however, join with critics in saying that special permits ought to be required for any air-rights transfers.
But Robert E. Nederlander, president of the Nederlander Organization, said a lengthy review procedure "will discourage many developers and result in many less theaters preserved and protected."
Rebecca Robertson, a Shubert vice president, said it was "critical that the transfer be as straightforward as possible."
The Shubert Organization has wrestled for years over what to do with its unused development potential. On one block alone, between 44th and 45th Streets, seven Shubert theaters are estimated by city planners to have 471,525 square feet of available air rights. Shubert has occasionally floated a plan to build an enormous new tower directly over that cluster on a platform supported by columns among the theaters.
WHILE that approach has been met at City Hall with reactions ranging from cool to incredulous, Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, believes that towers on platforms are exactly the kind of threat that the new zoning proposal would diminish.
"Every theater basically represents a development site with a large floor plate in the central business district of the hottest market in the country," he said.
City planners maintain that the zoning proposal would not add to the density of the theater district but merely redistribute it. The real-estate industry agrees. "Such districts do not increase the amount of allowable development," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, "they simply reallocate it in a carefully limited way to nearby areas to facilitate investment. In this case, the midtown area has sufficient infrastructure to absorb the redistributed density."
But critics say that the city should have prepared an environmental impact statement on what would happen to sidewalk and street traffic, open space and air quality if all 2.4 million square feet of development rights from the theaters were used.
Opponents also worry that a wide transfer area will be a model for more, particularly since it follows those around Grand Central and South Street. "The establishment of still a third 'unique' special district would obviously provide even more justification for others," declared the rezoning task force of Community Board 5 in mid-Manhattan.
The New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects told the planning commission that the proposal would "set a bad precedent for preferential treatment of a certain class of owners."
"It would allow other property owners, such as religious organizations, to claim they are similarly burdened and deserve special treatment through the ability to transfer air rights over a broader area," said Edward I. Mills, speaking for the chapter at a planning commission hearing.
Roberta Brandes Gratz, co-author of a newly published book, "Cities Back From the Edge: New Life for Downtown," asked: "Who is to say an argument won't be made for a religious-properties district with a cluster of churches and synagogues? And why not a 'school district' for N.Y.U. or Columbia, so they too can float air rights?"
Mr. Rose insisted that the theater air-rights proposal would set no precedent, since it involves a special zoning subdistrict that has existed more than 30 years as home to an industry that is recognized as culturally and economically significant.
But it is true that planners have heard other proposals for expanded air-rights districts. For example, there was discussion of allowing owners of the small buildings in the Stone Street Historic District to sell their development potential elsewhere in lower Manhattan. "It involved taking air rights from within a district and transferring them outside," Mr. Rose said. "That's not necessarily a principle we wanted to commence."
He also said the sale of publicly owned air rights would be evaluated case by case. "There is no agenda afoot to do some kind of massive sale of air rights over public buildings," Mr. Rose said. "But that doesn't mean it's not sometimes appropriate."
The case of P.S. 191 is a "win-win-win-win" situation, Mr. Millard said. "The Board of Education benefits. The city budget benefits. The developer benefits. And the school keeps 20 percent of its air rights so it can expand if necessary."
Under the arrangement, the city has acquired the air rights from the Board of Education and applied the value of the air rights against the board's budget, as part of a $17 million credit. In turn, the Economic Development Corporation will sell the development rights to Mr. Ginsberg.
In 1987, the Ginsberg family built an apartment tower at 108 East 96th Street that was 12 stories taller than allowed by zoning rules. The city required them to remove those floors. "They made a mistake and they paid dearly for it," said their lawyer, Paul D. Selver of Battle Fowler.
Public schools and Broadway theaters are not the only beneficiaries in the current round of air-rights transfers. So is the Lighthouse Inc., a not-for-profit agency that helps the blind and visually impaired. Its international headquarters is in a 14-story building at 111 East 59th Street.
AFTER constructing its new building four years ago, the Lighthouse had 10,000 square feet of left-over air rights, which were sold on Tuesday for $2.5 million to the 515 Park Avenue project on the same block, being developed by the Zeckendorfs and a fund managed by Goldman Sachs. "We had an asset we really couldn't use, from a building point of view, so the sale of those air rights was wonderful for us," said Barbara Silverstone, the president and chief executive of the Lighthouse. "It's money in the bank. It goes into our endowment. It was a win-win negotiation."
Between the Lighthouse and the 515 Park Avenue site are two five-story brownstones, whose air rights also figure in the transaction. The goal of amassing air rights is simple, Arthur Zeckendorf said.
"The higher the units, the better the views," he said. (And the greater the price, he did not have to say.) "What they add is obviously a larger building with more economies of scale," Mr. Zeckendorf said.
Although the transfer of air rights is commonly understood as a development technique, it also relieves the economic pressure on owners of undersized structures -- often 19th- and early 20th-century landmarks -- to demolish and rebuild.
"In terms of housing stock, building stock and residential tenants, it's a very pro-preservation technique," said Michael T. Sillerman of Rosenman & Colin, who has negotiated many air-rights deals, including the zoning issues posed by the 515 Park Avenue project. "You're preserving the scale, age and diversity."
Air-rights transfers are sometimes more than an enhancement; they are a necessity.
"This project could not have worked without the air rights," said Frank Williams, of Frank Williams & Associates Architects, designers of the Planet Hollywood Hotel, which Mr. Gladstone is developing. By extending the zoning lot to include the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, the hotel grew by 75 percent and gained larger floors. (The 300-foot-high sign tower that will rise next to the hotel does not count in the floor-area calculations.)
When the small L-shaped parcel at Broadway and 47th Street was auctioned in 1996, other prospective buyers were merely looking to use the shell of the existing building for retail. "I was the only developer there," Mr. Gladstone recalled.
That was because he had already struck a deal with Stanley Stahl, the co-owner with the Nederlanders of the Lunt-Fontanne, for the air rights that would make it possible to build a 53-story skyscraper on the little parcel. "We had a handshake," Mr. Gladstone said, "and that was it."

The ABC's of F.A.R.
 It is not simply the size of a building that determines its development potential but what zoning applies to it.
Since 1961, zoning rules have prescribed the permissible density of every district in the city, expressed as a ratio of floor area to lot size. Floor-area ratios (or F.A.R.) range from 0.5 in neighborhoods like Douglaston, Queens, with one-family detached homes, to 21.6 in the high-rise core of Manhattan.
 A theater with 40,000 square feet of floor space on a 10,000-square-foot lot is said to have a floor-area ratio of 4 -- that is, 40,000 divided by 10,000.
If this theater were on a neighborhood commercial street where zoning calls for a floor-area ratio of 4, it would have no left-over development rights.
But if it stood on a parcel in Manhattan where zoning would permit a floor-area ratio of 15, it would have potential to spare: 110,000 square feet.
And that can be a valuable commodity if there is an eligible transfer site.
If a new tower were being planned on a 10,000-square-foot parcel adjacent to this hypothetical theater, the owners would be in luck. They could sell their air rights to the developers, who would add them to the 150,000 square feet already permitted by zoning (in a 15 F.A.R. district), yielding a 260,000-square-foot tower.
The most common method of transfer is a zoning lot merger, in which the existing building and the development parcel are counted as a single lot for zoning purposes, even though they are separately owned.
A zoning lot merger can occur only if properties are adjacent. Slightly wider latitude is granted to landmarks, whose air rights can be transferred across the street or cater-corner across an intersection.
Unused development rights trade at anywhere from 50 percent to 150 percent of land value, said Samuel H. Lindenbaum of Rosenman & Colin. Because his law firm has been involved in dozens of such deals over the years, he can argue the transaction either way.
Buyers, Mr. Lindenbaum said, are offering "found money" to the owners of air rights by unlocking value that could not otherwise be exploited, without actually taking title to the property. (That's the 50 percent argument.)
Sellers, he said, are allowing buyers to add more height to their new towers. Those upper floors are the ones that will sell or rent at the greatest prices. (That's the 150 percent argument.) DAVID W. DUNLAP

PUB-DATE: May 17, 1998,

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1191 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
When Mega-Mergers Are Mega-Busts

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
MARRY reliable old Daimler-Benz with go-go Chrysler? The union is bound to yield better cars. How about SBC and Ameritech, the telecommunications giants? Streamlining their front offices and linking all those zillions of phone cables into one awesome network ought to save billions.
With industrial regulation out of fashion, even the largest mergers are greeted sanguinely by the stock market -- and Washington. Last week the House passed a bill that would end Depression-era controls on banking, opening financial industries to new mega-mergers. 
 Populist fears of industrial concentration have faded, replaced by the conviction that the globalization of markets and the speed of technological change has tied efficiency to size. Bigness is no longer a threat to consumers, the thinking goes, but the salvation of affluent economies struggling to stay ahead of the pack.
But just when you've learned to stop worrying and love Consolidated Amalgamated Technotronics, economists are putting another spin on the conventional wisdom: Many now doubt that huge mergers will increase productivity. Indeed, most of the hard evidence from past mergers, along with the anecdotal evidence from the current wave, suggests that mergers do as much harm as good. Mergers, it seems, are too often the progeny of executive megalomania and deal makers' dreams of year-end bonuses.
Still, few counsel a more aggressive anti-merger policy that tries to second-guess the outcome of the behemoth couplings. Economists and regulators no longer fear unchecked corporate power, the concern that drove antitrust policy for the first half of the century. In the last few decades, the politically acceptable grounds for blocking mergers have narrowed considerably.
"Conglomerate mergers between companies in different businesses are now acceptable, as are vertical mergers between suppliers and producers in the same industry. Only horizontal mergers between competitors and potential competitors are likely to be challenged, and only when they concentrate the market enough to restrict output and raise prices.
By this standard, DaimlerChrysler raises little concern because its combined share of the world auto market would be modest. And mergers that link regional companies -- BankAmerica-NationsBank, SBC-Ameritech, Bell Atlantic-Nynex -- are acceptable because they don't reduce competition in local markets. Even where there is risk of monopoly, the Justice Department's guidelines permit mergers that generate substantial operating efficiencies.
"A merger has to be flat-out anticompetitive to attract the attention of the antitrust division," concludes F. M. Scherer, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
 
Executive Ego
But just because most big mergers are legal doesn't mean they are good for the economy. The bulk of the evidence from the 1960's, 1970's and 1980's suggests that mergers are more closely linked to fad -- not to mention the boss's ego -- than they are to cost savings or marketing synergies.
While stockholders in acquired (typically smaller) companies usually do quite well in mergers, owners of the acquiring companies rarely do. A 1997 survey by Dennis Mueller, an economist at the University of Vienna, showed that the acquiring companies typically had better-than-average returns on capital before mergers and worse-than-average ones afterward. Highly profitable companies, it seems, can't resist the urge to buy other companies with their accumulated cash rather than let the stockholders get the proceeds.
Research by Michael Porter of the Harvard Business School echoes these findings. His study of acquisitions by 33 large, successful corporations from 1950 to 1986 found that over half the acquired companies were sold off or liquidated within a decade. General Mills, for example, sold three-quarters of the 86 new businesses it had bought. Even General Electric, considered the best-managed diversified enterprise on the planet, scrapped 63 percent of its 51 acquisitions.
Mr. Porter's research focuses on conglomerate mergers rather than acquisitions by companies that already have an understanding of the industry they are entering. Moreover, the fact that mergers don't last doesn't prove they all failed; in some cases acquired companies may have been sold at a considerable profit.
Perhaps the current wave of couplings between companies in related businesses will prove more productive, but that is by no means certain. While it is too soon to assay the impact of the dozens of giga-mergers of the last few years, horror stories are dribbling out.
Wells Fargo choked on its acquisition of the First Interstate Bancorp in 1996. Records were lost, customers were forced to put up with long lines and tens of thousands of account holders left for more efficient banks. Adding to the confusion, three-quarters of First Interstate's top and middle managers were encouraged or allowed to leave in the first year.
A.T.&T. bought NCR for $7 billion in 1991 and then invested billions more in the electronics company with the aim of taking the computer industry by storm. Four years later A.T.&T. spun off NCR and the market valued the stock at a humiliating $3 billion.
 
Big Duds
 Quaker Oats did even worse with Snapple, buying the New Age brand for $1.7 billion in 1994 and selling it last year for $300 million. Novell, the networking software giant, acquired WordPerfect for $885 million in 1994. Two years later it dumped the second largest maker of word-processing software for just $115 million.
Japanese consumer electronics companies lost huge amounts in Hollywood in the 1980's. Matsushita lost billions on MCA-Universal before Seagram took the ailing studio off its hands. Sony has hung onto the wreckage of Columbia Pictures but has been forced to write off most of its investment.
Arguably, though, the most spectacular merger fiasco of modern times is still playing out. In 1995 the Union Pacific Railroad agreed to swallow the Southern Pacific. And a year later, over the objections of shippers who worried that the consolidation of routes would give the railroad the power to raise rates, Washington approved the merger.
But far from improving service, the new railroad quickly descended into chaos. Union Pacific's by-the-book corporate culture clashed badly with Southern Pacific's, where managers had long been accustomed to making do with chewing gum and bailing wire. Meanwhile the two carriers' information systems proved as compatible as Sonny and Cher.
The railroad had three fatal accidents in its first seven months. Shipments piled up at bottlenecks, particularly along the Mexican border. And tens of billions of dollars worth of freight has been delayed or simply denied access to the rails.
For all their skepticism about merger mania, it is still hard to find an economist inclined to put up roadblocks. The unique strength of American-style capitalism, the argument goes, has always been the freedom of businesses to mix and match assets. And the only compelling reason to interfere is to prevent the growth of old-fashioned monopoly power.

HEADLINE: COPING;
A Time to Heal. A Time to Move?

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
THE REV. WILLIAM HANOUSEK, who grew up in Astoria and was educated at Stuyvesant High School and City College, took over the Bethany Reform Church on the southeast corner of First Avenue and 67th Street in 1977. He came from a church in Canarsie with his wife and three small children because he wanted to live and minister in Manhattan, and in a racially mixed neighborhood.
The funky 88-year-old stone church is owned by the city's four-century-old, rich and powerful Collegiate churches. All are members of the Reformed Church in America. Bethany is a kind of poor cousin. The Marble Collegiate Church's superstar, the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale, supported Bethany's programs, especially after Mr. Hanousek discovered what he decided was his mandate. 
 "Twenty years ago," he said, "we had lots of sports in the gym, a youth ministry, a vacation Bible camp. But after the first cancer patient wandered in looking for a place to lie down, I came to believe that God had put us across the street for a purpose."
Across the street was the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, its waiting rooms crowded with scared patients and their scared caregivers, often from out of town. By word of mouth, Sloan patients found out they could crash in the church across the street, make a hot meal in the kitchen, talk and cry through the night with other suffering families, be comforted by "the Reverend Bill," who lived upstairs. In the early 80's, the Dykstra family of Wyoming, Mich., arrived with 20-year-old Tim, who became a favorite of the entire congregation. They stayed in the church for more than a year as Tim had chemotherapy, lost his leg, eventually died of osteosarcoma. Mr. Hanousek pinned Tim's snapshot to his office door and vowed that Bethany would do more.
Bible study rooms and the choir room were renovated into bedrooms. Twenty people can be accommodated, five in a crowded "women's dorm." The fee is $10 a night for those who can afford it. There is nothing else so close and so cheap.
"We give them more than a room," said Lois Sullivan, a former pediatric nurse who coordinates Bethany's cancer ministry. A Catholic, she found out about the program when she enrolled one of her children in a Bible class. "We give them hope. We listen to them. What's happening now is wrong. The church is supposed to do what God told them to do, take care of the sick and the helpless, not make millions off their misery."
What's happening now is that the Collegiate Corporation wants to sell Bethany to a developer, Jack Parker, for $7.4 million. Mr. Hanousek is trying to stop the sale. He has filed a suit invoking old church contracts. This is being lawyered over in Civil Court before Supreme Court Justice Diane S. Lebedeff. Bethany has also appealed to the Reformed Church's national body. But with a congregation of under 50, few of whom are rich or well connected, Bethany is not exactly a power church. And according to the Rev. Arthur Caliandro, the successor to Dr. Peale at Marble Collegiate, it may not have an economic right to exist.
"It looks like a David and Goliath story," Dr. Caliandro said. "But there's more to it."
"I think he wants to be a martyr," he said of Mr. Hanousek. "At every turn he's been a snake in the grass. What I don't know is what he really wants. I'm buffaloed. We've always supported his cancer ministry. And we will continue. But that building is barely functional, that church is nonviable, and with the money we can build a new church and serve many more people."
Last Tuesday, Collegiate raised its original offer of $700,000 for the church to find a new home to about $1.25 million. But it stood firm on its alternative offer: Bethany can have only three bedrooms on the second floor of the new high-rise that Mr. Parker would build on the site. The small church had asked for enough space in the luxury apartment building for five bedrooms and a room for Sunday services. Justice Lebedeff told Bethany to find out what was available in its price range in the neighborhood.
Mr. Hanousek is scrambling and says he is afraid of being pressured into making a decision that will be wrong for his regular congregation and for the cancer ministry families. Mr. Caliandro is angry at being cast as a villain, he says, when his Marble Collegiate congregation raised $130,000 for local charities on Easter.
Meanwhile, Steve Samples, a 29-year-old from Florida, moved into a Bethany bedroom last week with his pregnant wife. His parents are in another room. He came from across the street after surgery for osteosarcoma, his third major cancer surgery since he lost an eye at 9 months. He's too seasoned to be scared by church politics, but with some heavy-duty outpatient chemotherapy coming up, he'd hoped to stay put for a while.
